Pragmatism and Principle in Korea
LEAD: South Koreans, blessed and maybe also a bit cursed with a limitless capacity for political surprise, put their democratic progress to a tough new test last week and wandered into wholly uncharted territory.
It was anyone's guess whether the journey would turn out well.


Asking Some Questions About Special Education
LEAD: I read the letter from Jane Goldblatt to the Long Island editor on March 6 and was disturbed by her attitude toward educating the handicaped.
I would like to offer a rebuttal, strictly addressing her need for defining education.
I am a speech therapist working in special education in the public domain and have been for over 20 years.


A Word on Diagnosing Medical Progress
LEAD: The scenario depicted in Penny Singer's article  [ ''Diabetic Doctor Offers a New Treatment,'' April 3 ]  is the stuff of old Hollywood romances: lone figure with miraculous intuitive insight struggles valiantly against his own affliction as well as against an indifferent, reactionary medical establishment unwilling to take at face value his anecdotal account of self-salvation and restoration to health.


U.S. Outslugged By Cuban Boxers
LEAD: Cuba's amateur boxing team beat the United States squad in 10 of 12 matches today.
It was the 15th time in 15 dual meetings between the countries, dating to 1977, that Cuba had won.

LEAD: Most American tourists know that the nation's wine country can be found in California's Sonoma Valley and that the Shakers live in Pennsylvania.

Police Guard at Kean's Home Accidentally Shoots Himself
LEAD: A state trooper assigned to guard the home of Governor Kean accidentally shot himself in the foot today while cleaning a gun in a trailer outside the Governor's house, officials said.

IMPATIENS - POPULAR, COLORFUL AND CAREFREE
LEAD: Snap or cut off faded daffodils to prevent the formation of seed pods, but allow foliage to ripen naturally.
Fertilize roses, if they have not been fed this spring.
Wait another week or two to plant corn, melons and beans.
Harvest leaf lettuce and spinach.
Plant perennials and new shrubs.
Impatiens

Public Employees Don't Live High on the Expense-Account Hog
LEAD: To the Editor:


Fish and Sauces: An Excellent Spring Marriage
LEAD: WITH the arrival of spring it is time to take a fresh look at fish.
The delicate flavor of fish fillets is adaptable to all sorts of interesting sauces.
White fish such as sole or flounder is ideal with cream sauces gently flavored with curry, saffron or turmeric.
A stronger-flavored fish such as red snapper or sea bass goes very well with a puree of yellow peppers, seasoned with shallots, fresh thyme and a dash of balsamic vinegar.

William Lloyd Fox Jr., a Unitarian minister, officiated.


Cuomo Orders Inquiry On Troopers' Testimony
LEAD: Governor Cuomo has directed a state commission to investigate allegations that state police officers lied under oath in a vehicular manslaughter case in upstate New York.


'On The Verge' Explores Time Travel
LEAD: IN less than three years, the Boston Post Road Stage Company has emerged as a small theater of audacity and intelligence.
With ''On the Verge,'' which concludes the company's second full season, it may have come up with its most challenging, offbeat play yet.


FICTION
LEAD:  SHINE ON.
By Fred Pfeil. (Lynx House/Small Press Distribution, Cloth, $14.95; Paper, $7.50.) The title of Fred Pfeil's first collection of stories suggests a transcendence his characters seldom attain.
Indeed, ''Shine On'' records the peculiar diminutions of American life during the 1970's and the way a shrinking economy pinches the imagination as well as the purse.

Headliners; By the Sword
LEAD: An Israeli judge said last week that ''there is no punishment in the rules of man that is severe enough'' for John Demjanjuk, whom an Israeli court found to be a Nazi death camp guard who helped torture and murder thousands of Jews during World War II.
The judge sentenced Mr.
Demjanjuk to death by hanging.

At S.I. School, Lessons In Curbing Racial Strife
LEAD: In 1980, a scuffle in the gymnasium of New Dorp High School on Staten Island erupted into violence.
Black students were forced to flee in buses as white students hurled stones and shouted racial epithets.
The school was closed temporarily, and it was days before black students returned to class.

LEAD: DR.
HAROLD J. RAVECHE, the next president of Stevens Institute of Technology, says that the nation was built on a foundation of strong education and that ''hands-on experience and studies'' can improve the quality of its future leaders.


Foreign Medical Graduates May Get New Test
LEAD: After years of battling for equal recognition, graduates of foreign medical schools may soon be able to take the same test in basic and clinical sciences that is given to graduates of American medical schools.

NOTED WITH PLEASURE
LEAD:  Feeling Lovable
Floyd Patterson demystifies boxing and shows us what it's actually like.
Here he tells Gay Talese how it feels to be knocked out.
This is from ''Reading the Fights,'' edited by Joyce Carol Oates and Daniel Halpern (Holt).


TIME STANDS STILL
LEAD: For years, architects and designers in major cities have been restoring and renovating buildings that date from early in this century.
Evident from the street are highly polished stone facades, or those freshly painted in colors reproduced from original paint chips.
And inside many residential buildings, apartments are also being renovated in ways that make them appear as though they had never been prey to decades of changing tastes.


U.S.O.C. Cutting Foreign Aid Program
LEAD: The United States Olympic Committee's annual House of Delegates meeting ended today with no major decisions.
However, one minor decision seemed to reflect a growing feeling among some members that less money should be spent on direct aid to athletes and programs of other countries.


An Epidemic of Meningitis Strikes Wide Areas of Africa
LEAD: An epidemic of meningitis in central and western Africa has affected thousands of people and killed hundreds, but vaccination programs are controlling the spread, according to the United Nations Childrens Fund.

We agreed in a letter that she would pay half of the rent and the utility bills.

Native American Potters At Montclair State College
LEAD: ACOMA, a native American pueblo on a mesa in the desert near Albuquerque, N.M., has been described as an awesome, wind-swept plateau.
Said to be the oldest continuously inhabited settlement in North America, Acoma is famous today for its pottery tradition.


Mount Laurel: Slow, Painful Progress
LEAD: After nearly two decades of bearing witness to suits, countersuits and endless appeals, Ethel Lawrence, a 62-year-old grandmother from Mount Laurel, N.J., recites without pause the gist of complex rulings handed down by the New Jersey Supreme Court and cited in discriminatory zoning cases across the nation.

LEAD: IN the carrying-coals-to-Newcastle department: the first shipload of American-made Honda Accord coupes left Portland, Ore., for export to Japan last month.
Honda, the fourth-largest automaker in the United States, plans to export 4,000 Accords to Japan this year.

LEAD: As strains of ''Amazing Grace'' streamed down Fifth Avenue yesterday morning, 8,000 police officers saluted the flag-draped coffin of Sgt.

The very idea convulses public officials in New York.
Horsefeathers! they gibe in response.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Bowling  Williams Wins 2d Firestone Title: After opening with four strikes, Mark Williams beat Tony Westlake, 237-214, in the championship game yesterday to capture his second $250,000 Firestone Tournament of Champions in Fairlawn, Ohio.
Williams, at 30 the oldest among the five players in the nationally televised championship round, collected his sixth Professional Bowlers Association crown and $50,000.

Beside the Sea In Brighton, Royal Fantasy
LEAD: Its owner was impossible, its architect impractical, its workers often unpaid; it was the wrong building at the wrong time in the wrong climate, a visionary extravagance that affronted many of its visitors and was abandoned within 30 years of its completion.
And yet, today, despite restoration work and scaffolding, the Royal Pavilion at Brighton shines forth as the proof that style and imagination can indeed create the most unlikely of masterpieces.

Fresh Air, Fresh Outlooks
LEAD: When 9-year-old DeeDee, from New York City, went on her first visit to an apple farm in Maine, she was amazed.
She never knew, she said, that apples grow on trees.
She thought they arrived in plastic bags.
Her enlightenment came by way of the Fresh Air Fund, which offers poor inner-city youngsters free vacations in the country.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. I recently painted my living room.
The radiator, which is the old-fashioned cast-iron type, has brown stains on it and is peeling in places.
It has been painted many times before.
How can I paint this so it won't develop these dark stains and peel, and can I do this while the heat is on?


ARAB RAGE INSIDE ISRAEL
LEAD: Last December's Israeli-Arab general strike indeed was a shock to many Israeli Jews.
But the Police Minister, Haim Bar-Lev, reported that violence occurred in only four Arab communities, and those incidents were condemned by the strike's organizers.
In contrast to the violence in the territories, the Israeli-Arab demonstrations on Land Day in March were peaceful, as was the general strike Israel's Arab citizens held in June 1987 to protest inequities in municipal services, education, housing and employment opportunities.


Is This the End?
LEAD: HE hasn't even seen the doctor, but Jimmy Connors, who has been nursing a sore foot for months, has the scenario mapped out.
The doctor will tell him he needs surgery and suddenly his career will be over. ''I'm finished,'' he said. ''I'd have to take six months off, then I'm 36 years old.
Then it would take me six months more to get back in decent shape.

LEAD: When Motorola Inc. introduced a system of quality control at its plant in Arcade, N.Y., it found that many employees lacked the mathematical skills needed to understand the new statistics-based approach.
In response, Motorola officials added six hours of remedial training in grade-school mathematics for all workers.

CHARLESTON
LEAD: For years, the standard itinerary to Charleston, S.C., included touring a meticulously restored home, riding the ferry to Fort Sumter, dining on a bowl of she-crab soup and picking up a souvenir: a coiled seagrass basket, or perhaps a miniature bale of cotton.


Forrest Bess: Desire Ruled His Vision
LEAD: Forrest Bess WAS BORN IN BAY City, Tex., in 1911.
He went to Texas A. &amp; M. and the University of Texas, studying architecture, philosophy and religion.
Like his father, he worked in oilfields.
He lived in Mexico.
He wandered.
During World War II, he served in the Army and was commended for camouflage design.

Posting: Condominium Hotel; A Return to Victoriana in Chautauqua
LEAD: A resort hotel at a resort with a season only nine weeks long needs an innovative plan to be successful.
That is why developers of the St.
Elmo Hotel in Chautauqua, N.Y., joined a nationwide trend toward hotel condominiums.
The 63-unit, Victorian-style hotel will be among the first built exclusively as a condominium.

WHO WILL WIN THE KENTUCKY DERBY?
LEAD: It is not any race horse who can achieve a 7-for-7 lifetime victory record over different racetracks, at various distances, against the best horses in the East.
Along with these accomplishments, intelligence, honesty and heart are necessary for greatness.
My 1988 Kentucky Derby choice embodies all of these qualities.

LEAD: A music review last Sunday about the Juilliard American Opera Center's production of Benjamin Britten's ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' misidentified the singer in the role of Theseus.
He was Scott Wilde.


Culture Shock
LEAD: To the Editor: When I returned home from Europe on a recent trip, the one startling impression that struck me at Kennedy Airport, and as I eventually emerged into city traffic, was the sight of traffic policemen with revolvers sticking out at the ready from their holsters.
Momentarily it was frightening.

Fish and Sauces: An Excellent Spring Marriage
LEAD: WITH the arrival of spring it is time to take a fresh look at fish.
The delicate flavor of fish fillets is adaptable to all sorts of interesting sauces.
White fish such as sole or flounder is ideal with cream sauces gently flavored with curry, saffron or turmeric.
A stronger-flavored fish such as red snapper or sea bass goes very well with a puree of yellow peppers, seasoned with shallots, fresh thyme and a dash of balsamic vinegar.

LEAD: Look, say the Presidential candidates: Our allies prosper while the United States strains to provide far more than its share of the common defense.

The theme already has been reduced to shorthand: burden-sharing.
Like most slogans, this one reverberates with simplicity, power - and ignorance.

Switzerland
LEAD: To the Editor: Switzerland has instituted an entrance fee to use its highways.
They charge 40 Swiss francs (about $24) to enter the country driving a car.
What is unfair is that this charge is a yearly one, so that anyone who drives into Switzerland for a visit of a couple of hours, as we did, is required to pay the fee.

LEAD: Mention Wimbledon to most people and it naturally means tennis.

Wimbledon was a convenient venue - the last stop on the District Line of London's underground - and the company was often there in springtime.

Posting: East 30th Condos; A 421-a Trade-Off
LEAD: Lawrence A. Smiley will be the first Manhattan developer to renovate city-owned shells for low- and moderate-income families as part of a new 421-a tax abatement program.
Except he has not yet been shown the buildings.
As Mr.
Smiley completes work on Lexington Parc, whose 73 market-rate condominiums will benefit from the 10-year tax reduction, the Department of Housing Preservation and Development is still choosing two suitable buildings for the 22 apartments he is required to renovate.


Prospects
LEAD: After the Trade Bill  After nearly three years, the Senate ratified a trade bill last week.
The President has vowed to veto the legislation because it contains a provision requiring companies to give 60 days notice before plant closings.
But the bill also gives authority to the President to negotiate at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and paves the way for the upcoming vote in Congress on a free trade agreement with Canada.


Second Round of Nicaragua Talks End
LEAD: The second round of peace talks between the Sandinista Government and contra guerrilla leaders ended today without an accord.
Government officials said a third round would begin May 12, but the contras said they had not agreed to a date.

...and Labeling
LEAD: To the Editor:


Business Forum; GRAY MARKET PRODUCTS: BACK DOOR IMPORTS SHOULD BE BANNED
LEAD: America's gray markets, also called parallel importation, are now big business.
These markets arise when clever traders purchase well-known brand-name products from foreign suppliers and sell them to other domestic middlemen who are not part of the manufacturer's normal distribution chain.
The practice is most likely to occur when currencies change value both substantially and quickly.

LEAD: Tennis Courses  Question:Do any Northeastern ski resorts run tennis schools with lodging in the summer? - F. T. S., Princeton, N.J.

LEAD: To the Editor:


WEEK IN BUSINESS
LEAD:  Economic Signals: The Right Mix The economy grew at a 2.3 percent annual rate in the first quarter.
That was off from the 4.8 percent pace set in the fourth quarter of 1987, but economists seemed to think that was almost a good sign.
What really seemed to cheer them was the mix of factors creating the rise in the gross national product, particularly the reduction in inventories of unsold goods and the vigorous growth in capital spending.


Refugees From Sudan Strain Ethiopia Camps
LEAD: Thousands of starving refugees from the Sudan, fleeing drought and civil war in their country's south, are crossing the border into southwestern Ethiopia every month and severely taxing overcrowded relief camps.


DANCE VIEW
LEAD: Lar Lubovitch's new ''Of My Soul'' is an awkward dance.
It is fascinating, as well.
Usually, in dance, awkwardness is undesirable.


Vladimir No Russian
LEAD: To the Editor:


On Language; The Bloopie Awards
LEAD: A SINISTER FORCE for solecism exists on Madison Avenue.
It is the work of the copywrongers.


SHAKEN BY DOWNSIZING, THE GROUPS REGROUP
LEAD: One way that trade associations reflect American business as a whole is that both have been shaken by the recent trend toward consolidation.


Boarding School At State Expense
LEAD: The concept - a free public boarding school specializing in science and mathematics for gifted high school students - has been in operation since 1980, when North Carolina opened the first such school.


Maine Tribe Finds Strength in Music
LEAD: When the Passamaquoddy Indians were fighting to regain ownership of tribal lands in the 1960's and 1970's, Wayne Newell felt uncomfortable protesting against the Federal Government.
It was through his tribe's music that he found strength.


A Voice Familiar With the Disease
LEAD: The article ''New Product Is Offered to Reduce Lyme Disease''  [ April 3 ]  did an excellent job in reporting information as presented by the manufacturer of Damminix, by authorities in the field of Lyme disease, by health officials, etc.
Some additional caveats are in order.


Fewer Diplomats Scoff At a Threat by Britain
LEAD: A new Government policy that threatens diplomats with expulsion if they do not pay parking tickets has sent foreign envoys rushing to pay fines.

The Northeast and the West Are Faring Well - for Now
LEAD: The Western United States has what some economists call a ''Swiss cheese'' economy - pockets of great prosperity and pockets of depression.
While the job market has generally been improving in the last year, the precise outlook depends on the specific region and the specific industry.

A Fantasy Flight Into Bygone Skies
LEAD: THROUGHOUT 1987, a calendar entitled ''Ghosts - A Time Remembered'' hung on the wall of my office.
A gift from my father, it reflected our shared fascination with World War II aircraft.


Review/Pop; Sounds of the Middle East
LEAD: Dissidenten, a band from West Berlin, has its ears turned to North Africa.
The songs the group brought to S.O.B.'s on Tuesday, opening a two-night stand, used Moroccan-style melodies, with modal scales and microtonal inflections, in settings that moved from Africa toward Europe as the early set progressed.


South Africa - A Terrorist Nation
LEAD: On April 7, Albie Sachs, a white South African lawyer who had been an active opponent of apartheid, was seriously injured in a bomb explosion as he opened the door of his car outside his home in Maputo, Mozambique.
One week earlier, the African National Congress's chief representative in France, Dulcie September, was gunned down as she arrived at her office in Paris.

LEAD: There rrxhare some similarities between George Bush and Martin Van Buren, the last man to be elected President while serving as Vice President: Both spent most of their lives on the public payroll, and, as Vice Presidents, both were regarded as confidants of their Presidents.


New Policy on Illegal Drugs Permits U.S. to Seize Boats
LEAD: The Reagan Administration has toughened its drug enforcement by allowing the Coast Guard to seize any boat or ship on which even a small amount of contraband is found, Transportation Secretary Jim Burnley said today.

AIDS Vaccine Test Produces Immune Response in 6
LEAD: The first American test of an experimental AIDS vaccine has produced an immune response in six volunteers, an important step toward developing an effective vaccine against the disease, the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases said today.

Elizabeth Perle Named Prentice-Hall Executive
LEAD: Elizabeth Perle has been named publisher of Prentice-Hall Press.
She was previously associate publisher of hardcover and trade paperbacks at Bantam Books, where she held positions in marketing and sales.
Prior to that she was employed at Harper &amp; Row and Times Books.
The press is part of the Prentice Hall Trade Division, itself part of Simon &amp; Schuster's consumer group.

LEAD: Every Presidential election year provides a forceful reminder that a glass can be portrayed as half empty or half full.
In 1988, the battery of figures Republicans are marshaling emphasize what the White House calls the ''significant and good news'' about the economy; Democrats are trying to accentuate the negative.

Car Rentals: Medical Aid, Rates, Routes
LEAD: AVIS EUROPE has added referrals to English-speaking doctors and dentists to its On Call Europe 24-hour phone service.
By calling from Belgium, France, West Germany, the Netherlands, Italy, Switzerland or Britain, Avis renters can get the name and location of the nearest participating doctor or dentist with 24-hour call service.


On Choppy Water, Penn Captures Cup
LEAD: The men's varsity heavyweight crew from Pennsylvania defeated Navy, Harvard and the Severn River this morning to gain possession of the Adams Cup for the second time in the last three years.


ARAB RAGE INSIDE ISRAEL
LEAD: Israeli Arabs need only look at the second-class status of Jews in Moslem lands to appreciate the rights and freedoms they enjoy as an increasingly hostile minority in Israel (''Arab Rage Inside Israel,'' by Ze'ev Chafets, April 3).
But Israeli Arabs want it both ways: they demand full acceptance as Israeli citizens while proclaiming loyalty to an Arab state on the West Bank whose leaders are sworn to the dismantling of Israel.


Spreading Sunshine
LEAD: The new laboratory and classroom facility at the Oregon Institute of Technology in Klamath Falls was designed by Michael R. McCulloch ''to make a transition,'' he says, ''between the inside of campus and the outside, where there's a dramatic backdrop of mountains.'' So its 1,800-square-foot, crescent-shaped skylight, created by the Portland artist Ed Carpenter, is integral to the building's architectural intent.

LEAD: Pressure eased on the Government of Gen.
Wojciech Jaruzelski today after workers at the steel and armaments plant here accepted a Government pay offer and ended a one-day strike.

LEAD: To the Editor: My first and only experience with Now Voyager was nowhere near as rosy as the piece would have newcomers believe.
Having booked a trip to Sydney three months in advance, I was informed three days before my departure that the company I was traveling for had no freight to send and my services were not required.

Correction
LEAD: The Practical Traveler column on March 27 about lost and stolen airline tickets carried an incorrect report from Northwest Airlines about its policy.
The service charge for refunding a ticket is $50 for a domestic ticket and $30 for an international ticket.


Delhi Aide Says Libya Conscripted Workers
LEAD: Nearly 100 Indians who traveled to Libya for jobs in a leather factory were swept from the Tripoli airport to a nearby army camp for military training before some of them escaped and sought help from the Indian Embassy, according to a top Indian police official.

LEAD: Iraq has successfully test-fired a new surface-to-surface missile with a range of 560 miles, far enough to hit Iranian targets in the Strait of Hormuz and increase pressure on Iran's oil traffic through the Persian Gulf.

Color It Green
LEAD: A LONG line of farmers and gardeners make up my family tree, but when genes for a green thumb were handed out, I was not on the list.


Going With Kids
LEAD: To the Editor: The article about traveling in Europe with children omitted one of the most interesting ways to see Europe: camping.
We traveled extensively with our children (the youngest was 8) on two occasions, and each time we camped, the first time for six weeks, the second for a month.
We have pitched our tents in Oslo, Copenhagen, The Hague, Munich, Lucerne, Vienna and the Bois de Boulogne in Paris.

LEAD: The leader of a P.L.O. faction, buoyed by the Palestine Liberation Organization's reconciliation with Syria, has announced plans to increase attacks against Israel from Lebanon.
At the same time, Israeli troops have been conducting an extensive search in southern Lebanon for suspected guerrillas.

Man Is First to Escape From Prison Barge
LEAD: A man accused of burglary became the first inmate to escape from New York City's prison barge when he crawled to freedom yesterday through an air-conditioner opening behind the barge's kitchen, city corrections officials said.

LEAD: Brighton is known as the princely resort, and for once the boosters' claim is not hyperbole.
The Prince Regent's Royal Pavilion is as splendid and exotic as Kublai Khan's pleasure dome, and the Regency squares and terraces built for his courtiers and aristocratic friends are a contrast in cool elegance.

THE LITTLE ENGINE THAT COULD
LEAD: All the images about the withering of American industry these last few years seemed a little truer here and felt a little sadder.
Bethlehem Steel and Mack Trucks, the big-name companies that once built the industrial centers of eastern Pennsylvania, were shrinking down or pulling out.
Sometimes, it seemed as if the companies had turned against their towns, testing them to see whether they could take it.

Under the circumstances, this was astounding.
Ads for the film offered little more than its dismal title and a photograph of unidentified workmen (they turned out to be miners) in an unidentified location (it turned out to be Newfoundland).

So the art dealer stored them, studied them and became increasingly convinced of their merits.

LEAD: I smile and nod as I walk by a nurse seated behind the reception desk.

But now I feel visiting anonymously is preferable to advertising my presence.


Ramses II Visits a Boston Museum
LEAD: For the next three months, a 40-foot-high model of an ancient Egyptian temple will stand at the front of the Boston Museum of Science.
The building is the temporary home of the imposing Colossus of Memphis, a 3,000-year-old, 57-ton granite statue of Ramses II.

Dave Winfield leaves his New Jersey home, steers his luxury foreign car across the George Washington Bridge and through the congestion of the Bronx, and parks in the players' lot at Yankee Stadium.

BLACK-AND-WHITE OUTSHINES COLOR
LEAD: Recently I was invited to select the worthy entries for a juried exhibition to which anyone with a photograph and five dollars could submit.
This is called ''jurying'' a show, but to my mind it amounts to being prosecutor, judge and jury simultaneously.
Not exactly a fair trial, mind you, but then no one who enters such things really expects objectivity to rule.

Correction
LEAD: An article on March 20 misstated the date of the purchase of Alaska from Russia.
It was 1867.
A map with an accompanying article misidentified the river that flows past Fairbanks.
It is the Tanana.


2 Former Employees Indicted In Killing of Jersey Executive
LEAD: Two former employees of an asbestos removal company have been indicted in the slaying of the company's president, who was shot to death in the driveway of his Rumson home.

LEAD: CONGRESS has followed the New Jersey Legislature's lead and enacted legislation that challenges industries to release their grip on chemical information.
Industries' response to this challenge will reflect how much they have learned, in the decade since Love Canal, about dealing with communities.

LEAD: AT An Evening Dinner Theater in Elmsford on Monday and Tuesday evenings, one can usually see variety attractions (Big Band shows, comedy specials) or a local theater group in the likes of a Neil Simon comedy or an Agatha Christie mystery.


Mystery Deepens in New Delhi Arms Scandal
LEAD: One year after the first disclosures of possible bribery in an arms contract, the Government of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi remains beset by corruption charges and a deepening mystery about who received a series of illegal payments from abroad.


Correction
LEAD: A report in the Travel Advisory on Feb. 28 misstated the days on which the Emily Dickinson Homestead in Amherst, Mass., is open for tours from May through October.
They are Wednesday to Saturday, in the afternoon.


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. I recently painted my living room.
The radiator, which is the old-fashioned cast-iron type, has brown stains on it and is peeling in places.
It has been painted many times before.
How can I paint this so it won't develop these dark stains and peel, and can I do this while the heat is on?

LEAD: To the Editor:


BURIED TREASURE IN THE CITIES OF ROCK
LEAD: One can only imagine the astonishment of 19th-century explorers upon finding under jungle creepers and desert sands carefully worked stone figures and large, complex structures.
With ancient texts as their sole guides, they must have fancied that these cities of rock had sprung from the pages of classical literature, rather than the other way around.

Crash Legacy
LEAD: To the Editor:


Prison a Setting for Hoboken Drama
LEAD: IN HIS new two-character play at the Renegade Theater Company, Alan Brody seems so determined to pound away at truth and reality that he has turned out an implausible play.


Election Fever Grips Mexico (Yes, Mexico)
LEAD: To the Editor:


WHO WILL WIN THE KENTUCKY DERBY?
LEAD: Brian's Time.
The extra eighth of a mile in the Derby will greatly benefit his style.
John Veitch, his trainer, will have to work on getting Brian's Time to break more quickly from the gate and he must hope for a beneficial post position.
Posts 1 and 2 and the outside posts will greatly hurt his horse's chances.


ARAB RAGE INSIDE ISRAEL
LEAD: Ze'ev Chafets reports that in Israel there are ''more than 50 organizations dedicated to Arab-Jewish understanding.'' Query: How many such organizations are there among Israeli Arabs in the West Bank or anywhere in the Arab world?
The answer is: None.
That fact is only one reason why the possibility of reconciliation and peace between Israel and its Arab neighbors is, perhaps, even more remote than Mr.

LEAD: One after another, the faces of Oregon citizens have been popping up on posters and in videos, begging for donations to pay for organ transplants that their state no longer finances.

Trying to Unlock A Big Market
LEAD: Locked-out motorists in Dover, Del., have always relied on the city police to open their car doors for nothing.
The city's locksmiths say they are losing thousands of dollars each year in business to the police.


Review/Dance; 'Utopia' Blends Life And Stage
LEAD: Phyllis Lamhut's new ''Utopia,'' which opened on Thursday at the Westbeth Theater Center (151 Bank Street), will not disappoint those who have come to admire this veteran choreographer's comparatively recent forays into the darkness of history and the heart.
It is a powerful dance that boasts an equally powerful and ambitious score by Ben Hazard and stunning performances from its six leads that are alone worth a trip to the theater.

Affordable Housing Needn't Be Impossible Dream
LEAD: I WAS alone in my kitchen one recent Sunday morning, reading an interview in the Long Island Weekly with David Emilita  [ ''A Planner Balances Quantity and Quality'' ] .
Upon reading his words about affordable housing, I wanted to stand up and applaud.


Review/Rock; NATALIE MERCHANT: STUDY IN CONTRASTS
LEAD: Natalie Merchant, lead singer for 10,000 Maniacs, doesn't want listeners to know exactly what she's up to.
Her lyrics hint and tease at their subjects, only gradually revealing their stories.
And on stage Thursday at the Beacon Theater she was by turns open and oblique, graceful and awkward, sidestepping ordinary rock theatrics as if she'd never seen them.


Correction
LEAD: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the County Chamber of Commerce misidentified the man shown.
He was James P. O'Toole, the chamber's immediate past president.

LEAD: TWENTY-FIVE years ago, what is now known as the Route 9 corridor through western Monmouth County was a scenic two-lane back road dotted with truck farms and, in season, roadside stands selling fresh produce.


FORMING EXPORT ALLIANCES - AND AVOIDING ANTITRUST
LEAD: International trade is a chief concern of many trade association executives.
The newest twist in such programs is the ''generic'' export trading company, introduced last year by the National Machine Tool Builders Association.
This company is generic because, rather than specifically naming the partners, its export trade certificate - which allows joint trade activities to foreign markets - covers the association's entire membership, including new members as they join, said Charles G.


Donald Trump's $1,500 High-Roller Ringside
LEAD: DURING the negotiations for Ali-Frazier I at Madison Square Garden in 1971, each boxer was guaranteed a flat fee of $2.5 million, then a record sum.
But soon it was time to set the ticket prices. ''Some people kept telling me that we could charge $200 for a ringside seat, but I decided that $150 was enough,'' Harry Markson, the Garden's boxing president of that era, recalled with a laugh.

Another friend, a Smith alumna, told me its students saw the young male faculty, married or not, as ''fair game.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; 42.9% Gain for Quarter At Grey Advertising
LEAD: Grey Advertising released its first-quarter earnings on Friday, and they were good enough to elicit a cautionary note from Edward H. Meyer, its chairman, who said that while he appreciated the performance, he doesn't want shareholders to expect similar percent gains during the rest of the year.


100 Children to Dance
LEAD: One hundred children from Jacques d'Amboise's National Dance Institute will perform in ''Dancing the New Stories'' on May 10 at Alice Tully Hall.
The event, directed by Mr. d'Amboise and presented by the institute and Lincoln Center's Meet-the-Artist program, will include a tribute to Irving Berlin, based on his song ''God Bless America,'' on the eve of his 100th birthday.


The Boom in Home Health Care
LEAD: In the face of rising hospital and nursing home costs, more Americans are receiving sophisticated medical care at home, from cancer chemotherapy drugs to kidney dialysis.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Information Resources' Shopping Cart With TV
LEAD: Information Resources of Chicago, the nation's third-largest marketing research company, is making an interesting diversification move: into TV-equipped supermarket carts.
It is called ''VideOcart,'' with a capital O. That's right, carts that have 6-by-8-inch video screens mounted on the handles and cued electronically to run commercials when they pass the shelfspace of an advertiser's products.


Bullish on Billy Beer
LEAD: It is going on 11 years since the brother of President Jimmy Carter entered the suds business.
Billy Beer caused something of a sensation when it was introduced, but 12 months later, in October 1978, Reynolds Metals bought nearly 9 million empty Billy cans and melted them, signaling the end for the brew.

LEAD: A man with a history of mental illness, who apparently went berserk and clubbed a woman to death with a two-by-four in Harlem Saturday, collapsed in a crowded cell at Police Headquarters yesterday and died soon afterward.


Market Place; Revising Realty Partnership Plans
LEAD: SPONSORS of limited real estate partnerships are like badly wounded soldiers.
Having been dealt a blow by the Tax Reform Act of 1986 and by further tax changes last year, the sponsors are ever so slowly recovering.


Why Fear the Speech of Foreigners?
LEAD: Americans treasure the right to speak freely -for everyone except foreigners whose views the Government considers offensive.
That's because of the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act of 1952, a vestige of the McCarthy era that blights the nation's willingness to be a marketplace of ideas.
Congressional efforts to overhaul this objectionable law at last should get a lift from a recent ruling by a United States Court of Appeals.


Courtesy on the Lawn
LEAD: Standing in the special visitors gallery last Wednesday as Prime Minister Brian Mulroney arrived on the south lawn of the White House was the comedian Red Skelton.


GLOBAL BRIEFS
LEAD: *
West Germany's eight bourses reported that trading volume fell in April by nearly 28 percent, to 163.7 billion marks, or $95.4 billion, from 226.5 billion marks, or $135 billion, in March.
There were only 19 trading days in April, compared with 23 in March.
Also, average daily stock sales in April fell to 8.6 billion marks, or $5.1 billion, from 9.8 billion marks, or $5.8 billion, in March.

Review/Television; Supreme Court Justices: America's Judicial Stars
LEAD: The Supreme Court was once remote and mysterious, the Federal equivalent of Mount Olympus.
It may even be argued that the remoteness was a source of power: Olympus could command in a way that politicians could not.
A Justice had a divine calling.
Divinity, however, is hard to sustain in a media age.

LEAD: Red Flag, the theoretical journal of China's Communist Party for three decades and long a stronghold of hard-line Marxists, will shut down this summer, the official New China News Agency reported today.

LEAD: In the latest round in its battle to gain control of the USG Corporation, Desert Partners L.P. said yesterday that it would pay $45 a share in cash for 39 million outstanding shares if a friendly deal could be worked out.


No Accord By OPEC On Oil Cuts
LEAD: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries ended four days of meetings early today without an agreement on a production cut.
OPEC officials said the cartel would meet again next month.
The failure here is bound to depress oil prices by at least $1 a barrel, an analyst said, because the oil markets had been anticipating some kind of decision to reduce output, which would have propped up oil prices.

LEAD: The chief of staff to a Maryland Congressman died yesterday when he plunged from a 24th-floor window of the Helmsley Palace hotel in Manhattan, the police said.
They said it was apparently a suicide.


Cyclists Pedal for Youth
LEAD: Participants in the 12th annual Citibank/American Youth Hostel Five Boro Bike Tour on Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive yesterday.
Riders included unicyclists, recumbent bicyclists, cycling families, Olympic riders, children, cycling pros and riders out for fun, more than 22,000 in all.
Of the $6 registration fee for participants in the bike tour, $2 will go toward the development of a 477-bed hostel.


Rona Silver Married To Dr. Kevin Loshak
LEAD: At Temple Beth Am in Merrick, L.I., Rona Silver, the daughter of Jean Silver of Merrick and the late Stanley W. Silver, was married yesterday to Dr.
Kevin Loshak, a son of Mr. and Mrs.
Elias Loshak, also of Merrick.
Rabbi Ronald N. Brown officiated.
Mrs.
Loshak, a sales marketing planner in advertising at The New York Times, graduated from the State University at Albany, as did her husband.


British Trade Deficit Cut
LEAD: Britain's merchandise trade deficit narrowed unexpectedly and sharply in March to a seasonally adjusted $1.61 billion from $2.48 billion in February, the Government said Friday.
Nevertheless, the deficit was much wider than the deficit a year ago, which came to $703 million.
Britain's total trade deficit also narrowed sharply.


WHITE HOUSE SEEKS INCREASE IN SALES OF ARMS OVERSEAS
LEAD: The Reagan Administration has told Congress that it wants to increase arms sales abroad substantially this year to more than $15 billion worth of weapons.
This is $3.3 billion more than the United States sold to other countries last year.


Results Plus
LEAD:  Tennis  Lendl Overcomes Edberg: Ivan Lendl came back from a shaky start to defeat Stefan Edberg yesterday in the final of the $500,000 Challenge in Atlanta.
Edberg won the first set, 6-2, but Lendl took the next two sets, 6-1, 6-3, to win the exhibition tournament, held at Horseshoe Bend Country Club.

LEAD: John S. Chamberlin, who resigned last week as president and chief operating officer in an unexpected development at Avon Products Inc., said yesterday that the move was mostly the result of changes in Avon's business since he took his post three years ago.

LEAD: United States warships escorted three Kuwaiti oil tankers northward through the Persian Gulf today after reports that Iranian gunboats were sighted near the Strait of Hormuz, maritime officials said.

LEAD: The Bear Stearns Companies announced yesterday that it had dismantled its system of co-presidents and named one of them, James E. Cayne, to be president.
The other, E. John Rosenwald Jr., was elected vice chairman.
Alan C. Greenberg remains chairman and chief executive.

LEAD: THE 500-plus fruit fly species of Hawaii have long been honored by biologists for the spectacular diversity of their shapes, making them one of the world's most striking examples of evolutionary branching.

The two part-time barbers are also full-time cheese-puff makers, right, at a food plant in Maplewood, N.J.

Population Growth
LEAD: The growth rate of the world's population is higher than many experts predicted only a few years ago, according to a new study.
The global population, now more than 5.1 billion, is now growing by about 1.7 percent a year and is expected to reach 6 billion by the year 1998, according to the Population Reference Bureau, a research organization in Washington.

Wedtech Aide Testifies on Plan To Kill Founder
LEAD: A former Wedtech executive testified yesterday in the racketeering trial of Representative Mario Biaggi and six others that Wedtech executives had discussed assassinating the company founder.


Rig Count Falls by 28
LEAD: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States fell by 28 last week, to 880, Baker Hughes Inc. said today.
The rig count, the widely watched industry index of drilling activity, totaled 780 a year ago.
Baker Hughes's rig count reflects the number of rigs actively exploring for oil as of last Friday, not the number of rigs producing oil.


NBC to Buy Cable Service
LEAD: The National Broadcasting Company said yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent to buy Tempo Television, a cable service owned by Tempo Enterprises Inc. of Tulsa, Okla.

HUNGARY GEARS UP FOR CHANGE AT TOP
LEAD: A special meeting of Hungary's Communist Party will discuss whether to replace its 75-year-old leader, Janos Kadar, who has led the country since 1956, Prime Minister Karoly Grosz said today.


Reviews/Music; Queens Symphony's 'Sounds From the Left Bank'
LEAD: For the past three years, the Queens Symphony has presented some of its players in a series called ''Sounds from the Left Bank'' - the bank in question being Queens, and the sounds being contemporary chamber works.
In keeping with the title, an artsy, informal and intimate atmosphere surrounds these Sunday afternoon concerts at Project Studios One (46-01 21st Street, Long Island City), an old school building converted into artists' studios and a gallery.


Dinosaur Eggs Yield Glimpse of Their Embryos
LEAD: EVERY gigantic dinosaur started out as a tiny embryo in an egg, but only now have paleontologists, applying advanced medical imaging technology, discovered some of those embryos preserved inside fossilized eggs.
The new findings are yielding important insights into the full life cycle of dinosaurs.

Ruling Said to Help in Policing Prices
LEAD: Yesterday's Supreme Court decision upholding a manufacturer's ability to stop supplying a discount retailer broadens the power of producers to control the prices of consumer goods, corporate lawyers and antitrust experts say.
It will also almost certainly cause some retailers to limit discounts, particularly for electronics goods and clothing.


Albany Nears Alcohol Limits For Stadiums
LEAD: Sales and consumption of alcohol would be prohibited in at least 6 percent of the seats at major professional sports stadiums and arenas under a bill agreed to by key state legislators.


T.L. van Winkle, 65, Atomic Researcher And Priest, Is Dead
LEAD: The Rev.
Thomas Leo van Winkle, an atomic scientist who later became a Roman Catholic priest and the headmaster of Portsmouth Abbey School in Portsmouth, R.I., died of lymphoma Saturday at Jane Brown Hospital in Providence.
He was 65 years old.

14 Die, Dozens Trapped in India As Wing of a Hospital Collapses
LEAD: A new wing of a children's hospital collapsed today in Kashmir, and at least 14 people died in a crush of bricks and concrete.
Dozens of children, their moans growing fainter, were trapped.


Plant-Notice Rule Assailed By Reagan
LEAD: In a speech before the United States Chamber of Commerce today, President Reagan heatedly denounced a provision of the recently passed trade bill that would make companies provide 60 days' notice of plant closings or large layoffs.

Cold Water as Survival Aid
LEAD: Submerged in cold lakes and rivers, human beings have survived without oxygen for otherwise fatal lengths of time because low temperatures slow the body's metabolic rate and restrict the flow of blood to non-vital areas.

Cullinet Plans To Lay Off 400
LEAD: Cullinet Software Inc. said yesterday that it will lay off about 400 employees, or 17 percent of its work force, as part of a restructuring and realignment.
Cullinet, based in Westwood, Mass., said the move will result in a write-off of about $8 million in fiscal 1988, ended April 30, but will reduce expenses in fiscal 1989 by about $25 million and should allow it to regain profitability after two years of losses.


J.P. Morgan Gets Financing
LEAD: J. P. Morgan &amp; Company, the bank holding company, said yesterday that it had secured $400 million in financing on its new headquarters buildings at 60 Wall Street.


Chess
LEAD: Considering the fine crop of young grandmasters in Iceland, it was not surprising that one of their number, 27-year-old Jon Arnason, won the 13th Reykjavik International Open Tournament.
Arnason topped a strong Swiss-system field of 54 players with an 8 1/2-2 1/2 score and was awarded $9,000.


Political Marketing; Picking Spots for Candidates' Spots
LEAD: If you are buying television time for George Bush commercials, ''60 Minutes'' is a good bet, but ''Saturday Night Live'' is not.


House Votes Bill Giving Benefits To Veterans Exposed to Radiation
LEAD: The House gave final Congressional approval today to a bill granting new benefits to veterans who were exposed to radiation when the United States occupied Japan in 1945 or in postwar tests of American nuclear weapons.


Updating WordStar
LEAD: WORDSTAR, the venerable word-processing program that just last year was resurrected in a greatly improved version called WordStar Professional Release 4, has been updated again in WordStar Classic Release 5.
The company says it has more than 200 new features and improvements.


Henry P. C. Keuls, Inventor, 96
LEAD: Henry P. C. Keuls, a New York inventor, died Saturday at the Red Bank (N.J.) Convalescent Center after a brief illness.
He was 96 years old and lived in Middletown, N.J.


Oil Prices Decline Almost $1
LEAD: Oil prices fell sharply yesterday after the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries backed away from a proposal to cut production in concert with seven other oil-producing nations.

LEAD: The Publishers Information Bureau, a sister organization to the Magazine Publishers of America, has announced that its member publications in March showed a 1.4 percent gain in ad pages over March 1987, to 14,407, while ad revenues clocked a 3.6 percent gain, to $483.6 million.
The revenue figure is an estimate.

3M Buys Pattis Group, Magazine Representative
LEAD: The 3M Company, owner of Media Networks, which allows companies to place local advertising economically in national magazines, has acquired the Pattis Group in Chicago, a major national advertising representative for magazines.
Details of the sale were not made public.


McGraw-Hill Drops College Publication
LEAD: McGraw-Hill Inc. has suspended publication of Business Week Careers, its five-year-old magazine for college students because of an inability to attract new advertisers.
The closing last week came several months after the company had begun efforts to attract older readers.


PATTERNS
LEAD:  Citywear as Weaponry


McGregor Released
LEAD: After more than two years of steadily declining performances from a pitcher who won a total of 135 games in the last 10 seasons, the Baltimore Orioles released Scott McGregor.
The 34-year-old left-hander, whose 138 victories are the fifth-highest total in Oriole history, had an 0-3 record with an 8.83 earned run average this season.


Boy, 8, Drowns in Creek
LEAD: An 8-year-old boy drowned after he slipped and fell into a creek while searching along the bank for returnable cans and bottles, the police said.
The victim, Roderick Hines, who was submerged for more than an hour in Rondout Creek, was pronounced dead Sunday night at Kingston Hospital.
He was walking with three other youths, one of whom tried unsuccessfully to rescue Roderick with a stick.


County Aide in Atlanta Guilty Of Extortion in Zoning Plot
LEAD: A. Reginald Eaves, who rebounded from a brief reign as Atlanta's public safety commissioner to win a seat on the Fulton County Commission, was found guilty of extortion Monday in connection with payoffs for zoning votes.


Maryland Legislator Terms His Aide's Death 'Tragedy'
LEAD: Representative Roy Dyson, Democrat of Maryland, today termed the apparent suicide of his chief of staff Sunday a tragedy, but he did not comment on what the motive might have been.


Jeff Malone Leads Bullets
LEAD: Jeff Malone scored 8 of his 35 points in overtime tonight to lift Washington to a 114-106 victory over the Detroit Pistons and keep the Bullets alive in the opening round of the National Basketball Association playoffs.

The Color of Spring
LEAD: To the Editor:


The Editorial Notebook; Reforming China: Nuts and Bolts
LEAD: ''We are building socialism with Chinese features,'' say China's leaders.
Right.
But what about cooking oil?
Should the Government end its subsidy?
What would be the reaction from residents of the cities, whose meat and chicken prices went up 17 percent last year?
Behind the grand slogans of reform, there must be people fitting together all the endless little pieces.

Equestrians Chosen
LEAD: The United States Equestrian Team has announced the five riders chosen for the 1988 Olympic team in the three-day event, which along with show jumping and dressage make up Olympic equestrian events.
They include Bruce Davidson of Unionville, Pa., who has been on three Olympic teams, two of which won the gold medal (in 1976 and 1984) and one the silver (in 1972), and who has twice won the individual world championship.

Bridge
LEAD: If, in a trump contract, a declarer plays toward a K-Q combination in the dummy, many defenders step up with the ace because the declarer might have a singleton.
They have it backward.
In most situations a defender should play second hand low because the lead might be a singleton.
Playing low may indeed mean that the ace does not score, but it holds the declarer to one trick in the suit.

Gas System Studies Canada Asset Sale
LEAD: Columbia Gas System Inc., a major United States carrier of natural gas, is considering the sale of its Canadian oil and gas properties to provide more money for its domestic operations.
The company said that it would not reduce its commitment to oil- and gas-related activities but wanted to focus on domestic concerns closer to its market areas.


Cyanamid Shares Jump on Rumors
LEAD: The American Cyanamid Company's stock jumped $2.75 a share yesterday, to $53.50, on the New York Stock Exchange, but analysts were skeptical of rumors that the drug and agrichemical company would receive a takeover offer.
The analysts said that potential bidders would probably be deterred by American Cyanamid's price tag of about $5.8 billion and by its desire to remain independent.

K. C. Jones to Retire as Coach
LEAD: In a surprise announcement, the Boston Celtics' coach, K. C. Jones, said today he would retire after the season and would be succeeded by the assistant coach, Jimmy Rodgers.


Review/Rock; Del-Lords: 60's Mufti, 80's Sounds
LEAD: The Del-Lords started Sunday's first set at the Bottom Line with a ringing guitar chord and a wild holler, two rock-and-roll basics; the bomping drumbeat came in a few seconds later.
The band members, in T-shirts and blue jeans, looked like every generation of bar-band rockers since the 1960's - but their songs, especially Scott Kempner's lyrics, are unmistakably 1980's rock.


Tax Receipts In Albany Fall Short
LEAD: New York State collected almost $500 million less than expected in income-tax receipts last month, the state budget division announced today, prompting Wall Street to raise the interest rates on the state's borrowing and Governor Cuomo to call for plans for possible spending cuts.


Coleco Job Cuts
LEAD: Coleco Industries said yesterday that it would cut about 475 workers.
About 330 of the positions are at the toy maker's manufacturing and distribution sites, where the reduction represents about 50 percent of the staff.
The company, based in West Hartford, Conn., also said it would reduce its headquarters staff by about 145, or roughly 35 percent.

LEAD: TIME is money, and New Yorkers are not ones to idle away precious moments as they dash along the city streets.

According to Nynex and Metro One, which service the telephones, about 10,000 are currently being paraded around the metropolitan area.

LEAD: SWEET custards are the quintessential dessert of childhood, and in the form of flan are inextricably linked to Spanish cooking.

Review/Theater; Growing Up Insufferable in Two One-Act Plays
LEAD: In the second of two related one-act plays grouped together as ''Terry by Terry,'' the title character announces that he is the author of the first play on the bill.
Shifting between levels of reality, ''Terry by Terry'' has a novel Pirandello twist: a play within a playwright.
The real playwright (at the Manhattan Punch Line Theater) is Mark Leib and his own possible proximity to his protagonist is one of the evening's several curiosities.


Drug Counts Dropped for Woman at Slaying Scene
LEAD: Drug charges were dismissed yesterday against Maritza Battista, one of the two women in an apartment where a police sergeant was accidentally shot to death in a narcotics raid last week.
The charges were dropped after a police laboratory report said not enough cocaine had been found in the apartment to warrant a felony indictment.

LEAD: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, after a lengthy and embarrassing search, has chosen Harold G. Christensen, a Utah lawyer, to become his chief deputy at the Justice Department, according to an Administration official.

LEAD: The poet Galway Kinnell will give a lecture on ''The Form of Free Verse'' at 8 P.M.

New Cray Product
LEAD: Cray Research Inc., based in Minneapolis, introduced a new series of supercomputers offering up to four times the memory at the same or lower prices than the Cray X-MP series that it will replace.
The new machines dubbed X-MP EA, for ''extended architecture,'' are based on the design of the Cray Y-MP introduced in February and can run programs developed for either the X-MP or Y-MP systems.

LEAD: Belgium's unemployment rate improved last month from a year ago, falling to 10.5 percent from 11.5 percent in 1987, the National Labor Office reported today.

'Cocoanuts' Extends Run
LEAD: The Arena Stage's production of ''The Cocoanuts,'' which had been scheduled to run until June 5, has been extended at least through July 3.
The production, directed by Doug Wager, received uniformly favorable reviews.
It is the first staging in 60 years of the George S. Kaufman and Irving Berlin show that introduced the Marx Brothers to Broadway.

LEAD: The Omnicom Group, whose components include BBDO Worldwide and DDB Needham, said yesterday that its first-quarter net income rose 21 percent, to $7.6 million, or 31 cents a share, from $6.3 million, or 26 cents a share, in the 1987 quarter.

LEAD: Under pressure from Gov.

Metro Datelines; 2 On IRT Are Shot In Theft of Chains
LEAD: A gunman shot and wounded two people on an IRT train in Brooklyn while stealing gold chains, the transit police said yesterday.
The robber escaped with the jewelry.
The incident occurred as the transit police, citing preliminary statistics, reported that felony crimes in the subways rose 5.4 percent in the first three months of the year, compared with the same period a year ago.

Guard Is Charged in Slaying
LEAD: A Brooklyn grand jury indicted a security guard on murder charges yesterday in the beating and strangulation death of a teen-ager in the mall he patrolled.
The security guard, Fred Bradley, 23 years old, of Brooklyn, was charged with three counts of second-degree murder and one count of aggravated sexual abuse in the killing of Julissa Rivera, 18, of Manhattan, according to the indictment.


Eliminating The Meter Reader
LEAD: Microelectronics has begun to change the electric meter, the device that measures electricity consumption.
New meters equipped with microprocessors and other sophisticated electronics can measure electrical use in five-minute increments around the clock, and report back to the utility headquarters monthly, daily, or even on demand, all by using the customer's phone line.


Chemical in Wine Tied to Migraines
LEAD: A TEAM of English researchers may have discovered why some red wine gives some people severe headaches.
The group, headed by Dr.
Merton Sandler at Queen Charlotte's Hospital in London, thinks that flavanoids, the powerful chemical compounds that give red wine its color, are partly to blame.

Election's Price in France: Values Above All
LEAD: The word is on every politician's lips: ''valeurs,'' or values.
Sensing a popular backlash against their traditional discourse, French politicians of the right and the left are appealing to values rather than dwelling on economic or social issues The emphasis on values suggests the fluidity of a campaign in which President Francois Mitterrand, a Socialist, has managed to cast himself as an almost nonpartisan, essentially conservative figure.

Donald Byrd Offering Two Dance Premieres
LEAD: Donald Byrd/The Group is to present two world premieres, ''Enactments in Time of Plague'' and ''Speakeasy,'' in a season today through Saturday at Symphony Space Theater, Broadway at 95th Street.
Mr.
Byrd's work combines ballet and modern dance, Afro-American social dance and theater dance and often deals with social issues.


Dukakis's Strong Suit Turns a Bit Weak
LEAD: Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis is campaigning for President as a strong financial manager, but management of the Massachusetts budget is giving him political headaches at home.


Guerrillas in Colombia Kidnap Five Foreigners
LEAD: Leftist guerrillas kidnapped four foreigners today and took responsibility for the kidnapping of a French diplomat, officials said.


General Dynamics Pact
LEAD: The General Dynamics Corporation has been chosen to design a new space launching rocket for military satellites and to build 11 such rockets for more than $500 million, the Air Force said today.
The St.
Louis-based company had been competing with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation to provide the new Medium Launch Vehicle-2 rockets, the Air Force said.


Bears Release 2
LEAD: The Chicago Bears have released a former All-Pro safety, Todd Bell, and a tight end, Tim Wrightman, a member of the 1986 Super Bowl champions.
Bell, a six-year veteran, was waived.
He earned All-Pro honors in 1984, sat out the Super Bowl season because of a contract dispute and has seen only part-time duty two years.


Anchor Glass
LEAD: The Anchor Glass Container Corporation said it would close a Tennessee container plant and a Pennsylvania mold manufacturing plant by early August as part of its restructuring.
The closing could mean that about 350 employees at the Chattanooga, Tenn., plant and 100 at the Reno, Pa., factory will lose their jobs.


Texas Electric Offering Bonds
LEAD: The Texas Utilities Electric Company is offering $300 million of first and collateral trust bonds in two equal parts through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley &amp; Company.

LEAD: For years the freeway from Metropolitan Airport into Detroit was one large litter basket, strewn with rusty auto parts and other urban flotsam.
Not anymore.
Now, seven days a week, work crews in orange vests remove the debris.


Corrections
LEAD: The Social Events column on Sunday gave an incorrect date for a benefit at the Joyce Theater for Dan Wagoner and Dancers.
It will be held Thursday, not today.
The location of the party afterward has been changed to the Tower Gallery, 45 West 18th Street.

LEAD: Barbara Hendricks's virtues as a song recitalist begin with a delectable, shimmering voice of pure quality: a sensuous pleasure to the ear.

Carroll Righter Dies; Hollywood Astrologer
LEAD: Carroll Righter, an astrologer to movie stars and a writer of a syndicated daily column for 166 newspapers around the world, died Saturday.
He was 88 years old and lived in Hollywood.


A Maverick Horseman Upsets Tradition at Churchill Downs
LEAD: Louie Roussel 3d is sometimes called King Louis III in his native Louisiana.
In Kentucky, where the owner and trainer is preparing to send out Risen Star in the Kentucky Derby on Saturday, he is being called ''a loose horse'': headstrong, flighty and hard to run down.

LEAD: Dr.

He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

In Taiwan, Change Sweeps Out Taboos
LEAD: This is the image of Taiwan in flux: on a sultry Saturday night in the busy West Gate market, a taxi driver stands on a flag-bedecked truck and shouts his anti-Government protest to the crowd.
Nearby, shoppers continue haggling over the price of shoes and snake blood, while worshipers crowd into an open-air temple holding burning incense sticks aloft and bowing before the gods.

60-MINUTE GOURMET
LEAD: LAMB is the meat most closely associated with spring, but the term spring lamb is often misused by restaurants and retail shops.
A real spring lamb should be less than a year old and weigh between 40 and 60 pounds.
Such lamb is prized for its tenderness.


A Second Festival of Serious Iconoclasm
LEAD: ''Serious Fun!,'' the experimental arts festival that brought downtown performance art to Lincoln Center for the first time last year, is to return to Alice Tully Hall next July with an expanded series of iconoclastic performance, dance and musical events.

LEAD: Despite the increased momentum of anti-drug operations in Bolivia, new plantings of coca bush dot the main growing area for the raw material of cocaine.


Economic Scene; Soviet Reforms Meet Reality
LEAD: EVEN the most enthusiastic admirers in the West of perestroika predicted that the Soviet economy would slow to a crawl while enterprises retooled and learned to fend for themselves in free markets.
But through miscalculation or political expediency, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, chose to sell the effort to restructure the economy and to reduce rigidity in the Soviet system as painless change.


Gullah Cooking: Improvising on Cultures Past
LEAD: WHEREVER Vertamae Smart-Grosvenor is, she cooks. ''I think that's why my friends keep me around,'' she said, as she tried to find her way around a ''borrowed'' kitchen in South Carolina's low country near Charleston, not far from where she was born. ''They always say, 'Come see me and stay over,' and they want me to cook.

LEAD:  Tennis  Kohde-Kilsch Advances: Claudia Kohde-Kilsch of West Germany, seeded third, overpowered Kathy Caversazio of Italy, 6-0, 6-1, yesterday in the second round of the Italian Open in Rome.
Play was suspended because of rain before Chris Evert, seeded first, could play against Ni-cole Provis of Australia.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  TENNIS  Evert Wins: Chris Evert, the No. 1-seeded player, got off to a slow start yesterday in the Italian Open in Rome before beating Nicole Provis of Australia, 7-6, 6-2, in a second-round match.
Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina, the second-seeded player, also played her first match in the $200,000 event, advancing to the round of 16 with a 6-4, 6-2 victory over Amy Schwartz, a qualifier from the United States.


Allegheny Petition
LEAD: Allegheny International Inc., the maker of Sunbeam and Oster appliances and Northern electric blankets, said a number of its non-consumer products businesses had joined in the company's filing in February for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code.


House Votes to Cut Spending on Anti-Missile Plan
LEAD: The House of Representatives, disregarding the threat of a veto, voted today to reduce the spending ceiling on President Reagan's plan for a space-based defense against missiles next year.
It set the limit at $3.5 billion, $1.4 billion less than the Administration requested.

Yachting's Crocodile Dundee
LEAD: IT wasn't over, but Ben Lexcen knew it was over.
Out on the blue water of the Indian Ocean off Fremantle, Australia, early last year, the 12-Meter yacht Kookaburra III was about to lose to Stars &amp; Stripes in the third race of what would be a 4-0 sweep in the America's Cup final.
Not even bothering to watch the finish through the wide windows of the press boat, the designer of the winged keel that enabled Australia II to win the cup in 1983 shook his head.

Parent &amp; Child
LEAD: THEY are small acts of terrorism, at least when measured against hijacked airliners and explosions at U.S.O. clubs.
The extortion payment may be milk money, the injuries limited to a black eye and bruised pride.
Yet the young victims of bullies describe their ordeals in terms much like those used by adult victims of terrorism.

LEAD: Norman S. Matthews has resigned as president and chief operating officer of Federated Department Stores, whose acquisition by the Campeau Corporation of Toronto was completed this week.

Before being named Federated's president in March 1987, he was a Federated vice chairman for three years.

Vehicle Sales Down 2.6% In Late April
LEAD: Late April sales of American-made cars and light trucks were down 2.6 percent from the comparable period last year, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

Jesse Jackson is to follow Thursday and Gov.

Health at the Top
LEAD: With the current crop of candidates more or less youthful and apparently healthy, the health of the next President has not been an issue in the campaign.
Nor does the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, appear to be in anything but the pink of condition.
But The Harvard Medical Alumni Bulletin, in its current issue, has published a statistical reminder that the health of those who lead the two superpowers ought never to be taken for granted.

Fight for Rowntree
LEAD: The food company Jacobs Suchard A.G., which is competing against Nestle S.A. for the British confectioner Rowntree P.L.C., said it had raised its holding in Rowntree to 23.48 percent from 21.14 percent.
In the British press, the assaults by the two Swiss companies on the producer of Kit Kat bars, Smarties children's candy and Polo mints have been called the ''chocolate wars.

Eastern Loss Seen From Safety Inquiry

Review/Concert; Aeolian Chamber Group
LEAD: At Town Hall Monday night, the Aeolian Chamber Players introduced a brief new work by Peter Lieberson, entitled (without benefit of program-note elucidation) ''Raising the Gaze.'' It is a six-minute burst of drum-driven, occasionally jazzy energy, with sharply pointed instrumentation (flute, clarinet, string trio, piano, percussion), spiky but not dreary dissonance and an authentic rhythmic life that made it a pleasure to follow.


F.A.A. Widens Inspections for Boeing Cracks
LEAD: Reacting to further data produced in the inquiry into the rupture of an Aloha Airlines jet over Hawaii a week ago, the Government yesterday widened the scope of emergency Boeing 737 inspections that have been looking for skin cracking and corrosion.

CHRYSLER REACHES PACT WITH UNION
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers reached agreement today on a new 28-month contract covering about 60,000 union members.


Snake Smuggling Is Charged
LEAD: The owner of a wholesale tropical fish business was charged yesterday with smuggling about 700 baby boa constrictors into the United States, Federal officials said yesterday.
The snakes are protected under international trade agreements.
The suspect, Agremiro Espana, 43 years old, owner of the Miro Espana Company in Jamaica, Queens, was also charged with violating the Lacey Act, which outlaws interstate or foreign transportation of illegally captured wildlife.


Back in Court
LEAD: The National Football League Players Association has returned to Federal court in Minneapolis in an attempt to overturn the N.F.L.'s restrictions on free agency.
The union thought it scored a victory last week when the National Labor Relations Board did not agree with team owners' contention that the players had refused to bargain in good faith.

Hospital Roommate Can Affect Recovery Time, Study Finds
LEAD: Hospital roommates can affect the course of recovery from surgery, new research indicates.
Recovery time was shorter by about a day and a half for patients awaiting surgery who shared a room with someone who had already undergone surgery, rather than someone who was also waiting for an operation.

Review/Theater; Ketron's 'No time Flat'
LEAD: As the author of ''Asian Shade,'' ''Fresh Horses'' and many other plays, Larry Ketron has sensitively delineated lives in America's heartland.
The landscape may appear to be small, but Mr.
Ketron's stories are brushed with humanity.
In his new play, ''No Time Flat'' (at the WPA Theater), the leading role is, uncharacteristically, that of a writer.


Q&amp;A
LEAD: Q.We have a ranch house that is built on a hillside.
During a heavy rain water seeps into the basement where the concrete floor joins the wall that is against the side of the hill.
I know you have recommended perimeter drains for problems like ours, but for us this would mean ripping out lots of paneling and breaking up the concrete floor.

Police Versus Firefighters
LEAD: The scene of a tragic accident is hardly the place for the New York Police and Fire Departments to engage in a shouting match over bureaucratic prerogatives.

NORWAY IS MISSING ATOM ARMS WATER
LEAD: Norway said today that a significant amount of Norwegian heavy water was missing and appeared to have been diverted four years ago into the international black market for materials that can be used to make nuclear weapons.


Tenneco's Earnings Surge
LEAD: The net income of Tenneco Inc. more than doubled in this year's first quarter, helped mainly by a one-time $25 million foreign tax credit, the company said today.
The credit was related to Colombian oil operations.


All-Lunceford Show Is Tribute to a Star of Swing
LEAD: The American Jazz Orchestra was steaming through ''T'ain't What You Do,'' a Jimmie Lunceford Orchestra standard, at a Tuesday afternoon rehearsal in Cooper Union's Great Hall.
As John Lewis, its conductor, beamed from the podium, the horns rose to their feet to finish the last chorus, swinging their saxophones to the irresistible two-beat - and finishing up with grins all around.


POLAND'S BISHOPS NAME 5 MEDIATORS IN LABOR CONFLICT
LEAD: Poland's Roman Catholic bishops, apparently acting with the approval of the Polish authorities, authorized five Catholic laymen today to act as mediators to break the deadlock in labor conflicts now in their second week.

LEAD: The Bank of New York Company announced yesterday that it had reached agreement with a majority of the Irving Bank Corporation's 15 preferred shareholders in an attempt to dismantle a ''poison pill'' provision that would make any takeover of the Irving more difficult.

Life in the 30's
LEAD: IT seems that most of the men in my life have wanted to possess things, but not actually to purchase them.
You see the problem.
If I am hanging around the house and it crosses my mind that, hey, we could use a toaster oven, the next logical step in my mental progression is to go to a store where I will buy a toaster oven, tote it home and toast up a storm.

Business Spending Rises Sharply, But Imports Get Much of the Gain
LEAD: A surge in business spending is under way in the United States.
But just as the American economy has failed to reap the full benefit of the consumer buying boom of the 1980's, it is missing out on many of the rewards of this new growth for the same reason: Much of the spending is on imports.

LEAD: In the broadest statement in months of his views on the economy, Alan Greenspan, Federal Reserve Board chairman, said that major countries do not know the optimum exchange rate of the dollar and that unemployment could fall further without causing higher inflation and inducing the Fed to raise interest rates.

Corrections
LEAD: An April 24 obituary of Lord Ramsey, a former Archbishop of Canterbury, misstated the origin of the line of English Primates.

Trims Are Made in 'Chess,' Saving Time and Money
LEAD: The Broadway play ''Chess'' has lost a few moves.
The 3-hour-plus, $6.2 million musical has become a 3-hour-minus, $6.2 million musical, in a move that saves thousands of dollars a week in overtime costs on a show that received less than favorable notices and is very expensive to run.

Baseball Notebook; Looking to Lefties: The Right Move?
LEAD: Perhaps it's a Communist conspiracy designed to subvert the possibility of a Subway Series, but the Mets and the Yankees are seeing an awful lot of left-leaning opponents this season, more, in fact, than any other team in their respective leagues.

Bellow Auctioning Off 'Sammler' Manuscript
LEAD: Saul Bellow is selling the notebooks, typescript and all papers relating to ''Mr.
Sammler's Planet'' at Sotheby's on June 7.
The manuscript material of the novel, published in 1970, is the first archive of a major living author's published work to be auctioned, and the first manuscript material to be sold by Mr.

LEAD: At the Leningrad college where Nina Andreyeva teaches chemistry, her colleagues give out her home phone number with nasty glee, throwing in a bit of gossip about the woman whose conservative ''manifesto'' prompted a national showdown over ideology.

Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about the credit markets misstated the source of a request for the repricing of New York State's offering of $2.6 billion in one-year notes.

Currents; Art Deco, to Adorn the Home Stage
LEAD: AS the interest in preserving and renovating Art Deco buildings has grown in recent years, home furnishings companies are producing products that recall the patterns and colors of the 1930's.
The latest of these is F. Schumacher's Radio City Music Hall Collection.
Twenty designs of printed and woven fabrics, wall coverings and borders, as well as carpet, were all adapted from the original archives.

People's Bank

The agency will start to work immediately and will be producing a mostly television campaign.
The budget is $4 million.
David Deutsch Associates, which won the account in 1985, was in the competition to retain it.

N.Y.U. Student Found Dead
LEAD: A 22-year-old photography student from Boston was found dead in his dormitory at New York University late yesterday morning, the police reported.
They said the man, whose identity was not released until his family could be notified, had been found in his undershorts in his dormitory apartment at 33 Third Avenue, near Ninth Street in Greenwich Village.

LEAD: Efforts to increase American access to Japan's beef and citrus markets have broken down, American officials said today, and the United States will take its complaint to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the world body that oversees commerce.

Sun Microsystems Stake for A.T.&amp;T.
LEAD: Sun Microsystems Inc., based in Mountain View, Calif., said it would issue 879,947 shares of its common stock to A.T.&amp;T. for about $40.6 million.
The sale, which is expected to be completed in 30 days, is based on the average price for the last 20 trading days through Monday of $36.8875 a share plus a 25 percent premium, bringing the total price to $46.1094 a share.


Benjamin Lawrence, Adman, Is Dead at 83
LEAD: Benjamin Lawrence, whose advertising art agency, Lawrence Studios, was among the largest in the industry in the 1930's and 1940's, died of lymph cancer at Beth Israel Hospital on April 25.
He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.
He had lived for many years in New Paltz, N.Y.

LEAD: HOPELESSLY unmechanical souls, take heart.
It's not all your fault.

Wings West Planes
LEAD: Wings West Airlines Inc. said that the AMR Corporation had established a deadline of next Tuesday to resolve differences over the airline's proposed acquisition of 10 British Aerospace advanced turbo-prop jets and that if an agreement was not reached, AMR would void their proposed merger.
AMR offered in mid-April to buy Wings West, a regional carrier that feeds passengers to American Airlines, for $10.50 a share.

Ogilvy Income Soars
LEAD: The Ogilvy Group, whose main component is the Ogilvy &amp; Mather worldwide ad agency, had a marvelously improved first quarter.
Although revenues only improved 17.6 percent from the corresponding quarter in 1987, net income more than doubled thanks to a large improvement in operating profit.
Revenues were $190 million, up from $161.6 million, while net income was $3.5 million, up from $1.4 million, or 24 cents a share compared with 10 cents.

His program was mostly contemporary and American, and offered an impressive overview of how composers have lately tapped the organ's considerable resources.

LEAD: AS architects become more involved in the total design process -creating everything from skyscrapers to tea cups - it seems only natural that they design store window displays.
Bergdorf Goodman has asked 10 top New York architects to transform its windows, using clothes from the fall collections.


Joe Niekro Cut
LEAD: The Minnesota Twins asked waivers yesterday on Joe Niekro, one of the most successful knuckleballers in baseball history, for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release.
