NEWS SUMMARY
LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL A3-12  Polish forces crushed a 10-day strike at the big Lenin steel mill at Nowa Huta.
Meanwhile, riot policemen kept the Lenin shipyard in Gdansk sealed as several hundred workers continued a four-day walkout.
Page A1


Offer to Protect Koppers Jobs
LEAD: In the latest round of its takeover battle with the Koppers Company, Beazer P.L.C. has offered to make ''substantial and important'' guarantees to all Koppers employees in Pittsburgh except for senior management if the company agrees to an immediate merger.


A Rockwell Closing
LEAD: The Rockwell International Corporation said it would discontinue operations at the plant here that its North American Aircraft division operates to make structural components for the B-1B aircraft.
The company has delivered the last of the B-1B's ordered by the Air Force.
Rockwell said final closing would require about 15 months.


Review/Film; Self-Absorbed Oblivion Before the Nazi Storm
LEAD: In a peaceful Viennese garden, a man and woman who have recently embarked on a love affair discuss the matters they care about most.
He has found a good apartment, in a building he says Mozart often used to pass; will she move in?
She has an offer to travel abroad for professional reasons; will he object too strenuously?

Troopers' Role in Drug War Expands
LEAD: Declaring that the Federal Government has ''failed miserably'' at stopping drugs coming into the United States, Governor Cuomo yesterday announced that 110 state troopers are being deputized by the United States Customs Service to help seize drugs smuggled into New York State.


WEEKENDER GUIDE
LEAD:  Friday  COMMERCIALS AS ART


Review/Art; The Elusive Bronze Sculptures of Joel Fisher
LEAD: Joel Fisher's slender sculptures resemble trees or figures but they resist exact definition.
His current exhibition at the Diane Brown Gallery, entitled ''Subtle Delusions,'' expands on an idea the artist has fruitfully pursued for several years - copying in three dimensions various shapes derived from chance arrangements of lines on paper.

Bourque Lives Behind a Mask
LEAD: After a Bruin victory, Ray Bourque, the defenseman who balances the rarest of skills with the lunchpail mentality so highly prized among Boston Garden's athletic contingent, sits slumped at his locker.


Review/Opera; Dame Janet Baker as 'Orfeo' in Concert
LEAD: In 1982, Dame Janet Baker completed a retirement from the operatic stage by singing Orfeo in Gluck's ''Orfeo ed Euridice'' at Glyndebourne.
But she has continued as a recitalist, and Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall she appeared in the same role in a semistaged concert performance of the opera with the Oratorio Society of New York.


Cable Consortium Formed
LEAD: Four of the nation's largest cable television companies said today that they would form a research and development consortium to focus on developing high-definition television and other new technologies for the industry.

LEAD: ''Brazil Projects at P.S. 1'' is one of the more ambitious and flawed shows of the season.
With works by around 70 painters, sculptors, photographers, architects, video artists, costume designers and television directors, this cultural extravaganza fills all three floors of P.S. 1's exhibition space.

Kaisertech Says It Sees Buyout Offers Coming
LEAD: Kaisertech Ltd. said today that it expects one or more acquisition proposals and that it had set up a committee of outside directors to evaluate the offers.


Review/Film; 'Judgment,' on a Hijacking and Its Aftermath
LEAD: ''Judgment in Berlin'' (no relation to ''Judgment at Nuremberg'') is an account of the aftermath of a 1978 hijacking of a Polish airliner by an East German seeking asylum in the West.
Helmut Thiele's appearance at Tempelhof Air Force Base in West Berlin was an embarrassment to the West Germans, so they tossed the case to the equally embarrassed Americans, who had no enthusiasm for punishing a refugee from the East but were bound by international treaty to crack down on hijackings.

Jorgen Jenk, 65; Rescued Jews
LEAD: Jorgen R. Jenk, a member of the Danish resistance in World War II and later an international business executive who was president of Georg Jensen Inc., died of heart and liver failure on Tuesday at Charing Cross Hospital in London.
He was 65 years old and lived in London.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Davis Joins Sherwood
LEAD: Marvin David, who has been running a one-man advertising show called Davisworks with the help of the city's multitude of freelancers, has moved in with Sherwood &amp; Schneider and has brought his four clients with him.
Total billings are about $3 million, the president, Lew Sherwood, said.
The clients are the Portuguese National Tourist Office, the Grow Group, Fownes Brothers &amp; Company, glove makers, and James Edmund Inc., maker of Oleg Cassini label menswear.


Fortune Financial
LEAD: A group led by the investor Paul A. Bilzerian said it now controlled about 9.9 percent of the common shares outstanding of Fortune Financial Group, a bank holding company based in Clearwater, Fla.
Earlier this week the investor, who this year took over the Singer Company, said that he had accumulated a 6.25 percent stake in Fortune Financial and that he might seek control of the company.

LEAD: For the next five days, the Cavendish Club, at 105 East 73d Street in Manhattan, can claim to be the center of the bridge world.

Yemen Oil Exploration
LEAD: Yemen and Southern Yemen have agreed on a joint exploration venture for oil in their border region, newspapers here reported today.

George Rose, 68, Broadway Star And Winner of 2 Tonys, Is Dead
LEAD: George Rose, a veteran comic actor who was as adept at Shakespeare as at Gilbert and Sullivan and who won two Tony Awards, was found dead early today in an overturned car near his vacation home in the Dominican Republic.

8 Decline Olympic Bids
LEAD: The list of players who have declined invitations to try out for the United States Olympic basketball team has grown to eight, and it could grow longer as potential Olympians choose to pursue the big money of the National Basketball Association rather than risk injury playing for a gold medal, according to Coach John Thompson of the Olympic team.

Review/Film; Imamura on Updating Divine Squalor
LEAD: The robust good looks of Shohei Imamura's 1968 Cinemascope epic ''The Profound Desire of the Gods'' only heighten the perverse quality of the action, and Mr.
Imamura's ribald, casually comic direction has much the same effect.
This three-hour film, which will begin the Film Forum 2's Imamura retrospective, makes an ideal introduction to the maverick qualities of this film maker's idiosyncratic style.

N.H.L. Playoffs; Oilers Rally to Gain 2-0 Lead in Series
LEAD: Mark Messier scored his second goal of the game and assisted on Craig Simpson's game-winner at 5 minutes 1 second of the third period, capping a three-goal surge that gave the Edmonton Oilers a 5-3 victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight in Game 2 of the Campbell Conference finals.


Inspection of Aloha Airlines Found Maintenance Wanting
LEAD: An extensive inspection of Aloha Airlines last December by the Federal Aviation Administration found the airline did not have an adequate system to assure that its aircraft were properly maintained, according to agency documents.


Williamsburg Bridge Not Ready to Reopen
LEAD: The Williamsburg Bridge will remain closed until at least next week, New York City transportation officials said yesterday.
The bridge was closed April 12 as a danger to the public, and officials have made different predictions as to when it can be reopened.

LEAD: Wearing a hard hat and overalls, Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts spent more than an hour in a coal mine today and then promised a national energy policy that would stimulate coal production and ''invest special resources'' in depressed mining towns like this one southeast of Charleston.

It stars Richard Chamberlain and Jaclyn Smith, known in the industry as king and queen of the mini-series form.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; A Selective Approach to Spirit Sales
LEAD: CARILLON IMPORTERS, which handles such spirits as Absolut vodka, Bombay gin and La Grande Passion and Grand Marnier liqueurs, likes to put its advertising where its customers are but its competition is not.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ketchum Yellow Pages Appoints Top Officials
LEAD: Robert Hickson, 61 years old, and Steven Troy, 39, have been promoted to chairman and president, respectively, of Ketchum Yellow Pages.
That specialty advertising unit of Ketchum Communications grew from $13.5 million in billings in 1982 to more than $64 million this year.


American Stores May Lift Lucky Bid
LEAD: The American Stores Company disclosed that it had told Lucky Stores Inc. it was willing to pay more than $60 a share for the company if non-public information provided by the company justified a higher price.
American Stores signaled its determination not to halt its battle for control of Lucky, even though the Dublin, Calif., supermarket chain has accepted a buyout offer of $61 a share, or $2.4 billion, from Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen Ltd.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; An Audit to Determine Location of Magazines
LEAD: The new interest in Whittle Communications' plans for publishing magazines specifically for doctors' offices makes it timely for someone to introduce syndicated research on which magazines can be found where.


Cooper Says It Is Seeking Buyers
LEAD: The Cooper Companies said that the board of directors had decided to seek a buyer for the whole company or for any or all of its businesses individually.
The decision follows an announcement last week by the Federal Trade Commission that it will seek to block Cooper's proposed sale of its contact-lens business to the Schering-Plough Corporation because it would reduce competition in soft contact lenses.


Impressionist Shows at 2 Auction Houses
LEAD: THIS is the May weekend when bidding paddles are polished and art enthusiasts by the thousands make the rounds of New York's auction galleries.
From today through Sunday, Sotheby's and Christie's will welcome the multitudes who come to view the largest exhibitions of Impressionist, modern and tribal art to be presented by the auction houses this year.

LEAD: ''The Mass Is Ended'' begins with a young priest, Don Giulio, returning to his home in Rome after service on a picturesque island, only to find more problems than he can handle.
They are mostly problems of the heart.
The priest whom Giulio is replacing had to give up the pulpit when his love affair produced a child.

Walter H. Miller, Banker, 55
LEAD: Walter H. Miller, chairman of the Richmond Hill Savings Bank and a former chairman of King Kullen supermarkets, died of a stroke Tuesday at his home in Garden City, L.I.
He was 55 years old.

Fossil Hand Could Upset Notions on Human Evolution
LEAD: In a finding that could upset established ideas of human evolution, a scientist reported yesterday that fossil hands from a South African cave strongly indicate that the direct ancestors to early man were not alone in developing the ability to make and use tools.


IRT Shooting Suspect Has an Arrest Record
LEAD: A Brooklyn high-school student charged this week with shooting one of six men who attacked him on an IRT train has two previous arrests for robbery, one of them in an incident on the IRT, police records show.

Steamy Nuns and Junkies
LEAD: When Yolanda's boyfriend dies of a dose of heroin laced with strychnine, with which she unknowingly supplied him, she seeks refuge from the police at the convent of the Holy Redeemers, dedicated to Our Lady of the Forsaken.

Cuban Riot Study Says Clues Weren't Heeded
LEAD: Officials at two Federal prisons where Cuban inmates rioted last November failed to secure the facilities partly because early signs of trouble were not relayed to them by prison personnel, a Justice Department report concludes.


Realty Broker Is Sued Over Racial Steering
LEAD: The New York State Attorney General today sued a Yonkers real-estate broker, Dan Merlino, and three employees of his company, Realty Forum, accusing them of racial steering by providing listings of apartments in particular neighborhoods based solely on a client's race or color.

LEAD: The evening before the Rev.
Jesse Jackson was defeated in the Ohio Democratic primary was a peak moment for Gerald Austin, the Ohio political consultant who is Mr.
Jackson's campaign manager.


U.S. Denounces Attacks on the Polish Strikers
LEAD: The White House deplored the violent attacks on Polish strikers today and urged a peaceful dialogue between the Government and the workers, including the outlawed free trade union movement, Solidarity.

Poison Gas Leak in Soviet
LEAD: Fifty-one people were hospitalized last month with gas poisoning after hydrogen sulphide leaked from a gas refinery in the Ural Mountains, the newspaper Sovetskaya Rossiya reported today.
The daily said that on April 26 many people in the village of Muzhichya Pavlovka woke up with severe headaches, weakness and nosebleeds.

Fire Damages Wright's Office
LEAD: Fire broke out late today in the Capitol Hill office of House Speaker Jim Wright, Democrat of Texas, and the blaze raged unimpeded for 10 minutes because of a lack of fire hoses and alarms, said a Congressman who was one of the first at the scene.


17 Die as French Free Hostages in New Caledonia
LEAD: French commandos freed 23 hostages today in the South Pacific territory of New Caledonia in an eight-hour siege in which 15 of the hostages' captors and 2 commandos were killed, the Government said.

LEAD: A television viewer in Tokyo watching members of two multinational mountain-climbing teams that simultaneously scaled Mount Everest, transmitting the first live broadcast from the summit yesterday.

Palestinian-American Held
LEAD: The Israeli authorities arrested Mubarak Awad, a Palestinian-American advocate of nonviolent protest, Thursday, Palestinian sources said.
The Palestinian sources said the police arrested Mr.
Awad during the night at his East Jerusalem home and took him for questioning.
Mr.
Awad, who advocates non-violent resistance to Israeli occupation, is a United States citizen.


One Dead, 30 Hurt in Los Angeles Skyscraper Fire
LEAD: Flames and smoke spewing from the 12th through 15th floors of the 62- story First Interstate Bank Building in Los Angeles early yesterday.
A building engineer died and more than 30 people were injured.
Officials called it the worst high-rise fire in Los Angeles history.

Economic Scene; When the News Is Good and Bad
LEAD: IT is becoming harder and harder to distinguish good news from bad news.
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said this week that he was ''optimistic that the balance of trade will continue to improve in 1988 and beyond.'' That sounded great.
But Mr.
Greenspan quickly added that the faster the trade balance improves, ''the greater the burden on monetary policy to curtail private domestic spending,'' lest the rapidly improving trade balance, combined with strong domestic spending, accelerate inflation.

Correction
LEAD: Because of a transmission error, an article in some copies yesterday about reported Justice Department appointments misidentified a Salt Lake City lawyer said to be in line for Deputy Attorney General.

Pop/Jazz; Seductive String Music Strikes a Global Chord
LEAD: STRINGS are a musical and cultural common denominator: they're found on disco records - a wall of violins wailing away - or in Sudanese pop music.
They're found in prim halls of European high culture and in studios seductively backing soul singers.
Now an integral part of Indian classical music, the fiddle defines bluegrass music in Tennessee.

SALIVA MAY HINDER AIDS TRANSMISSION
LEAD: Human saliva contains substances that prevent the AIDS virus from infecting white blood cells, a new study has found.
The researchers said the finding might help explain why no cases have been documented in which the AIDS virus was transmitted from person to person through saliva.

Evert, who was scheduled to play a third-round match against Helen Kelesi of Canada, defaulted because of a heel injury in her right foot.

NUCLEAR DUMPING AT LAKE SUSPECTED
LEAD: Chemical evidence strongly suggests that low-level nuclear waste has been dumped into a large California lake in the past 36 years, a team of geologists reported yesterday.
The scientists said they did not know the source of the waste, which they stressed posed no health hazard.

Texaco-Icahn Suit: June Hearing Set
LEAD: A Federal district judge in White Plains scheduled a preliminary hearing for June 3 in the suit filed by Texaco Inc. against Carl C. Icahn, its largest shareholder.
Texaco's annual meeting is on June 7, and Mr.
Icahn is seeking to be elected as a director, along with three associates.
Texaco wants the court to block him from voting his 14.8 percent share in the company or proxies for others and from buying more shares.

Marks &amp; Spencer Planning Brooks Brothers Expansion
LEAD: Brooks Brothers' new British owner, Marks &amp; Spencer, plans to open at least 50 percent more stores and expand the offerings of women's and casual clothes.


From a Team of Women
''Sticky Fingers'' is the work of a female director (Catlin Adams), female screenwriters (Miss Adams and Melanie Mayron) and a mostly female cast (including supporting players like Eileen Brennan, Gwen Welles and Carol Kane), but it's less feminist than dizzily feminine.
The two leading characters, struggling musicians sharing a picturesquely shabby downtown flat, are as bubble headed as they can be.
This is especially apparent after fate sends a suitcase full of money their way, courtesy of a drug-dealing friend (Loretta Devine) who asks them to watch it for an indefinite period.
What do they do about this windfall?
They shriek, they squabble and then they shop.
Helen Slater and Melanie Mayron, careening through the film in the kinds of zany ''Desperately Seeking Susan''-inspired outfits that are fun as long as they're on somebody else, play the blithe Hattie and Lolly at a screwball pitch.
To enhance this, Miss Adams often directs them to talk frenetically at the same time, and she establishes the characters' charming eccentricity with cute shots of their unusual shoes.
A lot of care has gone into the film's earring wardrobe, too.
So ''Sticky Fingers'' tries too hard, but it does have a fundamental good-naturedness that comes through.

Tom Clements, former Notre Dame quarterback, retired from the Winnipeg Blue Bombers, ending a 12-year Canadian Football League career in which he played for Grey Cup champions in Winnipeg and Ottawa and twice was voted as the league's most valuable player.

LEAD: The Seattle Mariners shortstop, Rey Quinones, was placed on the club's disqualified list Wednesday and will be docked a day's pay and service time for each day he is away from the team.

Suspect in 50 Robberies Seized
LEAD: A resident of a Manhattan men's shelter who is a suspect in more than 50 holdups of take-out desert shops since last November was arrested yesterday after officers followed him from the scene of a robbery of an Upper West Side cookie store, the police said.


Newspaper Carrier Claim
LEAD: A newspaper carrier who was injured in a car accident while on the job can file a worker's compensation claim against his newspaper, a state appeals court ruled today The decision by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court allows James Pittman to continue his claim against The Poughkeepsie Journal, a unit of the Gannett Company.


Las Vegas Tourney Halted by Winds
LEAD: In a rare decision by PGA Tour officials, play in the second round of the Panasonic Las Vegas Invitational tournament was suspended late this afternoon because of winds so severe that golf balls were blown off greens when placed for putting and golfers were in danger of being hit by flying debris and sand.

R. D. Darrell, 84, Dies; Recorded Music Critic
LEAD: R. D. Darrell, a music critic and author who was one of the first American critics to concentrate primarily on recordings, died on Sunday at Kingston Hospital after suffering a stroke earlier in the week.
He was 84 years old, and lived in Stone Ridge, N.Y.

LEAD: Sean Burke and Doug Brown, who reflect the youthfulness of the Devils, were the heroes in the second game of the Stanley Cup series with the Bruins.

The race, called a Micro Marathon, is sponsored by B.J.'s Kids, a day-care center.
There is a $4 registration fee.

Review/Film; Guns and Corruption
LEAD: In ''Shakedown,'' something fancy happens every 15 minutes or so, which is part of what makes the whole film so unremarkable.
It becomes difficult to remember why the stolen police car being driven by the runaway thug, for example, has got upside-down amid the piles of burning rubble.
Or why the roller coaster has run amok at Coney Island, or why the taxi has been impaled on the wrecking ball.

LEAD: The Prime Minister of the Bahamas, Sir Lynden O. Pindling, on Wednesday denied charges that he took bribes from drug smugglers.

He was 86 years old.

Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 426 money market mutual funds increased $611.7 million, to $273.61 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 117 institutional funds increased $1.94 billion, to $76.04 billion.
Assets of the 212 general purpose funds were up $85.2 million, to $82.69 billion.

Crooks Die Hard But So Does Cop
LEAD: There is one scene in ''Dead Heat,'' now at the National and other theaters, that produces a cold sweat: A dead cop has a shootout with a dead bad guy.
Blat blat blat go their guns; thunk, thunk, thunk go their torsos.
Only nobody falls down.
The prospect that they will keep it up forever is enough to chill even the professional moviegoer.

LEAD: Fixed-rate home mortgages headed higher in April, ending the decline that began after October's stock market plunge.

LEAD: United States trade officials who had been threatening retaliation against South Korea have begun expressing pleasure over steps promised by Seoul during four days of talks that ended today, Americans familiar with the negotiations said.

But he asserted that even after Soviet troops withdraw, the Afghan Army could easily defeat the guerrillas on the battlefield.

Costantino Nivola, 76, A Sculptor Of Public and Small-Scale Works
LEAD: Costantino Nivola, a sculptor who did public commissions for buildings at Harvard, Yale and a number of other sites in the Northeast, died of a heart attack Thursday at Southampton (L.I.) Hospital.
He was 76 years old and lived in The Springs on Long Island.

LEAD: For years, the Ingram family ran its White Castle restaurant chain in a stubbornly old-fashioned way.
Instead of advertising heavily, franchising or resdesigning stores, it relied on a simple menu of a square little hamburger that die-hard fans would buy by the bagful and devour at one sitting.

LEAD: China is planning to develop high-technology industries by setting up six ''silicon valleys,'' the official New China News Agency said today.
The zones will be in Beijing, Shanghai, Canton, Tienjin, Wuhan and the Shenzhen Special Economic Zone, near Hong Kong.

Suchard Increases Stake in Rowntree
LEAD: Jacobs Suchard S.A., a Swiss food and confectionery maker, raised its stake in the British confectioner Rowntree P.L.C. to 29.9 percent, the maximum allowed under British law short of a full takeover bid.
Jacobs Suchard has paid an estimated $:450 million (about $841 million) for the Rowntree shares, which it has acquired gradually since getting a 14.9 percent stake on April 13.

LEAD: A West German company accused by Norway of diverting a chemical used in nuclear reactors acknowledged today that the shipment had gone to Switzerland rather than West Germany.

U.S. Issues Fatality Data on 65 M.P.H.
LEAD: Preliminary figures show that traffic fatalities on rural Interstate highways with a 65 mile-per-hour limit rose last year at virtually the same rate as on rural Interstates that have kept the limit at 55 m.p.h., the Transportation Department said today.


In a 'Moral Rut'
LEAD: To the Editor:


Texaco Shares Up
LEAD: Shares of Texaco Inc. rose yesterday on speculation that its largest shareholder, Carl C. Icahn, would make a bid for the company soon.
Texaco gained 75 cents, to $52.125, in heavy New York Stock Exchange volume of three million shares.
It was the second-most-active issue on the Big Board. ''There's a lot of fast money that thinks a bid is coming over the weekend,'' one trader said.


'He Always Runs at the End'
LEAD: With the slanting sun behind him as if it had been positioned there by a lighting expert, Charlie Hadry stood outside Barn 37 at Churchill Downs in a tan cap, tan windbreaker over a brown sportshirt, tan slacks and brown shoes.
Short and stocky, he's been around race horses in Maryland for 40 years.

China Is Praised in Pravda
LEAD: Pravda today praised changes in Chinese economic policy that have attracted foreign investment, and it called for a rebirth of the work ethic to bring similar prosperity to the Soviet Union.
The Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, has made favorable references to recent Chinese economic experiments, but the article in the Communist Party daily was the most complimentary Soviet report on such changes in China.

LEAD: The masters of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority have decided to invest $1 million in an advertising campaign to tout something called ''Midday Business Service.'' The purpose is to entice ''25-to-44-year-olds with household incomes of at least $50,000'' back to the IRT.
I wish them luck.
But as someone in the target group, I don't need to be persuaded.

LEAD: A 37-year-old man was sentenced to three years in prison yesterday for unlawfully transporting two girls from Brooklyn to a New Jersey motel for sex.
The defendant, Victor Einhorn, pleaded guilty in February to two Federal charges of unlawfully transporting minors - aged 11 and 12 - across state lines to engage in unlawful sexual activity.

LEAD: The Murray Ohio Manufacturing Company, which makes bicycles and lawn mowers, yesterday rejected a $182 million takeover bid from Electrolux A.B. of Sweden.

Prudential Sues Over Asbestos
LEAD: The Prudential Insurance Company of America said it had sued the First Republicbank Corporation of Dallas for $135 million for the cost of removing asbestos from a building in Dallas that First Republicbank sold to Prudential.
In its suit, filed in Federal court in Dallas, Prudential said that the company had known about the asbestos problem in the Renaissance Tower but withheld the information.

At End, Knicks Look Forward
LEAD: Moments after the Knicks had been eliminated from the playoffs last night, the players milled round the locker room, not sad, not happy, but more or less in a state of contented relief.
They had lost, but they had won.
They had fallen short, but they had also taken great strides.

LEAD: The United States Attorney in Providence, R.I., filed criminal charges against E. F. Hutton &amp; Company yesterday, accusing the securities firm of being involved in a money-laundering conspiracy for organized-crime figures and business executives.


Federated's President Is Resigning
LEAD: Robert H. Morosky has agreed to resign as president and chief operating officer of Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores, the Campeau Corporation said yesterday.


Lay President for Duquesne
LEAD: Duquesne University today named John E. Murray as the first lay president in the Roman Catholic school's 110-year history.
The 55-year-old law professor at the University of Pittsburgh succeeds the Rev.
Donald S. Nesti, who was president since 1980 and resigned in August.


Bridge; FOREIGN PRESENCE IS REDUCED IN CAVENDISH INVITATIONAL EVENT
LEAD: The prestigious Cavendish Invitational Charity Pairs, to be played today and tomorrow at the club's premises at 105 East 73d Street in Manhattan, was expected to have a big foreign participation.
But the withdrawal of players from Brazil, England and Poland has reduced the number.

Canada Jobless Rate Dip
LEAD: Canada's unemployment rate dipped to 7.7 percent in April from 7.8 percent in March, Statistics Canada reporteds today.

R. D. Darrell, 84, Dies; Recorded-Music Critic
LEAD: R. D. Darrell, a music critic and author who was one of the first American critics to concentrate primarily on recordings, died on Sunday at Kingston Hospital after suffering a stroke earlier in the week.
He was 84 years old, and lived in Stone Ridge, N.Y.


U.S. QUARANTINE ON BEE MITE IS LIFTED
LEAD: A month-old, 13-state Federal quarantine to curb the spread of tiny bee mites was lifted today because it has proved unworkable, the Agriculture Department said.


Shock Absorbers for the Insurance Cycle
LEAD: Three years ago, everyone suddenly seemed beset by a crisis in liability insurance - municipalities, day care centers, ski lifts.
Premiums soared, more than doubling in some cases.
Insurers imposed sharp restrictions on coverage.
In many places, they canceled policies altogether.

LEAD: Two million lives are now at imminent risk from famine in Ethiopia, twice the number who died in the 1984-85 calamity.

This time the problem is different.
It's not the lack of food, but the regime's refusal to let it reach the famished.

Buffer for Civil War Site
LEAD: Two House Democrats who are Civil War buffs moved Wednesday to protect a historic Civil War battlefield in Virginia from nearby development of a shopping center.
The two, Representatives Robert Mrazek of Nassau and Suffolk County, New York, and Michael Andrews of Texas, introduced legislation for the Government to buy 600 acres next to the Manassas National Battlefield Park, where the Battles of Bull Run, known in the South as the Battles of Manassas, were fought.

Spring Cleaning
LEAD: A cold wind was blowing off Jamaica Bay.
Sixteen shivering students and their teacher from Lafayette High School in Brooklyn were cleaning up Plumb Beach.
The students, wearing white cotton gloves and carrying blue plastic garbage bags, picked up old milk cartons, beer cans, bottles, buckets, pieces of cardboard and plastic-foam plates - a winter's worth of litter washed up on the sand.

Film; 1960's Counterculture Spirit Becomes Airborne

GUIDEPOST: Mortgage Indexes
LEAD: Adjustable-rate mortgages, or ARM's, offer borrowers an alternative to fixed-rate mortgages, which now average 10.36 percent in the United States.
These variable-rate mortgages rise or fall with a particular financial index.
Lending institutions select their indexes based on an analysis of what best protects their loan portfolios.


BULLS AND BEARS
LEAD: JAY SPIELER SAYS HE'S STILL PARTIAL TO the vivid shirts, paisley ties and plaid suits he wore in the giddy days before Black Monday.
Spieler, a broker with Drexel Burnham Lambert, insists last October's market collapse hasn't caused him to change his image by a thread. ''In other words, '' he jokes, ''I'm not wearing a hair shirt.


POSTINGS: 200-Acre Tract; Preserving Woodlands, Fields and Ponds in Pawling
LEAD: While most condominium associations own an exercise room and maybe a sundeck, residents of Squire Green in Pawling, N.Y., will share West Mountain, not to mention South, West and East Lakes.
The mountain, actually a low ridge, and the lakes, really ponds, are part of a 268-unit town-house colony that will preserve over 200 acres of woods and fields.

LEAD: IN assessing the state of the nation's space program as the Reagan Administration nears an end, experts inside and outside the Government often use two words: muddle and disarray.
President Reagan, one of the biggest space enthusiasts to occupy the White House, will leave behind a host of costly projects and innovative policies.

LEAD: In a reversal, the Hong Kong Government has begun to acknowledge that rising emigration among skilled and professional workers is hurting the thriving economy of this British colony, which is due to be returned to China in 1997.

FICTION
LEAD:  BEAUTIFUL ISLANDS.
By Russell Martin. (Linden/ Simon &amp; Schuster, $17.95.) Russell Martin's well-written first novel traces a year in the life of Jack Healy, a decent, fortyish family man whose strenuous career has put too much pressure on his marriage.
This seemingly predictable material is made fresh because Healy is not a typical overworked professional but an astronaut, and because the year revolves around the real-life explosion of the space shuttle Challenger.

LEAD: Profits of New York's farmers increased in 1987 for the second consecutive year, up 23 percent from 1986, according to a report from the State Agricultural Statistics Service.


Gulch Captures Carter
LEAD: Gulch, trained by D. Wayne Lukas, who saddled the Kentucky Derby winner, Winning Colors, took the Carter Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.

Afleet, the favorite, was runner-up in the field of eight.


The Rockies by Narrow Gauge Rail
LEAD: BETWEEN 1870 and the early 1890's optimism about Colorado, embodied in discoveries of gold but mostly of silver, crested in the Rockies and converged with the other national sensation of the era, the steam-driven narrow gauge railroad.
Along with their precious ore the trains carried ''the emotional treasure of a westering people,'' wrote Lucius Beebe, the extravagant chronicler of Colorado's railroads.


NATIONAL GRIDLOCK
LEAD: LIKE COUNTLESS OTHER STREETS and highways around the world at that very moment, the Harbor Freeway in Los Angeles was an instant catastrophe, the lines of cars jerking to a halt, the traffic congealing in the fuzzy Southern California sunlight.
A television camera was watching somewhere overhead.
Magnetic sensors embedded in the pavement measured the speed and density of passing cars.


WHAT'S DOING IN: Memphis
LEAD: Memphis begins at the river, wide and brown and swollen with the rains of spring.
From the bluffs in Confederate Park, at the edge of downtown, the Mississippi sweeps past in a kind of cinematic panorama: trains of barges moving slowly beneath the twin arcs of the Hernando DeSoto Bridge; small riverboats, copies of 19th-century paddle wheelers, churning upriver against the current.

The Economy Still Churns Out Jobs
LEAD: Unemployment went down again in April, reaching a level not seen in 14 years.
The April rate was put at 5.4 percent, down from 5.5 percent in March.

Is 'The Last Emperor' Truth or Propaganda?
LEAD: The advertisements these days are proclaiming it ''the most honored film in 25 years,'' and indeed, Bernardo Bertolucci's new movie, ''The Last Emperor,'' which won nine Oscars at last month's Academy Awards ceremonies, does dazzle the eye.
The film, in telling the life story of Henry Aisin-Gioro Pu Yi, the last, quivering twig on the Manchu Dynasty's venerable tree, is distinguished by its gorgeous re-creation of the lacquered, ceremonious interior of the Forbidden City, where Pu Yi was virtually imprisoned for 12 years after the tottering dynasty crumbled into nothingness in 1912.

In Maremma, Etruscan Ghosts Linger
LEAD: MAREMMA L'AMARA it was called, Maremma the bitter, for the harsh life of its inhabitants, their unforgiving lands, their ruined villages.
Of all the well-traveled regions of Tuscany, it was the most feared and remains the least known.
Yet it is the one that most captivated the Tuscan imagination - from Dante's lugubrious evocations of violent death and disease in the region he elevated to a symbol of human vanity and eternal despair, to Giovanni

LEAD: There's a new man in town in Washington and for someone born in 1848 he's looking remarkably fresh.

THE WOLF INSIDE
LEAD: In his poignant article ''The Wolf Inside'' (Body and Mind, April 3), John Stone showed great sensitivity for the suffering and pain of lupus patients.
The outlook has indeed improved since Flannery O'Connor was diagnosed in the early 1950's, but there are still too many lives cut short by this pernicious and complex disease.


ARE WOMEN BETTER DOCTORS?
LEAD: Perri Klass asks if women are better doctors.
The question is sexist and irrelevant.
A female physician is no less able to perform open-heart surgery than a male doctor is able to tell patients, caringly, that they have cancer.
Sensitivity, empathy and sincerity are not female qualities; they are human ones.

His is a bold, clear, strong voice - trying to find its way through a good deal of static clutter.

FICTION
LEAD:  UNDERCOVER.
By Soledad Santiago. (Bantam, Paper, $3.95.) Two cops - one brutal and vengeful, the other kind and caring - patrol the mean streets of Alphabet City in this gritty first novel about the drug subculture of New York's Lower East Side.
True to the schematic conventions of such crime procedurals, the ''human'' partner oozes compassion for the local criminals and their prey, who are joint victims of the rampant illegal drug economy, while the hard-nosed cop just wants to beat all the dope fiends to a pulp.

LEAD: Senate approval of the foreign trade bill last month didn't end the legislative maneuvering that has dogged its three-year course across Capitol Hill.

But the sense of freedom is what comes across most strongly - freedom to be yourself, to stay up at all hours, to share the life of the street; freedom to stroll around and observe.

Sizing Up The Shape of Music
LEAD: I used to have record shelves.
They held LP's and 45-r.p.m. singles, more or less alphabetized.
In the late 1970's, I squeezed in 12-inch singles and a handful of cassettes, and set aside a shelf end for a novelty, 10-inch EP's.
Then the 1980's came, and the Walkman.
Cassettes started to stack up -cassettes with more songs than the album with the same title, cassettes of rare albums, cassette-only recordings, dance tapes.

OPERA SEEN THROUGH A PLAY OF THE SAME NAME
LEAD: Purist music lovers - the kind who regard anything more grandiose than a chamber-music concert as borderline vulgarian -look with extreme suspicion on opera.

Opera is a hybrid, a form of musical theater that partakes of both music and theater.

FICTION
LEAD:  GREEN CITY IN THE SUN.
By Barbara Wood. (Random House, $19.95.) An interesting tale of Africa in the stormy days before independence is buried under about 300 pages of excess verbiage and extraneous characters in this new novel by the author of ''Domina'' and ''Vital Signs.'' In ''Green City in the Sun,'' Barbara Wood chronicles life in Kenya from 1919 to the present through the experiences of two families, the English Trevertons and the African Mathenges.

LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
LEAD:  HAPPY MOTHER'S DAY  Today's the day mothers get their due, and those who want to go beyond the ordinary - the card and the dinner to say you care the most - can take advantage of some offbeat ways to share togetherness on Mother's Day.

LACROIX OR LE CASH?
LEAD: Patricia Volk's arithmetic explained: A 10 percent discount after New York City sales tax nets out to about 2 percent.
Fifty Lacroix dresses ($750,000) less 2 percent discount equals one Lacroix ($15,000) free (no discount, no sales tax, dated register receipts and price tags required).
FRANK J.


AGNES DE MILLE: EAGER AS EVER
LEAD: When, in 1975, the American choreographer Agnes de Mille suffered a debilitating stroke, it was believed she would never again speak, never again walk and, most tragically, never again make dances.
Indeed, Miss de Mille's career, spanning some 50 years, was thought to be virtually over, marking a sad end to an extraordinary chapter in dance history.

No Headline
LEAD: THE vibration of the gong washed over the tones of the other instruments.
Suddenly, the drummer reared his head and the pace became frenetic.
Dynamics and density escalated.
The wooden hammers struck the bronze keys relentlessly, in perfect synchronization.
Rhythmic patterns repeated and repeated; melodic lines interlocked precisely.


A Festival of All Those Notes in Between
LEAD: Most Western music is based on an octave divided into 12 equal pitches.
Of course, the octave can be split differently, as it is in other cultures, and as composers of the Microtonal persuasion have argued for decades.
Microtonalists insist that the mathematically pure intervals yielded by, for instance, a 31-note scale, are inherently more pleasing than the slightly impure ones we are used to.

Sam Labe of New Milford, N.J.

Her father is the president of Simplex Machinery, a machine tool importer and distributor in Hackensack, N.J.

Question of the Week; Do the Yanks and Mets Need Mascots?
LEAD: A mascot for the Yankees?
Absolutely yes!
He should be oversized and out of proportion so he can easily be seen from the far reaches of the Stadium.
He should possess a large enough mouth so that he can be heard at least two sections away.
The ideal mascot will also be able to involve the players in his nutty antics.

Anchors for Making Strong Joints
LEAD: THE ability to hammer nails skillfully has always been required for most carpentry tasks.
But in recent years, fastening aids called construction anchors have been developed that allow strong joints to be created with less skill, particularly in toenailing, the difficult technique of driving nails at angles.


Newark Hospitals Forming AIDS Unit
LEAD: FACED with the strain of a constantly increasing number of AIDS patients, this city's five major hospitals -University, St.
Michael's Medical Center, Columbus, Beth Israel and United Medical Center - are forming a consortium to open a nonacute-care facility for such patients.
It would provide a level of treatment similar to that of a nursing home.

Some Golf Rules Are Outdated
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:


Japan's Favorite Tax Inspector
LEAD: Japanese think of themselves as an honest lot, and, for the most part, the self-trust is not misplaced.
Their low crime rate attests to that.
But sometimes they give themselves too much credit.
Take Japanese tax codes.
The law allows the shopowner, the farmer, the real-estate speculator - basically anyone in business for himself - to declare his own income and expenses.

Woody Woodpecker picks up. ''It's Woody Woodpecker,'' he says. ''Thanks for calling.
Haaa-haa-ha-ha-haaa.'' Then he puts on Dinosaur Buddy who tells how the telegraph and the telephone came about.

To Dr.
Alan Gelperin, a research scientist at Bell Labs in Murray Hill, N.J., they are creatures worthy of respect. ''The degree of sophistication and complexity of their biological machinery is awe inspiring,'' he said in a recent interview.

Serving Seafood, Not Stereotypes
LEAD: THEODORE'S in Oyster Bay doesn't serve clam chowder, shore dinners or breaded fried shrimp, yet it bills itself as a seafood restaurant.
Which goes to prove that there are seafood restaurants and seafood restaurants.
Theodore's calls itself unique, and is.
Here, smoked shark, fish soup Provencal, snapper en croute and bouillabaisse tempt fish fanciers.

Is Beethoven no better than the Clash?
Allan Bloom believes that creeping relativism is eroding society - and that it's partly Nietzsche's fault.

The Slow March Toward More Trade
LEAD: THE political thaw in Soviet-American relations is beginning to work its effect on the commercial front.
This is the impression I brought back from last month's United States-Soviet Union Trade and Economic Council meeting in Moscow.
This twice-postponed event brought together 500 chief executives from major American corporations and their Soviet counterparts in a four-day series of seminars and talks devoted to improving bilateral trade ties.

Car Rental
LEAD: To the Editor: This is a warning to European travelers: Check carefully before renting a car, especially on a short-term basis.
We rented a deluxe car from Hertz in Paris for a two-day trip to the Loire Valley.
It cost almost $600, based on the five-day, unlimited-mileage rate (which was cheaper than the daily rate with mileage -about 400 miles - added) and 33Y percent tax.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Tennis  Sabatini vs.
Kelesi in Final: Second-seeded Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina and 14th-seeded Helen Kelesi of Canada advanced to the final of the Italian Open yesterday with straight-set victories in 86-degree heat in Rome.
Sabatini, the heavy favorite after the withdrawal of top-seeded Chris Evert because of a heel injury, staved off a set point and needed nearly two hours to beat 13th-seeded Judith Wiesner of Austria, 7-6, 6-3.


SLICES OF LIFE
LEAD: DEFINING A SANDWICH IS ALMOST impossible.
Two slices of bread surrounding a filling doesn't do it, since a sandwich can be open-faced, or triple-faced.
A sandwich can be humble, as in a slice of meat loaf on toasted white bread; grand, such as a sliver of velvety smoked salmon with cucumbers and beluga caviar, or grandiose, as in a listing tower of meat, cheese, lettuce and vegetables.

LEAD: I was a student in Richard Ford's writing workshop at Princeton in 1981 (''Richard Ford's Uncommon Characters,'' by Bruce Weber, April 10).

Beneath Hawthorne's Gables, Tourism Aids Needy
LEAD: Nearly 150,000 people visit the House of Seven Gables in Salem every year, but few who tour the 17th-century house overlooking Salem Harbor, the house made famous as Nathaniel Hawthorne's ''House of Seven Gables,'' know their visits support a neighborhood settlement house that began in 1908.


MOTHERHOOD: VARIATIONS ON A THEME; 'There's Still a Girl Inside Me'
LEAD: HOW can my first-born be 45 years old today when I am still in my 20's?
How could she have changed so quickly from the cute little red-faced baby who was born on that icy day in January 45 years ago, when I am still the same young woman?
And as I kiss her and wish her a happy birthday, I wonder if she is asking herself how that graying lady with the wrinkles here and there could have changed so soon from the dark-haired, round-faced person she remembered from her childhood.


Japan May Join Air Venture
LEAD: Japan and the United States are expected to explore the possibility of jointly developing a supersonic airliner that could fly between Tokyo and New York in two and a half hours, a Japanese Government spokesman said.


Wendy Schack, a Lawyer, Is Wed to Alan M. Forrest
LEAD: The marriage of Wendy Gail Schack, a corporate counsel for Group Health Inc. in New York, to Alan Michael Forrest, a lawyer for the Clark Boardman Company, a publisher of law books in New York, took place yesterday at the Old Westbury (L.I.) Hebrew Congregation.
Rabbi Israel Miller, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.


Chinese 'Silicon Valleys'
LEAD: China is planning to develop high-technology industries by setting up six ''silicon valleys,'' the official New China News Agency said Friday.
The zones will be in Beijing, Shanghai, Canton, Tienjin, Wuhan and the Shenzhen Special Economic Zone, near Hong Kong.
They will concentrate on such businesses as computers, robots, microelectronics, optical-fiber communications and lasers.


BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  The Fed is under increasing pressure to raise interest rates, the latest squeeze coming from the release of April employment data.
Some analysts took heart from the fact that payroll employment increased by only 174,000 jobs, but others were concerned about inflation because unemployment had fallen to its lowest level in 14 years and the total number of hours worked had risen sharply.


Repeal of New York City Mayoral Primary Runoff Falters in Albany
LEAD: With many leading New York City Democrats favoring the present system of mayoral primary runoffs, a politically significant bill to repeal it appeared to be in serious trouble over the weekend.


U.S. Bond Sales Fell in April
LEAD: Sales of United States savings bonds dropped in April for the first time in eight months, falling 6.4 percent, to $661 million.


New Yorkers &amp; Co.; In Stormy Markets, Safe Havens Sell
LEAD: If it weren't for the stock market collapse last fall, Robert N. Gordon might still be struggling to earn his first $10 million before he turns 40.
But Mr.
Gordon has handsomely profited from the turmoil on Wall Street as investors have sought a money manager who can earn a double-digit rate of return without the heartburn caused by the dramatic fluctuations in the market.


After Rebellious Youth, MTV Tries the System
LEAD: From the moment it arrived on Aug. 1, 1981, the cable-television music network MTV was everything the rest of television was not.
It was fast, it was loud, it was scary to parents and, mostly, it was hip.
Even the time it went on the air - one minute past midnight - was a kind of anti-television statement.

GLOBAL BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Argentina's cost-of-living index rose 17.2 percent in April after a gain of 14.7 percent in March, the national statistics institute said.
The index showed a rise in the year to April of 247.8 percent, compared with 206.9 percent in the year to March.
Inflation in the first four months of the year was 62 percent.

LEAD: On the first hit, Tim Teufel just couldn't get the ball out of his glove.
On the second, a sprinting Darryl Strawberry couldn't quite grab the ball.
On the third, everyone stood and watched as a bunted ball refused to come up off the infield grass.


Drabek Prevails On Near No-Hitter
LEAD: Doug Drabek pitched eight hitless innings today before a pinch-hitter, Randy Ready, led off the ninth with an infield single as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the San Diego Padres, 6-2.


Soviet Change vs. the Worker's Scrutiny
LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's new economic reality visited this Black Sea port city last year, passing like an unexpected tremor through the rock-stable lives of longshoremen, crane operators, mechanics and clerks.


Senate Primary Race Divides G.O.P. in Nebraska
LEAD: Hand outstretched, head thrust forward, a determined smile on his face, Representative Harold J. Daub bounced from table to table, greeting the mostly Republican members of the Norfolk Rotary Club in the mostly Republican northeastern part of this predominantly Republican state.
Again and again, he was greeted with restrained smiles.


S.E.C. Official Is Nominated
LEAD: The White House announced today that it would nominate Charles C. Cox to a second five-year term as a commissioner of the Securities and Exchange Commission.


Workers Don't Have 'Parachutes,' Mr. President
LEAD:  To the Editor: The legitimacy of a government depends to a large extent on its ability to appear fair and evenhanded.
A nation will accept a great deal of suffering if its citizens perceive that this suffering is both necessary and evenly distributed.
When, however, an administration violates this rule of legitimacy, when it becomes the captive of a small, privileged interest group, its days are surely numbered.

3 Sizable Accounts For Symon &amp; Hilliard
LEAD: Symon &amp; Hilliard has popped up with three new $1 million accounts.
The General Electric Company, a client for eight years, has assigned it the GE Automotive business, which serves the auto industry.
GE Automotive previously had no agency.


A Soviet Day To Remember Past Victories
LEAD: When he left Moscow to fight in Germany more than 45 years ago, Vasily Bakumenko knew why he, then just 16 years old, was going to war. ''For Stalin, for Stalin,'' said the veteran, now 61 years old. ''We were so sure.
We wrote it on our tanks and our helmets.
For Stalin.''


Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. Why is it that spiders don't get caught in their own webs?
A.
Nobody knows, because nobody has investigated it thoroughly, according to Dr.
Herbert Levi, professor of zoology at Harvard University. ''I don't know of anybody who has worked on this,'' agreed Dr.
William Mitchell Masters, assistant professor of zoology at Ohio State University, who has studied how fast spiders can run across their webs and how well they detect vibrations through the web.

Officials Doubt Arson Caused Skyscraper Fire
LEAD: Investigators have virtually ruled out arson as the cause of the fire that ravaged the tallest building in California last week.
The investigators said today that they might never know what started the blaze.


Unusually Large Output
LEAD: The current issue of Books in Print, a catalogue of authors and titles, credits 64 books to Robert A. Heinlein, one of the country's most successful science-fiction writers.
An in-print listing of 64 books is unusual, although some books are represented on the list more than once.


The Pound Is Up Sharply; Dollar Steady as Gold Gains
LEAD: The British pound rose sharply yesterday on unfounded rumors that the Government's key advocate of currency weakness was preparing to quit.
The rumors reinforced predictions of a $2 exchange rate for sterling in the near future.


Publishing Schedules Speeded on Regan Book
LEAD: The disclosure in Donald T. Regan's new book that Nancy Reagan regularly consulted an astrologer about the scheduling of major Presidential activities would likely have created headlines whenever the news broke.
But when Newsweek reported it last week, it not only generated headlines but caused considerable scrambling at Time and Harcourt Brace Jovanovich.


Federal Aid for Destitute Reaching Just Half of Those Eligible
LEAD: A Federal program for the destitute is reaching only about half the elderly, blind or disabled people who are eligible, according to lawmakers who have studied it.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on the Consumer's World page on Saturday about Raffoler Ltd., a mail-order house, misstated the number of packages the Lillian Vernon company sends by mail.
The company sent 3.6 million packages in its last fiscal year, 200,000 of them by parcel post.

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  Tax-exempt organizations face new taxes on some commercial activities under Congressional proposals endorsed by the Administration.
Advocates of change say the issue is fairness, not revenue, and complain that small businesses are at a competitive disadvantage in competing with not-for-profit groups.


Rutgers Players Mourn a Teammate
LEAD: Doug Kokoskie looks for answers in his dormitory room at Rutgers University, but they are not there.
He peers out the window, stares at the ceiling and finds nothing.
He is not alone.
It is difficult, if not impossible, to explain the death of a young person.


I.B.M. Produces Half-Micron Chip
LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had produced the first fully functioning computer chips measuring only a half micron.
The compact chips were made for the Defense Department and will be used for such things as capturing and processing radar and sonar signals.
Compact chips run faster because the electricity travels less distance.


A Trading Halt Won't Calm the Market
LEAD:  To the Editor:  The New York Stock Exchange is now considering a halt to all trading any time the market declines a specific amount, still to be determined.
This will almost guarantee declines of the set amount as sellers rush to get out before the shutdown when there appears to be a major sell-off.


Calvin Klein Is in Treatment For Alcohol and Drug Abuse
LEAD: Calvin Klein, one of the most celebrated and successful American fashion designers, recently checked into a leading drug and alcohol rehabilitation center and will remain there until the end of the month, according to a spokesman.

Maxtor Offers Erasable Drives
LEAD: The Maxtor Corporation, a leading manufacturer of computer hard disks, today introduced two erasable optical disk drives that it said offer the highest capacity and performance available.
Scheduled to be shipped in September, the drives are priced in quantity at $1,000 for the 3 1/2-inch model and $2,500 for the 5 1/4-inch model, both industry-standard sizes for hard disks.


U.S. Labor's Lost Power: 5-Year Decline of Strength Shows as Wages Barely Rise Despite a Falling Jobless Rate
LEAD: In years gone by, an announcement that the civilian unemployment rate had fallen to 5.4 percent would have signaled the coming of big wage increases - sparked by growing competition among employers for a dwindling supply of workers.
But clearly times have changed: despite some shortages, wages are barely rising and there are no signs that they will begin to soar.

LEAD: A livery taxicab driver was shot to death in the Bronx yesterday in an apparent robbery, the authorities said.

Sentence in Freeway Killing
LEAD: A motorist who fired on a pickup truck in one of several highway shootings in the Los Angeles area last summer was sentenced today to serve up to life in prison for murder.
The man, Ronald Elam, 28 years old, was sentenced by Superior Court Judge Madge Watai in connection with the death of Debbie Ann Scott, a 26-year-old mother of three, who was a passenger in the pickup.

U.S. Oil Rig Count Up
LEAD: The number of working domestic oil and gas rigs rose by 17 last week, to a total of 897, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today.
The rig count, the widely watched industry index of drilling activity, totaled 767 a year ago, Baker Hughes said.

Senators Want U.S. To Fight 'Crisis' of Drunken Driving
LEAD: Ninety-nine senators asked Surgeon General C. Everett Koop today to declare drunken driving a ''national crisis,'' but Dr.
Koop said he believed the problem was most effectively handled locally.


Steel Production Down
LEAD: Steel production fell to 2.03 million tons in the week ended Saturday, a decrease of nine-tenths of 1 percent from the previous week's 2.05 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The industry's production amounted to 94.6 percent of capacity for the week, compared with 95.5 percent in the previous week.

Shrinking Companion For Very Fast Pulsar
LEAD: A VERY rapid pulsar, a pulsating star that spins 622 times a second, has a companion that regularly eclipses the pulsar and itself appears to be ''evaporating,'' Princeton University scientists have found.

Norway Cuts Key Rate
LEAD: Norway's central bank cut its major interest rate by half a percentage point today amid signs that the country's trade and inflation difficulties could be receding.
The central bank cut its overnight lending rate to commercial banks to 13.3 percent from 13.8 percent and said it expected the banks to pass on the lower rate of borrowing to customers.

Richard Ogilvie apparently suffered a heart attack today and was in critical condition at Northwestern Memorial Hospital, officials said.

LEAD: Corporate financial managers expect continued economic growth for at least 12 months, but many foresee a mild recession after that, according to a poll by a trade group.


Fire Causes Airport Delays
LEAD: A weekend fire at an Illinois Bell switching station kept telephones idle for 35,000 customers in Chicago's western suburbs today and caused delays at major airports.Crews at the Federal Aviation Administration's control center in Aurora were using a backup phone system, but the lack of full service meant controllers had to stagger the arrival of flights by 20 miles.

Housing Crisis, Housing Emergency
LEAD: Anyone who thinks the shortage of affordable housing is bad now need only look forward. ''Homeless'' does not simply describe thousands of low- and moderate-income families that have no suitable place to live today.
Under existing law, thousands of homes occupied by poor families will soon soar in price, driving ever more people to the streets.


In Lizards, Eggs' Heat Linked to Behavior
LEAD: ZOOLOGISTS have known for several years that the sex of certain reptiles is determined by the temperature at which they are incubated in the egg.
But in a new development, University of Texas scientists have found that incubation temperatures can profoundly influence adult behavior as well.

France Faces the Center
LEAD: What a difference from Francois Mitterrand's first presidential victory seven years ago.
Then, a specter of Communism alarmed France's allies; some prominent businessmen left the country.
But yesterday, the French stock market celebrated the Socialist president's overwhelming re-election by registering a solid gain.


Beazer Clarifies Koppers Offer
LEAD: In an effort to decrease opposition to its proposed takeover of the Koppers Company, Beazer P.L.C. yesterday provided details of its job-guarantee offer.
It said last week that it would protect the job of every employee of the Pittsburgh-based company except senior management if Koppers agreed to a quick merger.


Just the Right Touch
LEAD: COMPUTER keyboards, more than any other computer components, are subject to the Goldilocks syndrome.
The user goes from one to the next trying to find the one that is just right.
This one is too hard, that one is too soft.
This one is too crisp, that one is too mushy.
This one is too loud, that one is too quiet.

By Design; The Return of the Hat
LEAD: It's true.
The hat is back.
For several seasons fashion oracles have been telling us that hats would return to high style.
Now it seems to be happening.
Stores like Bergdorf Goodman and Barneys New York have been steadily enlarging their millinery areas and report increased sales to women of all ages.

LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $400 million of short-term floating-rate notes due on Nov. 10 at a price of par through various securities dealers.
The size of the financing was increased from the original $350 million because of good investor demand.


13 Hostages Are Freed By Rebels in Colombia
LEAD: Leftist guerrillas today released 13 of the 15 foreigners and journalists they kidnapped last week.
The rest were expected to be freed soon.

Music Noted in Brief; A Sylvan Anniversary
LEAD: The Sylvan Winds were founded in 1976, but on Friday evening at Town Hall the ensemble offered what it called its 10th-anniversary gala - apparently counting its age from the first time it offered a formal subscription series rather than from its birth.
The group's playing, fortunately, is more precise than its math, and about as creative.

Panama Banks Reopen Under New Constraints
LEAD: Banks here opened under close restrictions today in an effort by the military Government to make enough cash available to the public to permit a limited return to normal of economic activity.


Profits Up Strongly at Major Banks
LEAD: In commercial banking, if the first quarter is any indication, this should be a very good year.


France's Financial Markets Now Unfazed by Mitterrand
LEAD: When Socialist candidates win big in Europe, stock markets usually nose-dive, but the Paris Bourse bucked that historical tide and rose strongly today, the day after France's Socialist President, Francois Mitterrand, won election to a new seven-year term.


New Top Editor at The Post Is Said to Have Been Chosen
LEAD: Jane Amsterdam, founding editor of Manhattan,inc. and a senior editor at Alfred A. Knopf since January, will be named editor of The New York Post today, people at the newspaper said.


Legal Abortion Under Fierce Attack 15 Years After Roe v. Wade Ruling
LEAD: Fifteen years after the United States Supreme Court ruled that women have a constitutional right to abortion, groups on both sides of the issue say that right is increasingly vulnerable to attack.


Two Agencies Work Together In Water Rescue
LEAD: A week after the New York City Police and Fire Departments erupted into a bitter dispute over their roles in a water rescue operation, the two departments worked together, with the Coast Guard, Sunday night to save a man who had thrown himself into the East River.


Pistons: All Eyes on Jordan
LEAD: There was a lot of film-watching yesterday in the Detroit Piston offices, and Michael Jordan was the center of attention.


Budd Taking Rest
LEAD: Zola Budd, the center of an international track controversy, said last night in London that she would follow medical advice and not participate in international competition ''for a substantial period'' while she recovers from nervous exhaustion.
Budd said in a statement to the British domestic news agency Press Association that she needs a ''substantial period of recuperation along with the support of my family and friends to regain my health.

Patterns
LEAD:  Charvet at Saks The house of Charvet, the grand old Parisian shirt maker, has reached an agreement with Saks Fifth Avenue to carry its line of men's shirts, ties and robes in New York and later in most Saks branches.
The deal has been especially quiet and has surprised the fashion industry, because for many years the house has had an exclusive arrangement with Bergdorf Goodman, which will continue to carry

Anticipating a Cabinet May Hurt a Candidate
LEAD:  To the Editor: I appreciate A. M. Rosenthal's suggestion (''One More Question,'' column, April 19) that Presidential candidates indicate what sort of people, or even name some specific people, they would want to head up important cabinet posts should they be elected.
For a voter this would be important information about the candidate and could conceivably affect his voting decision.

Robert A. Heinlein Is Dead at 80; Renowned Science-Fiction Writer
LEAD: Robert A. Heinlein, a former aviation engineer whose clever interweaving of imagination and technical expertise helped make him one of the country's most successful writers of science fiction, died Sunday morning at his home in Carmel, Calif.
He was 80 years old and had been in ill health for some time.


Education Secretary to Depart in Mid-September
LEAD: William J. Bennett, the Secretary of Education, a frequent critic of low standards in the nation's schools and colleges, announced today that he would leave the Cabinet in mid-September.


Sales Exceed $4 Billion at Top 100 Black-Owned Concerns
LEAD: Bolstered by the results of a large New York investment concern, sales of the nation's leading black-owned industrial and service businesses rose to a record $4.1 billion last year, according to an annual survey being released today by Black Enterprise magazine.


Gdansk Workers Reject Polish Offer to End Strike
LEAD: Striking shipyard workers rejected a management compromise offer today, delivering a severe setback to Government efforts to peacefully end the week-old strike at the Lenin shipyard here.


Lucky Stores Gives Data to American
LEAD: Lucky Stores Inc. said it had provided confidential information to American Stores Inc. in exchange for an agreement that American would sweeten or end its hostile takeover bid by May 17.


Chess
LEAD: Murray Chandler, now based in London, made a rare return to his native New Zealand and tied for first place with his fellow grandmasters, Boris Spassky of France and Eduard Gufeld of the Soviet Union, in the Plaza International Tournament in Wellington.
They each scored 7 1/2-2 1/2.

Corrosion on the Williamsburg Is Mainly on Approach Roads
LEAD: The corrosion on the Williamsburg Bridge, while serious enough to keep the bridge closed after four weeks of inspections and repairs, is concentrated in an area that many people may not consider part of the bridge at all: the approach roadways.


Guilty in Shooting of Officer
LEAD: A man was convicted in the Bronx yesterday of shooting a police officer in the leg.
A State Supreme Court jury found the defendant, Raymond Casiano, guilty of assaulting a police officer and criminal sale and criminal possession of a controlled substance.
He faces up to 32 years in prison.
Sentencing was scheduled for May 31.


For Geoffrey Beene, 25 Years at the Top
LEAD: Geoffrey Beene is the quiet one.
He speaks slowly, in the mellifluous tones of his native Louisiana.
Of medium height, with a shock of white hair, he fits nobody's image of the typical fashion designer.
He has a tendency to fleshiness, intensified by his love for good food.
He could be a professor at an obscure university or the doctor he once planned to be.


First Fidelity
LEAD: The First Fidelity Bancorp is offering $150 million of 9 3/4 percent subordinated notes due in 1995 at a price of 99.925 to yield 9.765 percent through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company.
Noncallable, the notes yield about 96-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.


Lilco Seeks Albany's Help In Effort to Block Takeover
LEAD: The chairman of the Long Island Lighting Company met limited success here today as he sought support for a negotiated settlement that would allow Lilco to remain a private, investor-owned utility in return for abandoning its $5.3 billion Shoreham nuclear power plant.

LEAD: A six-month suspension imposed on A. J. Foyt was lifted by Nascar yesterday, eight days after the penalty was leveled following a fender-banging incident in the Winston 500.
Les Richter, Nascar's vice president for competition, announced the decision following a review of an incident late in the race at Talladega, Ala.

Post-Traumatic Stress: Biological Clues Found
LEAD: Vietnam veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder were less sensitive to pain after seeing scenes from a war movie, according to a new study that gives a glimpse into the complex biology of the disorder.
The finding may also be a step toward new treatments, scientists said.


A.T.&amp;T. Displays Midsize Computer
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company introduced a new mid-range computer as well as some enhancements to its Starlan computer communications network.
A.T.&amp;T.'s new 3B2/700 mid-range computer could support up to 80 users at once and it could process up to nine million instructions a second, company officials said at a news conference.


Gasoline Evaporation Termed a Pollution Factor
LEAD: Evaporation of gasoline from fuel systems while cars are running may be making cities significantly smoggier than previously predicted, but new regulations could clear up the problem, according to several analysts.

LEAD: The United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, said today that an agreement to liberalize South Korea's cigarette market could result in several hundred million dollars in new sales for United States tobacco companies.

Grand Met Optician Deal
LEAD: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. of Britain said today that it was buying a chain of optician superstores in the United States for $32 million.
The 38 Eye and Tech superstores, in the Southwest and West, will be part of its Pearle Health Services unit, which is a retailer of eye-care products worldwide.
Grand Met, a diversified company whose interests include hotels and beverages, said the purchase would complement its acquisition earlier this month of Vision Express, which runs 27 superstores in the Middle West.

Kleinwort in U.S.
LEAD: Kleinwort Benson Ltd. said today that it had been negotiating with the Fuji Bank Ltd. for several months to sell a 24.9 percent stake in Kleinwort Benson Government Securities Inc., its Chicago-based primary dealership.

LEAD: Saudi Arabia is drafting a new charter for the Arabian American Oil Company, cutting its legal ties to the United States but seeking joint ventures with the four American oil companies that formerly owned the oil giant, an oil newsletter reported today.


Refinery Worker Identified
LEAD: Forensic specialists identified another body today from the Shell Oil Company refinery explosion, and emergency crews searched for a final missing person, company officials said.
The dead man was identified as Roland Satterlee, 35 year old, of LaPlace, said Sarah Colletti, a Shell spokeswoman.
Six Shell employees are known dead and 42 were injured when the gasoline-refining unit blew up here and caught fire before dawn Thursday.

Moderate Quake in Alaska
LEAD: A moderate earthquake struck parts of south-central Alaska early today, but there were no immediate reports of damage or injuries, the Alaska Tsunami Warning Center reported.

He was 88 years old.
Mr.
Calhoun, who was an Atlanta City Councilman from 1974 until 1978, devoted most of his political energies to grass-roots organization among black people.

LEAD: The massed ranks of North American experts have always beaten back foreign invaders at the Cavendish Invitational Charity Pairs, but did not do so this year.

Drug Addict Guilty in Fatal Stabbing of Nun
LEAD: A crack addict was convicted yesterday of fatally stabbing a nun when she refused to give him money for drugs, the Bronx District Attorney announced.


U.S. Planning to Send Food Money to the Contras
LEAD: Thwarted in its effort to deliver food and other aid to most of the Nicaraguan rebels, the Reagan Administration said today that it was planning to send cash to the contras inside Nicaragua.


Market Place; Soybean Supply Draws Attention
LEAD: SOYBEANS have long been termed the ''invisible commodity,'' which consumers hardly ever see but which they use every day.


Soy Ink for Newspaper
LEAD: The Champaign-Urbana News-Gazette will be printed with ink made from soybean oil, starting June 1, the newspaper announced today.
Its editor, John Foreman, said a ''commitment to the farm economy'' was a major reason for becoming the first Illinois newspaper to do so.


Chrysler Incentives
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation said it would extend its buyer incentive program with several revisions.
It includes about two dozen models and offers cash rebates ranging from $400 for the Plymouth Reliant and Dodge Aries to $1,500 for the Dodge Daytona Pacifica and the Chrysler Conquest.
Most vehicles carry rebates between the two extremes.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''There was a moment, a mood, when I felt we were broken.
But the mood is changing; people are coming back.
Wives are listening to the radio, and telling their husbands: 'You cannot leave them alone.
Go back, go back.' ''  Lech Walesa, addressing strikers in Gdansk.  [ A10:1. ]


Ford's New Hiring Is First Since 70's
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said it was hiring new hourly workers at several United States plants for the first time in a decade.
A spokesman, Tom Foote, said Ford had a ''smattering of new hires'' at plants in Plymouth, Wixom and Milan, Mich., and in St.
Paul.
He said the auto maker was running out of laid-off workers who have first rights to any jobs that become available.


Fetisov Gets a Go-Ahead
LEAD: Vyacheslav Fetisov, perhaps the world's best hockey defenseman, has reportedly received permission from the Soviet national hockey coach, Viktor Tikhonov, to play in the National Hockey League.

Owen Epstein, Lawyer, 36
LEAD: Owen Epstein, a partner in the Manhattan law firm of Meibach &amp; Epstein, died of a brain tumor Saturday at New York University Medical Center, said Martha Katz, a spokeswoman for the firm.
He was 36 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Review/Concert; Chamber Group and Cello
LEAD: Gerard Schwarz and the New York Chamber Symphony began Sunday afternoon's concert at the 92d Street Y by doing a service for a work most of us have underestimated, Aaron Copland's ''Dance Panels'' of 1959 (revised 1962).
One thing about Mr.
Copland's music: you can always recognize it.
The man has a true style and a true voice, and this ''abstract'' ballet score - produced at a time when interest in the composer was distinctly waning and largely neglected -speaks authentically.


Review/Cabaret; A Torch for Harold Arlen
LEAD: Jill Corey is a singer who stretches songs to their emotional breaking point but stops just short of turning heartbreak into histrionics.
Miss Corey, who opened a two-week engagement singing an all-Harold Arlen program at Danny's Skylight Lounge (346 West 46th Street) last Thursday, is nothing at all like the perky ingenue who arrived on the pop scene in the mid-1950's chirping trivial novelties like ''I Love My Baby (My Baby Loves Me).


Restroom Inequity: Evidence and Solution
LEAD: AS any woman who has tried to use restrooms in airports, movie houses and theaters knows all too well, men's and women's lavatories are not allocated according to need and use patterns.
Now, a Cornell engineering student has carefully documented this inequity and developed a computer program to help future designers prevent the lines outside women's rooms.


Olympic Notebook; Korean-American Worries About Site
LEAD: Insook Bhushan, America's best female table tennis player, is uncomfortable about competing in the Seoul Olympics this year.
But unlike other athletes, who have expressed concern about North Korea and terrorism, she is worried about South Korea and nationalism.

Confusion Reigns In Hockey Fiasco
LEAD: IN the confusion of a Stanley Cup playoff game where the National Hockey League's own president could not be reached and the fill-in linesmen were wearing yellow warm-up jerseys, SportsChannel worked hard Sunday night to bring sanity to the craziness.

Clemens Strikes Again
LEAD: Roger Clemens pitched a three-hitter tonight, striking out 16 and retiring 24 in a row at one point, as the Boston Red Sox beat Mark Gubicza and the Kansas City Royals, 2-0.


G.M. and Toyota Join in Australia
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation and the Toyota Motor Corporation have signed agreements to join forces in Australia.
The Australian divisions of the Japanese and United States giants will share several models to be sold under their brands - a move forced by the Government's decision to restructure the country's auto industry.


Tennis Notebook; European Swing A Break for Agassi
LEAD: From the Italian Open this week through the men's singles final at Wimbledon on July 3, the focus of tennis will be in Europe.
And that may be the best thing that could happen to Andre Agassi.
There will undoubtedly be many more Americans jumping on the 18-year-old's bandwagon after he followed his victory in the United States clay-court championships with one in the Eagle Tournament of Champions at Forest Hills on


Corrections
LEAD: Articles on Sunday and in some editions on Monday about a 1985 meeting between Vice President Bush and the Ambassador to Panama gave part of the Ambassador's name incorrectly.


Music Noted in Brief; Sounds of South Africa
LEAD: Malombo, a South African trio led by Philip Tabane on guitar, finds worlds of music within the simplest structures.
Most of the pieces Malombo played Friday night at Greenwich House would set a handful of chords and a melodic phrase or two over quasi-traditional rhythms from the Venda people of northern South Africa; Oupa Monareng played a set of standing drums and Raymond Phale added rattles, bells and other percussion.
