LEAD: Owners of the Chicago White Sox and representatives of the Illinois Sports Facilities Authority broke off negotiations yesterday without reaching agreement on a new stadium for the team.
Vincent Petrini, a spokesman for deputy Gov.
James Reilly, said the state had asked the White Sox owners, Jerry Reinsdorf and Eddie Einhorn, to put their negotiations with St.


Typing for Adults
LEAD: IF you've ever wondered why the names of so many computer products use nonstandard capitalization or punctuation, like WordStar, Compute! and dBASE, now we have an answer.
It's a conspiracy to improve our typing skills.


Phone Services To Tromson
LEAD: Tromson Monroe Advertising, a longtime specialist in travel advertising, has become the agency for Calaber Communications' Calaber Telecommunications Network.


Diamond-Star Output
LEAD: Diamond-Star Motors will begin production of its new sports coupe in the first week of September, two months ahead of schedule, officials said today.
Construction at the new $650 million Diamond-Star plant - a joint venture of the Chrysler Corporation and Mitsubishi Motors - was completed several months early, the company said.


Quake Looms Off Alaska
LEAD: Within 20 years a very large earthquake, rated magnitude 8.3 to 8.5 on the Richter scale of energy release, is likely to occur in a zone 125 to 150 miles long in the Shumagin Islands south of the Alaska Peninsula, according to scientists at Columbia University's Lamont-Doherty Geological Observatory.


Review/Music; San Francisco Virtuosi's French Flavor
LEAD: Merkin Concert Hall became a curious geographical crossroads on Sunday afternoon - two Soviet emigres from San Francisco joining a New Yorker in music of late 19th- and 20th-century France.
Those worrying whether Igor Shochetman (piano) and Leo Igudesman (violin) would bury French style under dour Soviet determination had only intermittent cause.


Rolls-Royce U.S. Sales
LEAD: Rolls-Royce P.L.C. said today that United States sales of its Rolls-Royce and Bentley luxury cars jumped 6.4 percent in the first four months of the year.
The British company's American subsidiary said it had sold 349 cars in the United States, up from 328 in the corresponding period a year ago.

U.S. Banks' Global Role
LEAD: Robert Heller, a Federal Reserve Board governor, is urging United States banks to reverse a trend of shrinking their activities in international markets.


China to Issue 100-Yuan Bills
LEAD: China will issue larger denomination bank notes, overcoming an eight-year fear of fueling inflation.


Maputo Journal: In Marx's Garden: Atheism Wilts, Faith Blooms
LEAD: At the corner of Vladimir Lenin and Mao Zedong Avenues, hundreds of Mozambican students swarmed noisily out of classes, happy to be out in the sunshine after an afternoon spent memorizing a universal doctrine.


Athletics Capture Their 14th Straight
LEAD: Jose Canseco hit his league-leading ninth home run and Bob Welch allowed four hits in eight-plus innings tonight as the Oakland Athletics beat the Detroit Tigers, 3-1, to extend their winning streak to 14 games, the longest in the major leagues in 11 years.

Edward van Westerborg, Publisher, 88
LEAD: Edward van Westerborg, the founding publisher of Facts on File, died Saturday at his home in Walnut Creek, Calif., after suffering from cancer.
He was 88 years old.


Careers; High Grades A Corporate Fetish, Still
LEAD: ''WE want only the best and the brightest.'' This has become a cliche whenever corporate personnel directors look for new graduates with a bachelor's or master's degree.


Warner in Deal to Acquire Lorimar
LEAD: After several months of on-again, off-again negotiations, Warner Communications Inc. yesterday agreed to acquire the Lorimar-Telepictures Corporation, the movie and television studio, in a stock transaction valued at $1.2 billion.

Sentence in Freeway Killing
LEAD: A motorist convicted of firing on a pickup truck in one of several highway shootings in the Los Angeles area last summer was sentenced Monday to serve up to life in prison for murder.
The man, Ronald Elam, 28 years old, was sentenced by Superior Court Judge Madge Watai in connection with the death of Debbie Ann Scott.


Impresario Is Back in Moscow, for Now
LEAD: One of the most prominent Soviet cultural figures forced into exile for challenging artistic orthodoxy has returned to Moscow this week to help stage a play at the theater he founded.


Old Novel Returns to Haunt a Current Musical
LEAD: It began as the case of the ''Phantom'' author and the phantom author; it has become a battle of words over the words ''inspired by'' and ''based on'' - over which ones are appropriate to describe the novelist Gaston Leroux's contribution to the Andrew Lloyd Webber musical version of Mr.
Leroux's ''Phantom of the Opera.


Irving Berlin, Still on the Charts
LEAD: ''Blue Skies'' was a show-stopper when Belle Baker first sang it in the musical ''Betsy'' in 1926.
Al Jolson kept it going in ''The Jazz Singer.'' In 1941, a Tommy Dorsey recording made it No. 1 on the Hit Parade.
Fritz Kreisler, the concert violinist, recorded it.
The comedienne Beatrice Lillie did, too.


Transactions
LEAD:  BASEBALL  BALTIMORE (AL) - Activated Don Aase, pitcher, from the 15-day disabled list.
Released Tito Landrum, outfielder.
SEATTLE (AL) - Called up Edgar Martinez, infielder, from Calgary of the Pacific Coast League.
Placed Mario Diaz, infielder, on the 15-day disabled list.
PHOENIX (PCL) - Announced the retirement of Ed Lynch, pitcher.


CRIMINAL INQUIRY IS SOUGHT ON DRUG
LEAD: A Congressman said today that he would ask the Justice Department to investigate whether a drug company delayed giving the Government information about a sedative linked to at least 36 deaths.

U S West Loses Case On Pricing
LEAD: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that U S West Inc., the Denver-based regional telephone company, had engaged in discriminatory pricing to win contracts to provide the Government with computerized switching service for the Federal phone system.


Police Evidence Counters Martin's Story; Yankees 17 White Sox 3
LEAD: At 8:36 P.M., in the third inning of the Yankees' 32d game, on the third pitch of his 125th time at bat, Don Mattingly hit a home run last night.
Finally.
Ordinarily, a Mattingly home run would be nothing unusual.
He had, after all, hit 123 home runs in his first five seasons, including 96 in the last three.

Chester Schwimmer, Ex-G.O.P. Leader, 75
LEAD: Chester Schwimmer, a former leader of the Queens Republican Party, died of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or Lou Gehrig's disease, today at Deepdale Hospital in Queens.
He was 75 years old and lived in Freeport, L.I.


Among Records, A Record Holder
LEAD: IT was a sweltering day in the Peruvian jungle last year when Ashrita Furman jumped into the Amazon River with his pogo stick and made history.
Unperturbed by reports of piranhas nearby, for 3 hours and 40 minutes he bounced from the river's clay bottom to its surface, eight feet above, setting a world record in aqua pogo.

Bhopal Issue Of Sabotage
LEAD: A report from a consulting firm hired by the Union Carbide Corporation said today that sabotage by a disgruntled employee, not negligence, had caused the deadly gas leak at a subsidiary's plant in Bhopal, India.


Ford's Probe Gets Fast Start
LEAD: The sporty 1989 Ford Probe, built for the Ford Motor Company by its Japanese partner, the Mazda Motor Company, will make its debut this week with enough advance orders to fill production schedules until October, Ford officials said today.


Sharpton Arrested in Queens on Warrant Stemming From Court Walkout Last Week
LEAD: The Rev.
Al Sharpton, a minister active in racial issues, was arrested in a Queens courthouse yesterday for having walked out of a Brooklyn courthouse last week during a hearing on charges stemming from a civil-disobedience demonstration.


The Taking of Car No. 4776: Homeless Men Find a Haven
LEAD: The Grand Street Shuttle pulled into the station at its last stop late yesterday morning, but none of the passengers in subway car No. 4776 got off.
Nine men lay sprawled on the seats on this particular five-minute trip from West Fourth Street, and nine went back, slumped and ragged, in postures of exhaustion or intoxication.


Latest Israeli Weapon: Bureaucracy
LEAD: Thousands of Palestinians grumbled and sweated, but most seemed resigned as they stood in long, slow-moving lines today to comply with the Israeli Army's order that they obtain new identity cards.


Elusive Liver-Disease Virus Is Isolated, Researchers Say
LEAD: Scientists at a California biotechnology company said today that they had isolated an elusive virus that causes liver disease in thousands of people who undergo blood transfusions each year.

Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''Imagine if you didn't see your family for years.
Imagine your love for them, for the streets, the house you grew up in, the place you were born in and grew up in.
That's exactly what I feel and it's always painful to talk about it.''  - Yuri Lyubimov, the exiled Soviet director, on returning to Moscow.


Budd Goes Back To South Africa
LEAD: Zola Budd, the South African-born runner who had jeopardized Britain's participation in the Seoul Olympics, returned to South Africa suddenly today, effectively ending her chances for participation in the 1988 Games and possibly ending her career.

ABOUT EDUCATION
LEAD: Speech is the basic skill overlooked by many who urge a return to the Three R's.
The ability to speak clearly and persuasively, and to think on one's feet, can be as vital to success as reading and writing.
Beginning with the job interview, speech classifies a person.

LEAD: DEEP, dark suntans are fading from fashionability because of the threat of skin cancer and the fear of wrinkles, according to a survey sponsored by a dermatologists' group.

LEAD: An article last Wednesday about the selection process for Vice Presidential nominees misstated a 1968 election result.
In that year Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine was the Democratic Vice Presidential candidate and the Democratic ticket indeed carried Maine.


Review/Dance; Ralph Lemon's Stories
LEAD: The idiotically entitled ''3-D'' series opened last night at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street) with a performance by the Ralph Lemon Dance Company that suggested this two-week series, featuring 11 other companies, may be a serious contender in the current dance fray.


FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
LEAD: The Public Service Electric and Gas Company, a unit of Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., is offering $200 million of first and refunding mortgage bonds with a four-year maturity through a group of underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company, which won the account in competitive bidding yesterday.


Landmarks May Get New Rules
LEAD: Sweeping changes in the way New York City designates landmarks will be proposed today by the Koch administration, which says that its new system would increase protection of potential landmarks and give owners a more certain idea of their properties' status.


Mitterrand Selects Moderate Socialist as Prime Minister of France
LEAD: President Francois Mitterrand today designated Michel Rocard, a moderate Socialist, as France's next Prime Minister, giving him the difficult mission of forming the first minority Government in the 30 years of the Fifth Republic.

After Acclaim, The Controversy
LEAD: Zola Budd burst into international prominence in 1982 more as a curiosity than a prominent runner.
Here was this wisp of a teen-ager, barely 5 feet 4 inches and 95 pounds, who ran barefoot.


NATO Foes Lead in Cloudy Danish Vote
LEAD: An election that focused on Denmark's full participation in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization failed to produce a definitive answer today, but Prime Minister Poul Schluter asserted that the anti-NATO forces had been weakened.


Prosecutors Allowed to Fight Ruling on Jurors in Davis Trial
LEAD: The trial of Larry Davis was adjourned yesterday until Monday to allow the prosecution to appeal a judge's decision on jury selection.


Economic Scene; Soviet Reforms: A Need for Time
LEAD: HAS Mikhail Gorbachev fallen victim to his own brand of voodoo economics?
Few Western analysts ever believed Mr.
Gorbachev could meet his self-imposed goals for perestroika, restructuring a failing economic system, without even a temporary reduction in living standards.
And the latest evidence bears out their skepticism.

Richard B. Ogilvie Is Dead at 65; Illinois Governor From '68 to '72
LEAD: Richard B. Ogilvie, who served as Governor of Illinois from 1968 to 1972, died yesterday a day after suffering a heart attack and undergoing emergency bypass surgery at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago.
He was 65 years old.


Soybeans Advance Again On Specter of Dry Summer
LEAD: Prices of soybean futures bounded higher for the fourth straight session yesterday, and analysts said an Agriculture Department forecast of a steep drop in the nation's stockpile would keep the rally from faltering.


5 Wall St. Firms Move to Restrict Program Trades
LEAD: In a move intended to restore investor confidence in the stock market, five large Wall Street firms announced yesterday that they had suspended computerized program trading for their own accounts.

Mexican Inflation Slows
LEAD: Prices in Mexico rose 3.1 percent in April, which was less than the 5.1 percent increase in March, the Banco de Mexico reported today.
Inflation in the 12 months ended April 30 was 161.3 percent, the central bank added.


Wine Talk
LEAD: THE Bordeaux wine trade, faced with a backlog of wine and mounting price resistance from American consumers and importers, is dropping prices for the 1987 vintage an average of 30 percent below 1986 vintage levels.

Lessons
LEAD: There is no defending the Greek way, as college fraternity and sorority life might be called.
It is self-selecting and therefore discriminatory; it is exclusionary and therefore anti-democratic.
Those qualities of faculty and administrative life aside, colleges are supposed to be islands of virtue.

Topics of The Times; A Check on the Beer Slobs
LEAD: Disappointed by team owners' diffident response to rowdiness at ballparks, the New York Legislature is moving sensibly to curb stadium drinking.
A bill sponsored by Senator John Dunne and Assemblyman Richard Brodsky and approved by the Senate would set aside 6 percent of the seats in all sections as alcohol-free.

Corrections
LEAD: A listing in Business Day on May 2, with a brief article about the week's major debt financings, incorrectly described a $64 million tax-exempt offering in Tennessee.
The financing was by the Nashville and Davidson Counties Metropolitan Government.


'Colonus' to Close
LEAD: ''The Gospel at Colonus,'' a musical by Lee Breuer based on Robert Fitzgerald's version of Sophocles' ''Oedipus at Colonus,'' will close after the matinee on Sunday at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater.
The show, directed by Mr.
Breuer, with music by Bob Telson, will have run for 15 previews and 61 regular performances.


U.S. Says Laos Government Is Deeply Involved in Drugs
LEAD: Federal officials in New York expressed concern yesterday about mounting evidence that the Government of Laos was heavily involved in the production and export of heroin, including highly pure Southeast Asian heroin that has been flooding the New York market for two years.

Dow Chemical Sets Venture With BOC
LEAD: The Dow Chemical Company said it would form an equal joint venture with BOC Group P.L.C. of Britain to separate oxygen and nitrogen from air and supply the gases to industrial users around the world.
A spokeswoman for the company, based in Midland, Mich., said it would contribute its membrane filter technology to the venture, while BOC would offer both technology and its marketing network for industrial gases.

Campeau Reportedly Seeks Cutbacks at Bloomingdale's
LEAD: Urging all Federated Department Stores divisions to streamline their operations, Robert Campeau has ordered Bloomingdale's to reduce its annual operating costs by $60 million through various economies, including staff cutbacks, executives in the retailing industry said yesterday.


BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  MARKETS  Five large Wall Street firms suspended program trading for their own accounts, in a move intended to restore investor confidence in the stock market.
The firms involved are Morgan Stanley; Salomon; Bear, Stearns; Paine Webber, and Kidder, Peabody.
Index-arbitrage trading has come under intense criticism as a leading cause of volatility in stock prices.


Bell &amp; Howell Debentures Are Priced to Yield 12 7/8%
LEAD: The Bell &amp; Howell Group is offering $225 million of 8 1/4 percent senior subordinated debentures, due in 1998, at a price of 88.80 to yield 12 7/8 percent, through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert.
Originally the size of the debt issue was planned at $205 million, but it was increased because of good investor demand.

Two Views on a Schism in the Middle East
LEAD: The drama of Israeli-Arab relations is played out every day on American television.
Bits and pieces emerge in sound and color. ''Worldview,'' on the CUNY cable channel today and tonight at 11 A.M., 4 P.M. and 9 P.M., tries to make the bits and pieces fall in place.

LEAD: The failure of two Northwest Airlines pilots to follow required checklist procedures before takeoff led to the crash last August at Detroit Metropolitan Airport that killed 156 of the 157 people aboard, a Federal report concluded today.

'Mail' to Close Saturday
LEAD: ''Mail,'' a musical with book and lyrics by Jerry Colker and music by Michael Rupert, will close after the evening performance on Saturday at the Music Box Theater, 239 West 45th Street.
The play, directed by Andrew Cadiff, will have run for 20 previews and 36 performances.


Nebraska and W. Virginia Pick Dukakis in Landslides
LEAD: Michael S. Dukakis won sweeping victories over the Rev.
Jesse Jackson in Democratic Presidential primaries in West Virginia and Nebraska yesterday.


TV Campaign to Begin For California Magazine
LEAD: California magazine, based in Los Angeles, is about to break its first television campaign and its first advertising will come from Hal Riney &amp; Partners.


Greek Violinist Wins Competition at Carnegie
LEAD: Leonidas Kavakos, a 20-year-old resident of Greece, has been named winner of the Naumburg International Violin Competition.
The finals took place Monday at Carnegie Hall.

LEAD: To the Editor:


City College Lacrosse Shock
LEAD: Hector Munoz squinted through the dust, searching for a yellow flag resting among the many rocks on the City College lacrosse field.
It had been nine years and 92 games since City had won a lacrosse match, and Munoz, the team's coach, just wanted to make sure he didn't celebrate prematurely.


Bedeviling an Arms Pact: The Details
LEAD: By any objective standard, the treaty on medium- and shorter-range nuclear missiles is one that should have made its way easily from the negotiating table to ratification.
The accord enjoys overwhelming official and public support in the United States, the Soviet Union and in Europe.
And in the grand scheme of superpower relations, arms control experts on both sides regard its primary significance as political rather than military.


Review/Performance Art; Beckley Runs in Place
LEAD: The Winter Garden is a vast new indoor public space that is part of the still uncompleted World Financial Center at Battery Park City.
Since March, the center's arts and events program has been sponsoring a series of free lunchtime and early evening performance events of various sorts there.
Yesterday at noon the composer, painter and performance artist Connie Beckley presented a piece that will be repeated this evening at 6 o'clock.


Romulus Journal; From Air Disaster, a Roadside Shrine
LEAD: There is a wooden cross on the hillside, covered now with spring dandelions, and a small circle of tattered floral arrangments: drooping plastic floral sprays, a pot with an Easter lily, a handful of red carnations tossed loosely in the grass.


VLSI and Hitachi In Technology Deal
LEAD: VLSI Technology Inc., the San Jose, Calif., semiconductor company, has formed a long-term technology exchange agreement with Hitachi Ltd. of Tokyo.
According to the agreement, VLSI will provide Hitachi with application-specific integrated circuit, or ASIC, technology, while Hitachi will make its process and manufacturing technology available.


Suns Pick Fitzsimmons
LEAD: The Phoenix Suns named Cotton Fitzsimmons yesterday to replace John Wetzel as coach.
Paul Westphal, 37 years old, a former All-Star guard for the Suns, was hired as Fitzsimmons's assistant until he is ready to take over the coaching reins.

Mike Shula Retires
LEAD: Like his father and his older brother, Mike Shula has announced his retirement as a professional football player at a young age in order to get started as a coach in the National Football League.
The 22-year-old reserve quarterback for the Tampa Bay Buccaneers said Monday he would make the switch to assistant coach, as an offensive aide to Ray Perkins, the Buccaneers' coach, who was also Shula's boss when he was a quarterback at Alabama.

LEAD: Tests on five employees involved in the fatal crash of a commuter train in Mount Vernon last month - the engineer, three tower operators and the dispatcher in Manhattan - showed traces of drugs after the accident, the Federal Railroad Administration said today.

A Degas Sets Price Record: $10.2 Million
LEAD: Edgar Degas's ''Little Dancer at 14 Years of Age,'' a bronze of the artist's 1881 wax sculpture of a bold young dancer in a relaxed pose, was sold last night for $10.12 million, a record at auction for the artist and for any sculpture.
The buyer, was identified only as a Euorpean.

U.S. Vetoes U.N. Resolution To Condemn the Israeli Raid
LEAD: The United States vetoed a Security Council resolution today that would have condemned what it called the ''invasion by Israeli forces of southern Lebanon'' for two days last week.
It also would have called for the ''immediate withdrawal of Israeli forces'' from southern Lebanon.

LEAD: A Federal licensing board today upheld a Lilco plan to use three centers as evacuation sites in case of an accident at the Shoreham nuclear plant.


Police Evidence Counters Martin's Story; He Is Blamed For Altercation
LEAD: The Arlington Police Department has concluded that Billy Martin's claim that he was assaulted in the restroom of a topless bar early Saturday morning was unfounded.
The police said that Martin, the Yankee manager, threw the one and only punch in the incident and that he was injured when he was thrown out of the bar.

Review/Television; Goetz Trial as Drama
LEAD: Bernhard Goetz again.
The very thought is likely to induce groaning.
For more than two years, the Goetz case preoccupied the public.
From editorial pages across the nation to chic Manhattan cocktail parties, it became an almost obsessive center of attention.
The trial ended last June with Mr.
Goetz being acquitted of the more serious charges in connection with his shooting of four teen-agers he said had menaced him on a subway car in Manhattan.

Somalia Loans Barred
LEAD: Somalia was added today to the list of countries that may no longer borrow from the International Monetary Fund because of overdue payments on previous loans.
The East African republic owes the fund about $37 million.
Other countries on the list are Vietnam, Liberia, Peru, Sierra Leone, Guyana, the Sudan and Zambia.

Colgate Will Get A Part of Cotelle
LEAD: Henkel KGaA and the Colgate-Palmolive Company will split up the French company Cotelle S.A. between them after a proposed joint venture failed.
Henkel's board chairman, Helmut Sihler, told reporters that the French authorities would not allow each company to own half of Cotelle since they already had a joint share of almost 80 percent of the French household detergents market.

About New York; On Each Lapel, A Small Badge Of Distinction
LEAD: The badge of the conventioneer in midtown Manhattan is the name tag, and most of them tend to bore.
Either they run along the strictly business lines of, say, ''Maurice Tiddlewhipple, Boise Cascade,'' or they take the casual, howdy approach, as in, ''Hello, I'm Sharon, Bayou La Batre.'' Given the dreariness of the usual identifications, then, it was arresting earlier this week to run across people festooned with chest labels that marked their achievements, such as ''bass fisherman'' or ''grower of largest squash'' or ''bubble gum blower.


Japanese Official Fires New Furor on the War
LEAD: A Cabinet minister who caused a stir with recent comments about Japan's wartime role embroiled himself in fresh controversy today by saying that the Japanese invasion of China five decades ago was not a war of aggression.


The Pain of Change
LEAD: The strains of attempting limited reform in Communist countries these days provoke reflections on old political and even deeper human issues.
Change is necessary and inevitable, but it always brings pain.
Violent revolutions make subsequent change even harder, not only because they concentrate power beyond civil challenge, but also because they instill such an attachment to order, stability and predictability, and such a fear of risk.


Alaska Oilfield Report Cites Unexpected Harm to Wildlife
LEAD: An unreleased preliminary report by officials of the Fish and Wildlife Service says oil development in northern Alaska has caused far more environmental damage than the Government predicted.


Loan Given to Rebuild a Harlem Hospital
LEAD: Governor Cuomo yesterday announced a $150 million loan to rebuild the financially beleaguered North General Hospital in Harlem, the only minority-owned hospital in the state.

Corrections
LEAD: A correction in this space on April 26 about the Eating Well column in The Living Section of April 20 misstated the amount of fat in three and a half ounces of beef sirloin.
It is nine grams.

LEAD: The Government signed a peace accord today with an ethnic Sinhalese group that has conducted a guerrilla campaign in which at least 260 people have died, officials announced.

LEAD: A United States marshall padlocking a sporting goods store in Queens after it was seized in a drug raid.
Officials announced the arrest of a man they described as the leader of a multimillion-dollar heroin and cocaine operation.
The suspect Thomas (Tony Montana) Mickens, 24 years old, was arrested at his home in Dix Hills, L.I.

Hugh Laing, Specialist in Ballets By Antony Tudor, Is Dead at 77
LEAD: Hugh Laing, one of the finest dramatic dancers of 20th-century ballet and a former star of both American Ballet Theater and the New York City Ballet, died yesterday at St.
Luke's Hospital.

Laing had been suffering from cancer.

And just as the small towns have shops that serve up personal service along with freshly baked breads, produce, fish and meats, so every

Dismissal Is Upheld In New Yorker Lawsuit
LEAD: A Federal appeals court has upheld the dismissal of a libel suit against The New Yorker magazine brought by a man who said he was unfairly portrayed in an article about another libel case.


NASA Is Urged to Develop Space Platforms
LEAD: The National Academy of Sciences recommended yesterday that the nation develop small unmanned space platforms ''as soon as possible'' as a bridge to a larger and more elaborate space outpost planned for the 1990's.


Making Computers Compatible
LEAD: The barriers that separate different brands of desktop computers, like the Macintosh and I.B.M.
PC, are being torn down by a new type of software that permits one computer to emulate the functions of another.


SPREAD IN ABUSES IS SEEN IN PANAMA
LEAD: The military regime of Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega is using sexual humiliation, threats, imprisonment, beatings and punitive fines to intimidate its opponents, according to human rights investigators, diplomats and opposition leaders.


Car Imports Up in Japan
LEAD: Sales of foreign cars in Japan rose 40.1 percent in April from a year earlier, to 10,675, marking the 52d successive monthly year-to-year gain and a record high for the month, an official of the Japan Automobile Importers Association said today.


HOUSE VOTE BACKS A PLASTIC-GUN BAN
LEAD: The House today passed, 413 to 4, a bill that would ban the manufacture, sale or possession of any plastic firearm that could evade detection by X-ray machines or metal detectors.

LEAD: ''THE paprika sauce,'' said the luncheon guest, dropping his voice and glancing around, ''is of a thin consistency.'' His companion nodded sympathetically. ''The rabbit is not very exciting,'' he whispered back.

60-Minute Gourmet
LEAD: THE versatile leek is one of the oldest known cultivated vegetables.
There is much dispute about its origin, but it is known that leeks were grown by the ancient Egyptians, and evidently were much revered.
The food historian Waverly Root recounted that an Egyptian of the time wrote, perhaps jocularly, that ''onions are adored and leeks are gods.


Cargoes Adore a Vacuum
LEAD: One of the best insulators against heat flow is a vacuum.
The familiar thermos uses the principle: A vacuum is created between two walls of glass.
This greatly reduces heat flow into or out of the bottle, keeping soup hot and apple juice cold.


Jackson Is Top Rookie
LEAD: In the 35 years it has been given out, the National Basketball Association rookie-of-the-year award almost always went to a player who was a high first-round draft choice, and, in recent years, usually one with a rich long-term contract.


Mondale Gives Warning on Picking Running Mate
LEAD: Walter F. Mondale says the interviews he held four years ago with prospective running mates proved a ''damaged strategy'' and adds that Michael S. Dukakis ought to find a different way of selecting the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee this year.


House Approves Bill On Copyright Treaty
LEAD: The House of Representatives passed legislation today to permit the United States to join the Bern Convention for the Protection of Literary and Artistic Works, an international copyright treaty to which 76 other nations subscribe.

LEAD: After largely ceding the black vote to the Rev.

LEAD: Senator Moynihan, whose public duties include trying to save the country from coming to a complete standstill, says that by the year 2020 Interstate 95 will have to be 44 lanes wide to carry the traffic between Fort Lauderdale and Miami.

LEAD: Affiliated Publications Inc., the owner of The Boston Globe and Billboard Publications, yesterday reported a first-quarter net loss of $14.4 million, largely because of losses from the company's investment in the McCaw Communications Companies.


Misery Rises in Philippines' Swollen Slums
LEAD: Two weeks ago someone apparently knocked over a kerosene lamp and, in what seemed a nightmare out of the last century, more than 1,000 flimsy homes were burned to the ground within five hours.


Kodak-Immunex Pacts
LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company and the Immunex Corporation said today that they had expanded the activities of their partnership, which was formed in 1986 for drug research activities.
The new agreements cover an advanced drug development process and the division of marketing rights.
Also, Kodak will invest an additional $20 million in Immunex and Immunex will buy out Kodak's share of the joint venture's manufacturing plant.


Topics of The Times; Impaired Vision at CBS
LEAD: Three of every four players in the National Basketball Association are black, including most of its biggest stars.
And unlike big league football and baseball, the N.B.A. even has several black head coaches.
But when CBS, which broadcasts N.B.A. games, convened all its basketball commentators on camera recently to discuss the playoffs, there wasn't a black face in sight.


Laurence Sickman, Scholar and Expert In the Art of China
LEAD: Laurence Sickman, a connoisseur and scholar of Chinese art who built one of the world's best collections of Chinese paintings, sculpture and furniture at the William Rockhill Nelson Gallery and Atkins Museum of Fine Arts in Kansas City, Mo., died Saturday at St.
Luke's Hospital in Kansas City.
He was 81 years old.

Washington Talk: Congress; Judicial Impeachment: Is Process Antiquated?
LEAD: The power of impeachment, the procedure devised for placing public officials suspected of wrongdoing on trial by elected lawmakers, was given to Congress by the framers of the Constitution 200 years ago.
But now, as two Federal judges face possible impeachment, a debate is under way on Capitol Hill over whether the procedures make sense today.

Metropolitan Diary
LEAD: KATE COLBORN of Brooklyn is waiting for the traffic light to change at the corner of Third and Atlantic Avenues.
Alongside her is a small, frail elderly woman.
The woman is clutching a cane and, it is apparent, is quite concerned about crossing against the aggressively turning traffic.
Ms.
Colborn smiles in understanding, takes the woman's arm and escorts her - slowly, gently - across the intersection.


U.S. Subpoena In Hughes Case
LEAD: Albert D. Wheelon, who resigned last week as chairman and chief executive of the Hughes Aircraft Corporation, has been named in a subpoena related to a Justice Department investigation of the Los Angeles-based military equipment contractor, a person familiar with the inquiry said today.


Wheat Estimate Up 4%
LEAD: The Agriculture Department said today that 1988 winter wheat production is estimated at 1.62 billion bushels, up 4 percent from last year's harvest of 1.56 billion bushels.
Officials said the average yield, based on indications as of May 1, was estimated at 40.7 bushels an acre, compared with last year's 39.8 bushels.

And there is something else unusual about ''A Death in the Family,'' being shown this evening at 9 on Channel 13.

Sports People; White Sox Progress
LEAD: Chicago White Sox owners have agreed not to move their team if Illinois lawmakers approve a revised lease on a new stadium, saving the team up to $60 million over 10 years, Gov.
James R. Thompson said yesterday. ''They have given us their word that if we pass this bill, they'll stay,'' Thompson said at a news conference.


Sports People; A Dash of Spice
LEAD: The sprinting jrivals Ben Johnson of Canada and Carl Lewis of the United States will compete head to head in the 100-meter dash at a French meet on June 27, their first showdown since Johnson's world-record performance last September during the world championships in Rome.


Autopsy Reveals Crushed Neck
LEAD: An autopsy on the body of a Brooklyn man with epilepsy and heart trouble who died in police custody this week revealed a severe neck injury, according to preliminary findings announced yesterday by the New York City Medical Examiner's office.


Daniel Peterkin Jr., 82, Ex-President of Morton
LEAD: Daniel Peterkin Jr., former chairman of Morton-Norwich Products Inc., now Morton Thiokol Inc., died from complications of heart disease Monday at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago.
He was 82 years old and lived in Chicago.


Swiss Urged to Lift Barriers
LEAD: The British Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe, said today that the Swiss Government must be prepared to allow British companies to make takeover bids in Switzerland without legal restrictions if Swiss companies expect to be able to buy British concerns.


That's the Way a 'Berliner' Crumbles
LEAD: To the Editor:


RJR Picks Chairman At New Del Monte Unit
LEAD: RJR Nabisco Inc. announced yesterday that it was creating Del Monte Foods to stand as a separate major business, alongside its tobacco and Nabisco Brands operations.
It named Robert J. Carbonell chairman and chief executive of the new unit.

Air Crash Laid to Fuel Leak
LEAD: A fuel leak has been found in the engine of a Horizon Air commuter aircraft that caught fire and crash-landed last month at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, injuring 19 people, investigators said.
The leak occurred because a ring was out of place in a fuel filter assembly, and the filter was not seated properly, Ted Lopatkiewicz of the National Transportation Safety Board said.

LEAD: President Reagan ended one of Washington's longest-running and least suspenseful political dramas tonight when he endorsed Vice President Bush as his successor.

China Said to Seek Bond Credit Rating
LEAD: China has hired the Morgan Stanley Group to help it obtain a credit rating for possible bond issues in the United States, Chinese sources said today.
They gave no timetable but called this the ''first step in a long process.''

Humana to Buy Maxicare H.M.O.'s
LEAD: As part of a previously planned $120 million restructuring, Maxicare Health Plans Inc. agreed to sell its health maintenance organizations in Kentucky and San Antonio, representing 143,000 members, to Humana Inc. for undisclosed terms.


Review/Television; 'Koppel Report' on TV Evangelists
LEAD: ''The Koppel Report'' separates itself from ''Nightline'' by giving us more of Ted Koppel.
The program tonight, the first in a quarterly series, begins and ends with him in the pew of small country church; the rest of the time he's in an auditorium with 7 evangelists, 4,000 Christians and a large choir.

Furniture of Original Design and Aboriginal Flavor
LEAD: MATTIA BONETTI and Elizabeth Garouste, a Paris-based design team, believe in contradictions.
In their new collection of tables, chairs and lamps, which is being shown at Furniture of the Twentieth Century beginning Saturday, they combine primitive imagery with sophisticated design; rough-hewn materials like wrought iron or cast bronze with lacquered wood or sandblasted glass.


Mets Score 3 in 9th, Beat Astros in 10th
LEAD: Terry Leach saw the ball that Tim Teufel hit in the ninth inning clear the wall and bang solidly off the concrete above it.
His view from the bullpen was clear, his angle good, his opinion unshakable. ''It was a home run,'' Leach said.

Parks Book Aids the Disabled
LEAD: ''ACCESS AMERICA,'' the most ambitious project to date of Northern Cartographic, a small Vermont publishing house, is a much-needed reference work that describes in text and full-color photographs, charts and maps the facilities and programs for the disabled at 37 national parks.


Prime Computer To Cut 700 Jobs
LEAD: Prime Computer Inc. said it plans to lay off about 700 employees, about 5 percent of its work force, as part of the first phase of its integration of the Computervision Corporation, a computer work station maker that Prime acquired in February.


N.H.L. Playoffs; Oilers Gain Final
LEAD: Craig Simpson and Mike Krushelnyski each had two goals and an assist tonight as the Edmonton Oilers beat the Detroit Red Wings, 8-4, and advanced to the Stanley Cup finals.

Sports People; Keenan Dismissed
LEAD: Mike Keenan of the Philadelphia Flyers, who had the best winning percentage (.638) among active National Hockey League coaches and one year remaining on a three-year contract, was dismissed yesterday.
Keenan and Bob Clarke, the general manager, were unable to resolve contract differences.
Keenan, the coach of the Flyers for four seasons, demanded a contract clause that would let him leave for a general manager's job elsewhere in the league, if one were offered.


Yields Post Broad Rise
LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds rose in the week ended yesterday, but the momentum may well increase significantly after yesterday's rise in the prime rate.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Agency Sells One-on-One Marketing
LEAD: RAPP &amp; COLLINS, one of the better direct-marketing agencies, has won eight accounts in the last 12 months.
Six came in as the result of the book ''Maximarketing,'' written by Stan Rapp and Tom Collins and published by McGraw-Hill in November 1986.

Arms Control for City Schools
LEAD: In too many New York City schools, guns and knives are as common as notebooks.
School Chancellor Richard Green deserves support for his efforts to turn the deadly tide.


Stores Suffer Without the Williamsburg
LEAD: Since the 85-year-old Williamsburg Bridge was closed to vehicles nearly a month ago, merchants on both sides of it have coped with the sudden disappearance of their customers by cleaning, pacing and looking for any conceivable sign that the bridge will reopen.


Record U.S. Fish Catch
LEAD: United States fishermen had a record catch of 6.9 billion pounds of fish and shellfish last year, breaking the previous record of 6.5 billion pounds set in 1980, the Government said on Tuesday.
The 1987 catch, valued at $3.1 billion, was 865 million pounds higher than the 1986 total, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said.

The Needless Tragedies of Accutane
LEAD: Accutane is a valuable drug with a horrifying side effect.
It's a unique cure for the severest form of acne, but when taken by pregnant women it often causes deformities in the fetus.
Use of the drug has been badly mismanaged by its maker, Hoffmann-La Roche, by the Food and Drug Administration and by the doctors who carelessly prescribed it.

BRIEFS
LEAD: *
British Airways P.L.C., London, said it wants to fly the supersonic Concorde to Atlanta as part of its regularly scheduled service.
The tentative plan calls for three Concorde flights a week from London to Washington to Atlanta.


Trump Sale Of Resorts Collapses
LEAD: Donald J. Trump's deal to sell his controlling interest in Resorts International Inc. to Merv Griffin collapsed today, and the men immediately resumed their feud over the Atlantic City hotel-casino company.


Carnegie Hall Marks a Milestone for a Cornerstone
LEAD: In the course of building its future, Carnegie Hall has been digging up its past.
Tomorrow at 4 P.M. both strands of history will be joined in a special ceremony on West 57th Street.

LEAD: The messages in dispute were secretly exchanged 17 years ago between Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's national security adviser, and Kenneth Rush, the United States Ambassador to West Germany.

Study Suggests One Saturated Fat May Deserve Clean Bill of Health
LEAD: A new study has shown that stearic acid, one of the main saturated fats in beef and chocolate, may actually lower cholesterol levels in the blood and thus moderate the cholesterol-raising effect of other saturated fats in these foods.


Market Place; Some Confusion For Regulators
LEAD: A PROPOSAL by the Philadelphia Stock Exchange for a new trading instrument is fueling a controversy over which regulators are responsible for the oversight of products that have qualities of both a security and a futures contract.


Estimate of New Homes
LEAD: An organization representing the nation's home builders said Tuesday that it expected 1.5 million new homes to be started this year, down from 1987, but still what the group's leader described as a ''reasonably good'' showing.
Dale Stuard, president of the National Association of Home Builders, said single-family homes would account for 1.1 million starts in 1988, with multifamily homes accounting for about 400,000 starts.


N.B.A. Playoffs; Bird Leads Celtics by Hawks
LEAD: Larry Bird set a team playoff record with 24 points in the first quarter and the Boston Celtics held off a late rally by the Atlanta Hawks for a 110-101 victory in the opener of their National Basketball Association second-round playoff series tonight.

TV Notes
LEAD:  A Lip Theory of Identity ''Most of the things start in the lips.'' Daws Butler was telling how he slips into the voice of Jimmy Stewart or Charles Laughton - not to say Huckleberry Hound, whose 30th year will be celebrated with a cartoon movie on May 21 from 1 to 3 P.M., on Channel 5.


Pork Prices Sharply Higher As Drop in Supplies Is Seen
LEAD: Prices of pork futures rose sharply yesterday on a combination of technical factors and indications that a seasonal downturn in hog supplies had begun, analysts said.

LEAD: Jim Schoenfeld, the Devils' coach, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena yesterday.
He said he regretted the incident that caused his suspension and that ''the light should be shining on the players.'' Page B11. (NYT/George McNish)


Chess Set With an Edge
LEAD: THOUGH chess sets are customarily made of such weighty materials as ebony, ivory or wood, Peter Hewitt has departed from this convention by designing a chess set of paper.
The design was perhaps, for him, inevitable.

New Index Future Allowed
LEAD: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission today approved a new stock index futures contract for the first time since the October stock market crash.


Buck Clayton Big Band
LEAD: The jazz trumpeter Buck Clayton, a Count Basie alumnus, is to appear with his big band on May 12 at 8 P.M. at the Loeb Student Center of New York University, 566 La Guardia Place.
The concert is the last of the Highlights in Jazz series at the university.
Also appearing are to be Marty Napoleon, pianist; Harold Alden, guitarist; Spanky Davis, Randy Sandke and Paul Cohen, trumpeters, and Loren Schoenberg, a tenor.


Lottery Games Shut Down In Connecticut
LEAD: On Sunday, with ''horns, bells and whistles,'' according to its director, the Connecticut State Lottery went on line with its new computer system.
Yesterday, with the alarm sounded by two ticket sellers who knew they weren't entitled to $16,500 they had won, the entire system was shut down for most of the day.


Thrift Unit Notes Issued in Michigan
LEAD: First Federal of Michigan is offering $100 million of floating-rate notes due in 1993 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.
The notes' initial interest rate, or coupon, is 7.26 percent.
The underwriters said the notes would be offered to the public at various prices.

LEAD: IT'S interesting to note the way medical miracles can go from brave new world to simple acceptance almost overnight.

Gabriel Kirschenbaum, Army Colonel, 87
LEAD: Dr.
Gabriel Kirschenbaum, a retired Army colonel, died Tuesday of congestive heart failure resulting from leukemia at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan.
He was 87 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

Review/Music; Faure Requiem Restyled For Chamber Orchestra
LEAD: According to John Rutter, the Faure Requiem with which modern audiences are most familiar may not in fact have been written by Faure.
Mr.
Rutter, a composer and choir conductor from Britain, brought to Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday evening his own reconstruction of the score, one that called for a chamber ensemble rather than full orchestra and that most faithfully conforms, he says, to the composer's intentions.


Van Gogh's 'Adeline Ravoux' Is Sold
LEAD: Van Gogh's glowing blue 1890 portrait of Adeline Ravoux was sold last night at Christie's for $13.8 million -more than six times the price paid for it in 1980.
Neither the buyer nor the seller were identified.

Two Forks Journal; Coloradans Anxiously Await Decision Over a Proposed Dam
LEAD: While the construction of Two Forks Dam on the South Platte River 25 miles southwest of here has been on the drawing board for decades, Coloradans have spent the last few weeks debating whether Denver and its suburbs need the 550-foot-high dam, now or ever.


Korea Shipyard Decline
LEAD: South Korea's shipbuilding orders have dropped by 41.3 percent this year, compared with the 1987 period, because of the national currency's appreciation in foreign exchange, officials said today.
The value of the South Korean won has risen 7.43 percent against the United States dollar since the beginning of the year.


3 More Killed as Standoff Persists at Sikh Temple
LEAD: Three more people were reported killed today in the third straight day of armed confrontation between Indian security forces and Sikh militants based in the Golden Temple at Amritsar, Sikhdom's holiest shrine.


A Bit of Hancock's History May Have Been Found
LEAD: Archeologists say they may have found traces of John Hancock's Beacon Hill estate amid piles of dirt dug up on the State House lawn during a renovation project.


A Broadside in Favor Of Aid for the Young
LEAD: The Reagan years have been hard on disadvantaged youths, in the opinion of liberal critics.
High budget deficits have resulted in the underfinancing of existing social programs, they say, and discouraged new efforts.
Especially harmful to those with nowhere else to turn, the critics contend, is the Reagan philosophy that government is largely part of the problem of poverty instead of the solution to it.


A New Antiques Fair With an Intimate Touch
LEAD: SOME antiques dealers believe that less is more.
As an antidote to large antiques fairs that feature hundreds of dealers, the owners of five antiques shops - Briger Fairholme, Doris Leslie Blau, J. Mavec &amp; Company, Stockspring Antiques and Ursus Prints -have organized the tiny May Antiques Fair.
It opens today and displays their wares in an intimate setting.


Results Plus
LEAD:  Tennis  No Easy Victories: Ivan Lendl, Mats Wilander and Andre Agassi were extended to three sets before posting second-round victories yesterday in the Italian Open in Rome.
Lendl, the top-seeded player, overcame Milan Srejber of Czechoslovakia, 6-1, 5-7, 6-1, on the slow red clay of the Foro Italico.

British Coal Industry
LEAD: The British Government said today that it would like to sell the state-owned coal industry to private investors, but not for several years.
Energy Minister Michael Spicer said at a seminar that there were no plans to sell off state-owned British Coal before the next general election, due by 1992, but his speech marked the first time the minister had publicly said the Government planned to sell the coal industry.


Knight Reported Going
LEAD: Bob Knight returned to Indiana today, reportedly to tell his team and university officials that he has accepted the coaching job at New Mexico.
The Dallas Times-Herald, quoting unidentified ''sources close to Knight and the Lobos' program,'' reported in Wednesday's editions that Knight reached an oral agreement on a five-year, $350,000-a-year contract with New Mexico.


Princeton Beats Princeton After Bitter Mayoral Campaign
LEAD: Clifford F. Lindholm, Princeton, Class of 1953, unseated Mayor Robert Jackson, Princeton, Class of 1978, by about 1,000 votes in the municipal election here Tuesday.


Laidlaw's Chief Sells Big Stake
LEAD: Laidlaw Transportation Ltd.'s chairman, Michael G. DeGroote, unable to attract a buyer for his entire company, said today that he had sold his controlling stake in North America's largest school bus operator to Canadian Pacific Ltd. for $500 million (Canadian), or about $404 million.


Metropolitan Opera Schedules Park Series
LEAD: The Metropolitan Opera's 22d annual summer series of free opera performances - in concert version - in parks in and around New York City will begin June 21 on the Great Lawn of Manhattan's Central Park with Donizetti's ''Elisir d'Amore.'' The opening-night cast will include Kathleen Battle, Luciano Pavarotti, Paolo Coni, Giuseppe Taddei and Dawn Kotoski, with Marcello


Corrections
LEAD: The Foreign Exchange table in Business Day last Saturday misstated the value of the dollar in South Korean won for Friday's trading.
It was 735.90 won to the dollar.


Asian Exemplar Moves Toward Authoritarianism
LEAD: The Government of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew, which labored for more than a quarter of a century to make this small nation a model for the developing world, is responding to stirrings of opposition by creating a climate of fear through increasing use of surveillance and detention without trial.

Health; Personal Health
LEAD: Until recent years, few professionals or lay people acknowledged the extent of serious alcohol problems among older Americans.
It was generally assumed that few people took to drinking heavily after five or more decades of sobriety, and many physicians believed that most longstanding alcoholics either died or stopped drinking before getting old.


Review/Theater; An Appalachian Fling
LEAD: You worry that you have not seen everything?
You might try ''The Yellow Dog Contract'' by Ed Setrakian at the Apple Corps Theater.
About two hours into the play you might conclude that Mr.
Setrakian has thrown every imaginable bafflement into it except resurrection.
Don't be hasty; that, too, will come.


Oilcan Art: Living as One With the Urban Environment
LEAD: HIS materials - old car parts and broken tools, gears, nuts and bolts, fragments of metal chair backs, bits of plumbers' tubing and rusted farm implements - are the detritus of the modern industrial age.
Out of these pieces of scrap metal, Linus Coraggio is fashioning some intriguing and original pieces of furniture.


Parking Rules
LEAD: Because of Ascension Thursday, alternate-side parking rules are suspended in New York City today.
Other regulations remain in effect.


Black Students End Occupation Of Office at Harvard Law School
LEAD: Black students at Harvard Law School ended a 24-hour occupation of the dean's outer office today after the school administration promised to continue to give high priority to hiring faculty members from minority groups.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. Our wood deck appears to be made of cedar.
There seems to be no sealer or finish, and when people walk or sit on it, a gray-brown dust gets all over clothes and shoes.
What can we put on the deck to prevent this?
A.
First clean the wood thoroughly with one of the special wood restorers or cleaners that are sold for rejuvenating old wood siding and shingles.

LEAD: Three police officers were arrested yesterday in separate cases on charges that included perjury, illegal drug possession and public lewdness, officials said.

LEAD: A former hostage said today that he and two other Frenchmen were freed by captors in Lebanon because the public pressured France to negotiate with Iran, and he urged Americans and Britons to put the same kind of pressure on their Governments.

LEAD: The dollar received a lift from rising interest rates and closed higher yesterday against most major currencies in domestic trading after dipping overseas.

Group Assails U.S. Information Flow
LEAD: Librarians are alarmed at what they regard as a reduction of access to Government information, according to a report issued by the American Library Association.


EXECUTIVE CHANGES
LEAD: *
AMC Entertainment Inc., Kansas City, Mo., a theater chain, announced the resignation of Ron D. Leslie as president and chief operating officer.
Stanley H. Durwood, chairman and chief executive, will take over as president, and William B. Doeren will become chief operating officer.


A GARDENER'S WORLD
LEAD: I WAS just beginning to relax a bit, as last fall's planting rewarded me with some attractive new wild tulips and as this spring's planting was almost finished.
Then something gruesome turned up in my garden and I suspect in a good many others in the Northeast.
It bears an ugly-sounding name, plasmolysis.


Williams-Sonoma
LEAD: Williams-Sonoma Inc., a retailer of cookware and home furnishings based here, said it had agreed to develop free-standing Ralph Lauren Home Collection retail stores in the United States.
Under the agreement, the Polo Ralph Lauren Corporation will supply its proprietary line of home furnishings, which ranges from towels and bedding to upholstered furniture, while Williams-Sonoma will own and operate the stores.


Martin Gains Support
LEAD: Despite a police report that labeled Billy Martin's version of a weekend fight in Texas as unfounded, George Steinbrenner said yesterday that he accepted his manager's version and planned no action against him.


Paraguay Cancels a Civic Meeting With Pope
LEAD: As Pope John Paul II continued a tour of South America today, the Paraguayan Government canceled a planned meeting between the Pope and civic leaders next week.

And Kelley Drye &amp; Warren has hired a New Delhi lawyer to serve clients with Indian interests.

New Bank Product
LEAD: Into the hotly contested New York City consumer-banking market, the Chemical Bank has introduced a product aimed specifically at recent college graduates.

3 Dead in Explosion of Car Bomb Near Israel's Embassy in Cyprus
LEAD: A car loaded with dynamite blew up about 200 yards from the Israeli Embassy here today after the police prevented the driver from parking at the embassy building.
The car's driver and two Cypriots were killed in the explosion and 15 others were wounded, the police said.

Why the Rush to Tax Nonprofits?
LEAD: Should the local ''Y'' be permitted to run an expensive health club, but not pay taxes on the profits?
Should tax-exempt college bookstores compete with stores that sell everything from tennis rackets to Beatles tapes?
No, say some members of the House Ways and Means Committee.
With Reagan Administration support, they propose to tighten the tax rules on the unrelated businesses of nonprofit organizations.

Danger on the Railroads
LEAD: Every now and then the newspapers and TV report a local story that takes hold of the country.
The stories startle us, not because they are bizarre, but because they force us to face plain dangers that come with the way we live, but which we usually manage to push out of our minds.
Two planes collide in the sky, a subway rider whips out a gun and opens fire.

LEAD: Annie Dwyer hit one up the middle and headed to first base using only one crutch.
A coach held the 11-year-old's arm and carried the other crutch.
A helmet hid her face, except for the smile.


FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
LEAD: MBNA Credit Card Trust is offering $500 million worth of asset-backed securities with a final maturity in 1993 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.
The securities are backed by credit card receivables from Maryland Bank N.A. and have an estimated average life of 2.51 years.

LEAD: Last winter, the debate centered on this question: Should Dave Righetti continue to be a relief pitcher or should he become a starter again?
At the moment, Righetti doesn't seem to be either.
Instead of being in the bullpen or in the rotation, he is in limbo.

Stand Firm Against School Surrender
LEAD: During seven months of contract negotiations, New York City's Board of Education has tried to break the stranglehold of the school custodians.
The board president, Robert Wagner Jr., has now issued a bold ultimatum: Unless ''significant progress'' is made toward a new contract by next week, the board will hire private contractors to clean the schools.

Big Client Pressed 2 Firms To Halt Program Trading
LEAD: Salomon Brothers Inc. and Morgan Stanley &amp; Company, two of the Wall Street firms that suspended their program trading on Tuesday, had been warned just days before that they would not get the investment banking business of a large corporate client unless they halted the controversial practice.

Buckner a Royal
LEAD: Less than a week after his release by the California Angels, Bill Buckner agreed to contract terms yesterday for the remainder of the season with the Kansas City Royals.
Buckner, 38 years old, will be used primarily as a designated hitter, the Royals said.
Contract terms were not announced.
Buckner, who has played the outfield and first base for four teams in a 17-year career, was hitting .209 with 9 runs batted in after 19 games with the Angels.

Don't Discount Supply-Siders and the Curve

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  A new method of regulating long-distance telephone rates was proposed by the F.C.C.
The plan could save callers $1.6 billion in the next four years, the agency said.
The new system would allow A.T.&amp;T. and local phone companies to set their own rates for long-distance calls and access charges as long as they do not exceed new price ceilings.

LEAD: At Byrne Meadowlands Arena, where acts of civil, and uncivil, disobedience have become something of a playoff trend, the fans got into the act tonight after the Bruins scored a second-period goal that produced a 2-2 tie in a game the Devils won, 6-3.

Taiwan Grants Asylum to Two Who Hijacked Mainland Jet
LEAD: Two Chinese men, seeking to defect, hijacked a domestic airliner from the mainland to Taiwan on Thursday.
They were granted asylum, and the jet took the other 116 people aboard back to China early today.


Dutch Plan Insider Law
LEAD: The Dutch Government has toughened its proposal for countering insider trading by making all such trades illegal even if they fail to generate profits, a Finance Ministry spokeswoman said this week.
The move is expected to win wide support in Parliament, and the new law could come into force at the end of this year.

LEAD: Reports that a mortally wounded man waited 40 minutes on a Brooklyn street for an ambulance Monday were exaggerated by at least 15 minutes, the police and the Emergency Medical Service, which operates the city's ambulance system, said yesterday.

LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said today that it would invest more heavily in products and manufacturing technology, strive to increase the share of its profits from financial services and develop a third business sector, probably in electronics.

LEAD: New Jersey will be the host for a National Arts Convention in October, Governor Kean announced yesterday.

Foiled, Car Bomber Sought To Prevent Blast on Cyprus
LEAD: The driver of a car rigged with explosives that blew up in Nicosia Wednesday was racing to warn an accomplice not to detonate the bomb, Interior Minister Christodoulos Veniamin said today.


Marsh Seeks Return
LEAD: Terry Marsh, the former world light welterweight champion, wants to return to the ring eight months after being diagnosed as an epileptic.
The unbeaten Briton said yesterday that he believed the diagnosis was wrong and that the blackouts he had been suffering may not have been symptoms of epilepsy.


Just a Few Feet From Victory
LEAD: Tammie Green hasn't won on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour.
But everyone expects the 29-year-old from Ohio to get her first victory soon if she just starts dropping some of those 10- and 15-foot birdie putts.

Marion Hartshorne, Professor, 78
LEAD: Marion Holmes Hartshorne, the Harry Emerson Fosdick professor emeritus of philosophy and religion at Colgate University in Hamilton, N.Y., died of a malignant brain tumor Tuesday at Community Memorial Hospital in Hamilton.
He was 78 years old and lived in Hamilton.


New Chrysler Contract Is Narrowly Approved
LEAD: Members of the United Automobile Workers have ratified a two-year contract with the Chrysler Corporation by a margin whose narrowness one union official attributed to anger toward the company.


Accounting Merger
LEAD: Laventhol &amp; Horwath, the nation's ninth-largest accounting and consulting firm, announced that it would merge with Stuart Becker &amp; Company, accountants and consultants in New York.
Laventhol &amp; Horwath said the combined New York office would have 550 employees and revenues of $70 million.
Laventhol &amp; Horwath is based in Philadelphia and has offices in 50 American cities.


Chief Resigns At Wickes Unit
LEAD: Alfred S. Crimmins, the president and chief executive of one of the Wickes Companies' largest subsidiaries, said today that he was resigning to pursue other business opportunities.

U.S. Natural Gas Supply
LEAD: The nation has a 35-year supply of recoverable natural gas at prices below $3 per thousand cubic feet, the Energy Department said today.
A price increase to $5 would encourage the development of only another 10 years' supply, the department said.
The nation uses about 17 trillion cubic feet of natural gas a year.


Dining Out Guide: TriBeCa
LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars.
Stars are followed by the date of original publication.
Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.
Arqua


Duckworth Honored
LEAD: Kevin Duckworth, the 7-foot center who nearly tripled his scoring average and helped lead the Portland Trail Blazers to 53 victories, has been named the National Basketball Association's most improved player, receiving 33 of the 80 votes from a national panel of news-media representatives.
Duckworth, who was traded from the San Antonio Spurs to Portland for Walter Berry midway through his rookie season in 1986-87, averaged 15.8 points and 7.4 rebounds this season.

Treatment for Common Type of Fish Poisoning Is Discovered
LEAD: Doctors have discovered a simple but apparently effective treatment for severe cases of the most frequently reported form of fish poisoning affecting people.


Makers of Helicopter Engine Are Sued in East River Crash
LEAD: The owner of the sightseeing helicopter that crashed into the East River on May 1 filed a lawsuit yesterday seeking at least $24.5 million in damages from two corporations involved in the manufacture of the aircraft's engine.


Soviet Survivor Relives 'Doctors' Plot'
LEAD: To wait was Yakov Rapoport's way, and his only weapon.
His memory wound itself protectively around the days in early 1953 that took him from the top ranks of Soviet medicine to a prison cell and back.
When he returned, he kept silent, he kept waiting, and he kept remembering.


Bush Finds Himself Defending Reagan's Backing
LEAD: Vice President Bush attacked the Democrats as weak on national defense today but found himself on the defensive about the strength of President Reagan's support for him.


Review/Film; Terror and Haunting, Through a Child's Eyes
LEAD: Ghosts are rarely as intriguing as the people they haunt, so ''Lady in White'' has a shrewdly chosen focus.
Its sympathetic, engaging, haunted hero is Frankie Scarlatti, a 9-year-old boy who sees the ghost of a murdered 10-year-old girl.
Frankie is locked in a spooky school cloakroom on Halloween night in 1962, when he sees the apparition of Melissa and is nearly strangled himself.


Wooing White Sox
LEAD: Gov.
Bob Martinez of Florida last night agreed to meet today in Tallahassee with Eddie Einhorn and Jerry Reinsdorf, the owners of the Chicago White Sox.
Earlier yesterday, Martinez canceled the breakfast meeting after he heard reports that the White Sox would not be moving to Florida, but would probably keep playing in Chicago.

Sports of The Times; A Snapshot Of Jonathan
LEAD: IT'S a family snapshot like millions of others: a smiling little 4-year-old boy with his cousin and one of his sisters.


A Slow Beginning For an I.B.M. System
LEAD: Software is now being sold that is designed to run with OS/2, the operating system introduced last fall by the International Business Machines Corporation and the Microsoft Corporation, a major software publisher.
But analysts say the new products fall short of tapping OS/2's vast potential.


Market Place; Behind the Rise In Texaco's Stock
LEAD: MOST oil stocks move primarily on oil prices.
But Texaco in the last few weeks has been jumping in anticipation of a bid for control by Carl C. Icahn, its largest shareholder, as well as an anticipated round of asset sales.
Those sales seemed imminent when Texaco emerged two months ago from a year in bankruptcy, but shareholders are still waiting.

Washington Talk: Briefing; Looking for a Home
LEAD: Charles Blitzer, the newly appointed director of the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars, is already itchy to move.
He notes that the Wilson Center is being cramped by crowded quarters in the Castle of the Smithsonian Institution on the Mall.


Bid for Rowntree Arouses Anxiety
LEAD: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said the Government would wait for a report from regulators before making any decisions about Nestle S.A.'s bid to buy Rowntree P.L.C., the British candy maker.
British politicians have strongly objected to Nestle's bid of $:2.1 billion ($3.9 billion) for Rowntree, which makes Kit Kat candy bars, saying they want the company to remain British.


U.S. Halts Funds to Develop Self-Contained Heart Implant
LEAD: The National Institutes of Health announced yesterday that the Federal Government would no longer finance the development of an artificial human heart.
The decision does not halt all artificial heart research, but it deals a blow to the half-century-old dream of building a mechanical pump to replace a heart that no longer functions.

The Shoreham Syndrome
LEAD: New York's politicians propose cutting a deal to scrap the completed, ready-to-run Shoreham nuclear power plant on Long Island.
That folly could threaten the nation's security, not just Long Island's, by further eroding public confidence in nuclear power.
Its cost will become clear enough when brownouts or even rolling blackouts hit


Saatchi &amp; Saatchi Picks 2 Britons for Group Post
LEAD: Terry Bannister and Roy Warman, both from England, have been elected to the board of the Saatchi &amp; Saatchi Company and have been named joint directors of operations for the Communications Group.
That group is made up of the giant company's advertising agencies, public relations firms and marketing services firms.


Fighting in South Beirut Subsides As Syria and Iran Broker a Truce
LEAD: A cease-fire brokered by Syria and Iran took hold today in southern Beirut after six days of fierce street battles between rival Shiite militiamen.


Review/Theater; The Telekinetic 'Carrie,' With Music
LEAD: Those who have the time and money to waste on only one Anglo-American musical wreck on Broadway this year might well choose ''Carrie,'' the new Royal Shakespeare Company co-production at the Virginia Theater.
If ''Chess'' slides to its final scene as solemnly and pompously as the Titanic, then ''Carrie'' expires with fireworks like the Hindenberg.


'Ridiculous' Game Just Fine With Mets
LEAD: Dave Smith, the Houston closer who couldn't finish off the Mets Wednesday night, had no problem today describing the game.


The Law; At the Bar
LEAD: The man was 58 years old, out of work and broke.
So, despite degrees from Dartmouth and New York University Law School, he found himself driving a limousine.
But as much as he hated the work, things could always be worse: the next passenger could be one of his former partners.


Devils Tap Survival Instincts
LEAD: It was a case of survival of the wiliest, and the Devils, for the first time in this Stanley Cup semifinal, outwitted the Bruins.
The Devils kept their playoff crusade intact with a 6-3 victory that was the first indication, through six games, that they might be capable of subduing the Bruins.


Jury Strips 2 Concrete Racketeers of Their Assets
LEAD: A jury decided yesterday that two businessmen must forfeit millions of dollars in assets to the Federal Government because they took part in the racketeering activities of the Genovese crime family.


Washington Talk: Briefing; A Parable, by Valenti
LEAD: For some years now, Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, has been inveighing against what he perceives as the cable television industry's perpetration of rampant evil, the common denominator of which he calls ''monopoly.'' He was doing his own version of ''Hooray for Hollywood'' again Wednesday in a hearing on the video marketplace before the House Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Telecommunications and Finance.


Study Ties Teen-Age Suicide To Abnormalities in the Brain
LEAD: Depressed teen-agers intent on killing themselves show chemical abnormalities in the brain that appear to predispose them to suicide, according to a study released today.

A New York Sound and Light Show
LEAD: Changing the spectacular array of illuminated skyscraper tops that has become a trademark of nighttime New York may fall into the category of fixing what isn't broken.
But the event planned for the opening of the American Institute of Architects convention is intended to be a one-time effort to correct what the architects feel is the only thing wrong with the city's nightly display, which is that it looks the same from the moment the buildings light up at dusk to the moment the lights go off in the middle of the night.

Black Publishing Firms Subject of Conference
LEAD: A free daylong conference on the issue of black-owned publishing houses will be held tomorrow at the City College of New York, North Academic Center, Convent Avenue and 138th Street.
It begins at 10:30 A.M. with a discussion on the history of black publishing houses over the last 70 years.
The future of such publishing houses will be the topic of a talk at 1:30 P.M.


NEWS SUMMARY
LEAD:  International A2-9


Units of Travelers
LEAD: The Travelers Corporation announced yesterday that it would offer its Canadian subsidiaries for sale.
The properties to be sold include Travcan Ltd. and two of its insurance subsidiaries, Travelers Life Insurance Company of Canada and Travelers Indemnity Company of Canada.
The company, which is based in Hartford, said it would concentrate on its United States insurance operations and use the capital from the sale to finance long-range business goals.


William Sunners, Author, 84
LEAD: William Sunners, who wrote more than 100 books on how to win prizes in contests, died of congestive heart failure Monday at Brookdale Hospital in Brooklyn.
He was 84 years old and lived in Brooklyn.


Health of Vietnam Veterans
LEAD: A Federal study finds that Vietnam veterans are as physically healthy as other veterans but that they have more emotional problems.
Page A13.

Mets Wait for Aguilera to Make the Call on Return
LEAD: On Wednesday afternoon, Rick Aguilera sat at the table in the clubhouse playing cards with his teammates.
He won a couple of hands with good cards, several more with shrewd bluffs.
Aguilera's mind is a tough one to read, perhaps never more so than when the only thing he has in his hand is a baseball.


Review/Art; 2 Sides of Constable: Classic and Romantic
LEAD: Although John Constable (1776-1837) has been generally recognized as one of the giants of English art, it has not always been apparent why.
There were classic and romantic sides to him, and his attitude toward them changed.
Occasionally he reached for a synthesis, and when he succeeded, his paintings have a soaring, earthy power.


Soviet Forces Prepare for Pullout By Leaving Eastern Afghanistan
LEAD: Soviet troops have begun moving out of positions in eastern Afghanistan in preparation for their first withdrawal from a major Afghan city this weekend, Afghan and Western diplomats said today.


Shen Congwen, 85, a Champion Of Freedom for Writers in China
LEAD: Shen Congwen, a novelist, short-story writer, lyricist and passionate champion of literary and intellectual independence, died Tuesday in Beijing, his relatives reported.
He was 85 years old.

Second Genetic Code Deciphered, Solving a Protein Synthesis Puzzle
LEAD: Scientists have deciphered a second genetic code that has eluded molecular biologists for two decades.

Restaurants
LEAD:  Mezzogiorno If you are addicted to the buoyant northern Italian fare at Mezzaluna on the Upper East Side but rarely find a free table in its dollhouse-size dining room, an alternative is the new SoHo branch, called Mezzogiorno.
The menu at this casually sophisticated trattoria is similar to that of the original: sprightly carpaccios and salads, vivid pastas and excellent brick-oven pizzas.

Money Fund Assets Fall
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 426 money market mutual funds decreased $3.2 billion, to $270.56 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 117 institutional funds decreased $3.65 billion, to $72.43 billion.
Assets of the 212 general-purpose funds were up $217.1 million, to $89.94 billion.

LEAD: A man accused of killing 16 people last December was convicted of two of the slayings today and was sentenced to death.

LEAD: A Manhattan woman, Anita Escuadra, 68, was hit and killed by a bus near Eighth Avenue and 50th Street yesterday.

Connecticut Resumes Lottery After Repairs
LEAD: About 75 percent of the state's lottery terminals were back on line today, two days after a new computer system developed a glitch that allowed tickets to be purchased after the winning numbers were announced, forcing the system to be shut down.


Central City Chorus
LEAD: The Central City Chorus is to sing Benjamin Britten's ''Hymn to St.
Cecilia,'' with a text by W. H. Auden, and Ralph Vaughan Williams's ''Dona Nobis Pacem,'' a setting of Walt Whitman's Civil War poetry, at Central Presbyterian Church, 593 Park Avenue, at 64th Street, on Sunday at 7 P.M.
Nancy Bergman, a soprano, and Richard Christopher, a baritone, will be the soloists in the Vaughan Williams work, which is to be accompanied by David Graf, an organist.

Economic Scene; Behind Rate Rise, The Fed's Hand
LEAD: THIS week's jump in the prime rate by half a point, back to the 9 percent pre-crash level of October, troubled the stock market, but it was no surprise.
The prime usually lags behind other interest rates, most of which have been climbing for the past two months, and its rise was overdue.


Teacher Tells Committee Of Ordeal by Bureaucracy
LEAD: A 24-year-old teacher who had long dreamed of teaching a first-grade class in New York City's public schools told yesterday how three months at the mercy of the Board of Education's bureaucracy and an elementary school's hierarchy forced her to quit.


Review/Art; 'Painters by Painters' at the Academy of Design
LEAD: The first thing to be said about the new exhibition at the National Academy of Design is that although everything in it comes from the Uffizi in Florence, it is not made up of masterpieces.
Of the 30 paintings on view, 2 or 3 at most deserve that appellation.

Seidon said in a rare phone interview from some place; he wouldn't say where. ''But I couldn't let my girls be abused.

10 Years as Practitioner, None as Lawyer
LEAD: The Chicago law firm of Sonnenschein Carlin Nath &amp; Rosenthal appeared before a Federal judge here last week with a very unusual motion.
The firm wanted to withdraw one of its partners from a civil case because the partner, a highly regarded trial specialist, had never been licensed to practice law.

LEAD: ''Vital Signs,'' at the Whitney Museum of American Art, bites off a small but substantial chunk of an almost ridiculously ambitious subject - the influence of nature on art.
Organized by Lisa Phillips, an associate curator at the museum, the show addresses nature's varied impact on American abstractionists.

LEAD: The Treasury Department wound up its quarterly note and bond auctions on a modestly successful note yesterday, as investors purchased $8.5 billion of new 30-year bonds at yield levels that were a bit lower than had been expected.

Review/Art; From Camera to Paint: New Style for Wegman
LEAD: William Wegman has forged a major career by striking consistently minor, even off-key notes in a number of media.
In a body of work that has so far included video, photography and drawing, Mr.
Wegman has repeatedly thwarted our expectations of artistic mastery, ambition and unity.
He has drawn badly, produced videotapes that make the average home movie look like Oscar material and taken as his main photographic subject a Weimaraner in an array of strange costumes and situations.
