RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  TENNIS  Wilander Upset: Ronald Agenor of Haiti shocked the defending champion, Mats Wilander, 6-3, 7-5, last night in the Italian Open championships in Rome.
In today's quarterfinals of the $825,000 clay-court tournament, Agenor will face No. 9 Andre Agassi of the United States, who beat Thomas Muster of Austria, 6-4, 7-5, for his 14th straight victory.


Moderate Inflation Seen
LEAD: Inflation in the most-developed countries is likely to remain moderate through 1989 while growth is likely to slow, the Bank of England said today.
In its quarterly bulletin, the British central bank predicted consumer prices in major nations would rise 3.2 percent this year and 3.7 percent in 1989.


Power Plant Bond Ruling
LEAD: The State of Washington's Supreme Court ruled today that purchasers of Washington Public Power Supply System bonds could sue the state for its role in the huge default on those bonds.

The Real Palace to Be Spared in Building Demolition
LEAD: The 11-story Palace Theater Building, at top, is being torn down to make way for a 43-story hotel at Seventh Avenue and 47th Street.
The Palace Theater itself, the adjoining, set-back building at left, and its landmark auditorium are to be preserved.
Workers have uncovered a bow-shaped marquee frame that had been out of view for years over the theater entrance on the facade of the office building.


Retail Sales Declined 0.6% in April
LEAD: Retail sales fell six-tenths of 1 percent in April, the first setback in six months, but economists said they were not particularly concerned because the March figure was revised upward significantly.

Alexander Fried, 85, California Arts Critic
LEAD: Alexander Fried, a widely respected critic of music, dance and art in San Francisco for 51 years, died of a heart attack Monday morning at St.
Luke's Hospital in San Francisco.
He was 85 years old.
Mr.
Fried's plain-spoken, gentle, supportive criticism was practiced mainly at The San Francisco Examiner, but he also lectured and was a host of San Francisco Opera radio broadcasts and a master of ceremonies at San Francisco Symphony youth concerts.


Demolition Plays the Palace (But the Theater Plays On)
LEAD: As startling as it is to behold, the latest demolition spectacle on Broadway - involving the ''Valhalla of Vaudeville'' - is actually a little less than meets the eye.
Although the Palace Theater Building is being torn down, the theater itself is to be spared.


I.B.M.'s New Line
LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced a new line of high-performance products that allow customers to turn their typewriters into modified word processors.
The Wheelwriter 10, 30, 50 and 70 all include spelling aids while the 50 and 70 have 25-line screen display.
They include options to expand memory to 720,000 bytes with a diskette drive.

Mexico City Journal; Extra! Extra! A Race You Won't Hear All About
LEAD: When Manuel Clouthier, presidential candidate of Mexico's leading opposition party, was interviewed on state television recently, the event made headlines here.
The news came not so much from anything specific Mr.
Clouthier had to say, but from the fact that he had appeared at all.


AIDS Inmates Get Poor Care, Report Says
LEAD: New York State prison inmates who have AIDS often receive inadequate medical care and are segregated with little to do in overcrowded, makeshift infirmaries, a report released yesterday by a nonprofit group says.

Review/Film; Champion Couch Potato Pays Price in 'Record'
LEAD: Rico Moreno (Uwe Ochsenknecht) has dark rings under his eyes, and no wonder: he's a pathological video addict with the James Dean and Marilyn Monroe posters to prove it.
Rico and his best friend, Banana (Laszlo I. Kisch), have been busily running an ingenious movie-pirating operation, but even when he isn't working, Rico is apt to be glued to the set watching an old movie or perhaps the Academy Awards.

Park Weather
LEAD: Plenty of people, but no sheep, on the Sheep Meadow in Central Park yesterday as the temperature climbed to a high of 74 degrees.
Today should start sunny with clouds increasing and a threat of thundershowers by evening.
Tomorrow is expected to be the opposite: clouds followed by sunshine. (NYT/Chester Higgins


Corrections
LEAD: A front-page picture caption in some copies on Wednesday about workers leaving the Lenin shipyard in Gdansk, Poland, misidentified the portrait they carried.
It showed the Black Madonna of Czestochowa.

Harley's Exports Lead to Profits
LEAD: Harley-Davidson Inc., which had until recently had benefited from United States tariffs on imported motorcycles, said 20 percent of its 1987 production was exported.
Harley-Davidson's chairman, Vaughn L. Beals, in a speech to the Milwaukee World Trade Association on Wednesday, said exports were the key to the company's return to profitability.

In Poland, a Draw and a Challenge
LEAD: Police action, church mediation and the calming counsel of Solidarity veterans have combined to halt Poland's latest labor revolt.
The last workers left Gdansk's Lenin Shipyard neither broken nor victorious.
The Jaruzelski Government bargained with them, but conceded little.

LEAD: Senior Angolan and South African officials arrived here tonight for direct talks to explore a regional settlement to the conflict in Angola and the dispute over neighboring South-West Africa.

Trouble Still Goes With Tyson's Car
LEAD: When Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, crashed his $180,000 silver Bentley convertible into a parked car in lower Manhattan Sunday, two Port Authority police officers offered to help.
And Tyson offered them the car, saying, ''I've had nothing but bad luck and accidents with this car.''


Mixing Ballet With the Blues Of Ray Charles
LEAD: AS the New York City Ballet's American Music Festival draws to a close this weekend, the final two evenings will feature an audacious collaboration that brings together the formality of ballet with the spontaneity of rhythm-and-blues.


Judge Denies Lilco Bid for a July Rate Hike
LEAD: An administrative law judge today rejected the Long Island Lighting Company's request that the State Public Service Commission act on its application for a rate increase by July.


Hewlett-Packard Strategic Alliance
LEAD: The Hewlett-Packard Company said it had formed a strategic alliance with Northern Telecom Inc. to provide corporate-wide networking systems incorporating distributed computing and telecommunications.
The new organization, known as the Corporate Networks Operation, will be based in Santa Clara, Calif., and will be financed and managed equally by the two companies.


Specialist Rule Gains Approval
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission today approved a New York Stock Exchange rule requiring specialists on the exchange floor to maintain a higher permanent level of capital to make markets in stocks.

LEAD: Andre Michel-Schub, the pianist, is to be the soloist with the Queens Symphony Orchestra in the Beethoven Piano Concerto No. 4 tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. at the Colden Center, Queens College, at Kissena Boulevard and the Long Island Expressway, in Flushing.
The program, to be conducted by Arthur Fagen, will also include Beethoven's Symphony No.


Bulgarian Instruments And Vocals
LEAD: To American ears, the sound of Bulgarian music can be bracing - or shocking.
Voices peal out in full-throated, penetrating tones, developed through the centuries to carry for miles across open fields, or they harmonize in close intervals that are dissonant in Western music.
The melodies follow exotic scales, elaborately ornamented with quavers and yelps; the dance tunes are in odd, asymmetrical meters.


TV Weekend; Beryl Markham, a Wonder in Kenya
LEAD: In ''Out of Africa,'' Meryl Streep portrayed the young Isak Dinesen having an adulterous affair with Denys Finch Hatton, the romantic adventurer played by Robert Redford.
Now, in television's ''Shadow on the Sun'' - a four-hour production getting under way Sunday at 9 P.M. on CBS - Stefanie Powers can be seen as Beryl Markham, still another remarkable woman on the Kenyan landscape, who apparently lured Finch Hatton away from Dinesen.

A Food-Filled Festival, And Larks in the Park
LEAD: A MILLION strolling gourmands on Ninth Avenue and several parks full of celebrators can mean only one thing: New York's festival season has begun.
The appearance of the Ninth Avenue International Food Festival, You Gotta Have Park Festivals in Central and Prospect Parks and a host of smaller outdoor festivities this weekend are as telltale signs of spring as the crack of a bat at Yankee Stadium or the year's first warm breeze over a newly green lawn.

LEAD: Most Channel ferry services were restored today as the National Union of Seamen told its members to stop picketing in support of workers staging a 14-week strike against one company.

Officers Chose Not to Give Aid At Shooting Site
LEAD: Six white police officers who responded to the fatal shooting of a black Haitian immigrant in Brooklyn this week decided against administering first aid during the 24 minutes it took for an ambulance to arrive ''because they were afraid they might cause more harm to the victim,'' a Police Department spokesman said yesterday.


And Him a Gramps!
LEAD: Certain sportswriters are propounding the silly proposition that grandfathers should stay out of topless bars.
I assume they are very young sportswriters, for only a very young man would presume to think he knows something about life that grandfather doesn't.


Joseph Shipley, 94, Drama Critic And the Author of Many Books
LEAD: Joseph T. Shipley, a drama critic in New York for more than 60 years, a writer, an editor and a member of the first faculty of Yeshiva College, died of a stroke Wednesday on a visit to London.
He was 94 years old and lived in New York.

LEAD: About a year ago some people connected with Indiana University sought to obtain use of the basketball arena for a charity function one night, a night that would not confict with the basketball season.
The school administrator in charge of sanctioning such arrangements listened and said, ''Sounds fine to me, but we'll have to get Coach Knight's blessing.


Troops in Punjab Enter Sikh Temple Complex
LEAD: Indian paramilitary forces entered the Golden Temple complex tonight and took over two strategic buildings a few hours after scores of Sikh militants besieged in the complex rejected an appeal to send out more than 20 women and children staying with them.


SENATE VOTES 83-6 TO GIVE MILITARY ANTI-DRUG POWERS
LEAD: Responding to election-year pressure, the Senate voted overwhelmingly today to expand the military's role in efforts to reduce the flow of narcotics into the United States.
The vote was 83 to 6.


New Exchange Head
LEAD: John J. Wallace, the president of a brokerage firm, Park Avenue Securities, has been elected chairman of the Philadelphia Stock Exchange.
Mr.
Wallace was named acting chairman on March 22 to replace Martin L. Longstreth Jr., who died of cancer on March 7.


Pickens Asks Mesa Changes
LEAD: T. Boone Pickens has proposed a series of amendments that would broaden the rights of unit holders of the Mesa Limited Partnership, the billion-dollar oil and gas concern of which he is general partner, and also greatly increase the compensation he could earn.


Envoy's Account on Noriega Surprises Three He Briefed
LEAD: An American Ambassador who has said he did not have the evidence to tell Vice President Bush of drug allegations against Panama's military leader at a meeting in 1985 briefed a Congressional delegation about the charges 17 days later, according to three witnesses to the later meeting.


Family Hints Brawley Might Talk
LEAD: Acting on a hint that Tawana Brawley might finally cooperate with his investigation, the chief state prosecutor looking into her claims that she was sexually assaulted has asked her lawyer to clarify the circumstances under which the Dutchess County teen-ager would break her five-month silence.

Famous Players
LEAD: Famous Players Inc., a unit of Gulf and Western Inc., said it would spend $50 million (Canadian), or about $40.5 million (United States), over the next three years to build eight movie theater complexes in the Toronto area.

LEAD: Prime Minister Michel Rocard indicated strongly today that the National Assembly would soon be dissolved in order to give France a Government with a stable parliamentary majority.

Taiwan Shift Jolts U.S. on Trade
LEAD: The United States may preach the virtues of democracy, but in its efforts to push Taiwan to reduce its trade surplus, Washington is finding that the people's will can be more difficult to deal with than a family dynasty.


Japan Trade Surplus Falls
LEAD: Japan's trade surplus decreased in April for the 12th straight month, the Government announced today, but private economists said further reductions would be harder to achieve because of surging exports.


Iceland Currency Halt
LEAD: Iceland's central bank stopped all foreign currency transactions today as the Government began talks on a devaluation, Government officials said.
They said the freeze was necessary because of increasing currency speculation amid rumors that the currency, the crown, would be devalued.


In Face of AIDS, a Chorus Stands Taller
LEAD: Stooped and thin, shivering despite a bulky winter coat, Dennis Haney was barely recognizable to his friends in the San Francisco Gay Men's Chorus when he auditioned last week for the new season.


Devils Eager for Showdown
LEAD: The Devils are in the seventh and deciding game of the National Hockey League semifinals after never having made the playoffs before this spring.
But when they gathered here this morning to depart for Boston, they acted like an experienced playoff team.


Chet Baker, Jazz Trumpeter, Dies at 59 in a Fall
LEAD: Chet Baker, a jazz trumpet player who was also a whisper-voiced, romantic singer, died Friday after falling from the second-floor window of a hotel in Amsterdam.
He was 59 years old.

LEAD: Business sales climbed by 1.9 percent in March, the largest increase in more than a year, while the buildup of business inventories slowed.

LEAD: Twenty Chinese composers - 10 from Taiwan and 10 from China - will take part in a weeklong conference at Columbia University in August on the history and future of Chinese music.

LEAD: The First Republicbank Corporation, the Texas banking company that is receiving emergency Federal aid, said today that it had suspended payments on $1.3 billion in long-term debt, which will save $78 million in annual interest costs.

Collapse of Mexican Factory Kills 14 and Injures Dozens
LEAD: At least 14 people were killed and about 70 were injured on Thursday when a furniture factory collapsed in central Mexico, the Red Cross said today.


The Best Way to Punish Illegal Building
LEAD: New York City's Board of Standards and Appeals must decide whether to legalize a new 31-story building on Park Avenue and 96th Street, where the zoning law limits height to 19 stories.
The developer has no serious claim to a variance, even if one accepts his assertion that the 12 excess floors resulted from an honest mistake.


More Tennis Fame
LEAD: Althea Gibson and Arthur Ashe, both winners of United States and Wimbledon singles championships, headed the first group induction in the Eastern Tennis Association Hall of Fame last night at the Marriott Marquis Hotel.
Gibson won the women's singles crown at Wimbledon in 1957 and 1958 and the United States women's championship in the same years.


U.S. Says It Will Deliver Cash to Contras for Food
LEAD: The Reagan Administration will begin providing the contra guerrillas inside Nicaragua with food and cash to buy food, the Agency for International Development announced today.

Williamsburg Bridge To Open in 3 Phases Starting in 3 Weeks
LEAD: The Williamsburg Bridge will remain closed at least three more weeks and will then gradually reopen - first to cars, then to subway trains and, finally, in August, to trucks, transportation officials said yesterday.

LEAD: These were professionals in Marianne Mitchell's graduate-level counseling class at Indiana University, not 18-year-olds whose mission in life includes the frequent humiliation of Purdue.

The Senate leadership gave all but final approval to the agreements reached in Geneva.

He was 53 years old and lived in Vernon, N.J.

Offer Is Made For Amfac Unit
LEAD: In another step toward completing its restructuring, Amfac Inc. said a group including management and an unidentified financial instituition plans to buy the company's wholesale pharmaceutical business for $120 million.
The hospital and chain store distributor is the fifth of eight operations that Amfac, based in Honolulu, plans to sell.


Navistar Plan Cited at Trial
LEAD: The Navistar International Corporation's sale of its money-losing Wisconsin Steel unit in 1977 was part of a strategy to leave the steel business, not an attempt to avoid pension obligations to workers, according to a company lawyer.


Corporate Leaders Toast Good Times, and Fret a Bit
LEAD: Business is good and getting even better, say the heads of the nation's biggest corporations.


A Death Penalty Bill Is Vetoed by Cuomo
LEAD: Governor Cuomo yesterday vetoed restoration of the death penalty in New York, making it 12 straight years that capital punishment has been blocked by the state's chief executive, six by Mr.
Cuomo.


Correction
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on May 4 about reports of a worldwide increase in development of biological weapons characterized a Defense Department research program incorrectly.
The research is intended to develop defenses against biological warfare, not to develop weapons.
The United States has forsworn the development, possession or use of biological weapons.


James Bliss Dies at 85; Ex-Window Designer
LEAD: James Albert Bliss, the former head of the Bliss Display Company, died of complications from cancer of the pancreas Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital.
He was 85 years old and had residences in Manhattan and on Fire Island.

Soviet Nuclear-Powered Satellite Expected to Hit Earth in Summer
LEAD: A crippled Soviet nuclear-powered satellite is expected to fall to Earth in August or September, threatening to spread radioactive debris.
Yesterday both Soviet and American officials said they were monitoring the situation.


3 Southern States Seek Progress Together
LEAD: The Governors of Arkansas, Louisiana and Mississippi, aboard a barge floating in the sluggish Mississippi, today signed wide-ranging agreements to coordinate their efforts to improve conditions in one of the nation's poorest areas.


Failure to Clarify in Denmark
LEAD: Frustrated by years of parliamentary nitpicking about Denmark's membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Prime Minister Poul Schluter called Tuesday's general election in the hope of forcing a clear up-or-down verdict.
Instead, the vote leaves Denmark's relations with NATO as unclear as ever.

LEAD: Treasury note and bond prices posted sharp early gains yesterday that were pared by afternoon bouts of profit taking.
Dealers attributed the early gains to relief that the Producer Price Index rose an unexpectedly moderate four-tenths of 1 percent in April.


Two Party Insiders to Lead Jackson's Convention Drive
LEAD: The Rev.
Jesse Jackson plans to make major changes in the structure of his Democratic Presidential campaign, giving new responsibilities to two black Democrats who have excellent relations with the party's leadership.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: Doug Smith, a center for the Buffalo Sabres, faced surgery yesterday at Ottawa Civic Hospital for injuries he suffered in an automobile accident May 8.
He has fractures in his left shoulder area, the most serious being a fractured scapula, a wing bone in his back. . . .
Joe Sakic, voted Canada's outstanding junior hockey player for the 1987-88 season, has signed with the Quebec Nordiques.


The Russians, Too, Embrace 'Secret Silliness' of Astrology
LEAD: In a one-room clinic a few paces from Moscow's most popular pedestrian mall, Dzhuna Davitashvili, celebrity psychic healer, gesticulates over the head of a deaf and blind man, as if pulling invisible weeds from his cranium.


About New York; Noteworthy Improvement On School Song
LEAD: Many, many years ago they held a contest to find an alma mater for Brooklyn College, and the winning composer, hands down, was a young woman named Sylvia Fine, who didn't get along with the head of the music department, who decided he would accept her music but not her lyrics, and therein lies a bitter tale that worked out sweetly more than a half century later, which is to say the other day.

Late Home Run Sinks Yankees
LEAD: The one bad pitch that Cecilio Guante threw last night, a fastball down the middle, hung over Billy Martin like a dark cloud.
He thought long and hard about it, and then he finally said he could not fault the pitcher.
It was simply the wrong pitch at the wrong time, nothing more.

The Elastic Price Tag: Why Clothes Cost More
LEAD: This is no time to need clothes, especially if you're a woman.
Not only are the fashions confusing, but prices are giving shoppers a case of sticker shock.
If you're a man, stock up now; experts say the price of men's wear is headed up the same path.


Soybeans Soar on Forecast Of Less Rain Than Normal
LEAD: Soybean futures prices soared yesterday and grain futures also advanced after the National Weather Service predicted a month of drier-than-normal growing conditions.


I.C.H. Is Seeking Partnership Deal
LEAD: The I.C.H.
Corporation, an insurance holding company with about $8.7 billion in assets, said that its senior managers would seek partners to buy all of the company's outstanding stock and take it private.
I.C.H., which in December backed away from a planned merger with the Southmark Corporation, a Texas real estate and financial services company, reported a first-quarter loss of $16 million, compared with a profit of $10.8 million a year earlier.


Celtics Take a 2-0 Lead Despite Bird's 16
LEAD: Scott Hastings, an Atlanta Hawks' forward, watched the Boston Celtics run off 6 consecutive points in 50 seconds tonight to break open what had turned into a close game.
He shook his head and said, ''These guys just have too many weapons.''


Drugs, and Death, Ride the Rails
LEAD: Evidence of drug abuse by an engineer who died in a Metro-North crash last month further strengthens the overwhelming case for routine drug testing of rail employees.
Yet their unions, with surprising sympathy from an appellate court, stand in the way of a sensible testing policy.


South Africa and Angola Agree to More Talks
LEAD: After 13 years of hostilities, South Africa and Angola met for three hours here today and agreed to another meeting with Cuban and American representatives in attendance.


Girl Fatally Struck; Driver Is Arrested
LEAD: A 7-year-old girl died last night after being struck by a van as she crossed a street near her home.
The driver of the van was arrested on a charge of driving while intoxicated.


Barry E. Gell, Watch Executive, 56
LEAD: Barry E. Gell, senior vice president of the Citizen Watch Company, died of a heart attack Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital.
He was 56 years old and lived in Fort Lee, N.J.


Watch Your Toes
LEAD: Now, when the grass is growing rapidly, mowing is a weekly chore.
Most homeowners use power mowers, and the Outdoor Power Equipment Institute, a trade group, wants them to be used safely.
The Consumer Product Safety Commission reported that 70,000 injuries associated with outdoor power equipment were treated in emergency rooms in 1986.


Bush's Fight Against G.O.P. Committeeman Heats Up
LEAD: An embarrassing fight among New York Republicans that could affect the Presidential campaign in the state is heating up.


Bridge
LEAD: If Rip Van Winkle had been an expert rubber bridge player when he fell asleep, and been faced with duplicate competition a century later, he would have had trouble adjusting to the march of bidding.
One can assume, however, that his card play would rescue him in some unfortunate contracts.

LEAD: As the members of Dorothy Donegan's trio were taking their bows at the end of their first set at Sweetwater's, 170 Amsterdam Avenue, at 68th Street, on Thursday evening, Miss Donegan's veteran bassist, Arvell Shaw, stirred by the steady billowing waves of enthusiastic applause, proclaimed her ''one of the world's greatest pianists - without category.

LEAD: Senior Republicans on Capitol Hill say they are increasingly alarmed that Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d is undermining the operations of the Justice Department and damaging party prospects for the fall.

LEAD: Shoppers don't need the Consumer Price Index to tell them that clothing prices have gone up.


Inquiry Is Widened Into Epileptic's Death
LEAD: A spokeswoman for the New York City Medical Examiner's office said this week that a severe neck injury found during an autopsy of a man who died in police custody could have been caused by medical workers, rather than by police officers.
But she stressed that a final determination was weeks away.


Iran-Backed Shiites Gain Ground on Syria's Allies in South Beirut
LEAD: After gaining control of two-thirds of Beirut's southern suburbs in nearly a week of bitter clashes, Shiite Moslem fundamentalists of the Party of God made new advances today, seizing additional positions from Amal, the rival Shiite militia.


Harold Gordon, Publishing Executive, 61
LEAD: Harold Gordon, vice president of business operations for Simon &amp; Schuster Inc., died of cancer Tuesday at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital.
He was 61 years old and lived in Fort Lee, N.J.


Lopez on Target Despite Putting
LEAD: Dee Darden, a 58-year-old retired Air Force lieutenant colonel, has been Nancy Lopez's caddie for the last four years.
Before he picked up her golf bag, Darden watched Lopez play a lot while he caddied for other pros, like Beth Daniel.


Orioles End Stewart's Streak
LEAD: It took the Baltimore Orioles to prove that Dave Stewart can be beaten.


Pope Urges Bolivian War on Drugs
LEAD: Preaching at a major crossroads of cocaine traffic, Pope John Paul II pleaded urgently today for Bolivians to combat a drug trade destroying their society with corruption and murder.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Golf  Crenshaw Takes Lead: Ben Crenshaw shot a five-under par 65 yesterday to take the second-round lead at the $750,000 Byron Nelson Classic in Irving, Tex.
Crenshaw had a six-birdie, one-bogey round for a 36-hole total of nine-under-par 131.
He had a two-shot lead over Jeff Sluman and Mark Wiebe and was three shots up on Craig Stadler and John Cook, who had the day's best round with a 64.

Don't Wound Branch Libraries
LEAD: Since the fiscal crisis in the 1970's, the New York Public Library has periodically suffered budget cuts that have forced service reductions at some of its 81 branches.
Mayor Koch has now proposed another cut, of more than $2.4 million, from the branches.
This retrenchment would cause even shorter library hours and other service reductions and ignores the important value branch libraries play in the city.


Your Money; More People Seek Credit Counseling
LEAD: When Luther R. Gatling opened a credit-counseling service in New York City 11 years ago, most of his clients had blue-collar jobs and earned relatively low wages.

LEAD: Whether because of road crews repairing the ravages of winter or weekenders crawling bumper-to-bumper toward beaches, now is the season for traffic tie-ups.

LEAD: The buildings, both vacant, stand side by side on East Ninth Street between Avenues C and D, symbols of the contrasts and complexities of housing on the Lower East Side.

Ex-School Employees Charged in Sex Case
LEAD: A Roman Catholic priest and a Marist brother are facing charges involving sexual abuse of students at a parochial preparatory school in the Bronx with which they were formerly connected, the Bronx District Attorney, Paul T. Gentile, announced yesterday.


K Mart Overseas
LEAD: The Australian retailer Coles Myer Ltd. said it would bring K Mart discount department stores to New Zealand.
Coles's chairman, Brian Quinn, said the first store was expected to open in the Auckland area later this year.
Coles acquired sole rights for New Zealand from the K Mart Corporation, the second-largest retailer in the United States.


Blockers Gets Permit
LEAD: CA.
Blockers Inc. said today that the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms had granted the company's Keeney Tobacco Corporation a tax permit allowing it to make and sell cigarettes.
The company said it would now be able to start production of its cigarette containing the additive N-Bloctin, which is intended to block the cancer-causing action of nitrosamines from cigarette smoke.

Reviews/Film; Troubled Charter Voyage Of a Blind Ophthalmologist
LEAD: Of all the infirmities that actresses can suffer on the screen, blindness is one of the best.
It affords the chance to be nobly cheerful even when, say, the star's husband is embracing one of his cute young employees right before the star's unseeing eyes.
And the potential for suspense can be boundless, as ''Wait Until Dark'' made clear.


I.R.S. Eases Rules on Deductions After Artists and Writers Protest
LEAD: In response to a storm of protest from authors, painters, photographers and other creative artists, the Internal Revenue Service today eased the rules on deduction of freelance artistic expenses that were imposed under the Tax Reform Act of 1986.


Germ Warfare Research Safe, Pentagon Says After a Study
LEAD: After what it called a comprehensive review of environmental risks, the Pentagon has concluded that its research into defenses against biological weapons is virtually free of significant danger to people or the environment.


Painting The Lilies: Cosmetics For Babies
LEAD: Cosmetics companies are going after a new market: young children.
The industry is courting the upscale cradle set with fragrances, soaps, mousse baby shampoos, sun blocks and even a scent for those born yesterday.


Atari Profits Decline 62.7%
LEAD: The Atari Corporation today reported that first-quarter earnings had a steep decline, which the company attributed primarily to the consumer electronics retailing unit it acquired last summer.


Honor for Jordan
LEAD: By leading the N.B.A. in scoring with an average of 35 points a game, Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls won recognition for the second consecutive season as the league's top offensive player.
Yesterday, he was also named the league's 1988 Defensive Player of the Year.


Expansion Set For Thrifty
LEAD: In a bid to expand into the Pacific Northwest, the Thrifty Corporation, a drugstore and sporting goods chain that is owned by Pacific Enterprises, said today that it plans to acquire 110 Pay'n Save drugstores and 37 Bi-Mart discount department stores for stock worth $232 million.
The deal provides for an added $225 million cash payment to Pay'n Save Inc.


Navy Will Not Appeal Ruling Freeing Doctor
LEAD: The Navy decided today to forgo an appeal in the involuntary manslaughter case of Dr.
Donal M. Billig, making the former heart surgeon a free man once and for all.


Cup Challenger Leaves
LEAD: New Zealand's challenger for the America's Cup left here today after its departure to the United States had been delayed for two days by a strike of British seamen.
The container ship Discovery Bay left this afternoon with the yacht New Zealand on board.


Tony Bird
LEAD: Tony Bird, a songwriter from Malawi, will perform at 8 and 10 o'clock tonight at the New York Open Center, 83 Spring Street (219-2527).
Tickets are $10.

Conviction of Queens Judge For Wire Fraud Is Dismissed
LEAD: A Federal judge yesterday dismissed 9 of the 26 counts on which William C. Brennan, a former State Supreme Court justice, was convicted and sentenced.
The nine counts dealt with making interstate telephone calls to commit fraud, and the dismissal was in line with a 1987 United States Supreme Court ruling.


Two Are Shot In Robbery Of a Payroll
LEAD: At least three gunmen, apparently lying in wait at a lower Manhattan office building yesterday morning, robbed a payroll service of nearly $400,000 in cash and shot a security guard and a cashier, the authorities said.


Brazil's Blacks Feel Bias 100 Years After Slavery
LEAD: The descendants of African slaves make up half of this vast and racially mixed nation, and the religions, food and music brought by their ancestors have molded a vital part of today's Brazil.

GUIDEPOST: FLASHLIGHTS
LEAD: Vacation equipment often includes a flashlight.
Today's models range from disposable plastic ''squeeze'' lights that can be attached to key chains and carried in a purse or pocket to Mag-Lites, aluminum flashlights with rechargeable batteries, adjustable beams, belt clips and Krypton bulbs.
The Mag-Lites are the costliest, but they are versatile and provide a bright light.

PATTERNS OF ADDICTION
LEAD: Doesn't it occur to the biologist James W. McKearney that the animal he concludes is racing toward the anticipated shock is, instead, frantically trying to speed past it?
After failing to do so, it is wearied by its extra efforts and by the shock itself, so it rests before it has to go through the whole tortuous routine again.

I was mired in the sweet innocence of youth, when weddings seemed to spring forth mysteriously through spontaneous generation.

LEAD: Beginning this afternoon, some 3,000 architects will descend on New York for the 120th annual convention of the American Institute of Architects.
It is expected to be the largest gathering of the profession ever - not a bad way, perhaps, to make up for the fact that the association has not chosen to meet in New York since 1967, preferring instead to gather in such architecturally significant cities as San Antonio, Kansas City and San Diego.

Souvenir
LEAD: To the Editor: While snorkeling off the Beach Club in Grand Case, St.
Martin, recently I spotted what looked like a piece of play money on the ocean floor.
Removing my mask, I dove down and retrieved it.
Sure enough, it was a real $10 greenback.
Dried out, it looks as good as new - if a little pale - and I expect to keep it as a treasured liquid asset.

Victory Cigars For the Knicks
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:


Bridge Hed; A Bear Wins at the Cavendish Invitational
LEAD: FOR many years the Russian Bear has been a cause of concern to the United States.
In the past decade there have been problems with Swedish bears.
First Bjorn Borg, whose first name means ''bear,'' arrived to plague our tennis courts and now Bjorn Fallenius is doing well at our card tables.
A week ago he and his partner, Magnus Lindquist, became the first players from another continent to win the Cavendish Invitational Charity Pairs in the 14-year history of the event.

IS AMERICA IN DECLINE?
LEAD: Paul Kennedy expounded the same thesis he pushes in ''The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers'' in a conversation on my patio in West Berlin in the summer of 1984.
His book ignores or misrepresents the most basic facts.
Our defense budget today is 7 percent of the gross national product.
In 1961, it was 9 percent.

Too Slippery to Characterize
LEAD: TO give a logical description in general terms of the strategy of any opening without getting involved in rank contradiction is impossible because each comprises possibilities for diverse strategies.


Dizzy Dames on a New Whirl
LEAD: There's a brief scene in ''Sticky Fingers'' in which a woman is tinkering with a shelf on a window ledge that already holds a row of flowerpots.
She's the kind of woman who giggles and shrieks and chatters too much while this job is being done.
When it's finished, she steps back to admire her handiwork and, of course, the expected thing happens.

Tainted Water Supply: A Way Out
LEAD: I HAD gone to Sanibel Island, on the Gulf Coast of Florida, to look at its potable-water processing plant.
Sanibel and adjacent Captiva share a narrow strip of land divided into two islands by a small river.
Together, they are shaped like Long Island and are, in many ways, a microcosm of it.

Headliners; Post-Retirement
LEAD: It is no insult to Beverly Sills to say that her retirement from the stage a decade ago was one of the best things that ever happened to the New York City Opera.
As general director of the company, Miss Sills proved to be as talented a fund-raiser as she was - and remains - a soprano.
By all accounts, her fund-raising abilities were the main factor in the growth of the City Opera budget from $9 million in 1978 to a projected $26 million in the 1988-89 fiscal year.


Deer Isle: Granite, Spruce And the Sea
LEAD: DEER ISLE looks on a map, in the words of a local historian, Vernal Hutchinson, ''like a figure eight drawn by a very shaky hand.'' At high water the sea all but meets at Long Cove and Northwest Harbor and divides the island.
Countless coves and inlets run along the island's jagged coastline.
Scores of smaller out islands, some no more than pink granite outcrops where cormorants spread their wings to dry, whorl about the shore.


Reassessments Hit Homeowners Hard
LEAD: NOT even in gentrifying Hoboken can Henry Wurtz imagine that his quirky little rowhouse - only 10 feet wide - is worth $212,200, the value recently put on it by a firm doing the city's new tax assessments.


Hispanic-Americans Are Part of Society Too
LEAD: With reference to the April 10 Opinion Page article ''A Divided Society Is an Unjust Society,'' I was keenly disappointed that Stan Lipton referred only very peripherally to our large and growing population of Hispanic-American ancestry.
We may talk with a bit of an accent, but I would reassure your readers that we are also part of God's human family, and wish to live in peace and brotherhood with all other Americans.

STREETSCAPES: Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive; Institutions Use Air Rights Over a Multilevel Marvel
LEAD: NEW YORK CITY and the state are jointly rehabilitating the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, a project expected to be completed by the mid-1990's.
Widely known as the East River Drive, it is certainly one of Manhattan's great public works, particularly the section between 53d and 92d Streets, a dizzying stretch of dips and rises, views and tunnels, sun and shadow.


Recapturing The Spirit Of Steamboats
LEAD: In the late 1800's thousands of passenger boats powered by steam plied America's waterways; today there are only a handful, according to David Crockett, president of the Steamship Historical Society of America.
Happily, nostalgic travelers can still sample the flavor of the era in the Northeast.
Short excursions are available on vintage boats (some now converted to run on diesel fuel) or recently built steamboats in a few locations; more common are replicas that aim to recapture the spirit of the steam age.


Review/Piano; Berenice Lipson-Gruzen
LEAD: Fragments of satisfaction and fragments of disappointment - placed side by side - made up Berenice Lipson-Gruzen's piano recital at Merkin Concert Hall Thursday night, and one's piecemeal response to her playing was actually a metaphor for the playing itself.
Its highest moments were the Debussy pieces - the three ''Estampes'' and the isolated Prelude from Book One called ''What the West Wind Saw.

LEAD: ''LET'S cut consumption'' has taken on the sound of an idea whose time has come although its practicality has yet to be examined.
This catch phrase has jelled into the consensus for remedial action to fix all that's gone wrong with the economy.
Prof.
Paul Kennedy, in his New York Times response to complaints that his best-selling book, ''The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers,'' expressed a passivity toward America's decline, replied that we could always cut consumption.

Program Trading
LEAD: To the Editor:


Dining Alfresco, New York Style
LEAD: FOR ALL THEIR POTENTIAL PLEASURES, outdoor cafes have their distinct perils - especially in such congested urban centers as New York City.
They include everything from flies performing kamikaze dives into your gazpacho to exhaust fumes, gawking passers-by, airborne napkins, cold food, street noise, sudden weather shifts and confused canines who mistake table legs for spindly shrubs.

Is it possible or even desirable to cultivate these identities in what amounts to a hothouse atmosphere?

A Cinch in Time
LEAD: COLORFUL six-inch suspenders called Mini-Grips are spanning the generations in popularity.
Mothers wear them to clasp cardigans and anchor scarves, while daughters use theirs to create mock Mary Janes out of plain flats.
The suspenders also shorten hems for a scalloped effect on skirts, T-shirts and pants, and can cinch waists like a belt.


Cleaning Fireplaces
LEAD: MOST fireplace owners know the importance of having chimneys cleaned regularly.
Doing so prevents the buildup of sooty deposits inside them, which can cause a fire, and also keeps fireplaces functioning efficiently and with less smoke.

Verbatim; Sinatra on Berlin
LEAD: ' What makes an Irving Berlin song special?


NONFICTION
LEAD:  THE IMPERFECT ART: Reflections on Jazz and Modern Culture.
By Ted Gioia. (Oxford University, $16.95.) This is an unusual jazz book for two reasons: it deals with the music not just on its own terms but in a broader cultural and esthetic context, and it was written by a musician.
Ted Gioia, a young pianist who teaches jazz history and performance at Stanford University, has chosen a formidable theme for his first book: ''how peculiar jazz is in comparison with other arts'' and what makes it that way.


THE REGION: City and State Plans; For Lack of Options, New York Gets Serious About Recycling
LEAD: THERE are only three things to do with trash: Dump it, burn it or find a new use for it.
For years, New York State and New York City have relied on the first two options, paying little more than lip service to the third.
But with landfills rapidly filling up, and pollution experts finding disturbing problems with incineration, officials are looking again at recycling.

By Clifford Browder.
Illustrated. 217 pp.

Outdoors; Better Habitat For Woodcock
LEAD: A reclusive bird that even the most dedicated hikers rarely see, the American woodcock, is in trouble, according to the Fish and Wildlife Service, which estimates that for the last decade and a half its numbers have been declining at the rate of about 2 per cent a year.


When Guests Invite Calamity
LEAD: THE REAL PROBLEM with entertaining is that it can't be done without guests.
And the real problem with guests is that you never know what they'll get up to.
They are, after all, only human - they can't be timed like roast beef, arranged like flowers or turned off like a cassette.
Sparkling house, fabulous food, a list of friends that sounds terrific - it can all come to nought if someone drinks too much, begins an argument or monopolizes the conversation.

LEAD: Asian arts and crafts made over five centuries for export to the West -porcelains, silver, ivory, lacquer, furniture and paintings - are now increasingly appreciated for their historical and esthetic value.
Just why these art works and objects are of enduring interest can be seen in the impressive displays that went on view yesterday in the new Asian Export Art Wing of the Peabody Museum of Salem here.

THE ALLURE OF THE OLDER WOMAN
LEAD: Noel Perrin may believe he is singing the praises of older women in his article ''The Allure of the Older Woman'' (About Men, April 17).
In reality, his left-handed homage only objectifies women in the familiar image of the eternal nurturer.
In his view: it is the woman who is counted on to assume the role of mother, teacher and therapist; the woman is merely a way station on the road to manhood; she herself is of consequence only insofar as she can help the younger man cultivate his own inchoate sense of self.


Democracy and Disappointment in Ecuador
LEAD: AFTER the tension stirred up by weeks of campaigning and rumors of a coup, Ecuadoreans were understandably relieved that the Presidential election last Sunday proved to be an anticlimax.
There was no violence, no cry of fraud, no rumble of tanks and, above all, no surprise victory for Abdala Bucaram Ortiz, a rabble-rousing populist who had come to personify political instability here.

Correction
LEAD: An article on May 1 about an increase in self-directed blood donations misstated a statistic attributed to the Red Cross.
The statement should have read: ''The Red Cross said the rate of blood donors testing positive for the AIDS antibody is 1 in 20,000,'' not a 1 in 20,000 chance of receiving an AIDS-infected pint of blood.

French Telepolitics Lessons
LEAD: Francois Mitterrand's strategy has never changed, says Claude de Kemoularia, a French banker, former ambassador and astute political observer.
He analyzes the plan in four stages: first, to create an electable alternative to the old Gaullist majority; then to smash the Communist Party; then reform a Socialist base into a non-Marxist social-democratic party; and finally, to smash the right, leaving a solid foundation for France to be governed from left-center.

'Custom Tailored' for Immunity Without Side Effects
LEAD: THE new generation of genetically engineered vaccines, unlike their earlier counterparts, does not contain live or killed disease organisms, which have been linked to side effects.
Instead, they make use of only portions of infectious organisms, like surface proteins called antigens, which arouse immunity but seldom cause side effects.

LEAD: IN Lackawaxen, Pa., an unprepossessing little town on the banks of the Upper Delaware River, stand monuments to two very different kinds of genius.

Tree roots are exposed.
The soil is so compacted that when it rains the park becomes a huge mud puddle.

Under the typical arrangement, the nonprofit group gets a small cut each time the cards are used to charge a purchase.

LEAD: Musical tastes ebb and flow, though not nearly so predictably as the tides.

The last serious Telemann revival that I recall came in the 1950's, when the arrival of the long-playing record permitted us to hear a representative selection of his immense but on the whole mediocre oeuvre.

Conceived as havens from the ailments of crowded central business districts, the suburban office centers, from riverside to corporate countryside, are going through a period of adjustment in which they are becoming more like urban centers.


Mamaroneck Day Care
LEAD: Plans are under way to begin the county's first municipally run, all-day child-care facility for working parents.
With the aid of $10,000 appropriated by the Trustees of the village of Mamaroneck, the day-care center will open in January 1989.


Designating Landmarks: Beware Hidden Agendas
LEAD: THE city of White Plains is reportedly in the process of drafting historic landmark-preservation legislation, and I want to offer a few personal thoughts on the subject.
The rush to place plaques in front of so-called historic sites in Westchester about a century ago left us with some rather strange heritage, including a number of markers to events that did not even occur here.

Greensward Care Without Pesticides
LEAD: FINISH planting crops such as lettuce, chard, beets, carrots; harvest peas just before cooking for best flavor.
Check ornamentals for immature insect pests and control, if found.
Prepare soil well before planting young shrubs and perennials.
Snap off faded flowers from daffodils and tulips to prevent seed pods.

LEAD: A University of Miami study has asserted that the Reagan Administration, Congress and the two political parties have neglected Latin America's growing economic difficulties ''to the detriment of our national objectives and well-being.''


Largent Staying Put
LEAD: At the age of 33, Steve Largent of the Seattle Seahawks is getting a bit long in the tooth for a National Football League receiver.
Because he has already made his mark - he holds the league receiving record with 752 career catches - it would seem to be time for Largent to start thinking about retirement.

THE NATION: Pro &amp; Con - Extending Welfare's Reach; Should Government Aid the Two-Parent Family, Too?
LEAD: THE overhaul of the nation's welfare policy that is working its way through Congress reflects agreement on the part of both parties that work is the solution to dependency, and training and job placement are the way for long-term welfare recipients to break out of the cycle.
But as always, efforts to define how and how far the Government should help the poor arouse fierce debate.


HOW ANTIQUE IS ANTIQUE?
LEAD: No subject is of greater interest to antiques collectors than how to detect fakes and repairs in period furnishings.
In FAKE, FRAUD, OR GENUINE?
Identifying Authentic American Antique Furniture (New York Graphic Society/ Little, Brown, $29.95), Myrna Kaye, a former consulting curator of furniture at the Society for the Preservation of New England Antiquities in Boston, describes scores of ways in which American antique chairs, tables, chests and sideboards are not all that dealers and auctioneers claim them to be.

'Interesting Numbers' for the Manufacturers
LEAD: NEW technology, particularly genetic engineering, is reviving interest in vaccines - agents that induce immunity to diseases.
After a 20-year slump that saw the number of vaccine producers shrink by half and fundamental advances slow to a crawl, the pace of development is quickening.

LEAD:  Q. We removed the wallpaper from our bathroom ceiling and walls, then painted with a water-base semigloss.
Almost immediately the paint started cracking and peeling.
We hired a painter who scraped and sanded, then painted with an oil paint, but now the walls and ceiling are flaking again.
Can you help me solve this problem?

Review/Film; A New 'Friday the 13th'
LEAD: The ''Friday the 13th'' series may have started as a slasher film and become a teen-age cult favorite, but somehow it has turned into a long-running serial about an odd but familiar neighborhood.
Like the evil twin of Lake Wobegon, Crystal Lake is the little town that time forgot, where all the men are dead, all the women are dead and all the teen-agers are above ground - but not for long.

Putting Public Works in Quasi-Public Hands
LEAD: IF the 10-year capital spending plan proposed by Mayor Koch last week meets all its goals, New York City should be able to build garbage disposal plants, highways and bridges more quickly and cheaply than before.
The key to this minor fiscal miracle would be the creation of three independent authorities, one to supervise the construction and financing of each kind of project.

Host's Guide to Outdoor Cafes
LEAD: IT IS OFTEN SAID THAT RESTAURANTS TODAY are part sustenance and part showmanship, not always in equal proportion.
And nowhere is the theater of dining more vibrant than in outdoor cafes, whether on a bustling urban thoroughfare, in a salt-sprayed seaside village or deep in a sylvan glade.
An outdoor terrace or garden can make an ideal setting for warm-weather entertaining.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036.
Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.
We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

World Oil Price Outlook
LEAD: World oil prices may not strengthen as fast as many think in the next decade and could remain low and unstable until the mid-1990's, the managing director of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group said today.
Speaking to an oil and gas symposium sponsored by the Dutch Government, John Jennings said the world oil surplus might last longer than first thought, depending on non-OPEC production.

Fitness; Swimming Conditions Heart, Mind and Body
LEAD: FEW human athletic endeavors are as beautiful as an accomplished swimmer gliding through the water, a study in grace and precision of movement.
For such people, swimming appears to come naturally.
For others of us, bullied into the deep end of a pool by a physical education teacher long ago, swimming is an ungainly struggle, a battle to breathe correctly and stroke efficiently.

Market Place; Unlocking Values In Hotel Stocks
LEAD: THE lodging industry rises and falls with the economy.
When the economy sparkles, more people travel.
As it softens, individuals and business travelers tend to stay home or at cheaper hotels.
Even though the economy is relatively stable now, the hotel industry is suffering from overcapacity, the result of overbuilding that ended when the tax laws were changed in 1986.

LEAD: *
Saudi Arabia will spend $14 billion to develop the city of Mecca over the next 20 years, Okaz, a Jiddah-based newspaper, reported yesterday.
Mayor Fouad Omar Tawfiq said a number of projects would turn Mecca into two cities: one for pilgrims and the other for residents.
As Islam's holiest city, Mecca is the host to millions of pilgrims each year.

Michel Camdessus (Reuters); Latin Frustration With I.M.F. Grows
LEAD: When the Latin American debt saga began in 1982, the International Monetary Fund took the lead in trying to prop up the region's ailing economies and prevent a flurry of defaults from damaging the international financial system.


Soviet TV, Accenting the Positive, Offers Heavy Coverage of Pullout
LEAD: The beginning of the Soviet Union's withdrawal of military forces from Afghanistan was given unusually prominent coverage today in Soviet newspapers and on the prime-time television news.


Bruhn Dance Prize Given
LEAD: Errol Pickford of the Royal Ballet and Rose Gad Poulsen of the Royal Danish Ballet have won the first Erik Bruhn dance prize, and will share $11,250.
The award, established in a trust fund by Mr.
Bruhn before his death in April 1986, is to be given annually to the best male and best female dancer between the ages of 18 and 26 who are members of the Royal Ballet, Royal Danish Ballet, American Ballet Theater or National Ballet of Canada - the companies with which Mr.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ownership Is Changing At Richmond's A.M.W.
LEAD: Richard E. Athey, the 54-year-old chairman, chief executive officer, chief creative officer and - most important - majority stockholder of Athey Martin Webb in Richmond has retired from the agency for health reasons.
Stephen H. Martin, 43 and president, is buying him out and will become chief executive of the 16-year-old agency.


Australia Becomes a Stand-In for Hollywood
LEAD: Six years ago, the miniseries adapted from Colleen McCullough's best-selling novel ''The Thorn Birds'' - the most popular Australian story of this generation - was filmed in the Simi Valley, northwest of Los Angeles.
The producers decided it was cheaper to simulate the Australian settings than to film Down Under.

Howard Lee Schiff of Avon, Conn., and Dr.
Minas S. Constantinides, the son of Dr. and Mrs.
Spiros Constantinides of Narragansett, R.I.

Jamie L. Kreitman Wed To Joseph Alan Cohen
LEAD: Jamie Lauren Kreitman, a daughter of Rabbi and Mrs.
Benjamin Z. Kreitman of Brooklyn, and Joseph Alan Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs.
Harold L. Cohen of Brooklyn, were married yesterday at Congregation Emunath Israel in New York.
The bride's father and Rabbis Kenneth Auman and Mayer Leifer performed the ceremony.

Spinks to Sign Pact
LEAD: Michael Spinks and Butch Lewis, his promoter-adviser, are scheduled to sign contacts today for Spinks's fight against the heavyweight champion, Mike Tyson, on June 27 in Atlantic City.
Milton Chwasky, Lewis's attorney, reported their plans to sign the pacts.
Bill Cayton, Tyson's manager, said all other parties in the fight had signed contracts.


SBK Acquires Stake in Cinecom
LEAD: SBK Entertainment World Inc. has acquired a substantial interest in Cinecom Entertainment Group, an independent film production and distribution company, the companies announced yesterday.


Hawks Even Series With Celtics, 2-2
LEAD: The Hawks sensed that the Celtics were in trouble tonight in the first 19 seconds of the game, when Dominique Wilkins hit his first shot, an 11-foot jumper on a pass from Glenn (Doc) Rivers.


Angolan Affirms Wider Cuban Role
LEAD: Rejecting comparisons with the Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan, Angola's President said today that the Cuban force here had been reinforced.


Rating Upgraded For Dow Chemical
LEAD: The rating on about $4 billion of debt issued by the Dow Chemical Corporation and its units was increased yesterday by the Standard &amp; Poor's Corporation.


O.E.C.D. Is More Upbeat on Growth
LEAD: The world's growth outlook is better than expected, but trade imbalances are being reduced more slowly than predicted, officials of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today.


Quotations of the Day
LEAD: ''I suspect, therefore, that members of our society will be shocked to learn that the Court, the ultimate guarantor of liberty, deems unreasonable our expectation that the aspects of our private lives that are concealed safely in a trash bag will not become public.''  - Justice William J. Brennan, in dissent on a ruling that permits the police to freely search through garbage.


Washington Talk: Briefing; A Harrowing Task
LEAD: Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, brought new definition to his career today as he explained how he wound up with a harrowing task behind the White House press podium rather than at harrowing work in the fields of his father's farm.


Natalie Wales Winslow, Author, 58
LEAD: Natalie Wales Winslow, an author of novels, articles and poetry, died of cancer on May 5 at her home in Winchester, England.
She was 58 years old.

'Killer' Bees? Get Serious.
LEAD: The equatorial sun bore down on the forested mountainside and the three beekeepers had already broken a sweat inside their protective garb.
They had hiked a good quarter-mile up a trail to the hives, isolated because this Venezuelan apiary was no backyard operation: it contained Africanized, ''killer'' bees.


U.S. WELCOMES PULLOUT
LEAD: The White House today welcomed the start of the withdrawal of Soviet troops as a first step in the pursuit of ''independence and self-determination'' for Afghanistan.


Manslaughter Charge Filed In Killing of Police Sergeant
LEAD: A Manhattan grand jury indicted a woman yesterday on charges of second-degree manslaughter in the shooting death of a New York City police sergeant, although the fatal shots were fired by another officer.


College Baseball Playoffs
LEAD: The Big East Conference double-elimination baseball playoffs will begin today at 5 P.M. a with a doubleheader at Muzzy Field in Bristol, Conn.
In the opener, top-seeded Villanova (16-2 in league games, 30-20 over all) will play St.
John's (9-9, 23-16-1).
In the second game, Seton Hall (12-6, 38-14) will play Providence (12-6, 22-27).


Chess
LEAD: In capturing the $20,000 first prize in the inaugural World Cup Tournament in Brussels, Anatoly Karpov achieved the 70th tournament victory of his career.
The former world champion from the Soviet Union now has a leg up in the competition for the $150,000 prize that will go to the overall winner of four of the six World Cup tournaments.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  TENNIS  U.S.
Edges Switzerland: The United States came from behind yesterday to edge Switzerland, 2-1, in the opening round of the $750,000 World Team Cup in Dusseldorf, West Germany.
In the other match in the eight-team competition, Argentina and France were tied at 1-1.
That match will be completed today.


Careers; Liberal Arts: High Road to 'Bottom Line'
LEAD: A NEW study of liberal arts graduates in the business world is optimistic.
The study, ''Liberal Education and Corporate America,'' was prepared by Prof.
Michael Useem of Boston University.


Cancer and Early Diet
LEAD: A new study of more than 1,000 Wisconsin residents suggests that frequent childhood consumption of fresh vegetables - especially broccoli, cauliflower and salad - is associated with a reduced risk of developing colon cancer later in life.


ALGERIA TO RESUME TIES WITH MOROCCO
LEAD: Algeria and Morocco announced today that they had decided to restore diplomatic relations after 12 years of bitter political dispute.


Books of The Times; On Clear Duplicity and Doubtful Consequence
LEAD:  The Secret Lives of Trebitsch Lincoln  By Bernard Wasserstein  Illustrated. 327 pages.
Yale University Press. $27.50.

Surgeon General Asserts Smoking Is an Addiction
LEAD: The Surgeon General of the United States warned today that nicotine was as addictive as heroin and cocaine and recommended the licensing of those who sell tobacco products and tougher laws prohibiting their sale to minors.


Patriots' Settlement
LEAD: In a settlement af a dispute that arose when Brian Holloway, a three-time All-Pro, was traded by the New England Patriots to the Los Angeles Raiders last Sept. 2, the Patriots agreed yesterday to pay Holloway an undisclosed sum.
The National Football League Players Assocation said it would drop charges before a National Labor Relations Board administrative judge that Holloway had been traded because of union activities.


From PC's to Nodes
LEAD: THE personal computer is dead; long live the node.


New Stock for Affiliated
LEAD: Shareholders of Affiliated Publications Inc., the owner of The Boston Globe, yesterday approved creation of a new class of stock with 10 times the voting power of its common stock.


Excerpts From Justices' Opinions on Searches of Curbside Trash by Police
LEAD: Following are excerpts from the opinions in the Supeme Court's decision today that the police may freely search through garbage left outside homes for collection.
Justice Byron R. White wrote the majority opinion, joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Harry A. Blackman, John Paul Stevens, Sandra Day O'Connor and Antonin Scalia.


3 Are Killed And 20 Hurt In Bus Crash
LEAD: Three people were killed and 20 others were injured yesterday afternoon when a school bus carrying mentally handicapped people overturned on a sharp downhill curve, hit a utility pole and slid down a wooded embankment in northern Dutchess County, the authorities said.

LEAD: PERHAPS the most important single element in determining the personality of a computer is its central processing unit, the chip that orchestrates the show.
That bit of silicon sets the speed of the computer, its memory capacity and the general efficiency of the entire system.

Bartels &amp; Carstens Adds Associates to Its Name

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL  Little progress has been made on ending farm subsidies, officials of the leading industrial democracies say as they prepare to meet in Paris.
The U.S. wants countries to set a firm date for ending protectionism.
But the European Community maintains the U.S. is as much at fault as anyone else for slowing down the elimination of barriers.


Cuomo Voices Hope on Shoreham Talks
LEAD: Governor Cuomo said today that negotiations with the Long Island Lighting Company presented the best and cheapest way to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

Poll Shows Dukakis Leads Bush; Many Reagan Backers Shift Sides

Excerpts From Koop Report on Smoking
LEAD: Following are excerpts from Surgeon General C. Everett Koop's report on smoking:  Nicotine: Pharmacokinetics, Metabolism and Pharmacodynamics


German Trade Surplus
LEAD: West Germany's trade surplus fell 21 percent in February, to 8.2 billion marks, or $13.8 billion, from 10.4 billion marks in the period a year earlier, the Federal Statistics Office said today.
The surplus came to 8.5 billion marks in January.
The February trade report had been delayed for six weeks because a new reporting system based on European Community guidelines went into effect.


A Judge Orders New Jury Panel For Davis Trial
LEAD: Acting on his earlier finding of racism by the defense in jury selection at the trial of Larry Davis, a Bronx judge yesterday removed the six jurors who had been seated and ordered a ''completely fresh'' trial.

Chambers Tape Depicts a Party Before His Trial
LEAD: In a videotape broadcast last night, Robert E. Chambers Jr., who pleaded guilty in March in the strangulation of Jennifer Levin, playfully acted out a story in which he accidentally broke the neck of a doll.


Skyscrapers Attract Imperiled Falcons
LEAD: High above the downtown area, two wild peregrine falcon chicks pecked out of their shells in a nest on a skyscraper ledge.


The Dollar Climbs Slightly While Gold Also Advances
LEAD: The dollar drifted slightly higher in quiet trading yesterday in advance of today's report on the United States trade deficit for March.


Treasury Prices Decline Narrowly
LEAD: A sharp rise in commodity prices pushed prices of Treasury notes and bonds narrowly lower yesterday.


Uniworld Group Lures Essence Programmer
LEAD: Gene A. Davis, formerly vice president of programming for Essence television, has joined the Uniworld Group, one of the largest black-owned ad agencies, as executive vice president of the its new unit, Uniworld Entertainment.


T. E. Stephens, Eisenhower Aide And G.O.P. Strategist, Dies at 84
LEAD: Thomas E. Stephens, a lawyer and former appointment secretary to President Eisenhower, died Sunday at the Morton Plant Hospital in Clearwater, Fla.
He was 84 years old.


Student's Suicide Stirs Protests in South Korea
LEAD: A student committed suicide Sunday to demand the release of political prisoners and the reunification of Korea.
The death set off protests today by hundreds of students, who hurled rocks and firebombs at riot police here.


Cajun Electric Power Co-op Places Top Yield at 10 1/8%
LEAD: Cajun Electric Power Co-op Inc. of Baton Rouge, La., is offering $200 million of noncallable cooperative utility trust certificates in a three-part financing through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham &amp; Company.

Senate to Begin Its Debate on Missile Pact Today
LEAD: Robert C. Byrd, the Senate majority leader, announced today that the Senate would begin floor debate on the new missile accord on Tuesday because all verification issues had been resolved.


A Prize Recital Sung In English
LEAD: Julia Davidson, winner of the 1987 Center for Contemporary Opera vocal competition, chose a program all in English for her prize recital Friday at Weill Recital Hall.
She met the first qualification for such an undertaking handily: texts to most of her selections were printed in the program, but only three or four times in the whole evening was it necessary to glance at them to learn what had been sung.


Europe Plans Fighter Plane
LEAD: West Germany, Britain and Italy today signed an accord to build 750 Eurofighters for $47 billion, the biggest West European military contract since World War II.
Spain is also expected to sign the agreement soon.


Carroll Kowal Is Dead; Housing Aide Was 59
LEAD: Carroll Kowal, a social worker and longtime advocate of adequate housing for the homeless and disabled, died of intestinal cancer Saturday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan.
She was 59 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Corrections
LEAD: A headline on Saturday about the New York State Investigation Commission's finding evidence of possible extortion by Alexander A. Levine, the former executive director of the State Thruway Authority, characterized the commission incorrectly.
It was established by the State Legislature.


Soviet Television Broadcasts Censored Film About Stalin
LEAD: A two-hour documentary film held back by Soviet censors for eight months was shown on television tonight, drawing together critics and defenders of Stalin to put his leadership on trial.

Lies Can Point to Mental Disorders or Signal Normal Growth
LEAD: WHILE recognizing that lying is a universal lubricant of social life, psychiatrists are seeking to determine when it becomes destructive and just which kinds of mental problems it can typify.


Firms May Merge
LEAD: The Wedbush Corporation and the Morgan, Olmstead, Kennedy &amp; Gardner Capital Corporation said they were discussing a merger of the two securities firms.
The companies said if a merger was completed, the combined firms would have more than $75 million in capital and more than $500 million in assets.

Forecasts Vary On Trade Data
LEAD: Perhaps the best evidence of skepticism about the monthly trade figures, related both to compilation difficulties and the ''lumpy'' nature of trade flows, is the wide range of forecasts.


Milton U. Copland, 79, Executive for Builder
LEAD: Milton U. Copland, for many years a top officer of the Uris Buildings Corporation, a major developer of Manhattan office towers, died of cancer of the colon yesterday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 79 years old.


Topics of The Times; The Fragrance of Infants
LEAD: The cosmetics industry has flourished by stoking the vanity of the baby boom generation.
Now it is at work on babies.
Under names like Eau de Senteur and Eau de Toilette, it is selling perfume, soaps and other cosmetics for babies and young children, at prices like $30 for 3.3 ounces.
Actually, the targets of this marketing ploy are not ''upscale'' children but their parents.


Corrections
LEAD: A headline yesterday about new anti-crack legislation in New York State misstated the scope of the bill.


Suspect in an Officer's Death Is Held
LEAD: A 28-year-old parolee, tracked to an apartment in northwest Philadelphia by New York City investigators, was captured in a police raid at dawn yesterday and held in connection with the slaying last month of a young housing police officer in Brooklyn.


Voters Near Denver Will Decide Today on Airport
LEAD: Adams County residents vote Tuesday on whether to allow Denver to annex 44.7 square miles of farmland to build what is described here as the largest airport in the world.

Kansas City Journal; Soviet Tour Reaches America's Warm Heart
LEAD: More than 50 Russians touring the United States with a cultural exchange exhibition have reached the heart of America.
To no one's surprise, it seemed, they found it open, friendly and warm.


New Round of Cuts In Airline Fares
LEAD: Eastern Airlines and Continental Airlines announced new cut-rate fares for children and the elderly for the summer.
United Airlines, the nation's largest carrier, said it would match the fares in the markets where it competes with them.
Eastern and Continental also said they were easing some restrictions on the regular Maxsaver deep-discount fares.

LEAD: In contrast to Presidential aides who thunder into print as soon as they depart the White House, Clark M. Clifford, an adviser to the last four Democratic Presidents and Secretary of Defense at the height of the Vietnam War, has waited more than 40 years to write his Washington book.

Perron Resigns
LEAD: Jean Perron resigned yesterday as coach of the Montreal Canadiens, who finished second in the overall National Hockey League standings but were eliminated from the playoffs by the Boston Bruins in the Adams Division final.
In making the announcement at a news conference, the Montreal general manager, Serge Savard, reported that Perron ''said he found the pressures of the job were quite difficult for him, and especially for his family.


Soviet Relinquishes Afghan Province
LEAD: Soviet officials said today that Russian troops had completed their withdrawal from a key eastern Afghan border province that has served as a buffer protecting the area around this capital city from guerrillas based in Pakistan.


Hutton Pays Fines to U.S.
LEAD: E. F. Hutton, now part of Shearson Lehman Hutton, today paid $1.01 million in fines for a money-laundering scheme in which $1.5 million in cash was hidden from the Government for clients, some of them members of organized crime.


Black Labor Congress Plans to Challenge Pretoria
LEAD: South Africa's major black trade union federation is to hold a three-day work stay-away next month, apparently in defiance of Government restrictions.


Critics Honor 'Joe Turner'
LEAD: August Wilson's ''Joe Turner's Come and Gone'' was named the best new play of the 1987-1988 season by the New York Drama Critics Circle at a meeting held yesterday at the Algonquin Hotel. ''The Road to Mecca'' by Athol Fugard was named best foreign play, and the Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine musical ''Into the Woods'' was named best new musical.

Sister Mary Beck, 82, Ex-College President
LEAD: Sister Mary Celeste Beck, the president of Molloy College in Rockville Centre, L.I., until 1972, died Saturday at the Queen of the Holy Rosary residence in Amityville, L.I., after a long illness.
She was 82 years old and lived at the home, the mother house of the Sisters of St.
Dominic of Amityville.


Trading Carelessly in Trade Figures
LEAD: On April 14 the stock market dropped 101 points, the dollar plunged and interest rates surged, all because of one unreliable statistic - the Commerce Department's report that the foreign trade deficit had got worse again in February.
Well, today's the day for the March figures, and perhaps another spasm of speculation.

LEAD: The Toronto Blue Jays yesterday placed the outfielder Jesse Barfield on the 15-day disabled list with wrist problems. . . .
Doug Moe of the Denver Nuggets has been selectedthe N.B.A.'s Coach of the Year in a news media poll. . . .
Don Koharski, the National Hockey League referee, has invited Jim Schoenfeld, the Devils' coach, to attend his celebrity golf tournament near Toronto in August to raise money for the mentally retarded.

Beene's Way With Furs: Masterly and Irreverent
LEAD: With equal helpings of originality and exuberance, seasoned with frivolity, Geoffrey Beene got the week of fall fur showings off to an exciting start yesterday.
He mixed fur with feathers and fabrics, dyed some pelts unlikely shades like taxicab yellow and tomato red and even lined sober sable with wildly patterned silks.


Pope Lectures Paraguay Leader on Human Rights
LEAD: Visiting Gen.
Alfredo Stroessner in the presidential palace from which he has ruled Paraguay for 34 years, Pope John Paul II delivered a tough lecture today on human rights and political freedoms.

Senate Vote Indicates Support for a Death Penalty in Drug Killings
LEAD: Continuing its campaign to get tough on drugs, the Senate today signaled strong support for a Federal death penalty for drug-related killings.


Students in Debt: Society Pays a Price, Too; Banks vs. Schools
LEAD: To the Editor:


Jackson Seeks a Strong Oregon Vote
LEAD: The voters of Oregon have a reputation for upsetting Presidential front-runners, and the Rev.
Jesse Jackson is asking them to do it again in Tuesday's primary.


Soviet Space Prescription: Artificial Gravity for Long Flights
LEAD: The accumulated experience of Soviet astronauts on long space flights suggests that any manned mission to Mars or beyond should be made in a craft that has a centrifuge to provide artificial gravity, according to the country's top expert on space medicine.


Monster Robots Bash Paradise in Mock Battle
LEAD: Weather permitting, tonight at 9 o'clock, the parking lot at Shea Stadium will be the site of an hourlong battle involving flame throwers, artillery, explosives and anthropomorphic metal machines that crush everything in their paths.


Allegheny Meeting Delay
LEAD: A Federal bankruptcy judge in Pittsburgh yesterday issued an order temporarily blocking the annual meeting of Allegheny International Inc., at which a proxy fight led by a New York brokerage firm was to take place.

Korea Eases Gold Curb
LEAD: South Korea plans to lift import restrictions and slash taxes on gold to help end widespread smuggling, Government officials said.
At least 20 to 30 metric tons of gold a year have been smuggled into South Korea, compared with about 24 tons imported legally, economic planning officials said Saturday.


Spending Cut By Brazil
LEAD: In a step toward obtaining a $1.5 billion standby credit from the International Monetary Fund, the Brazilian Government tonight announced a series of new spending cuts aimed at reducing its huge budget deficit.

Politics Hasn't Yet Swayed the High Court
LEAD: To the Editor:


Israeli Troops Kill Protester in Gaza
LEAD: Two Palestinians died and at least seven others were shot and wounded in renewed demonstrations across the occupied territories today.
But this evening the Israeli Army tried to determine if one of those killed, an Arab youth said to have been shot by soldiers, had actually died of natural causes.


Poland Is Said to Free Some Leaders in Strike
LEAD: Communist authorities today released Janusz Onyszkiewicz, a spokesman for the outlawed Solidarity union, and 11 strike leaders jailed in connection with Poland's recent wave of unrest, opposition representatives said.


Illinois Seeking Hambletonian
LEAD: A bid by the state of Illinois to bring the Hambletonian harness race back to southern Illinois will include a possible $1 million bonus for the winning horse, an aide to Gov.
James R. Thompson said today.


India Acts in Carbide Case
LEAD: The Government of India reissued summonses today against the Union Carbide Corporation and its former chairman in an effort to make them appear in court on homicide charges in the 1984 Bhopal gas leak.

LEAD: A year after promising to begin a process of withdrawing aid to farmers in exporting crops, officials of the leading industrial countries concede that they have made no real progress and do not hold much hope for any soon.

Review/Theater; Bill Irwin's Adventures as a Post-Modern Hoofer
LEAD: As usual, Bill Irwin's show - in this case, ''Largely/New York'' at City Center Theater - begins with no overture or fanfare.
The clown is by himself on stage.
Holding a remote control, he points it up at the curtain and slowly the curtain rises, revealing another curtain.
Abashed, he pushes the button again.


Police May Search People's Trash Without a Warrant, Court Rules
LEAD: The Supreme Court, over an impassioned dissent, ruled today that the police may freely search through garbage bags and other refuse containers that people leave outside the home for collection.


Review/Dance; City Ballet Completes Its Unpredictable Festival
LEAD: Fireworks lighted up the stage if not the sky, and intimations of Old Glory - stars and blurry tones of red and blue - were projected against a backdrop as the New York City Ballet closed its three-week American Music Festival on Sunday night at the New York State Theater.


Occidental Sets Share Offering
LEAD: Saddled with high debt from recent acquisitions, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation announced a new stock offering today.
Occidental has about 210 million shares outstanding and would offer 45 million common shares in June.
The proceeds would be used to reduce debt and for general corporate purposes.


New Publisher At Law Journal
LEAD: James A. Finkelstein will be named publisher of The New York Law Journal on May 23, succeeding his father, Jerry Finkelstein, who has been publisher for 25 years.


Hard Lessons in Grief To Absorb So Young
LEAD: Charlie Jones, the principal of the Radcliff Middle School, thumbed through the dark blue 1988 yearbook today, pointing out 16 of the children who died in one of the worst bus accidents in United States history.


Driver Charged With 27 Murder Counts
LEAD: The driver of a pickup truck that was driven the wrong way on an interstate highway and slammed head-on into a church bus was charged today with 27 counts of capital murder, one count for each person killed in the fiery crash near here Saturday night.
