LEAD: A UNIVERSITY of Michigan physicist has invented a fluid that thickens in response to an electric field, and he believes the material is destined to change technology as radically as the transistor.

After Seven Years And $7 Million, 'Carrie' Is a Kinetic Memory
LEAD: More than seven years after its authors first began work on it, the critically lambasted musical ''Carrie'' has closed after 5 regular performances and 16 previews, making the more-than-$7 million show the most expensive quick flop in Broadway history. ''Rags,'' a musical about the Jewish immigrant experience that starred Teresa Stratas, ran for only four performances in August 1986, but cost less: $5.25 million.


Bill Seeks Cadavers for the Training of Police Dogs
LEAD: To help train police dogs to track missing persons, two state legislators have introduced a bill to make cadavers available to law-enforcement agencies.

Armtek Corp., New Haven, and Pirelli S.p.A. said they had signed a stock purchase agreement for the sale of Armtek's Armstrong tire business to Pirelli for about $197 million.


BELGRADE ADOPTS AN AUSTERITY PLAN
LEAD: The Yugoslav Government imposed ceilings on wage increases today under a new program worked out with the International Monetary Fund.


Artificial Heart in Turmoil
LEAD: A permanent, fully implanted artificial heart has been one of medicine's most ambitious and controversial goals, and the Federally financed research project in pursuit of it has run a rocky course from its start 25 years ago.


New York City Asks State And U.S. for AIDS Help
LEAD: New York City, facing a dramatic rise in AIDS cases, will be unable to deal with the epidemic without more help from Federal and state agencies and the full participation of voluntary and private hospitals and clinics, a city report released yesterday said.


Saatchi &amp; Saatchi DFS Is Losing Its President
LEAD: Peter F. McSpadden, the top Saatchi &amp; Saatchi DFS executive on both the RJR Nabisco and Northwest Airlines accounts, will be leaving the company around September, a highly placed agency executive confirmed yesterday.


Omnicom Preparing for Acquisitions
LEAD: THE tumultuous events in adland in the last 18 months were felt yesterday at the annual meeting of the Omnicom Group, whose shareholders voted to allow the board to issue more stock so as better to compete in the acquisition marketplace with the deep-pocketed British companies.


Saudi Oil Tied to Spot Price
LEAD: Saudi Arabia has informed crude oil customers that its current market-related pricing arrangements will be extended until the end of July, the Middle East Economic Survey reported today.


MEESE DISMISSES CHIEF SPOKESMAN
LEAD: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d has dismissed his chief spokesman, Terry Eastland, provoking further turmoil in a Justice Department already torn by resignations and concern over investigations into Mr.
Meese's affairs.

Legalize Drugs? Not on Your Life.
LEAD: The escalating drug crisis is beginning to take its toll on many Americans.
And now growing numbers of well-intentioned officials and other opinion leaders are saying that the best way to fight drugs is to legalize them.
But what they're really admitting is that they're willing to abandon a war that we have not even begun to fight.


Environmental Fears Cast Pall Over Riis Park Project
LEAD: A $55 million redevelopment proposal that would add a performing-arts amphitheater and water rides to an oceanfront Queens park has been thrown into doubt because of vehement opposition from community and environmental groups.


European Output Up 2%
LEAD: Industrial production in the European Community increased by 2 percent last year, compared with 3.8 percent in the United States and 4 percent in Japan, the community's statistics office, Eurostat, said today.
The increase was marginally bigger than output growth of 1.9 percent registered in 1986.


Home Loan Agency's Rates
LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Banks will set interest rates today for a three-part bond offering totaling $3.18 billion.


Iceland Lowers Currency Value
LEAD: Iceland devalued its currency, the crown, by 10 percent today to help its fishing industry, which has been suffering from falling prices abroad.


Knight Decides to Stay With Indiana
LEAD: After meeting with the Indiana University president whose recent criticism had troubled him, Bob Knight today ended an obsessive tug-of-war between states by turning down an offer from the University of New Mexico and remaining as basketball coach at Indiana.

LTV Gets an Extension
LEAD: A Federal bankruptcy judge in New York today granted the LTV Corporation a 90-day extension to file a reorganization plan for the company and its 65 subsidiaries.
With the extension, LTV has until Aug. 18 the exclusive right to present a reorganization plan to the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan.


Mowry's Mulligan in Life
LEAD: FOR nearly a decade, the Senior PGA Tour has kept Arnold Palmer, Gary Player, Chi Chi Rodriguez and dozens of other cherished golf names out there on display.
It's been their ''mulligan'' in life, a second tee shot from age 50 on.
But none of the touring senior pros has hit a longer, straighter mulligan than a new name, Larry Mowry, who suddenly found himself walking onto the final green with Palmer and Player at last year's Pepsi Senior Challenge in Roswell, Ga.


White House Group Recommends Only Limited Changes in Markets
LEAD: The White House working group on the stock market crash recommended changes today that would only slightly alter the way trading is conducted on the nation's exchanges.


Gooden Is Hit Hard, but Mets Hit Harder
LEAD: Dwight Gooden pitched ragged ball for the third straight time tonight, but still won his seventh game without a loss when Gary Carter hit a three-run home run in the seventh inning to beat the San Diego Padres, 7-4.

LEAD: Vice President Bush, campaigning in the Northwest, has been urging greater domestic oil production and arguing that it can be achieved without endangering the environment.

Lane Enters Draft
LEAD: Jerome Lane of Pittsburgh has decided to skip his final year of college eligibility and has made himself available for the National Basketball Association draft.
He joins Rex Chapman of Kentucky, Rod Strickland of DePaul, Tito Horford of Miami and Charles Shackleford of North Carolina.

Cleanup for Closed Landfill
LEAD: Federal authorities have reached an agreement with 226 companies that calls for the firms to pay $4.98 million in cleanup costs at the now-closed Kin-Buc Landfill in Edison, N.J., the United States Attorney's office said today.
The Federal Environmental Protection Agency has identified at least 22 cancer-causing or suspected carcinogenic substances at the former landfill.

Jesse Jackson said today that he expected to play a powerful role in the selection of the Democratic Presidential ticket as well as in writing the party's platform.


Syrian Threat: Warning Signal to Iran
LEAD: Syria's threat to use its army against a pro-Iranian militia in southern Beirut is a signal to Iran that it cannot go too far in challenging Syria's role as a power broker in Lebanon.

LEAD: The New York State Senate recently approved an ill- advised bill to abolish New York City's runoff election system, and persuaded Governor Cuomo to lend his support.

LEAD: The New York Philharmonic will play 16 concerts in 10 European countries this summer, the orchestra has announced.

U.S. Rig Count Down
LEAD: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States dropped by 14 last week, to a total of 883, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today.
The rig count, the widely watched industry index of drilling activity, totaled 744 a year ago.
The rig count reached a peak of 4,500 in December 1981, at the height of the oil boom.


World Bank Criticizes Lag in Third World Aid
LEAD: The international strategy for resolving the third world's debt crisis is being jeopardized by the refusal of private banks to cooperate and by lower-than-expected economic growth in the industrial world, according to a World Bank report.


Boeing Gets $3.69 Billion Plane Order
LEAD: As expected, the International Lease Finance Corporation today awarded the Boeing Company three-quarters of a $5 billion airliner order, the largest order ever for commercial jetliners.
The European consortium Airbus Industrie won the remainder.


Prices of Soybeans and Corn Are Up Their Daily Limits
LEAD: Dry weather over the Grain Belt, dwindling crop surpluses, inventory building by food processors and speculative buying combined yesterday to send soybean and corn futures prices soaring by their daily permissible limits.


Syrians Delay Move in Beirut
LEAD: The Syrian Army delayed its deployment in southern Beirut today while Syrian and Iranian officials met in Damascus to discuss ways to avert a head-on collision between the Syrians and the Iranian-backed Party of God.


Police Officer Is Suspended
LEAD: A 27-year-old probationary police officer was suspended yesterday on charges that he used unnecessary force in subduing an emotionally disturbed patient at Elmhurst General Hospital in Queens, the police said.
Officer Stephen Benner, appointed to the force in July 1987, struck the patient, a 24-year-old woman from Jackson Heights, Queens, in the face after she spit at him, the police said.


Doctors Can Sue In Peer Reviews, Justices Declare
LEAD: In a case of great importance to the medical profession, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that hospital peer review committees are not absolutely immune from antitrust suits brought by the doctors they penalize.


In Quest for Fusion Energy, 2 Rival Techniques Fight for the Spotlight
LEAD: FOR decades the costly field of controlled nuclear fusion has been rocked by ups and downs, promise and problems.
But scientists are now confident enough of success to embark, albeit cautiously, on building a new generation of machines that would ignite fusion fuel for the first time, releasing controlled bursts of energy.


Devils Aim to Join The N.H.L.'s Elite
LEAD: Although the Devils fell a game short of playing the Edmonton Oilers for the Stanley Cup, they are still quite a distance from the upper echelon of the National Hockey League.

28 Injured in Cable Car Crash
LEAD: A crowded cable car heading downhill in light rain rammed the rear of a truck stopped at a red light today, injuring at least 28 people.

Pepitone to Begin 6-Month Jail Term
LEAD: Joe Pepitone, visibily nervous, was led out of a Brooklyn courtroom in handcuffs yesterday to begin serving a six-month jail sentence for his 1986 conviction for possession of Quaaludes and drug paraphernalia.


Bush Assails Kerry on Drug Issue
LEAD: Vice President Bush today accused Senator John Kerry of disclosing potentially ''slanderous'' information implying that a Bush aide had knowledge of drug dealings involving the Nicaraguan rebels.


Dear Mr. Rakhmanin
LEAD:  Ivan Rakhmanin  Office of the Procurator  Moscow, U.S.S.R.  Dear Mr. Rakhmanin,


Favorite in May Is Favorite in Fall, Too
LEAD: While polls taken six months before the election cannot be taken as predictive of the ultimate outcome, surveys by The New York Times/CBS News Poll since it was established in 1976 suggest that the candidate whom the electorate loved in May was also its favorite in November.


Irving Wins Vote On Board
LEAD: The Irving Bank Corporation defeated a hostile takeover bid by the Bank of New York Company in a proxy fight whose results were announced yesterday.


By Design; Flowers and Fresh Greens
LEAD: Some fashion successes are easy to fathom, while others are not.
The fabric flower, fastened to a barrette, has replaced the bow as this season's most popular hair ornament, store spokesmen say.
Other fashion observers report spotting scarves, skirts and shirts blooming with big floral prints all over town, even on the formerly clad-all-in-black downtowners.


Industrial Output Rose 0.7% in April
LEAD: Output of the nation's factories, mines and utilities jumped seven-tenths of 1 percent in April after two months of virtually no growth, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
It was the biggest advance since a 1.1 percent surge in October.


Soviet Dance Troupe Visits East Harlem School
LEAD: Members of Merani, a dance group from Tbilisi, U.S.S.R., performing a Georgian folk dance yesterday at Public School 99.
The performance was part of a Soviet-American cultural exchange; last month a chess club from the school traveled to the Soviet Union. (NYT/Chester Higgins Jr.)

LEAD: For they covered the face of the whole land, so that the land was darkened, and they ate all the plants in the land and all the fruit of the trees which the hail had left; not a green thing remained, neither tree nor plant of the field, through all the land of Egypt.'' Exodus 10:3.


Our Towns; Imagine a Light On Your Head At the Y.W.C.A.
LEAD: The Women's Network has been meeting at the Y.W.C.A. here for years.
Eighty percent of the women are college graduates, 40 percent have advanced degrees.
Two-thirds earn more than $40,000, 20 percent more than $75,000.
At the start of meetings, these businesswomen introduce themselves.
They work for Texaco, Merrill Lynch, New York Telephone, I.B.M.


Clayton Fox Nenno, Priest, 69
LEAD: The Rev.
Clayton Fox Nenno, a Jesuit priest and a former teacher at St.
Peter's Preparatory School in Jersey City, died of heart failure Thursday after surgery at Arden Hill Hospital in Goshen, N.Y.
He was 69 years old and lived at the Gonzaga Seven Springs Jesuit Community in Monroe, N.Y.


National Gallery to Show Jasper Johns Drawing
LEAD: The National Gallery of Art plans to mount a retrospective of the drawings of Jasper Johns in mid-May 1990 for his 60th birthday, something it has rarely done for the works of a living artist.


Texaco Says It Is Talking With Icahn
LEAD: Texaco Inc. announced yesterday that it was engaged in talks with Carl C. Icahn, its largest shareholder, in an effort to resolve their differences over the company's future.


Making Trade Data More Precise
LEAD: In addition to the traditional work of foiling drug smugglers and collecting more than a half-billion dollars a year in import duties, A. Robert Beikirch has a new priority: helping to improve America's trade statistics.


Steel Production Down
LEAD: Steel production fell to 1.99 million tons in the week ended Saturday, a decrease of 1.8 percent from the previous week's 2.03 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The industry's production amounted to 92.9 percent of capacity during the week, compared with 94.6 percent in the previous week.

Biaggi Is Endorsed By Bronx Democrats Despite a Conviction
LEAD: Representative Mario Biaggi was endorsed for renomination yesterday by Bronx Democratic leaders as part of a strategy to retain control over his Congressional seat, which has been threatened by his racketeering trial, a prior conviction and the threat of expulsion from the House.


New Yankee Call: Getcha Fresh Shrimp!
LEAD: Robert Brown was getting a pregame snack at Yankee Stadium last weekend.
For the first time in stadium history, he had lots of choices - sandwiches, pizza, hamburgers, chicken fingers, egg rolls or french fries.
He could drink an imported beer, like Dos Equis.
He could even eat clams or shrimp, served from a raw bar in little plastic boats.


Review/Television; Program Links C.I.A. to Drug Trafic
LEAD: Does the Central Intelligence Agency assist and even encourage drug smugglers? ''Frontline,'' on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight, says it does.
Secret wars and the narcotics trade apparently go together.
Drug lords have helped finance clandestine operations, the program charges, for 40 years.


Skier Retires
LEAD: Debbie Armstrong, who may be best remembered for her unrestrained glee after winning a gold medal in the giant slalom at the 1984 Winter Olympic Games in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, has announced her retirement from the United States Ski Team.
In two of the last three seasons, she was bothered by leg injuries, and she finished 13th in the giant slalom at Calgary in February.


Inmates Release Last 2 Hostages, Ending 3-Day Siege in Oklahama
LEAD: Inmates at a medium-security state prison released their last two hostages today, ending a three-day prison riot in which they seized eight hostages.


Gulf Insurance Rate Cut
LEAD: Lloyd's of London has cut war-risk rates for general cargoes in much of the southwest Persian Gulf, it said today.
The new rate for non-oil cargoes, which took effect Thursday, is 0.25 percent of the cargo's value, down from 0.30 percent.
The rate for oil cargoes remains unchanged at 0.375 percent.


Chemistry of Seeing
LEAD: USING pulses of laser light that last for only six millionths of one billionth of a second, scientists have directly observed a fundamental chemical reaction that permits animals to see.


For Travelers, Milk From Immunized Cows
LEAD: SCIENTISTS have devised ways to enrich cow's milk - in the cow - with antibodies that may prevent traveler's diarrhea, according to a new study.

LEAD: Cornell was invited while Hofstra, C. .W Post and Rutgers were not.
In essence, that was the selection process for the 12-team field for the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I lacrosse tournament.

LEAD: Because of security precautions and a great increase in visitors, guided tours of the Capitol have been sharply cut back, according the the Capitol Guide Service.

LEAD: The backbone of publishing is backlist books, those that will still be around years after this season's best sellers have been remaindered.
But best sellers are also important, providing not just prestige but help for a publisher's large overhead.

LEAD: The United States qualified for the soccer competition at the Seoul Olympics when Trinidad and Tobago beat El Salvador, 1-0, Sunday in a qualifying match.


Education: The College Reject; Several Factors Are Behind Growth In Number of Disappointed Students
LEAD: A senior at the Bronx High School of Science, one of the most selective high schools in the country, has a 93 average, three varsity letters, 1,490 out of a possible 1,600 on his Scholastic Aptitude Tests and has never missed a day of school.
Yet this New York student has just been rejected by Harvard, Yale, Stanford and Cornell.


FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
LEAD: New York City plans to sell about $200 million in general obligation bonds by competitive bidding no later than June 30, according to Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin.


Hole in Arctic Ozone Is Feared
LEAD: A Canadian researcher says that a hole in the ozone layer may be developing in the stratosphere near the North Pole each winter just as a similar hole is created over the South Pole.


Georgia Pacific
LEAD: The Georgia Pacific Corporation is offering $200 million of 10 1/8 percent notes, due in 2000, at a price of 99.85 to yield 10.146 percent, through a group of underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers.
Noncallable for seven years, the notes yield about 1.07 percentage points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

LEAD: In what has become a springtime ritual here, more than 1,000 landlords rallied outside the State Capitol today and then fanned out through its corridors to lobby against a variety of rent-regulation bills.

Stefan Edberg of Sweden, defeated Eric Jelen of West Germany, 6-1, 6-4.
Carl-Uwe Steeb of West Germany upset Anders Jarryd of Sweden, 7-6, 6-1.

Feedlot Cattle Up 4%
LEAD: Cattle being fed for the slaughter market as of May 1 in the seven leading beef states totaled 7.5 million head, up 4 percent from a year ago and 6 percent from two years ago, the Agriculture Department said on Monday.
As of May 1, feedlot inventories were larger than a year earlier in five states and down in two.

Connors Withdraws
LEAD: Jimmy Connors, the fifth-ranked player in the world, has withdrawn from the French Open, which starts Monday, because of an injured right foot.
Connors, 35, first suffered the injury before the United States Open last August.
He aggravated the injury three weeks ago.
The French Open is the only Grand Slam tournament he has failed to win.

LEAD: THE Chino Farm, 25 miles north of San Diego in a lush valley called Rancho Santa Fe, has taken on something of a cult status among food lovers across the country.

It was the highest monthly total since 1981.

Colombian Mayor Shot Dead
LEAD: A member of a leftist Colombian party who was elected to a mayor's office two months ago has been assassinated in the city of Medellin, the police said Tuesday.
Elkin de Jesus Martinez of the Patriotic Union, mayor of Remedios, a mining town in the northeastern province of Antioquia, was shot to death Sunday in a Medellin hotel lobby by two killers who escaped in a waiting car.

LEAD: Total energy use in the 12 nations of the European Community rose nine-tenths of a percent in 1987 from 1986, Eurostat, the community's statistics agency, said today.

Home Loan Bonds
LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Banks are offering $3.18 billion of bonds separated into one-, three- and five-year maturities, through various securities dealers.
The bonds are priced at par.
A $1.25 billion issue of one-year securities, due in 1989, yields 7.75 percent; $1.14 billion of a three-year issue, due in 1991, yields 8.50 percent, while $790 million of a five-year issue, due in 1993, yields 8.90 percent.

'Windsor Fallout': Jewels as Investment
LEAD: LAST October, two days after the stock market plunge, a 64.83-carat diamond was sold at Christie's for $6.4 million, the highest price ever paid at auction for a gem.
Last month, that record was broken by the sale of a 85.51-carat diamond for $9.13 million at Sotheby's.
The same Sotheby's auction set records with the prices fetched by a pink diamond ($4.73 million) and a cultured pearl necklace ($1.265 million).

Review/Music; Metier of Modern Dance
LEAD: There is music that demands to be danced - almost anything by Tchaikovsky, for instance - and other music that dancers must bend to their purposes.

A Way to Neutralize Toxic Waste Sites
LEAD: Toxic waste sites are often difficult to clean up, particularly when the wastes have seeped deep into the ground.
The Environmental Protection Agency, working with two private companies, recently demonstrated a technique to neutralize PCB's at a site at Hialeah, Fla., by boring holes into the ground and injecting a neutralizing chemical and cement.

Canadian Agency Wins Top Prize for Billboards
LEAD: For the first time in the 46-year history of the Obie Awards for outdoor advertising, a Canadian agency has received the top prize, for its billboard for McDonald's of Montreal.


Backers Fail to Get Lethal Injection Bid On California Ballot
LEAD: Backers of a measure that would allow the terminally ill patient to request a lethal injection from a physican have failed to gather enough signatures to place the measure on the November ballot in California.


Warner Signs Lorimar Pact
LEAD: Warner Communications Inc. and the Lorimar Telepictures Corporation announced today that they had signed a definitive agreement for Warner to acquire Lorimar, producer of ''Dallas'' and other hit TV shows, in a stock swap.


Robinson Hurt
LEAD: Manager Frank Robinson, who has a ruptured disk in his back, was hospitalized in Baltimore yesterday and will not be back to manage before Saturday.
Elrod Hendricks, the Orioles' bullpen coach, will guide the team over the next four games.
Hendricks, 47 years old, has been in the Orioles' organization for 18 and a half years as a player and a coach.

LEAD: *
Animed Inc., Roslyn, L.I., a veterinary clinical service and diagnostic company, appointed Larry P. Rapp chief financial officer.


Macmillan Gets a Bid From Bass
LEAD: The Robert M. Bass Group of Texas said yesterday that it had made an unsolicited offer to acquire Macmillan Inc., the New York-based publishing and information services company, for $64 a share, or about $1.6 billion.


Pennsylvania Bond Yields Range From 5% to 7.65%
LEAD: The largest competitive deal yesterday was a $155 million Pennsylvania general obligation bond offering, which was awarded to an underwriting group led by Prudential-Bache Securities.


Israel Awaits Modern Plague
LEAD: Israel set up emergency telephone hot lines Tuesday and prepared insecticide-spraying planes to fly into action against a possible plague of locusts, the desert insects dreaded since biblical times.
Only a small number of locusts were sighted in southern Israel and the Jordan River valley, but officials warned of a possible larger invasion from the south.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Foote, Cone In European Joint Venture
LEAD: FOOTE, CONE &amp; BELDING COMMUNICATIONS, a company with a venerable American heritage, is going to form an alliance with Publicis S.A. of Paris, that includes shared equity, an exchange of board members and the creation of an European joint venture with $2 billion in billings.


Federal Insurance Urged for Long-Term Care
LEAD: A Brookings Institution study recommended today that Federal social insurance replace charity care in paying for the rising cost of long-term health care for elderly people who are disabled.


What's in a Name?
LEAD: Edmund Morris, the authorized biographer of President Reagan, has a concern.
In a capital where the chief of state is commonly referred to as Ron, or even Dutch, where the Speaker of the House goes by Jim and the Senate minority leader Bob, Mr.
Morris has raised his voice against ''the unasked-for abbreviation of our proper names.


Site in Hiss-Chambers Case Now a Landmark
LEAD: Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel, rejecting the opinion of an advisory committee, granted landmark status today to a key site in the celebrated espionage case involving Whittaker Chambers and Alger Hiss.

Review/Film; The Many Kinds of Division in Israel
LEAD: In its exasperatingly prolix and tendentious way, ''Shattered Dreams'' accents the growing political, economic, social and religious divisions that are putting dangerous strains on Israeli democracy.
The painfully timely British-made documentary, which opens at Film Forum 1 today, is filled with confrontations between Arabs and Israelis, hard-liners and Peace Now demonstrators, religious zealots and people who drive on the Sabbath.

LEAD: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes fell by as much as a point in fairly light trading yesterday, as market participants reacted negatively to the implications of a report showing a big drop in the nation's merchandise trade deficit in March.

LEAD: The dollar advanced against all major foreign currencies yesterday on an unexpectedly sharp drop in the nation's trade deficit in March, while the pound plunged after a cut in the British base lending rate.

Review/Folk Music; The Songs of Bulgaria
LEAD: Wondrous, and not always invidious, are the ways of fashion.
Bulgarian folk music, and especially that country's keening, nasal, dissonant women's singing, has been a staple of record collectors for decades.
But in the last year, two disks were released in the United States - Nonesuch's ''Mystere des Voix Bulgares'' and Hannibal's ''Balkana'' - that became all the rage among pop stars, college radio stations, alternative weeklies and magazines and other arbiters of hip.

Correction
LEAD: A recipe and a chart with the Microwave Cooking column in The Living Section on May 4 gave incorrect instructions for sweet custard.
In step 2 of the recipe, the mixture should be divided among four custard cups.
The times given in the chart are for cooking in the four custard cups, not in a four-cup measure.

LEAD: IT is confusing enough to decide what your diet as an adult should be: we are told to eat more fiber and less fat, to drink skim milk and not to eat eggs more than twice a week.

Mr.
Meese may even have been right to want him out if he thought his aide was privately commenting on Mr.
Meese's plight with not wholly flattering candor.
What's astonishing about the firing is its insensitivity.

Education; Lessons
LEAD: College administrators can be much more than just the plotters of policy and budgets.

LEAD:  Selected Poems of Anne Sexton  Edited by Diane Wood Middlebrook and Diana Hume George  266 pages.
Houghton Mifflin Company. $21.95.
I am filling the room  with the words from my pen.
Words leak out of it like a miscarriage.
I am zinging words out into the air  and they come back like squash balls.

Gold Output Up in 1987
LEAD: Gold production in the non-Communist world rose 4 percent last year, to a record 1,341 metric tons, Samuel Montagu &amp; Company said today.
Mines in North America and Australia accounted for the increase from 1986's 1,290 tons.
South African output, affected by strikes, declined.

F.C.C. Approves Atlantic Cable Plan
LEAD: The Federal Communications Commission yesterday approved plans by an international group of telecommunications companies to build a new trans-Atlantic undersea cable that would go into service in 1991.
The fiber optic cable, known as TAT-9, will carry 80,000 simultaneous telephone calls, or about twice the capacity of the TAT-8 cable scheduled to go into operation between the United States and Europe this year.

License Revoked
LEAD: The thoroughbred training license of Robert DeBonis has been revoked by the New York State Racing and Wagering Board.
The license was revoked for ''attempt to commit a fraud in connection with racing and breeding,'' according to an announcement yesterday by Richard Corbisiero Jr., the board's chairman.

LEAD: Detroit advanced to the Eastern Conference final tonight as Bill Laimbeer scored 13 of his 19 points in the fourth quarter to lift the Pistons to a 102-95 victory over the Chicago Bulls.

Why Chess And Not Bridge?
LEAD: Graybeard former undergraduates who, in the 30's, majored in Benny Goodman and minored in bridge will be dismayed to hear what the Aquarian Age has done to their sport.
Alan Truscott, The Times's bridge columnist, recently reported on a study showing that for every bridge player on campus now, there are eight chess players.

LEAD: General Mills Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Talbots women's apparel chain to the Jusco Company, a large Japanese chain-store retailer, for $325 million in cash.
It will be the first major purchase by a Japanese company of an American retailer.

3 Couples Who Heard The Call of the Inn
LEAD: THE dream of operating an inn has seduced all kinds of people over the years.
In recent decades innkeeping has been perceived as an escape from the high anxieties of corporate life.
Some have been wise to follow their dream, others not, as the stories of Rabbit Hill's three most recent innkeepers attest.

LEAD: A schoolteacher charged with illegally shipping guns from Washington State to Pakistan for Afghan rebels can use classified documents to support his contention that the United States Government encouraged his activities, a Federal appeals court ruled today.

LEAD: Syria said today that it was suspending plans to deploy troops in Beirut's southern suburbs, the scene of 13 days of fighting between rival Shiite Moslem militias.


On Death ad te Job of Getting There
LEAD: In her new novel, ''Second Chances,'' Alice Adams describes one character's thoughts: ''Death, the idea of death, is not what she so much minds . . . dying will be a fairly simple matter, she believes, a losing of consciousness, quite possibly welcome, like sleep.
But the stages on the way to death, the ways that the world has now worked out for people to die, there's the real horror: hospitals, surgery, anesthesia.

LEAD: Brazilian negotiators suspended talks with foreign commercial banks today amid reports of differences over whether a new debt restructuring package should be linked to an agreement with the International Monetary Fund.

LEAD: Federal regulators will provide at least $2 billion to the Southwest Savings Association, a Dallas savings and loan, to help it acquire four insolvent Texas savings institutions in a deal worth $4.4 billion, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.


Review/Jazz; Quintet's Bop Standards
LEAD: The Metropolitan Bopera House, a virtually unknown jazz quintet, deserves more attention than the notoriety it has attracted as a result of being sued by the Metropolitan Opera Association over its name.
The group's members - John Marshall on trumpet, Ralph Lalama on tenor saxophone, Tardo Hammer on piano, John Weber on bass and Tom Melito on drums - are revivalists on a mission: they want to restore the overlooked compositions of jazz's hard-bop era to their proper place.

LEAD: Sin Cha Hong put her audience through a lot when she presented her new ''Seraphim'' on Friday night at the Joyce Theater, performed by her Laughing Stone company in the 3-D at the Joyce festival.
Hers was a look at humanity, ironically or sadly the highest angels of the dance's title, that unfolded at such an uncompromisingly slow and repetitious pace to a score of such uncompromising horror that she lost a good part of the audience by the time ''Seraphim'' had reached its eerie conclusion.

Fiat Earnings Up in '87
LEAD: The Italian auto maker Fiat S.p.A. reported today that its 1987 earnings rose 9.8 percent on the strength of higher sales.
The results for Italy's largest private company included the recently acquired Alfa Romeo unit and Snia-BPD, the textile and military group.
Fiat reported earnings of 2.37 trillion lire, or $1.9 billion, in 1987, up from 2.16 trillion lire a year earlier.

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  MARKETS  The stock market continued its sharp retreat amid growing concern over higher interest rates.
The Dow Jones industrial averaage fell 35.32 points, or 1.8 percent, to 1,951.09, the lowest level since early February.
Broader market indexes also fell and declining stocks far outnumbered advancing ones.

Union's Victory at Harvard Seen as Spur to Labor Drive
LEAD: Union organizers at Harvard University, riding high after winning the right to represent the university's 3,400 clerical and technical workers, are moving to the next phase: planning for contract talks.


Roscoe Moss to Pay Fine
LEAD: Government regulators said today that the Roscoe Moss Company had agreed to pay a record $500,000 civil fine to settle charges that it had failed to comply with Federal antitrust rules from 1984 to 1986.


Reviews/Music; A Puerto Rican Touch
LEAD: Yomo Toro brought the cuatro, a 10-string miniature guitar, out of Puerto Rican jibaro, or hillbilly, music and into modern dance halls.
With his electrified cuatro, which sounds like a mandolin that's been pumping iron, and his speed-demon technique, he makes the cuatro a lead instrument for salsa and hybrids of other pop styles from all around the Americas.

LEAD: Peter B. Desnoes, 45, who was to become the next chairman of the Television Bureau of Advertising, resigned abruptly from its board after a meeting in Bermuda last week.


SCHOOL BUSES GET HIGH SAFETY MARK
LEAD: Despite the crash that killed 27 people in Carrollton, Ky., on Saturday, school buses are the nation's safest mode of surface transportation, according to Federal, state and independent safety experts.


Award for Gilbert
LEAD: Rod Gilbert, the former Ranger, has won the Canadian Society of New York Hockey Achievement Award for 1988.
The award, established in 1983, is given for outstanding contributions to hockey.
Previous winners were Clarence Campbell, Gordie Howe, Maurice Richard, Bobby Hull and Jean Beliveau.
Gilbert, who played his entire career, from 1960 to 1978, with the Rangers, is the leading scorer in the history of the franchise.

Cocaine Jury Sees Tapes
LEAD: The jury in the cocaine-smuggling case of Carlos Lehder Rivas asked today to see two videotapes of the defendant, including one in which he called drugs a weapon against imperialism.
Federal District Judge Howell W. Melton allowed the review, on the jury's sixth day of deliberations.
Mr.
Lehder, 38 years old, and his co-defendant, Jack Carlton Reed, 57, of San Pedro, Calif., are charged with conspiring to smuggle 3.3 tons of cocaine into the United States from Colombia from 1978 to 1980.

Review/Theater; Kay Ballard Flies Solo
LEAD: Kaye Ballard, at age 61, still bubbles with the enthusiasm of a starstruck teen-ager.
For her, the era of vaudeville and of stars like Judy Garland and Mabel Mercer looms perennially fresh.
Her new one-woman show, ''Working 42d Street at Last'' at the tiny Kaufman Theater (534 West 42d Street) is an appropriately charming anachronism - a sophisticated 50's nightclub act expanded into a 100-minute evening that weaves together songs, jokes and impressions.

Australian Trade Gain
LEAD: Australia's trade picture improved dramatically in April, with the current account deficit narrowing to a smaller than expected $396 million (Australian), or $302 million (American), the Statistics Bureau said today.
The deficit in March stood at $1.09 billion (Australian), which was revised from $1.18 billion.

Life in the 30's
LEAD: I HAVE noticed that there are a great many more young people around than there once were.
By young people I do not mean people who are children, or who are not elderly, or who have not reached the age of consent.
I mean those people who are egregiously, aggressively young, the kind of people who tell you, bright-eyed, that they would like to do what you do when they grow up, or who treat you with respect and call you ''ma'am,'' or who see fit to mention that their parents often listen to the Beatles, too.

LEAD: Gondolas from Venice as part of the New York International Festival of the Arts?
That's right, says Martin E. Segal, the festival's founder and chairman.


Army Reports Problems in Its New Beretta Pistol
LEAD: The Army says it stopped accepting deliveries of its new 9-millimeter Beretta pistol last November because of cracking in the frame and that it is now investigating a second problem involving the gun's slide mechanism.


Soviet Ship Fire Toll Is 11
LEAD: The death toll in a fire on the Soviet cruise liner Priamurye reached 11 today, with 35 people injured.
The 4,870-ton Priamurye, sailing from Vladivostok with 129 crew members and 295 passengers, was in Osaka harbor on a three-week tour of Japan when the fire broke out.
Japanese firefighters struggled for 11 hours to put out the fire.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  TENNIS  U.S.
Gains Final: The United States defeated France, 3-0, yesterday to advance to the final of the $750,000 World Team Cup in Dusseldorf, West Germany.
The Americans clinched the victory when Tim Mayotte defeated Thierry Tulasne, 6-4, 4-6, 6-2, and Aaron Krickstein beat Tarik Benhabiles, 6-4, 6-7, 6-2, in singles.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Corrections
LEAD: A chart on Monday showing the number of epople on welfare in New York City carried an incorrect explanation.
The figures referred to the number of welfare cases, not individuals on welfare.


A Steel Quota Divides the Industry
LEAD: Big Steel and Little Steel bickered over import protection at today's session of the annual gathering of the American steel industry.


Regan's Book Gives Harcourt a Lift
LEAD: The huge success of Donald T. Regan's ''For the Record,'' which a week after its official publication date has jumped to the No. 1 spot on the best-seller list, could not have come at a better time for its publisher, Harcourt Brace Jovanovich.


FRANCE RESTORING ITS TIES WITH IRAN
LEAD: President Francois Mitterrand ordered the Socialist Government today to restore diplomatic ties with Iran, fulfilling a pledge made by the previous Government for Iran's help in winning the release of the last three French hostages in Lebanon.


Battles Erupt in South Korea As Protesters Mark Uprising
LEAD: Thousands of protesters calling for the overthrow of President Roh Tae Woo fought police with firebombs and rocks today as rallies were held to mark the eighth anniversary of the anti-Government uprising in the southern city of Kwangju.


Man Charged in Plot on Jackson Suggested Others Were Involved
LEAD: A law-enforcement official said today that a Missouri man who is accused of plotting to kill the Rev.
Jesse Jackson made a statement to an informer implying that others had done the high-level planning.


Editor of Brooklyn College Paper Caught in Imbroglio Over Content
LEAD: As a student at Brooklyn College and editor of a weekly newspaper at the college, The Kingsman, Michael Golub has been receiving an education about the newspaper business.


Finances of Minister Charged in Rape Being Checked
LEAD: The Rev.
Thomas Streitferdt at arraignment Monday on charges that he raped two teen-age members of his congregation.
Officials said yesterday that the minister, the pastor of the True Church of God at Third Avenue and 127th Street, has been the target of an investigation into his finances and lavish living.


Teheran Claims Gains in Northeastern Iraq
LEAD: Iranian gunboats attacked a Japanese-owned tanker in the Strait of Hormuz today and Iran said its forces killed or wounded 2,000 Iraqis in a new offensive in a rugged part of northeastern Iraq.


Arthur Long, 61, Consultant on Takeovers
LEAD: Arthur F. Long, a consultant on investor relations, died of cancer Monday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.
He was 61 years old, lived in Garden City, L.I., and also had homes in Quogue, L.I., and North Palm Beach, Fla.


U.S. Hopes for 3 Modest Pacts On Arms at Moscow Summit
LEAD: The United States hopes that several modest agreements on providing notice of missile tests and on nuclear testing will be signed at the summit meeting in Moscow, senior Administration officials said today.


Shift on Campaign Financing by Cuomo
LEAD: Governor Cuomo, increasing the chances for adopting public financing of statewide election campaigns, has agreed to consider legislation that does not include public financing of legislative races, but that simply lowers contribution limits for those contests, his aides said today.


New Plan for Media General Seeks Broadcasting Spinoff
LEAD: Media General Inc. yesterday received a recapitalization proposal that would involve a spinoff of its broadcasting and cable operations into a new company.

Meritor Financial
LEAD: Meritor Financial Group's drive to restore profits is being slowed by rising interest rates, Frederick S. Hammer, chairman of the troubled savings and loan institution, said.
After today's annual meeting, he said that if current interest rates held, ''we are not going to make it.'' Mr.
Hammer declined to predict when Meritor would return to sustained profitability but said that ''we are flirting'' with the break-even level.

LEAD: The Intermediate Range Nuclear Forces Treaty, which arrived on the Senate floor Tuesday, has on occasion encountered bizarre negotiating obstacles - for example the flap over ''osnashcheniye,'' a Russian term that can mean ''armed,'' ''armament,'' ''equipped'' or ''equipment,'' depending, it seems, on who does the translating.

Unicycling Jugglers
LEAD: Experts and amateurs will be taking part in the First New York Festival of Juggling and Unicycle Arts, tomorrow from 10:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. at the Naumburg Band Shell in Central Park, at 72d Street.
The free event is sponsored by the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation, the Internationl Jugglers Association and the International Unicycle Federation.


Indonesia's Debt to Rise
LEAD: Indonesia's total external debt is projected to hit $50 billion this year, with debt repayments by Southeast Asia's largest nation forecast to rise sharply, the World Bank said today.
But it said that a Government program to wean the economy away from dependence on oil was working, with non-oil exports expected to increase rapidly, and that the debt picture was not as serious as in many other heavily indebted nations.

Pontiac No. 2 at G.M.
LEAD: The Pontiac Motor division has replaced Oldsmobile as the General Motors Corporation's No. 2 car-selling division, behind Chevrolet.
Pontiac has also become the third-best-selling nameplate in the auto industry, behind Chevrolet and Ford.
According to G.M.'s latest sales reports, through May 10, the Pontiac division's sales have increased 3.9 percent for the 1988 model year, while Oldsmobile's sales have fallen 12.9 percent in the same period.

AGS Computers
LEAD: AGS Computers Inc. of Mountainside, N.J. said it had ended talks about acquiring C3 Inc., a computer systems integration company based in Herndon, Va.
It gave no reason for the decision.
AGS had agreed in principle in March to acquire C3 for $15.75 a share, or about $157.5 million.
C3's shares fell $2.875 yesterday, to $10, in New York Stock Exchange trading.

Noncallable for the life of the issue, the notes yield about nine-tenths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

They thought they had invested in a sure thing: a utility providing electricity to a booming suburb.

Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 425 money market mutual funds increased $3.70 billion, to $274.12 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Assets of the 116 institutional funds increased $2 billion, to $74.44 billion.
Assets of the 212 general purpose funds were up $1.05 billion, to $83.9 billion.


NEW YORK REACHES A TENTATIVE PACT WITH CUSTODIANS
LEAD: The New York City Board of Education yesterday reached a tentative settlement with the school custodians' union, and board officials say they believe it will lead to major improvements in the physical conditions of dilapidated school buildings.


Sports People; N.H.L. Award Finalists
LEAD: Wayne Gretzky, who has won the Hart Trophy as the National Hockey League's most valuable player in each of his first eight seasons, is in the running to get it again.
Gretzky, along with the Oiler goalie Grant Fuhr and the Pittsburgh center Mario Lemieux, are finalists for the award.
Kelly Hrudey and Bryan Trottier of the Islanders and Jan Erixon of the Rangers were named as finalists for other awards.

LEAD: Janos Kadar, the leader of Hungary's Communist Party, is facing a severe challenge for the leadership from Karoly Grosz, the man whom he installed as Prime Minister last June, party figures reported today.

LEAD: A special Labor Department committee will study the problems facing elderly workers, Secretary of Labor Ann McLaughlin said today.

Review/Film; 'Palace,' a South African Drama
LEAD: Shot in the stark, underpopulated style of a drama seen on public television, the South African film ''Saturday Night at the Palace'' serves as a primer for the roots of that country's racial strife.
It is, however, a very obvious and oversimplified work, essentially a three-character play that sustains a one-note quality all the way through.

Review/Art; The Provocative Contradictions of Markus Raetz
LEAD: Markus Raetz will represent Switzerland in next month's Venice Biennale.
His work is provocative, contradictory and perverse.
It asks us both to slow down and to keep moving.
It appears to be anti-dogmatic, yet it is insistent upon an esthetic, one of incompleteness.
It makes a point of its openness, but it is every bit as controlling as the masterpiece mentality it is reacting against.


Ex-Chief of Bullock's Considers His Options
LEAD: Four years ago, Allen I. Questrom abruptly resigned as chairman and chief executive of Rich's Inc., the big Atlanta department store, to spend seven months traveling around the world and contemplating life.


Sports People; Torres Steps Down
LEAD: Jose Torres said yesterday that his decision to resign as chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission after four years turned on a desire to resume his writing career, including writing a biography of the heavyweight champion, Mike Tyson.

LEAD: Lloyd Daniels, who played basketball at four New York City high schools but never earned a diploma, has been dismissed from the Waitemata team of Auckland in the New Zealand Basketball Federation on grounds that he missed practices and engaged in heavy drinking.

Review/Music; A Survey of Cuban Song, in Tropicana Revue
LEAD: Tradition and kitsch, salsa and showgirls swirl together in the giddy Tropicana revue at the Beacon Theater, Broadway at 74th Street, through Sunday.
More than 60 dancers, singers and musicians from the Tropicana are appearing in New York for the first time since the Havana nightclub was founded in 1939 - and to judge by its export company, the Tropicana mixes tourist attractions with a cultural conscience.


Reviews/Film; Images of Veiny Eyeballs And Desperate Goldfish
LEAD: ''White of the Eye'' could be described as a film about everything -about men and women, guilt and innocence, freedom and destiny - but then it could also be described as a film about nothing.
It's the work of Donald Cammell, well known in 1970 as the co-director of ''Performance'' and best known as (in the words of one British journalist) an ''occluded talent'' since then.


Economic Scene; Market Reaction To Trade Figures
LEAD: THE news this week that the United States trade deficit fell dramatically in March, to $9.75 billion, sent the stock market reeling.
A month earlier the unexpected news that the trade deficit soared in February, to $13.8 billion from $12.4 billion in January, also made the market fall.


Referee Says He's Bitter
LEAD: Dave Newell, the National Hockey League's senior referee, said he was angry because he was not chosen for the Stanley Cup finals and believed that the league was retaliating.

Review/Film; 'Willow,' a George Lucas Production
LEAD: Today's films have a way of being supplanted overnight.
However bright or ground breaking it may be, a new film can be followed in a flash by another that copies and comments on the first, and this process can repeat and repeat itself.
So five or six stages of fantasy film making separate the 1977 ''Star Wars'' from the new ''Willow,'' although George Lucas made his plans for both projects at roughly the same time.

Reviews/Film; Terror by Telephone
LEAD: ''Call Me,'' the wrong number now at the Baronet and other theaters, is about Anna, who gets a panting phone call one night (''I want you, I want you, I want you.''), which soon develops into an aural relationship as she and the caller share their fantasies about imaginative uses for an orange.
The dirty talk is the more wholesome slice of Anna's story.

The young go anywhere they can find work.

Electric Rates Dip
LEAD: Commercial and industrial electric rates in the United States fell fractionally in the year ended April 30, a consulting firm said yesterday.
In its annual study, the firm, National Utility Service Inc. said the nation's 24 largest investor-owned utilities charged their nonresidential customers an average of 6.28 cents a kilowatt-hour over the 12-month period, compared with 6.29 cents a year earlier.

Chrysler Air Bags
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation has begun installing driver's-side air bags as standard equipment on three of its models and will add them this week to three more, becoming the first United States auto maker to make air bags standard equipment.
Federal safety regulations require increased use of passive restraints, such as air bags, which inflate in event of a collision, or automatic seat belts.

Restaurants
LEAD: There are a handful of restaurants in town that, because of their view or viewpoint, capture the unflagging vitality of this metropolis - Windows on the World, the ''21'' Club, Four Seasons and River Cafe among them.
To this list must be added the Sea Grill at Rockefeller Center, a sophisticated subterranean setting facing the ice-skating rink (at this time of year, the area has become a graceful outdoor cafe).


Review/Art; Ilya Kabakov Portrays Communal Soviet Life
LEAD: ''Ten Characters'' is the title of an exhibition by Ilya Kabakov, a Soviet artist, at Ronald Feldman Fine Arts.
It has an amazing experience to offer.
Hardly are we inside the door than we are reminded of the Moscow Art Theater in its heyday, long years ago.
A complete environment is set before us, intact in its every last detail and yet shaped by a guiding imagination.

Review/Art; Arte Povera Installations: Engineering and Alchemy
LEAD: Gilberto Zorio, whose work is on view at the Sonnabend Gallery in SoHo, is a practitioner of Arte Povera, the unusually elegant and poetic installation art that emerged in Italy in the late 1960's and early 70's.
Like their American counterparts - such artists as Richard Serra, Robert Smithson and Robert Morris - the ''poveristi'' avoided portable, studio-made sculpture.

Reviews/Film; 'I Don't Give a Damn'
LEAD: ''I Don't Give a Damn'' is a soapy Israeli movie composed of the residue of better movies past.
It is about handsome Rafi (Ika Sohar), who is wounded in battle and loses the use of his legs. ''My story ends here in the hospital,'' says Rafi.
Promises, promises.
There is at least an hour more to go, which he spends raging against his condition, breaking things and being mean to the people who want most to help him - relatives, friends, other patients and, especially, pretty Nira (Anat Waxman).


Mavericks Gain Final; Jazz Ties Series; Mavericks 108, Nuggets 95
LEAD: Rolando Blackman scored 9 consecutive points in the fourth period tonight to lead the Dallas Mavericks into their first Western Conference championship series with a 108-95 victory over the Denver Nuggets.


OVERSEAS SPENDING BY U.S. COMPANIES SETS RECORD PACE
LEAD: The weak dollar, which has reduced the cost of manufacturing in the United States relative to that in other countries, should in theory be prompting American companies to halt or scale back expansion of their factories abroad, and even close some of them.

Man Convicted in Series of Rapes On the Basis of a 'Voice Lineup'
LEAD: A man accused of terrorizing the South Shore of Long Island in a four-year series of rapes and assaults was convicted today of 31 counts of rape and burglary, with his voice as the chief evidence against him.
It was the first time in New York State that a conviction was obtained based largely on a recorded ''voice lineup.


Review/Music; The Mozart Requiem In Alternative Version
LEAD: Mozart the man remains as much an enigma today as he must have been in his lifetime.
The exact size and cut of his musical genius are clear, but all the evidence as to his character and his deepest beliefs adds up to fog and ambiguity.
It is therefore fitting that his great final work, the unfinished Requiem, continues to be a maze of contradictions and blind alleys.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Chiat/Day Gets 3 Golds At Art Directors Club
LEAD: Chiat/Day, New York, won all three gold medals for television advertising awarded last night at the 67th annual awards presentation of the Art Directors Club.
They also won two of the five silver awards.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Comecon Pact Seen Near
LEAD: The European Community and the Soviet bloc's trade council are close to establishing official relations.


Uncommon Recognition
LEAD: The Veterans Administration recently broadened its program of paying for inscriptions citing valor awards on military headstones and markers and, as a result, a Medal of Honor winner from New Jersey is about to acquire his due.


London Journal; But for the Young, a Gypsy Would a-Traveling Go
LEAD: Bubbles Brazil is a matriarch with a mission that gleams like her gold earrings.
She is a leader of the Gypsy traveling folk who linger in odd macadam patches of outlying London districts, like Abbey Wood.
She is a proud Romany with a Cockney accent who loves the wanderer's life but has begun compromising lately for the grandchildren.

Soviet Strengthens Economic Links to Northern Afghanistan
LEAD: Some towns and villages in these arid northern Afghan plains have already been connected to the Soviet Union's electrical power grid.
The landscape is dotted with fertilizer factories, irrigation canals and natural gas pumping stations built with Soviet aid.

LEAD: The New York City Taxi and Limousine Commissioner, appointed less than two years ago by Mayor Koch, is expected to resign today to take a job in private industry, city and taxicab-industry officials said yesterday.

Sports of The Times; Oh, the Old Celtics

The Celtics?
In only the semifinals of the Eastern Conference playoffs?
Why, they've been in the National Basketball Association finals for the last four years running, and it appeared only last week that they might do it again.

LEAD: Notes from talks with New York City detectives:


Rainy-Day Blues Mount
LEAD: Bad weather is causing an overflow of major league doubleheaders and potential problems for pitching staffs.
Bad weather had forced the postponement of 28 games before yesterday.
Only 27 were wiped out last season.


8 3/4% Offering Set By Xerox Credit
LEAD: The Xerox Credit Corporation, a unit of the Xerox Corporation, is offering $150 million of 8 3/4 percent notes due in 1991 at a price of 99.95, to yield 8.77 percent, through a group of underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Marsteller Gains
LEAD: Burson-Marsteller has received the go-ahead from South Korea's Mnistry of Finance to open an office in Seoul, which brings its offices in Asia to seven.
The public relations firm had set up a small staff in Seoul a few years back to take care of the Seoul Olympic Organizing Committee account.


Fordam President Named to Election-Law Board
LEAD: The Koch administration has named the president of Fordham University to head the review board charged with administering and enforcing New York City's new law on public financing of municipal election campaigns, senior officials said yesterday.


Pop/Jazz; The Return Of Strayhorn And Carter
LEAD: In the last five years, the art of Benny Carter and Billy Strayhorn, two of jazz's greatest composers, has begun to reassert itself, center stage, after decades of benign neglect.


Review/Cabaret
LEAD: A pop singer who returns to the cabarets after 30 years of retirement is bound to be affected by such a long absence.
But while Monica Lewis, who is in Danny's Skylight Room at the Grand Sea Palace on West 46th Street) through tonight, is not the same singer that she was 30 years ago, she has skillfully retained her basic qualities as a performer.


Review/Theater; 'Wonderful Town'
LEAD: When Betty Comden and Adolph Green wrote the lyric ''Life is gay, life is sweet/Interesting people on Christopher Street,'' they were looking back to the idealized 1930's, when Greenwich Village was a crossroad between Ohio and Paris.
The tone of ''Wonderful Town,'' one of two New York musicals the lyricists wrote with Leonard Bernstein - the other, of course, is ''On the Town'' - is suffused with joyful innocence.


Weaver Arms Deal
LEAD: The Weaver Arms Corporation will make semiautomatic rifles in China that are similar to the Israeli Uzi.
Weaver, based in San Diego, will sell the first shipments of its 9-millimeter Nighthawk carbines in the United States and plans to sell the guns to American police agencies, private citizens and the military in developing nations, Robert Weaver, company president, said.

Review/Film; Australian Vagabond Comedy
LEAD: Not every road movie sends its characters off to do their rambling in a Bentley, but then ''Rikky and Pete'' is substantially out of the ordinary.
A charmingly offbeat comedy from Australia, it breaks the road-movie tradition at every turn.
The title characters are not runaway lovers or freewheeling pals; instead, they're a well-heeled brother and sister who've simply run out of options in Melbourne for the time being.

Reviews/Jazz; Adam Makowicz, His Piano and Friends
LEAD: The pianist Adam Makowicz began a series of four varied, nightly concerts at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday evening with a program of the music of Irving Berlin.
Mr.
Berlin's music has been inescapably ubiquitous since celebrations of his 100th birthday began last week, but Mr.
Makowicz managed to give a notably distinctive flavor to his performances.


Mellon Financial's $150 Million Issue
LEAD: The Mellon Financial Company, a unit of the Mellon Bank Corporation, is offering $150 million of floating-rate, rating-sensitive notes with a final maturity in 1993 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Victory for Flaxman
LEAD: Richard Flaxman Partners/ABP has been named to handle theCentral Federal Savings account.
The initial budget is $2 million, with other projects to be developed.
The other finalists were Altschiller Reitzfeld; Ephron, Raboy &amp; Tsao, and MGA.
The previous agency was Sturtevant &amp; Hildt.
The savings bank, with almost $2 billion in assets, has offices in Manhattan and in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.


Steel Industry Sees Decline
LEAD: Executives of several steel companies predicted today that industry shipments and profits would decline slightly in the second half of this year, saying they expected weaker overall demand from the automobile, appliance and home construction markets.

Review/Dance; Season's First 'Bayadere'
LEAD: The American Ballet Theater production of ''La Bayadere'' has proved to be one of the company's most popular staples.
And on Tuesday, when Ballet Theater presented the work at the Metropolitan Opera House for the first time this season, the three-act spectacle received a fine performance from Martine van Hamel as Nikiya, the young temple dancer or bayadere, Kevin McKenzie as Solor, who loves and is loved by her, and Cynthia Gregory as Gamzatti, the Rajah's daughter and Solor's fiancee.

Bridge
LEAD: The vast difference between ''single dummy'' and ''double dummy'' can be illustrated by the diagramed deal.

Cuba Seeks Extension
LEAD: The executive committee of the International Baseball Association has granted a request from the Cuban Olympic committee to extend by one week the entry deadline for teams that will participate in the Summer Olympics, an association official said.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration urged the Supreme Court today to use an expedited procedure reserved for cases of ''imperative public importance'' to decide the constitutionality of the new Federal system for sentencing convicted criminals.

Colombian Tied To Drug Empire Is Found Guilty
LEAD: Carlos Lehder Rivas, a reputed leader of a violent Colombian drug ring that is believed responsible for most of the cocaine brought to this country, was found guilty today of smuggling tons of cocaine into the United States.


Sugar Output Forecast
LEAD: World sugar production in 1988-89 is expected to be a record of about 103.9 million metric tons, slightly more than the 103.8 million tons produced in 1987-88, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday.
The latest estimate was revised downward from the department's first forecast issued on May 4, which indicated production at 104.1 million metric tons in 1988-89.


Corrections
LEAD: A music review on Sunday about the Riverside Opera Company's production of Zandonai's ''Giulietta e Romeo'' omitted the date of the final performance.
It will be at 3 P.M. this Sunday at Rutgers Presbyterian Church, 236 West 73d Street.


In Poland, Rumblings of More Liberalization
LEAD: Poland's Communist leadership appears to be facing increased pressure from within its ranks to step up the pace of change, following the resolution of strikes at major industrial installations last week.


Trial of Arizona Ex-Governor Begins
LEAD: Barnett Lotstein, left, and Michael Cudahy, prosecuting attorneys in the trial of former Gov.
Evan Mecham, as prospective jurors filled out questionnaires yesterday in Phoenix.
Mr.
Mecham, who was impeached earlier this year for misconduct, is being tried along with his brother on charges of concealing a $350,000 campaign loan.


BUSH AND REAGAN SEEM TO DISAGREE ON NORIEGA TALKS
LEAD: President Reagan and Vice President Bush seem to have agreed to disagree on how to deal with Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega, and aides to both men say further disputes between them are likely as the political campaign accelerates.

Elder Eases His Way Back Into Golf
LEAD: He plays less and has devoted practically no time to practice since suffering a heart attack three days before Thanksgiving, but the quality of Lee Elder's golf game is beginning to reach high standards again.


Senators Seeking to Overhaul War Powers Resolution
LEAD: The Senate majority leader and senior members of key Senate committees introduced legislation today to overhaul the War Powers Resolution, a 1973 law originally intended to give Congress a greater policy voice when American troops are introduced into hostile situations short of full-scale war.


Sasson Jeans Settlement
LEAD: Federal Bankruptcy Judge Burton Lifland yesterday approved a 100 percent repayment plan for creditors of Sasson Jeans Inc., despite the objections of Paul Guez, the company's founder.

About Real Estate; Rentals in Princeton Area Get Country Club Setting
LEAD: Traveling through East Windsor, N.J., a visitor might be forgiven for assuming that the attached homes just completed along One Mile Road are the usual suburban-style condominium developments that offer residents a country club setting with a plethora of recreational goodies.


Guy Lumia, 51, Violinist
LEAD: Guy Lumia, a violinist and one of the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra's two concertmasters, died of liver failure due to diabetes Wednesday at Roosevelt Hospital.
He was 51 years old, and lived in Manhattan.


12-Chef Farewell Meal for Claiborne
LEAD: Twelve of the country's leading chefs prepared a dinner at the Four Seasons restaurant in Manhattan on Tuesday night to honor Craig Claiborne, who recently announced his retirement as food editor of The New York Times.
The dinner - organized by Paul Kovi and Tom Margittai, owners of the Four Seasons, and Pierre Franey, a columnist for The Times and Mr.


17 of Suffolk's Legislators Denounce a Shoreham Deal
LEAD: All but one of Suffolk County's 18 legislators today denounced as an ''economic bailout'' the negotiated settlement being discussed by the Long Island Lighting Company and the State of New York that would result in a shutdown of the Shoreham nuclear power plant.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; TV Ads Up 12.6%
LEAD: The Television Bureau of Advertising reported that commercial television advertising in the first quarter of this year rose 12.6 percent, to $5.74 billion, from $5.1 billion in the period last year.
Network television advertising, which reflected expenditures of the Winter Olympics, totaled $2.46 billion in the first quarter, up 17.3 percent from $2.09 billion during the period in 1987.


In Taiwan, the Towering Chiang Image Is Losing Its Luster
LEAD: Even in death, Chiang Kai-shek still towers over this nation.
A vast marble memorial to the former President stands in the heart of Taipei.
At the center, poised high up a flight of stone steps, his robed figure smiles down beneficently.


At The Bar
LEAD: Thirty years ago Bruce Bromley, the legendary litigator of Cravath, Swaine &amp; Moore, regaled some Federal judges with tales from his early days in practice.
He recounted how he would exhaust the opposition by dragging out even the simplest cases ''almost to infinity,'' and how what was good for the client was also good for Cravath.


Reviews/Film; Manic Film Noir Thriller as Midnight Cult Film
LEAD: Billed as ''a film noir in living color,'' ''Kiss Daddy Good Night'' offers the expected seamy, noirish life that inevitably leads to murder.
But its unexpected heroine is a more threatening version of Susan Seidelman's harmlessly crooked downtown women.
Laura's life of petty crime owes something to ''Smithereens'' and ''Desperately Seeking Susan,'' though she has an unusually intriguing modus operandi.


To Our Readers
LEAD: A series of slowdowns and other job actions by the drivers' union have curtailed some distribution of The New York Times.
These actions are associated with contract negotiations, and The Times is unable to say how long the disruptions may continue.
We regret the inconvenience to our readers.

MCO-Maxxam Tie
LEAD: Charles E. Hurwitz, the Houston investor, completed the consolidation of two companies that he controls by merging MCO Holdings Inc. and Maxxam Group Inc.
The combination had been delayed because of shareholder litigation over the proposed terms.
Under the revised terms, MCO, a Los Angeles-based real estate and energy company, agreed to increase by $1 a share the cash that shareholders will receive.

LEAD: Japan and the United States remain very far apart in negotiations on the beef and citrus issue, the United States trade negotiator, Michael Smith, said today.

Security Tightened in Aruba As Drug Fugitive Is Arrested

Review/Film; Directors' Daydreams Become the Stuff of Opera
LEAD: Giuseppe Verdi never cried out ''I want my MTV,'' but he's gotten it anyhow.

The best of ''Aria'' isn't any more than cheerful kitsch, and a lot of it is junk.

IN FURS FOR FALL, A SHOCK OF PINK OR BLUE
LEAD: The basic coat for fall is 48 to 52 inches long, stops just above the ankles, swings easily from broad shoulders and is made of dark mink skins, most furriers agree.
Shorter coats, 38 to 48 inches long, are destined for the woman who already owns a fur coat, is not too tall, feels overwhelmed by the longer styles, or is fashionably addicted to short skirts.

For Canada's Art, a Home of Its Own
LEAD: As if Canadians could never quite persuade themselves that their art was worthy of a building of its own, governments here procrastinated for more than a century before heeding the urgings of the National Gallery of Canada for a permanent home.
Having started in a walk-up over a fishing exhibit in the 1880's, the gallery spent half a century sharing space with another museum before moving to a converted office building in 1959.

LEAD: A little more than two weeks after she suffered what may be permanent paralysis of her arms and legs during an accidental fall while warming up for a vault competition in Tokyo, 15-year-old Julissa Gomez will begin her return home to Blue Springs, Mo., today in a respirator.
Her parents, Ramiro and Otilia Gomez, who arrived in Tokyo two days after the accident, will accompany her, as will two doctors from the United States who made the flight arrangements after consultation with Japanese doctors.(

British Inflation Rate Up
LEAD: Britain's annual inflation rate rose to a faster-than-expected 3.9 percent in April from 3.5 percent in the previous month, the Government said today.
Consumer prices rose 1.6 percent in April from March, the Department of Employment said.
The index rose four-tenths of a percent in March from the previous month.

LEAD: When a child collapsed not long ago in his home in Amsterdam, N.Y., his mother grabbed the telephone to call an ambulance.
She could not get a dial tone.

Zinc Price Up in Europe
LEAD: The price of zinc, a metal used mainly in galvanizing steel, hit a three-year high on the London Metal Exchange today as big European producers raised their official prices, citing increased demand.
French, Belgian and West German producers set their base prices at $1,100 a metric ton, up from $1,070.

Fish Tale: Mississippi To Moscow
LEAD: With a deftness born of four years on the filleting line of the Delta Pride Catfish Company plant in Indianola, Miss., Elizabeth Smith fluidly cut into a two-pound farm-bred fish.
The leftover bone dropped away and the prime pinkish-white meat went onto a conveyor belt, carried away to another part of the chilly plant to be frozen for shipping.

LEAD: The Collegiate Chorale and orchestra will perform Janacek's cantata ''Amarus'' and Verdi's Four Sacred Pieces at 8 o'clock tonight at Carnegie Hall.

Tickets are $27, $22, $18 and $13.

Waterloo Music Festival
LEAD: A chamber music concert featuring works by Bach, Brahms, Poulenc and Schubert is to open the 13th Waterloo Festival and School of Music on June 17 at 8:30 P.M. at Waterloo Village, Stanhope, N.J.
The Waterloo Festival is to run through July 25 and feature appearances by Vladimir Feltsman, Rudolf Firkusny, Andre Watts, Nathaniel Rosen and Dmitri Sitkovetsky; the conductors are to include Gerard Schwarz, James DePriest and Maxim Shostakovich.

LEAD: Officials of Argonaut Group Inc. said that the company had received and rejected takeover inquiries but that the insurer was not for sale at this time.
Last year, Argonaut, based in Los Angeles, backed out of a $620 million leveraged buyout with Gibbons, Green van Amerongen after failing to come to terms over an unsolicited offer from Clarendon Group Ltd., a Bermuda insurer.

LEAD: Soft greens and fairways and ideal playing conditions brought low scores today at the opening round of the Nynex/Golf Digest Commemorative at Sleepy Hollow Country Club.

LEAD: With a dozen nuclear power plants in various stages of completion around the country, eyes everywhere are fastened on the political end game at Shoreham, the finished $5.3 billion plant on Long Island.


Opera; Glass and Poe Combine In Gothic Goings-On
LEAD: Philip Glass's operatic ambitions seem to be shifting slightly, from big, dreamy, imagistic works of musical theater to English-language librettos with real stories that work themselves up into real climaxes.

LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation, confirming an important legal victory, said the European Community commission had dropped an antitrust inquiry against the computer maker.

Samuel Foosaner, 81, Tax Lawyer and Writer
LEAD: Samuel J. Foosaner, a tax lawyer, writer and philanthropist, died of prostate cancer Thursday at his home in Cocoa Beach, Fla.
He was 81 years old and had formerly practiced in Newark and Millburn, N.J.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on May 12 about the growth of American law firms abroad misidentified firms involved in two takeover deals.
Squires, Sanders &amp; Dempsey advised the Bridgestone Corporation in its takeover of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company.
Two firms, Coblence, Warner, Hamilton &amp; Smith and Jones, Day, Reavis &amp; Pogue, represented Hachette S.A.


Easy Opener for Lendl
LEAD: Barring upsets, Ivan Lendl, the defending champion, could have a fourth-round meeting with John McEnroe at the French Open, setting up a possible replay of their memorable final four years ago.


Ausimont Study On Possible Sale
LEAD: Ausimont N.V., a specialty chemical maker largely owned by Montedison S.p.A. of Italy, said it had hired the Morgan Stanley Group to study the possible sale of all or major parts of its businesses.
Ausimont's shares jumped $4.625 today, to $31.50.
The 17.2 percent gain was the day's largest on the New York Stock Exchange.


New Soviet Motto: Down With Slogans!
LEAD: In a quiet attack on urban blight and public cynicism, Moscow and other Soviet cities have begun methodically dismantling the huge political slogans that are among the best-known features of the Soviet skyline.


U.S. Officials Report Huge Medicare Fraud
LEAD: Almost 1,000 doctors in Pennsylvania and New Jersey received kickbacks as part of a Medicare fraud scheme, Federal officials say.


Metromedia Wins Control of Orion
LEAD: Ending months of speculation about a possible takeover fight for the Orion Pictures Corporation, John W. Kluge, chairman of the Metromedia Company, has reached a deal to take control of the movie and television production concern.


EDITOR WHO WROTE THAT HE HAD AIDS
LEAD: Bill Cox, a newspaper editor in Kentucky and Hawaii who wrote an editorial column that disclosed he had AIDS, died yesterday in Manhattan Beach, Calif., of complications from that disease.
He was 39 years old.

Gregory Huffman, 35, a Dancer
LEAD: Gregory Huffman, a leading dancer in the Joffrey Ballet from 1972 to 1983, died of complications resulting from AIDS yesterday at New York University Medical Center.
Mr.
Huffman, who had been ill with pneumotoxis pneumonia for the last two months, was 35 years old.
He lived in Manhattan.

To House the Poor, First Help Basic Housing; Modular Noose
LEAD: To the Editor:


Oilers Turn On Their Power
LEAD: The Oilers waited just long enough for the Bruins to make this game dangerous.
Provoked by a 2-2 tie, Wayne Gretzky slid into the slot and gave Edmonton a 3-2 lead.
One empty-net goal later, the Oilers were halfway to their fourth Stanley Cup championship in five seasons.


CONSUMER INDEX, LED BY APPAREL, CLIMBS BY 0.4%
LEAD: Prices at the consumer level rose four-tenths of 1 percent in April, one-tenth less than the increase in March, the Labor Department reported today.

LEAD: The Pentagon selected four contractor teams today to develop a new type of high-speed, gallium arsenide computer chip.

LEAD: The Oakland Athletics, whose monuments are in the middle of the batting order rather than beyond the outfield wall, hit and scored in double figures last night in pounding out an 11-3 victory over the Yankees at the Stadium.

Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption on Thursday about John J. Foley of the Suffolk County Legislature referred incorrectly to his wife.
It is not she who works for a major backer of Mr.
Foley's bill on video-display computer terminals; the backer's employee is the wife of Mr.
Foley's chief aide.


Cancer Drug Therapy Urged For All After Breast Surgery
LEAD: In a major change of a longstanding policy, the National Cancer Institute is urging that all women who have breast cancer should have chemotherapy or hormonal therapy after the initial surgery, even if there is no evidence that the cancer has spread.

Parking Rules
LEAD: Because of the second day of Shabuoth, the Jewish Feast of Weeks, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City on Monday.
Other regulations remain in effect.


New York Plans to Add Welfare Hotel Services
LEAD: Services for thousands of homeless families living in welfare hotels across New York State would be stepped up under regulations proposed yesterday by Social Services Commissioner Cesar A. Perales.

LEAD: The National Cancer Institute, which considered its findings on breast cancer so important that it made the information public unusually rapidly to doctors, was unusually subdued in getting the news to the nation's press.


New British Films Made By Blacks
LEAD: Isaac Julien, a 28-year-old graduate of the St.
Martin's School of Art in England, is one of a new generation of young black British film makers.
This month, two full-length movies and three short works by Mr.
Julien and his compatriots begin a nationwide tour here.


The Preakness Stakes; An Upset Won't Be Much of a Surprise
LEAD: The Preakness Stakes at Pimlico on Saturday is being widely billed as a rematch of the Kentucky Derby two weeks ago, where the filly Winning Colors held off Forty Niner by just a neck at the finish.
But five colts who finished behind them are making another attempt, and a case can be made for any of the five to spring an upset, especially since the race is likely to be run over a sloppy track.


Koch Urges Ethics Panel To Call Aide
LEAD: Mayor Koch yesterday urged the State Commission on Government Integrity to allow his special assistant to rebut allegations that the aide altered or destroyed city personnel records to delete references to patronage affiliations.
