LEAD: The Irving Bank Corporation said yesterday that its directors had unanimously rejected a merger offer from the Bank of New York Company and had also erected a new roadblock to Bank of New York's takeover attempts.


GUIDEPOST: Barbecue Starters
LEAD: Barbecue equipment is coming out for the season, and it's time to choose a way to light the fuel, usually charcoal or briquettes.
Lighter fluid (liquid or gel; the gel is safer) is the most popular method, but it can flavor the food, as can briquettes or plastic starters treated with lighter fluid.

Trivial Pursuit Taken From Coleco
LEAD: Coleco Industries, which is battling to avoid bankruptcy, has lost its license to market the popular Trivial Pursuit board game.
The West Hartford toy maker also faces the possibility of losing its valuable license to market Cabbage Patch Kids products and dolls.

Music Zubin Mehta Conducts His First Mahler Ninth
LEAD: There are ways for a parachutist to prepare for his first jump, but at some point it is necessary to step out onto air and pull the rip cord.
Zubin Mehta, who had never in an extensive career conducted Mahler's Symphony No. 9, took the plunge with the New York Philharmonic on Thursday evening.
Any trepidation he may have felt in advance could easily be understood: the Philharmonic has a Mahler tradition dating back to the composer himself and under Leonard Bernstein played a major role in bringing these massive symphonies to their present state of popularity.


Takeover Era Increases Risk Of Lawyer Conflict of Interest
LEAD: John L. Duncan, president of the Murray Ohio Manufacturing Company, was shocked last month when an executive of the Electrolux Group told him it was making an unsolicited offer to buy Mr.
Duncan's company.

LEAD: The New York City Transit Police Department, facing the loss of 162 officers, said yesterday that it would discontinue the practice of having a police officer on every subway train at night.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, a Company News report in some editions of Business Day on Thursday, about the Meritor Financial Group, omitted the context for a pessimistic remark by the company's chairman.
In saying ''we are not going to make it'' if current interest rates hold, he was referring to the company's prediction of steady operating earnings by the end of the year.

Adding Warriors to the Drug War
LEAD: The politics of drugs suddenly alters the mood of Congress.
Alarmed by rising public concern over drug-related crime and corruption, members are rushing to enlist the Defense Department in a literal war on drugs.
Both the Senate and the House propose using the military to stop drug smugglers.

Ethiopia Frees 7 Relatives of Haile Selassie
LEAD: The Marxist Government of Ethiopia today set free seven members of the deposed royal family who had been imprisoned without trial since the 1974 revolution in which Emperor Haile Selassie was overthrown.


A Bar Where the Food Surprises
LEAD: PETER'S INN in East Northport may look like a neighborhood bar, but the food is certainly not pub grub.
First-timers are startled to find jalapeno pasta, carpaccio, Cajun shrimp with wild rice and lobster pasta on the menu.
Mixed grill at Peter's breaks the mundane mold with filet mignon au poivre, rare duck breast in a green peppercorn and brandy sauce and a grilled veal chop.

LEAD: An overwhelming yes.
I can't wait to tell my grandchildren of the exploits of great umpires like Doug Harvey, John McSherry and Dave Pallone in the banner year of '88. ''But Granddad, just how far could Strawberry really hit one in his prime, and how awesome was Gooden in 1985?'' ''Sonny, those trivial feats were nothing compared to the hundreds of exciting balks I witnessed in the summer of '88.

The Day I Quit Playing Baseball for Good

Do You Like the Stricter Balk Rules
LEAD: The purpose of calling balks is to protect the runner on base.
A pitcher must come to a discernible stop before pitching.
How can a pitcher be called for a balk when his team is going to intentionally walk the hitter?
Umpires have every right to call violations of the rules and regulations of the game, but let's call them only when there is clearly an infraction.


How to Repair Concrete Steps
LEAD: CONCRETE steps outdoors frequently crack and chip.
Concrete is brittle and requires stable support from beneath as well as reinforcement within to withstand even moderate stress.
Particularly damaging are rapid temperature fluctuations in spring.


Should Baby Read?
LEAD: THE IMAGE OF A 2-YEAR-OLD reading aloud from ''The Cat In the Hat,'' and laughing at the silly parts, warms the hearts of many young parents.
Parents who are themselves intellectual and upwardly mobile want their children to have all the privileges they have had - and then some.
How better to assure their children's success than to get them started early, to teach them to read during that brief shining time when kids absorb knowledge as naturally as they breathe?

PRACTICAL Traveler; Scheduling Flights to Beat Jet Lag
LEAD: WHEN jet lag was first named, an acquaintance of mine who affected only modish problems said that she was suffering a really bad case because she had taken the shuttle plane to Washington three times in the previous week.
Of course, the worst part of jet lag - flying across time zones too fast for the body to adapt - has nothing to do with one-hour trips in the same zone.


THE WORLD: Pizza, Pepsi and the President; The Russians Indulge Their Taste For American Taste
LEAD: THOSE who believe in the eventual convergence of the Soviet and American systems could take heart last week.
An ''Astro Pizza'' truck from New Jersey, parked on the Moscow river embankment, was doing a brisk business selling pizzas at stratospheric prices.
The score from ''Porgy and Bess'' blared from car radios Wednesday afternoon, and each evening, slick American commercials, translated into Russian, splashed across television screens promoting Pepsi-Cola and Visa credit cards.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. Two years ago we had a plank oak floor installed in our kitchen and dining room over a concrete slab.
In the summer, the last 18 inches of this floor warps, even when we use a dehumidifier.
In the winter the floor returns to normal except for a few spots that are starting to show signs of permanent damage.

The Subway, Palatial and Political
LEAD: AFTER a few days of bumping along on the official Soviet bus tour, from armories to monasteries to government buildings, visitors usually grasp what they are missing in Moscow's urban scene: the familiar traffic din of a city in motion.
Travelers weary of what can be an alienating, one-dimensional view of Moscow can find relief about 200 feet beneath the streets.


New Point-and-Shoot for Kodak's Anniversary
LEAD: ONE hundred years ago, George Eastman introduced a revolutionary idea in picture making: photography for everybody.
His first roll-film camera, introduced in 1888 and called the Kodak, allowed dilettantes and duffers to take photographs easily without the bother of carting around glass plates, tripods and other paraphernalia.

NONFICTION
LEAD:  CARL SANDBURG: His Life and Works.
By North Callahan. (Pennsylvania State University, $29.75.) ''A biography, Sirs, should begin with the breath of a man when his eyes first meet the light of day,'' Carl Sandburg once wrote.
Adopting this philosophy in covering Sandburg's 89 years, North Callahan has written a creditable biography of the writer and the man, often using his own extensive recollections of the poet whose ''reckless ecstasies of the language'' have become part of the American tongue.

FICTION
LEAD:  THE THIRD FRIDAY.
By George Bellak. (Morrow, $18.95.) Hot on the heels of the Government's insider trading cases and Oliver Stone's film ''Wall Street,'' there promises to be a spate of business-oriented novels.
After all, if the business of America is business, what better place to set a crime thriller for our times than on Wall Street, where fortunes are gained and lost quicker than it takes a body to fall 32 floors?


Correction
LEAD: The Executive Computer column last week misstated the capacity of two computer storage devices.
A 256K dynamic random access memory chip, or D-RAM, holds 256 kilobits of data.
A one-megabit single in-line memory module, or SIMM, holds 1,000 kilobits of data.


Tighter Federal Drug Dragnet Yields Cars, Boats and Protests
LEAD: The Federal Government's two-month-old policy of seizing boats, cars and other vehicles on which even small amounts of illegal drugs are found is causing dismay among civil libertarians and howls of protest from those whose property is confiscated.


Melbourne
LEAD: To the Editor: Julian West's piece on Melbourne (Travel, April 3) was most informative but left out one important segment under Shopping.
Little Collins Street, which parallels Collins Street, is Melbourne's equivalent of New York's 47th Street insofar as opal dealers are concerned.
Here are to be found black opals from Lighting Ridge as well as fire opals from Coober Pedy and stones from other mines.


Discriminating Against the Dead
LEAD: IT HAS been illegal for some time in New York City to discriminate against handicapped people.
In January 1987 a State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan extended the legal protection to the dead as well as the living.

LEAD: NOWHERE has the current crisis in nursing been more palpable than on Long Island, where the Nassau County Medical Center has been forced to deny admission to patients because of a dangerously low nurse-patient ratio.
As the shortage of nurses worsens, other hospitals, across the state as well as the country, are being compelled to limit services and to turn away patients.

LEAD: HARTFORD has an office vacancy rate of just 8 percent, one of the lowest in the country.

LEAD: IN 1984, with great fanfare and great expectations, the Federal Express Corporation introduced a service called Zapmail.

It was a novel, ingenious approach to image transmission, and forecasters were quick to predict its rosy future.

LEAD: ON THE AFTERNOON BEFORE the Dance Theatre of Harlem departs for its first tour of the Soviet Union, Arthur Mitchell, D.T.H.'s founder and artistic director, is in his closet-sized office, dancing.
Jammed in among a desk, some chairs and a staircase, he stutter-steps and swivels, his arms whipping jubilantly back and forth.

Prince Twice Is Still Prince Charming
LEAD: In one of the most enjoyable and peculiar career moves of the 1980's, Prince has completed two albums so far this year.
The first, ''The Black Album'' (no catalogue number, cassette only), was announced and then, just before its planned release, withdrawn from the market on Prince's orders.
Albums that had been pressed in Great Britain were scrapped, but not before bootlegs of ''The Black Album'' had begun to circulate.


Making Europe a Mighty Market
LEAD: THE battle between Europe and ''non-Europe'' is coming to a head.
With less than five years to go before a self-imposed deadline, the European Community is racing to remove the hundreds of trade barriers that bedevil its 12 member countries.


Zambians Kill Mozambicans
LEAD: Zambian troops crossed into Mozambique this week in pursuit of right-wing Mozambican rebels, destroying two bases and killing 73 of the guerrillas, a Secretary of State for Defense and Security, Alex Shapi, said today.
Mr.
Shapi said the cross-border attack followed a raid by the Mozambique National Resistance on the Zambian border village of Chadiza.


Correction
LEAD: A correction in this space last Sunday misidentified the holder of the men's world record for the 400-meter run and gave an incorrect time.
The record is 43.86 seconds; it was set by Lee Evans of the United States in the 1968 Olympic Games in Mexico City.

An Opportunity to Talk the Cold War to Death
LEAD: ONE week from today, when President Reagan arrives in Moscow for his fourth meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the evolution of Soviet-American relations will have completed a dramatic cycle.
From a surge of cooperation in the early 1970's and then into a tense period of frozen hostility, the two powers have now emerged into what may prove to be the healthiest relationship in their postwar history.

Smithsonian Adjunct Is the Ultimate Attic
LEAD: One Friday afternoon in 1973, when the Smithsonian Institution was fairly groaning under the strain of its enormous holdings, Porter Kier, the director of the National Museum of Natural History, remarked to one of his curators that he would like to decorate his office with a zoological specimen ''a little bigger'' than the stuffed groundhog perched on his desk.

On Third Hand Play
LEAD: ONE of the oldest rules of thumb in the game, dating back to whist, is ''third hand high.'' Whist-players, with no dummy in view to help them, followed this guideline blindly.
Bridge players are better off and can recognize the obvious exceptions.
At the first trick the third player usually preserves a high card that is poised over an honor in the dummy.

LEAD: Maple syrup production was up by 225,000 gallons this year, but producers did not have the banner year they had been hoped for.
The auality was what counted most, a Federal official said.

Paris
LEAD: To the Editor: I took advantage of your suggestion (Travel, Oct. 18) and stayed at the Hotel des Grands Hommes (17 Place Pantheon) for $75 a night in Paris.
I enjoyed a view of the Pantheon and such riveting traffic noises as to be convinced that Parisian cars are not equipped with mufflers.
In fact, such noises were ever present and make me wonder why this is not the case in New York City.

Soft-Shell Crabs, Three Ways
LEAD: NOW that the weather has finally warmed up, soft-shell crabs are coming into the market.
The most common way of cooking them is simple: dust them with flour and fry them in butter.
But soft-shell crabs beget a challenge to chefs, who come up with all sorts of interesting and unusual ways to prepare them.

Bearing Gifts
LEAD: To the Editor: To your list, in Q &amp; A (April 24), of small gifts to take to the Soviet Union should certainly be added picture postcards of American sights and landscape.
We were asked for these everywhere we went - mostly by children and teen-agers, who always were ready with postcards for us.
Sew-on patches (not those with political motifs) would also be highly regarded.

A Stalwart for the Summer Months
LEAD: PRUNE suckers from magnolias and water sprouts (upright shoots) from dogwoods.
Plant geraniums, begonias, ivy, petunias, vinca, impatiens, torenia, salvia, marigolds, zinnias and other showy annuals in tubs, planters and window boxes.
Set out started seedlings of peppers, tomatoes, eggplants, melons and sow cucumbers and sweet corn in hills.

From Key West, Key Limes
LEAD: EXACTLY how long Key lime pie has been around no one can say with certainty, although one of the young girls rolling out pastry dough at Theresa Bakery in Key West solemnly volunteered: ''Always.

MAKING SURE DOCTORS GET ENOUGH SLEEP
LEAD: It was 4 A.M., nap time for a second-year resident who had been on duty at a Long Island hospital for 20 hours.
As she dozed off, her beeper sounded.
A patient was having a seizure.
She gave him the drug he needed, keeping close watch on his heart monitor.
To stay awake, she sang along with the radio in his room.

Ornery - And Proud of It
LEAD: MY MATERNAL grandmother, Annie Sparks, lived with our family during the while I was growing up.
When I came home from school, after having made a detour to the kitchen to pour a glass of milk and fix a thick peanut butter sandwich on easy-to-tear white bread, I would go up to her sitting room.
She would put aside her crossword puzzle - which she did in ink - and tell me stories about our family.

Do You Like the Stricter Balk Rules
LEAD: The delicate and beautiful balance of the game has been upset by the ease of base stealing.
Pitchers should be given more, not less opportunity to hold runners on.
When every single, walk and hit batter turns out to be the same as a two- or three-base hit, the game is distorted.
The baserunning game should be high drama.


Puckering Up
LEAD: AN APOCRYPHAL STORY HAS IT THAT IN THE early 1950's, Joseph Haspel, a founder of Haspel Brothers, the New Orleans company that introduced washable seersucker, attended a business meeting in Florida dressed in one of his firm's new wash-and-wear suits.
When his colleagues doubted the properties he claimed for it, Haspel strolled into the ocean fully clad.


3 Bomb Attacks in Greece
LEAD: Two bombs exploded in the Athens suburb of Nikaia early today, and a third was thrown from a car in the port of Piraeus.
There were no injuries, the police said.
All three attacks were claimed by a local left-wing terrorist group, Revolutionary Popular Struggle.

Easy Does It
LEAD: THERE ARE TIMES WHEN even the most devoted cook looks for a way out of the kitchen.
Clearly, plenty of shortcuts exist today, but these have more to do with getting a meal on the table in a hurry than creating pleasurable dishes.
Fast food, however, doesn't have to look or taste that way.
It can be as simple as grilled fish, poultry or meat, or it can give the illusion of complexity.

LEAD: FOR centuries, trade statistics have tracked the course of human history.

I, for example, must support teams from either Massachusetts or New York.

Keeping Tabs on Adjustable-Rate Loans
LEAD: INTEREST rates are edging up, bringing new allure to adjustable-rate mortgages.
In April, 48 percent of new mortgages were adjustable, compared with 22 percent in April 1987, according to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.
Borrowers are attracted by introductory rates that are often dramatically lower than those of fixed mortgages and by the knowledge that if rates go back down, they won't be locked into a high rate, said Ray Durn, a real estate lawyer in Cleveland with Jones, Day, Reavis &amp;

The nation's purchasing agents, who order goods for their companies, predicted, by a margin of 7 to 1, that the economy would be better in 1988 than in 1987.

The film was Karel Reisz's ''Isadora.''
At this writing, one-third of the way into the 41st Cannes festival, it seems entirely possible that Natasha Richardson might win this year's best actress award for Paul Schrader's ''Patty Hearst,'' a biographical film that is less about an extraodinary character than about an extraordinary event.

Every day, 16,000 tons of lignite coal stripped from nearby mines is fed into a maze of pipes and throbbing machinery, where it is converted into enough gas to supply a city of nearly 250,000 households.

AMERICA'S RED ARMY
LEAD: Jim Robbins's article, ''America's Red Army'' (April 17), provides strong evidence that the Pentagon is finally preparing its soldiers for the next war rather than the last one.

Soft-Shell Crabs, Three Ways
LEAD: NOW that the weather has finally warmed up, soft-shell crabs are coming into the market.
The most common way of cooking them is simple: dust them with flour and fry them in butter.
But soft-shell crabs beget a challenge to chefs, who come up with all sorts of interesting and unusual ways to prepare them.


DRUNKEN DRIVING: ZEROING IN ON THE HARD CORE
LEAD: In Judge Edward E. O'Farrell's municipal courtroom in New Philadelphia, Ohio, anyone convicted of drunken driving can count on one thing these days: going to jail.
That is Judge O'Farrell's rule, and it is one measure of how American society's attitude toward drinking and driving is changing, even in smaller communities where people know each other and have preferred not to make an issue of such behavior.

Romancing the Stone
LEAD: BERND MUNSTEINER is a third-generation gem cutter from Germany who devised a technique of cutting stones that bears little relation to the traditional faceting of gems.
He gouges deep vertical, horizontal or asymmetic cuts into the back of a stone so that mysterious planes are revealed when the cuts are viewed through the smooth, unbroken surface.

'Slaughterhouse Rock'
LEAD: ''Slaughterhouse Rock'' brings together the usual suspects of teen-age horror films: murder, rock music, sex, low budgets.
Alex, a college student, is possessed by the spirit of a cannibal-ghost buried beneath Alcatraz, released from his grave by a dead rock star.
In order to exorcise the spirit from his dreams, Alex and a half-dozen of his most foolhardy friends head for Alcatraz in the middle of the night, where they stumble over skeletons, corpses and many live rats.


Inflation Worries Keep on Mounting
LEAD: This week's numbers did little to ease the nerves of anyone worried about inflation.
The most-cited measure of inflation, the Consumer Price Index, showed a gain of four-tenths of 1 percent in April, in line with expectations.
That works out to an annual rate of 5.3 percent, up from last year, but not too alarming.

CORRECTION
LEAD: A correction in this space last Sunday incorrectly identified the holder of the men's world record for the 400-meter run and gave an incorrect time.

Pro Football; Marshall Sparks a Dormant Fire
LEAD: HE plopped onto the concrete steps in front of the Washington Redskins offices, gaining a brief respite from a long, sweaty morning of minicamp practice.
The sun's rays dazzled as he squinted his right eye and then his left one.
A Concorde jet blazed overhead, leaving a trail of booming clatter.
Quickly, his thoughts shifted.


Federal Judge Slain by a Gunman in Westchester
LEAD: A 56-year-old Federal judge was shot and killed yesterday afternoon at his Westchester County home by an assailant who pursued him from garden to house with a blazing gun and then shot himself to death, the police reported.

LEAD: ADDRESSING the first brigade of Soviet troops to withdraw from his country last week, President Najibullah of Afghanistan offered expressions of confidence about his Government's ability to survive.

Cello and Piano Duo
LEAD: Karen Buranskas and Masako Hayashi make up an exceedingly fine cello and piano duo.
They have an understanding of the duo form (and of each other) unusual for its subtlety, and at Weill Recital Hall last week they gauged the acoustics of this presumably unfamiliar space with professional ears.

WHAT'S DOING IN: Basel
LEAD: In the heart of Switzerland's second city, the Rhine turns resolutely from a westerly course toward the north.
Local people call the bend in the big river its knee - a dramatic curve that marks the waterway's transition from an Alpine river into the throbbing artery of one of the continent's most heavily industrialized regions.


SHOULD NEW YORK TAKE JUDGES OFF THE BALLOT?
LEAD: New York is one of only 14 states in which voters still choose some or most of their judges in partisan elections.
Bar associations and other groups are urging the Legislature to switch to a system of appointment known as merit selection.
Their campaign gained the support last week of the New York State Commission on Government Integrity, created by Governor


How to Repair Concrete Steps
LEAD: CONCRETE steps outdoors frequently crack and chip.
Concrete is brittle and requires stable support from beneath as well as reinforcement within to withstand even moderate stress.
Particularly damaging are rapid temperature fluctuations in spring.


No Letup By Gooden As Streak Reaches 8
LEAD: The Mets, still streaking in all directions, won their sixth straight game tonight by beating the Los Angeles Dodgers, 4-0, as Dwight Gooden won his eighth straight by pitching a four-hitter with the oldtime mastery.


Soft-Shell Crabs, Three Ways
LEAD: NOW that the weather has finally warmed up, soft-shell crabs are coming into the market.
The most common way of cooking them is simple: dust them with flour and fry them in butter.
But soft-shell crabs beget a challenge to chefs, who come up with all sorts of interesting and unusual ways to prepare them.

POSTINGS: N.J. Condominiums; Converting a Mill
LEAD: In the last decade, the developer Gordon Ash has churned out mill conversions steadily.
First was Roger's Mill, a locomotive erecting shop he converted into offices and a museum.
Then came Ivanhoe Mill, a flax factory turned into stores, and Union Works and Argus Mill, yarn and textile factories that are now schools.

Tracking the Creative Process
LEAD: THERE are sculptures, prints and photographs by nine artists in the Gallery at Hastings-on-Hudson's ''Progressions.'' But the objects are less the subject of the show than the ways in which they are made.
Most of the items are backed up by drawings, molds, early impressions, written notes - whatever it takes to demonstrate the stages in a given technique.

THE WINGS OF ADVENTURE
LEAD: Daniel Menaker's article, ''Hell on Wheels'' (May 1), brought back memories of similar six-hour weekly drives to and from our farm in Vermont.
After five years, however, I realized Mr.
Menaker's dream of sprouting wings: I learned to fly and purchased a well-used four-passenger Piper airplane to speed the trip for my wife, two children and overweight dog.

Do You Like the Stricter Balk Rules
LEAD: The balk rule is serving only in slowing the game without really tackling the reason for its institution.
More balks appear to be called when the pitcher pitches to the batter than when he throws to first base to eradicate a troublesome man on base.
The rhythm of the pitcher is unnecessarily interfered with, and the resultant confusion serves only to make the game less enjoyable.

LEAD: Haiti has joined Panama as a growing drug-smuggling center, and members of its secret police are forcing their way into the distribution of crack in Florida, witnesses told a special Senate hearing today.

WESTCHESTER OPINON
LEAD: I REMEMBER the study where the Beaver went to receive the wisdom of the ages given to him by Ward Cleaver, his father.
I do not remember any of the pearls that this sage cast before the boy but I do remember the study and the magical maleness that emanated from that room and its surroundings.
I have always wanted a room like that for my own.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. Two years ago we had a plank oak floor installed in our kitchen and dining room over a concrete slab.
In the summer, the last 18 inches of this floor warps, even when we use a dehumidifier.
In the winter the floor returns to normal except for a few spots that are starting to show signs of permanent damage.

LEAD: A measure granting minority status to Cajuns has been approved by the Louisiana House of Representatives over the objections of black lawmakers who say the measure threatens black economic development, Cajuns are descendants of French settlers expelled from Canada who settled in the steamy bayou country of south Louisiana in the 1750's.

Hong Kong Bank Denial
LEAD: The Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation and Midland Bank P.L.C. are not discussing setting up joint headquarters in London and Hong Kong, George Cardona, manager of corporate public affairs at Hongkong and Shanghai, said Saturday.
He was commenting on a report by the Reuters news service on May 20 in which bankers and analysts were quoted as saying that such a plan would give the Hong Kong bank a safety net after the transfer of Hong Kong's sovereignty to China in 1997.

Staying Dry
LEAD: There was enough rain in the Northeast this week to draw comparisons with the Flood.
At the Big East baseball tournament in Bristol, Conn., the man who played Noah was a groundskeeper, 59-year-old Anthony Guerriero, who will retire this year as Parks Department Group Leader at Muzzy Field.
Guerriero's devotion to service may or may not have had something to do with divine instruction, but he managed to turn a swamp into the baseball equivalent of Mount Ararat.

Utility Bidders Named
LEAD: Samuel Belzberg, the Vancouver investor, is among the bidders for part of the British Columbia Hydro and Power Corporation, the provincial government said Saturday.
The company is a government-owned utility with annual revenues of about $2 billion (Canadian).
The government said Pacific Rim Gas Inc., a unit of the Hong Kong and China Gas Company Ltd., is one bidder for Hydro's mainland gas division, which distributes natural gas in the Vancouver area.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  GOLF  Wadkins Surges to Victory: Lanny Wadkins came from five shots back with a 65 to take a one-stroke victory yesterday in the Colonial National Invitation tournament in Fort Worth.
Wadkins finished at 270, 10 under par.
The 18th victory of his 18-year PGA Tour career was worth $135,000 from the total purse of $750,000 and pushed his earnings to $447,465 for the year.

Gasoline Prices Stable
LEAD: Retail gasoline prices were steady in the past two weeks, according to a survey of about 12,000 service stations throughout the United States.
The average national price for a gallon of gasoline on May 20 was 100.26 cents, just three-hundredths of a penny less than the average for May 6, said Trilby Lundberg, who oversees the twice-monthly Lundberg Survey of gas prices.

GLOBAL BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Spain, which ruled the Philippines for 300 years, has offered a $70 million loan to its former colony, according to the Spanish Prime Minister, Felipe Gonzalez.
Spanish colonial rule in the Philippines started in the 16th century and lasted until the Spanish-American war in 1898.
Mr.
Gonzalez said Spain would cooperate with other members in the European Community to help the Philippine economy.

LEAD: ''So you ask yourself: Which situation are we better off in, to have Noriega more or less in charge in Panama, and us with an indictment that we cannot do much about, but nevertheless holding onto it?
Or having Noriega giving up power in Panama and leaving Panama, but also, having paid that penalty, not having the indictment hang over his head?

LEAD: Canada's federal banking regulator said Friday that Canadian banks had been ordered to raise their third world loan-loss reserves to 35 to 45 percent of total loans to the developing world, from the current 30 to 40 percent.

Students Battle Police in South Korea
LEAD: University students hurling stones and gasoline bombs at police as thousands staged violent demonstrations yesterday in the southwestern city of Kwangju.
Police dispersed the rioters with tear gas.
Scores of protesters were arrested but there were no immediate reports of injuries.
The demonstrations were held to call for a full-scale inquiry into he army's crushing of an uprising in the city in 1980.


Rift on Noriega Deepens as Bush And Treasury Chief Oppose Deal
LEAD: American officials said today that there is a deepening rift within the Reagan Administration over how to remove Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega from power in Panama.


Million-Dollar Team Keeping Bush Campaign in the Money
LEAD: As a senior at an exclusive New England preparatory school, George Bush saved a younger classmate from being beaten by a bully.
Forty-seven years later, the events that day at Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., are bringing enormous financial rewards to Mr.
Bush's Presidential campaign.


Federal Express vs. Japan (Cont.)
LEAD: It is a familiar tale.
An American company tries for years to break into the Japanese marketplace.
Finally, just as it thinks it is through the last barrier, it hears of other regulations that prevent it from operating in Japan.


Review/Opera; Children Sing 'Noye's Fludde' By Britten
LEAD: It is nice to come across a children's opera intended for children.
Most serve adult needs, either as fantasies of what grown-ups think childishness should be or else as condescending exploitations of the cuteness they perceive in young innocence.
Benjamin Britten works hard to establish and defend the rights of children in his brief opera ''Noye's Fludde.

LEAD: Treasury financings this week begin with today's regular auction of three-month and six-month bills, followed on Wednesday by an auction of two-year notes and an auction of five-year notes on Thursday.


Militia War Abates in Beirut As Negotiations Go Forward
LEAD: Fighting between Shiite Moslem militias slowed today as negotiators worked on the terms for the deployment of Syrian forces in the capital's battle-torn southern suburbs.


HUNGARIAN PARTY REPLACES KADAR WITH HIS PREMIER
LEAD: Prime Minister Karoly Grosz became the new General Secretary of Hungary's Communist Party today, replacing Janos Kadar, whom the Soviet Union installed as party leader during the failed uprising in 1956.

Reviews/Television; Espionage in 'CAT Squad' Sequel
LEAD: The current silly season for television movies keeps clip-clopping along this evening at 9 with NBC's ''CAT Squad: Python Wolf,'' an action-adventure exercise distinguished by one of the year's more incomprehensible plots.
The film does carry an eye-catching credit.
It was directed by William Friedkin, who won an Academy Award for ''The French Connection.

LEAD: Paul H. Nitze, the arms control negotiator for the United States, is scheduled to view Paul H. Nitze as portrayed by an actor in a one-night stand this evening of ''A Walk in the Woods'' at the Library of Congress.


Retail Layoffs Start to Rise As Merger Wave Subsides
LEAD: With the wave of retailing mergers beginning to subside, their effect is now being felt hard by those who work in this people-intensive industry.
The number of people displaced from jobs is expected to be the largest in a long time because of the concurrent mergers, divestitures and internal restructurings at some of the nation's largest retailing companies.

LEAD: Talk about old fashioned! ''Moyers: Joseph Campbell and the Power of Myth'' is Stone Age television: six hours in which Bill Moyers and Mr.
Campbell talk to each other and hardly ever get out of their chairs.
Is this boring?
Sometimes it is; most of the time it is not.
Pay attention and you'll be engaged.

Warship Weapons Secrecy Is Rooted in Law
LEAD: To the Editor:


U.S. Judge Blocks Drug Tests
LEAD: A Federal district judge has temporarily blocked a Reagan Administration plan to test employees of the Federal prison system at random for drug use.
The testing, which was scheduled to begin Monday, would have affected 35,000 workers around the nation.

LEAD: In an evening of one-acts presented by the Working Theater at Intar Stage II, four playwrights have an opportunity to work out their dramatic problems.
None of the plays can yet be considered a forward step for the author.


Teachers In Day Care Questioned
LEAD: With salaries unappealingly low and turnover rates alarmingly high, almost half of New York City's day-care and Head Start classrooms are run by teachers who lack full qualifications, a study by the Bank Street College of Education has found.

Greek Quake Sets Off Slide
LEAD: A strong earthquake rocked the western Greek island of Cephalonia today and set off a landslide near the main town of Argostoli, the police reported.
There were no reports of casualties or building damage.
However, the quake, which was centered almost 200 miles west of Athens and registered 5.5 on the Richter scale, ''shook everybody awake this morning'' a police officer on the island said.


Kitty Dukakis Lends Emotion To Politics but Keeps Identity
LEAD: Kitty Dukakis does not slip easily into the fixed and adoring stare perfected by generations of political wives.
She is a toucher, a talker, a woman who laughs easily and gives orders with equal gusto.


Valenzuela Crushed by Mets
LEAD: The Mets completed their week's sweep through southern California today with a seven-game winning streak, a five-and-a-half-game lead and a two-round knockout over Fernando Valenzuela.
And they even escaped the rage of Pedro Guerrero, who hurled his bat past the mound after David Cone bounced a curveball off his helmet.


BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  Wall Street is worried that volatility will increase as a result of the low trading volume of recent weeks.
The market's liquidity -which allows stocks to be traded without distorting prices - is at its lowest level in two years, one investment firm says.
A trader described the situation as ''very dangerous,'' and others pointed out that a marketplace with low liquidity was vulnerable to shocks.


Consensus Emerges in Panama: Noriega Has Won
LEAD: Having weathered months of political crisis, Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega now appears able to hold on to power indefinitely if he chooses, according to several diplomats and Panamanian politicians.

John Richard Garrett Stanley, U.S.A.F., the son of Valerie A. Stanley of Pinckney, Mich., and Everett E. Stanley of Westminster, Md., took place yesterday at the Thomas Law House in Washington.


China Oilfield Sees Big Loss
LEAD: This year may be the first in which China's biggest oilfield reports an operating loss, the official New China News Agency said today.


SEVERAL GARRISONS ARE SAID TO FALL TO AFGHAN REBELS
LEAD: Afghan Army garrisons along the Pakistani-Afghan border, weakened by Soviet troop withdrawals, are rapidly crumbling in the face of assaults by heavily armed guerrillas, Afghan rebel officials and Western diplomats say.

LEAD: The defrocked evangelist Jimmy Swaggart reclaimed the pulpit at his Family Worship Center today with fire-and-brimstone fervor and an appeal for money.


The Life of the Club Pro Can Be a Winning One
LEAD: TRADITION is not kind to David Glenz the third weekend in May.
It is that time every year that the Morris County Golf Club in Convent Station, N.J., where Glenz is the head professional, stages one of the biggest events on its social calender: a member-guest tournament that includes 184 players.


S.E.C. Seeks Pacts Abroad
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission is negotiating securities enforcement agreements with France, Italy, Australia and New Zealand, David S. Ruder, the agency's chairman, said Thursday night.


Kim M. Burke, a Lawyer, Marries Glenn S. Goldberg
LEAD: Kim M. Burke, an associate in the Manhattan law firm of Semel, Boeckmann, Diamond, Schepp &amp; Yuhas, and Glenn S. Goldberg, the press secretary to Elizabeth Holtzman, the Brooklyn District Attorney, were married yesterday.
Judge Joel M. Goldberg of New York City Criminal Court officiated at the Tappan Hill center in Tarrytown, N.Y.


State Convention Is Disrupted
LEAD: Georgia's Republican state convention adjourned in chaos Saturday after supporters of Pat Robertson shouted down speakers.

LEAD: Long-awaited Federal regulations to overhaul the lending policies of the Farmers Home Administration are expected to cost $8.7 billion and push as many as 65,000 farmers into liquidation or foreclosure, the agency, a part of the Agriculture Department, said.

To Our Readers
LEAD: A series of slowdowns and other job actions by the drivers' union have curtailed distribution of The New York Times in some areas.
These actions are associated with contract negotiations, and The Times is unable to say how long the disruptions may continue.
We regret the inconvenience to our readers.


'Gold Card' Ruling
LEAD: Mastercard may now legally use the expression ''gold card'' in its advertising as a result of a ruling last week by Federal District Judge Charles Metzner.
He indicated that the term is generic and not a trademark of American Express.
A lawsuit was filed by American Express soon after Mastercard began an ad campaign for Gold Mastercard.


Bitter Trade Debate Near in Ottawa
LEAD: Seven months after turning Canada's economic policy around by signing a free-trade agreement with the United States, the Government here is entering a decisive phase of its battle for the agreement at home.


Giorgio Almirante, Italian Neo-Fascist, Dies at 73
LEAD: Giorgio Almirante, who had a minor role in Mussolini's last government and was a founder and longtime leader of Italy's small but vocal neo-Fascist party, died today.
He was 73 years old.


Antipodal Dream
LEAD: Andrew Gaze lived out a fantasy two years ago in the Georgetown University fieldhouse.


Met Takes 'Ring' Cycle Into the Recording Studio
LEAD: Down on West 34th Street, cars were honking and trucks were double-parked and the afternoon seethed with the raucous bustle of midweek in New York City.
But up on the seventh floor of the Manhattan Center, in the old barrel-roofed ballroom that serves as the city's premiere recording studio for classical music, a very different atmosphere prevailed.


Billy Carter Prepares to Try Experimental Cancer Therapy
LEAD: Billy Carter left here today for the National Cancer Institute in Bethesda, Md., to undergo a risky experimental treatment for pancreatic cancer.


British Rail Sale Report
LEAD: The British Government is considering selling British Rail, the national railroad system, the Economist reported in its latest issue.
The plan is being worked on by a policy unit within Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's office, the magazine said in its May 21 issue, which was made available today.


The Bird's Eye
LEAD: BEFORE yesterday's game, someone was saying that during this playoff series against Atlanta, Larry Bird hasn't been quite the Larry Bird that we've come to know. ''You mean he hasn't been Superman?'' ''No,'' said the first person, ''I mean he hasn't been Superduperman.'' Yesterday, he was Superduperman.


El Castillo Journal; A Crumbling Fort Sleeps On, Haunted by History
LEAD: No edifice in Central America has seen more drama than the crumbling fortress that sits atop a bluff overlooking this strategic bend in the San Juan River.


Caribbean Officials Criticize Outside Pressure on Panama
LEAD: The foreign ministers of the Caribbean nations closed a two-day meeting here late Saturday by calling for an end to foreign invervention in the affairs of Panama.


Anniversary Festivities For the New York Pops
LEAD: Peter Allen, Nell Carter, Carol Channing, Jackie Mason, Robert Merrill and Roberta Peters are to be guest stars at a concert celebrating the fifth anniversary of the New York Pops, Tuesday at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Hall.
Skitch Henderson will conduct.


Lacrosse; Virginia Surprises Hopkins by 11-10
LEAD: In lacrosse, Johns Hopkins almost always beats Virginia, but today the Cavaliers achieved a striking upset by defeating the defending national champion, 11-10, in a National Collegiate Athletic Association playoff contest.


Flea Market Vendors Raided for Tax Evasion
LEAD: Tax compliance agents for the State Department of Taxation and Finance removing clothes from a flea market vendor yesterday at the Yonkers Raceway Flea Market.
They said the vendor owed $24,000 in sales tax.

Review/Concert; Celtic-Tinged Songs of Paul Brady
LEAD: In 1980 Paul Brady moved from Irish folk music to more personal songwriting.
He came up with a style that occasionally draws on traditional Irish storytelling but more often exalts private feelings to metaphorical heights, like an Irish Jackson Browne.
Two of his songs, ''Steel Claw'' and ''Paradise Is Here,'' were recorded on multimillion-selling albums by Tina Turner - his main exposure in the United States.

LEAD: THE National Hockey League used to worry only about the new dents and scratches that might appear on the Stanley Cup when the winning players frolicked with the cup in bars, clubs, backyards, race tracks and bedrooms.

LEAD: Nicaragua announced today that it was extending a seven-week-old truce to allow more time for peace talks with the United States-backed rebels.

Razorback Offer
LEAD: The Razorback Acquisition Corporation said that it was prepared to increase its cash offer for the Arkansas Best Corporation to $23 a common share, from $20.

Mr.
Karmazin succeeds Gerald Carrus as president.
The company said Mr.
Karmazin's position as chief executive, a newly created position, would include responsibilities that he has held for for some time.

Banking on America's Word
LEAD: All the World Bank's 151 members have pledged funds to increase its capital.
Among the big ones, only the United States has not delivered.
A House Appropriations subcommittee has refused to approve America's share.
Unless the Reagan Administration bestirs itself, the result will be worldwide embarrassment.

LEAD: Artillery duels broke out again between rival Shiite Moslem groups today after the collapse of talks on moving 7,000 Syrian troops into the southern suburbs of Beirut to end the factional fighting.

LEAD: British track officials today delayed a ruling on Zola Budd's eligibility to run for Britain until she returns from her self-imposed rest period in South Africa.


Walter G. Stackler, 83, Long Island Builder
LEAD: Walter G. Stackler, a Long Island builder, died Friday at a nursing home in Delray Beach, Fla., after a long illness.
He was 83 years old and maintained residences in Gulf Stream, Fla., and Roslyn Harbor, L.I.

A Game for Adults
LEAD: Most adults prefer the slower-paced types of computer games, leaving the fast-reflex, arcade-style amusements to younger players.
Golf and baseball simulations, for instance, rely more on judgment and strategy than on lightning-quick reflexes.
Even the most realistic flight simulators are positively contemplative when compared with games in which you blast hordes of aliens.


F.D.A. Approves Cervical Cap As a Device for Birth Control
LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration today approved a birth control device called the cervical cap, a barrier contraceptive that is already available in Europe.

LEAD: Documents said to implicate the Panamanian leader, Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega, in drug-related activities have disappeared from the offices of the Drug Enforcement Administration at the United States Embassy in Panama, a Government official said here tonight.

Sports People; Tolentine Coach to Pitt
LEAD: John Sarandrea, who coached Tolentine High School of the Bronx to a 30-1 record last season, said yesterday he would become an assistant basketball coach at the University of Pittsburgh.
Sarandrea, 30, will replace John Caliperi, who has been named coach at the University of Massachusetts.
Sarandrea said he would give Pitt, coached by Paul Evans, ''some immediate credibility in the New York area,'' where the Panthers have not recruited well.

LEAD: Thousands of Hindu migrant workers from eastern India have fled Punjab after more than 50 of them were killed last week by Sikhs, the state's top police official said today.

LEAD: The American television rights to the 1992 Olympic Winter Games in Albertville, France, are expected to be awarded today to either NBC or CBS.

Silicon Valley Water Report
LEAD: A new study by the California Department of Health Services has concluded that ground-water pollution caused by the Silicon Valley electronics industry was ''probably not'' responsible for the higher-than-normal number of miscarriages and birth defects found in one neighborhood.
Its residents had drunk water contaminated by solvents from the semiconductor plants.

Steel Output Up 0.9%
LEAD: Steel production rose to 2.009 million tons in the week ended Saturday, an increase of nine-tenths of 1 percent from the previous week's 1.991 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The industry's production amounted to 93.8 percent of capacity for the week, compared with 92.9 percent in the previous week.

LEAD: David F. Schoenbrun, the witty and versatile CBS correspondent who was one of Edward R. Murrow's original team in the 1940's, died at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan yesterday morning.
He was 73 years old.

LEAD: Again Mikhail Gorbachev appears both bold and cautious, determined to change his deeply conservative country yet uncertain exactly how.

LEAD: Ron Oglesby figured his days as a pitcher were well behind him.
After all, he's 38 years old and hadn't pitched competitively since 1973.
But when called upon, he quickly came out of retirement.
Oglesby, the pitching coach of the Riverside Red Wave, took the mound in the 20th inning of a California League game against the San Jose Giants in Riverside and wound up suffering the loss in the 6-hour-19-minute game, which ended early yesterday.

Acquisition by Vickers
LEAD: Vickers P.L.C., a British military and automobile company, said today that it was acquiring the Imperial Metal and Chemical Company of Philadelphia for about $12 million.
Imperial, the second-largest provider of aluminum plates to American newspapers, will become part of Howson-Algraphy Ltd., a Vickers subsidiary.

Benedict P. Willis Jr. Chemical Executive, 66
LEAD: Benedict P. Willis Jr., a former vice president of the Stauffer Chemical Company, died of colon cancer Thursday at his home in Rutherford, N.J.
He was 66 years old.


U.S. Rig Count Rises
LEAD: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States increased by nine this week, to a total of 892, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today.
The rig count, the widely watched industry index of drilling activity, totaled 762 a year ago.
The count reflects the number of rigs exploring for oil as of last Friday.

Robert Bedingfield is used to dropping out of the sky and surprising folks.

About eight years ago he landed as pastor at the very rich Reformed Church of Bronxville.

The hardware is the give-away.
There is no trademark double-C on the buttons.
Ms.
Sharpe, who owns the Sharpe Gallery on Wooster Street in SoHo, is a bit of a fashionable fraud.

U.S. Deports 226 Aliens From Jails in New York
LEAD: More than 200 aliens serving sentences at Rikers Island and other New York City jails have been deported in the last year under a Federal and city program, officials said yesterday.


Bishops Decry Anti-Semitism
LEAD: A committee of Italian bishops expressed ''profound concern'' today over a recent upsurge of anti-Semitic threats and violence here, warning Italian Roman Catholics not to hold Jews responsible for Israeli Government policies toward the Palestinian uprising.


Regan and Speakes Draw Fire on Books
LEAD: Books by two former White House staff members, Donald T. Regan and Larry Speakes, should not have been published until President Reagan left office, the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, says.


Grain and Soybean Prices Fall After Weekend Rains
LEAD: Grain and soybean futures prices plunged on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday after a weekend of unexpectedly wet weather in the Midwest.


FMC in Turkish Deal
LEAD: Turkey signed a billion-dollar contract today with the FMC Corporation of the United States and its Turkish partner to build 1,700 armored combat vehicles, Turkish military officials said.
A consortium formed by FMC and the Nurol Group will build the vehicles over 10 years in one of several joint ventures aimed at developing Turkey's military industry, they said.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article last Thursday about the Beretta pistol misidentified the parent company of a Beretta competitor, Smith &amp; Wesson.
It is F. H. Tomkins, a British corporation, which acquired Smith &amp; Wesson in 1987 from the Lear Siegler Holdings Corporation.

LEAD: Indonesia and Spain agreed today to market aircraft jointly in the United States and discussed cooperation in agriculture, energy and tourism.
The Indonesian Minister of State, Murdiono, said the two countries had agreed to form a joint marketing company in the United States to sell Spanish-designed aircraft built in Indonesia by the state aircraft company.

LEAD: The United States Fish and Wildlife Service has decided to allow the Toledo Zoo to begin exhibiting two giant pandas on loan from China while zoo officials work to produce the required export papers, the service said today.

LEAD: Count Dino Grandi, an early leader of the Italian Fascists and a close ally of Mussolini, died on Saturday at his home in Bologna.
He was 92 years old and, according to a report by the state-run Italian television network, had suffered from cardiac and circulatory problems for some time.

Iran Reports Raids on Iraqis
LEAD: Iran said its jets flew five bombing missions Monday against Iraqi positions east of Basra, inflicting heavy losses on enemy troops and equipment.
The Teheran radio, monitored here, said all attacking jets returned safely from the raids on the southern front.
In another report, the radio said Iranian military exercises in the Gulf of Oman continued for a second day on Monday.

Bunshaft and Niemeyer Share Architecture Prize
LEAD: Gordon Bunshaft and Oscar Niemeyer, two of modern architecture's venerated masters, were awarded the Pritzker Architecture Prize yesterday in Chicago.
The presentation marks the first time that the award, which is given annually for achievement in architecture as an art and carries a $100,000 stipend, has been divided between two architects.

Comings and Goings
LEAD: The United States Olympic Hall of Fame, created in 1979, will induct five former Olympians tomorrow night aboard the M.S.
Seaward at Pier 88, 12th Avenue and West 55th Street.
The inductees are Bill Bradley, captain of the 1964 gold medal men's basketball team; the late Charles Daniels, winner of five gold medals in swimming in 1904, 1906 and 1908; Mal Whitfield, winner of three gold medals in track in 1948 and 1952; Tenley Albright, winner of a gold medal and a silver medal in women's figure skating in 1952 and 1956; and Jim McKay, the sports broadcaster, a special contributor.

LEAD: Hong Kong's trade deficit doubled in April from its level a year earlier, the Census and Statistics Department reported today.

LEAD: After more than 30 years of launching its own rockets, the Government has for the first time hired someone else to do the job.


Canadians Facing Fight On Trade Bill
LEAD: The Canadian Government went before Parliament today with legislation that would put into effect the free-trade agreement with the United States.
But the measure received a cool greeting, indicating it may take the Government several months to get the bill passed in the House of Commons.


Ford Chairman Backs Tax Idea
LEAD: The chairman of the Ford Motor Company on Monday endorsed the idea of a national value-added sales tax as a method of reducing the United States trade deficit and the Federal budget deficit.

Sandinistas Said to Prepare an Attack
LEAD: United States and Honduran officials say Nicaraguan forces appear to be preparing to attack the contras if cease-fire talks fail to produce a negotiated settlement to the civil war.


Mexican Oil Tank Fire Forces Mass Evacuation
LEAD: At least 20,000 Mexicans fled from their homes today when a fire at an oil storage depot threatened to ignite millions of gallons of gasoline.


'Into the Woods' Wins Award
LEAD: ''Into the Woods'' was selected by the Drama Desk yesterday as the outstanding musical of the 1987-88 season. ''M.
Butterfly'' was named best new play and ''Anything Goes'' the outstanding revival.
The Drama Desk, formed in 1949, is an association of New York critics, editors and reporters.


Where Are the Fathers?
LEAD: To The Living Section:


A Touch of Surrealism, Ready to Wear
LEAD: ''NOT OUT OF FASHION'' was the title of the fashion show last week that highlighted the New York Academy of Art's spring benefit for its scholarship fund.
But only a few of the clothes shown (direct from Seventh Avenue) have ever been in fashion.
The rest, designed by artists, architects and Off Off Seventh Avenue talents, were infinitely imaginative.


Propane Truck Fire Disrupts L.I. Traffic
LEAD: Three major transportation arteries on Long Island were closed yesterday for most of the day when a tank truck carrying as much as 3,000 gallons of propane overturned and burst into flames on the Seaford-Oyster Bay Expressway, causing large traffic delays and congestion.


U.N. CHIEF MAKING NEW GULF EFFORT
LEAD: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar has started a new effort to bring about a cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war and restore credibility to the Security Council's attempts to end the conflict, according to diplomats and United Nations officials.


Alfred C. Clapp, 84; Former Jersey Judge Led Kean Campaign
LEAD: Alfred C. Clapp, a former New Jersey judge who managed Governor Kean's first successful gubernatorial campaign, died of heart disease Monday at his home in Montclair, N.J.
He was 84 years old.


60-Minute Gourmet
LEAD: MANY cooks use the terms fricassee and stew interchangeably, although there are fundamental differences between the two.


Dow Rebounds 21.05 on Blue-Chip Trading
LEAD: Some institutional bargain hunting among blue-chip issues helped the stock market averages yesterday.
But plays to capture utility dividends accounted for a large part of the volume.

The Treaty and Its Enemies
LEAD: For a while, it looked as though several willful men could derail the Euromissile treaty and President Reagan's wish to make the treaty a centerpiece of his summit meeting in Moscow next week.
Two of them are Jesse Helms and Gordon Humphrey, Republican Senators who have been trying to obstruct ratification with one niggling amendment after another.


9 Accused of Arranging Marriages So Aliens Could Gain Citizenship
LEAD: Nine people were arrested today and charged in two separate schemes that provided mates - and the promise of United States citizenship - to foreign nationals in exchange for money, the United States Attorney said.

LEAD: When Frank Hague, starting in 1918, insinuated his political machine into every facet of Jersey City life, including the school system, he planted roots so deep that they have continued to surface to the present day.

LEAD: Ivan Lendl, ranked No. 1 among the men, and Martina Navratilova, No. 2 among the women, today led a string of veterans into the second round of the French Open.

Arthur M. Kreidmann, Lawyer, 80
LEAD: Arthur M. Kreidmann, a partner in the New York law firm of Weil, Gotshal &amp; Manges, died of complications from a heart attack Saturday at Mount Sinai Medical Center.
He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: She has been vilified and ridiculed, gossiped about and even dreaded by some who work in the White House, but Nancy Reagan remains the President's most influential and trusted adviser.

Metro Datelines; Mother Dies in Leap; Girl, 6, Found Dead
LEAD: A woman from Waterford who had apparently killed her daughter jumped to her death Tuesday from the Gold Star Bridge on Interstate 95 into the Thames River, the police said.


Review/Film; Rugged Tasmanian Grandeur
LEAD: ''The Tale of Ruby Rose'' tries hard to live up to the mountains and mists of Tasmania's central highlands, where it is set in 1933, but the story cannot compete with the country's rugged grandeur.
Ruby Rose makes her rough home in the wilderness with her trapper-skinner husband, Henry, and a young fellow whom they have adopted.


Murray Ohio Stock Jumps $8, to $59.25
LEAD: Shares of the Murray Ohio Manufacturing Company soared $8, to $59.25, on the New York Stock Exchange, indicating that investors expect Sweden's A.B.
Electrolux to raise its current $52-a-share bid.
Market analysts have said the offer must rise to at least $227 million - $60 a share -to be accepted.


New Storage Function For Digital Audio Tape
LEAD: DIGITAL audio tape, embroiled in a controversy as a consumer product, will soon come to market in another guise - as a computer data storage medium.


Chip Maker's I.B.M. Accord
LEAD: Chips and Technologies Inc. said today that it had reached an understanding with the International Business Machines Corporation so it would not need a license for its products under I.B.M.'s patents.

LEAD: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's message to Congress discussing his veto of the Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act of 1988.
Notice of Plant Closings


Northrop to Drop 700 MX Workers
LEAD: The Northrop Corporation said it will dismiss about 700 employees working on the MX missile-guidance system in Hawthorne, Calif., by year-end as the company's engineering requirements decline.
The move represents 18 percent of the 3,800-member division work force and will primarily affect engineers and support staff.


Bridge
LEAD: Until a decade ago, the bylines of North America's major syndicated bridge columnists (Becker, Goren, Jacoby and Sheinwold) remained unchanged for a generation.


44 Unhurt as Jet Lands at Abandoned Strip
LEAD: A Boeing 737 jetliner making an approach to New Orleans in bad weather lost power in both engines today and made an emergency landing near an abandoned World War II airstrip six miles short of the airport.

Capital Inflow Called Helpful
LEAD: Large inflows of foreign capital into the United States can help to increase United States productivity, a Federal Reserve Board governor, Wayne D. Angell, said today.


New Company Finds Success Selling 'Champagne of Teas'
LEAD: IN a storefront in downtown New Bedford, Mass., a 32-year-old entrepreneur, Sam Barrows, is busy packing his imported Darjeeling tea.
What distinguishes Barrows's brand Darjeeling Tea from other Darjeelings is its single-estate provenance: it is one of a handful of unblended Darjeeling teas sold in this country.


Surprising Choice on Saturn Ads
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday that it had chosen Hal Riney &amp; Partners, a relatively small advertising agency best known for its commercials for Bartles &amp; Jaymes wine coolers, to create advertising for the Saturn, its new line of cars.


J. C. Penney Sells New York Building
LEAD: The J. C. Penney Company said it had sold its Manhattan quarters at 1301 Avenue of the Americas for $350 million to a partnership consisting of two national developers - Tishman Speyer Properties Inc. of New York and Trammell Crow Real Estate Investors of Dallas.
William R. Howell, Penney's chairman, said the sale would result in a $150 million after-tax gain, to be recorded in August, when the closing is scheduled.

INSIDE
LEAD:  Budget Battle in Albany


They're Young and Chosen and Dancing
LEAD: Oscar Bravo's third-grade schoolmates teased him when he was chosen to study ballet at the New Ballet School, a program sponsored by the Feld Ballet in cooperation with the New York City Board of Education.


BRIEFS
LEAD: AMP Inc., Harrisburg, Pa., agreed to acquire the shares it does not already own of Matrix Science Corp.


Death Sentence in Missouri
LEAD: A Missouri dairy farmer was sentenced to death today for the slaying of his wife and two nephews in September.
Judge John E. Parrish followed the recommendation of the jury that convicted 37-year-old James Schnick last month and imposed the death sentence.
The defendant will be the 60th inmate on death row in Missouri, where no one has been executed since 1965.


Dorsett Deal Near
LEAD: Tony Dorsett, a Dallas Cowboys' running back, said he could be traded to the Denver Broncos this week, when the Broncos make a new proposal on his hefty contract.
The proposal, which would retire Dorsett's $6 million annuity, is expected in the next few days, according to an interview with Dorsett in The Dallas Morning News yesterday.


A Summer Preview (but Don't Put Those Raincoats Away)
LEAD: Strollers enjoyed the promenade along the East River at the United Nations yesterday as the temperature hit 83 degrees.
Cloudy skies and rain are expected today, however, with a high in the 60's. (NYT/Chester Higgins Jr.)

A Boon to Volunteerism
LEAD: To The Living Section:


Leiter Rebounds As Yankees Win
LEAD: When the no-hitter finally faded in the sixth inning tonight, Al Leiter did not react.
He simply watched Wally Joyner's single drop softly into center field, then waited for the ball to return to the pitcher's mound.


Crazy Eddie Loss
LEAD: Crazy Eddie Inc., now under the control of a new board backed by Entertainment Marketing Inc., said it expects to report additional, significant losses for the fourth quarter ended Feb. 28.
The company said the latest losses were caused by insufficient sales, a soft consumer electronics market, adjustments arising from the new management's completion of its evaluation of the company and certain business practices and policies of prior management.


Parents Call Reading Vital but ...
LEAD: Nearly all parents think reading is very important to their children's success but only a bare majority report their children are very interested in reading, according to a national survey released today.

Another Sad Polish Joke
LEAD: The story of Stefan Olszowski is so absurd it would be hilarious, if the ruination that he and his comrades have visited on Poland were not so sad.


CBS Is Awarded '92 Winter Games
LEAD: The American television rights to the 1992 Winter Olympics in Albertville, France, were awarded yesterday to CBS Sports, whose bid of $243 million exceeded the International Olympic Committee's expectation by $43 million and NBC's bid by as much as $68 million.


Thomas H. A. Lewis; Film Producer Was 86
LEAD: Thomas H. A. Lewis, a film and broadcasting producer and writer who founded the Armed Forces Radio Service during World War II, died Friday at his home in Ojai, Calif.
He was 86 years old.


No Lights, Then No Crowd; Hockey Halted for the Night
LEAD: In the year of the playoff jinx for the National Hockey League, the league's image grew still darker tonight.
A power failure in Boston Garden late in the second period forced officials to order the fans to leave the arena and then suspend the fourth game of the Stanley Cup championship series between the Boston Bruins and the Edmonton Oilers.

Vartanig G. Vartan Is Dead at 64; Times Financial Writer Since '63
LEAD: Vartanig G. Vartan, the main writer of the ''Market Place'' column in The New York Times since 1983, died of cancer at Roosevelt Hospital early yesterday.
He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Queen Elizabeth's representative in New Zealand has resigned as a leader of an animal protection group after complaints that he clubbed two pigs to death in ritual ceremonies.

LEAD: Mid-May sales of new American-made cars and light trucks rose 2.6 percent above the comparable period last year, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

He was 72 years old.

What Exit Polls Don't Predict

Ohio Power Selling 9 7/8% Bonds at Par
LEAD: The Ohio Power Company, a unit of the American Electric Power Company, is offering $100 million of first-mortgage bonds through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Hutton, which won the financing in competitive bidding.


Harper &amp; Row Names a New Chief
LEAD: George Craig, who had been joint chief executive of Harper &amp; Row Publishers Inc., has been named chief executive and president of the publishing company.


New Grolier President
LEAD: Hachette S.A. said yesterday that it had appointed Eric Laffont as the president and chief operating officer of Grolier Inc.
Mr.
Laffont succeeds Andrew J. Reinhart, who is retiring.
Robert B. Clark will remain chairman and chief executive of Grolier, which is a textbook publisher based in Danbury, Conn.


Students Turning to Nonprofit Companies for Tuition Loans
LEAD: Margaret E. Hankard, a 23-year-old student at the University of Massachusetts, learned last year that scholarship and marriage are not always a happy union, at least as far as the Federal Government is concerned.


BID FOR TAKEOVER OF SCHOOL DISTRICT IS BEGUN BY JERSEY
LEAD: Declaring that Jersey City's public schools are plagued by a ''cycle of failure,'' New Jersey's Education Commissioner moved today to have the state take over the district for at least five years.


Thaddeus W. Hentz, Advertising Executive, 61
LEAD: Thaddeus William Hentz, a retired vice president of Foote, Cone &amp; Belding Advertising Inc., died of heart failure May 7 at the Head Injury Center at Highgate in Troy, N.Y.
He was 61 years old and lived in Allendale, N.J.


Tour Moves to Ban New Irons
LEAD: The PGA Tour took a first step today to ban irons with U-shaped or square grooves and restrict its players to clubs with V-shaped grooves, the only modern clubs played before 1984.

Review/Theater; 'Romeo and Juliet' in the Shakespeare Marathon
LEAD: The New York Shakespeare Festival's Shakespeare Marathon, which got off to a fizzy start (''A Midsummer Night's Dream'') before shifting into low gear (''Julius Caesar''), has come to a dead halt with ''Romeo and Juliet.'' The production at the Public Theater is so devoid of pulse that it seems a form of indentured servitude.

LEAD: Dvorak's fairy-tale opera ''Rusalka,'' long recognized as a masterpiece in the Slavic world, has been gaining apostles in the West of late.

Rolls-Royce Jet Engine
LEAD: The chairman of Rolls-Royce P.L.C., Sir Francis Tombs, said today that his company expects to receive certificates of airworthiness for the V2500 engine next month.
He told the company's first annual meeting since privatization last year that the engine would go into service in 1989 as planned.
The V2500 was developed by a joint venture whose participants included Rolls-Royce, the United Technologies Corporation's Pratt &amp; Whitney unit and Fiat S.p.A.


'Streetcar' Closes
LEAD: ''A Streetcar Named Desire,'' a revival of Tennessee Williams's 1947 drama, closed after the Sunday matinee at the uptown Circle in the Square Theater.
Directed by Nikos Psacharopoulos, the play ran for 85 regular performances and 20 previews.


Corrections
LEAD: A Health page article on May 12 about prenatal diagnosis misidentified an institution conducting research in the field.
It is the medical center of the University of California at San Francisco.


Soybeans Resume Advance As Dry Weather Returns
LEAD: Shaking off the effects of last weekend's rains, the soybean futures market resumed its dry-weather rally yesterday.
Prices of some contracts advanced nearly the 30-cents-a-bushel daily limit.

LEAD: The Defense Department, long suspected of fashioning an acronym for a program or weapon before actually giving it a name, appears to have outdone itself.

Soccer Fans Riot
LEAD: Clashes in London during an exhibition game between fans of the national teams of England and Scotland last Saturday at Wembley Stadium resulted in injuries to 90 people and the arrests of 200.
Also hurt were the chances that English teams would be readmitted next season to Europe's three club soccer competitions, a leading official of the sport's ruling body for the European continent said yesterday.

LEAD: Deciding that it was best not to tinker with history, residents here have affirmed a vote by their forebears 200 years ago and have voted against ratification of the United States Constitution. Study Finds Chemotherapy Can Be Cut by 25% for Testicle Cancer
LEAD: The extent of chemotherapy needed to cure cancer of the testicles can be safely reduced by 25 percent, sparing men from some of the misery of the effective but difficult treatment, a study has found.

LEAD: A series of slowdowns and other job actions by the drivers' union have curtailed distribution of The New York Times in some areas.

We regret the inconvenience to our readers.

Honor at Yale
LEAD: For several years, Yale University has been manufacturing an astounding number of gifted students.
In 1986, for example, more than half the graduating class received honors of one sort or another.
The class of 1987 slipped a bit; even so, 46.4 percent graduated with honors - 23.9 percent cum laude, 11.5 percent magna cum laude, and 11 percent summa cum laude.

Trade Deficit Cut Seen
LEAD: C. William Verity Jr., Secretary of Commerce, predicted today that the United States trade deficit would be cut more than 15 percent this year, to below $150 billion.
Secretary Verity, interviewed on NBC's ''Today'' program, forecast that the Reagan Administration would cut last year's $171 billion deficit to a little below $150 billion and said he believed it could be cut below $100 billion in two or three years.


What's Fresh, Crisp and Grilled?
LEAD: WHEN it comes to grilling, vegetables often get shortchanged.
All the attention goes to those juicy, sizzling steaks that send mouthwatering aromas into the soft summer air.
If vegetables do make an appearance on the grill, they are usually stabbed through the heart with skewers, and included only to give color to a brochette.

LEAD: Big Eight basketball coaches who persist in publicly criticizing game officials next year could be suspended for one game under a policy adopted yesterday. LEAD: In vetoing the trade bill, President Reagan made the right move for the wrong reason.
The quick House vote to override was just wrong - a Democratic election-year stunt.
The supposed point of this massive exercise was to expand trade.
Yet the bill that finally emerged is a monster of disguised protectionism that would do the opposite.

Coach Serves Notice
LEAD: After coaching the United States men's volleyball team to victories at the 1985 World Cup and the 1986 world championships, Marv Dunphy will return to college coaching after the Summer Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea.
Dunphy, who in three years as coach of the United States team has a 162-27 record, will return to Pepperdine in Malibu, Calif., as men's volleyball coach, a position he held before taking the job as coach of the American team.

Compaq's Sales
LEAD: A shortage of computer chips has limited production at the fast-growing Compaq Computer Corporation.
The company said second-quarter sales would be reduced by the shortage of memory chips, which has squeezed manufacturing for the entire United States computer industry.


Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q.I live in an old house with wood floors, and in one room the floor squeaks when you walk across it.
Is this a major problem, or is there a simple remedy?
A.It is seldom a major problem, although in rare cases it can indicate a structural defect.
Squeaking is most often due to loose floorboards that move up and down when stepped on, making the edges squeak as they rub against each other.


Karl A. Wittfogel, Social Scientist Who Turned on Communists, 91
LEAD: Karl August Wittfogel, a social scientist and former Communist whose theories caused him to be denounced in Communist circles, died of pneumonia yesterday at St.
Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan.
He was 91 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption on the Education page on Wednesday about Washington University in St.
Louis misidentified a campus building.
The building shown in the photograph was Graham Chapel.

LEAD: Minstar Inc. said it had agreed to an improved buyout offer from its controlling shareholder and chairman, Irwin L. Jacobs, valued at $400 million.
Minstar signed a merger agreement under which a group led by Mr.
Jacobs will conduct a leveraged buyout of the company at $31.50 a share in cash, up from a previous offer of $29.

LEAD: The Senate, by voice vote, today approved a bill that would ban the manufacture, sale or possession of plastic firearms and other weapons not detectable by security devices.
The action clears the way for a conference committee to work out a compromise with the House, which overwhelmingly approved similar legislation earlier this month.

They're good old-fashioned small-town parades, with fire engines and police cars and high-school cheerleaders carrying their pompons and kicking their legs in the air.

LEAD: American Ballet Theater's production of ''Don Quixote,'' staged by Mikhail Baryshnikov after choreography by Marius Petipa and Alexander Gorsky, is an unflagging swirl of toreador capes and gypsy skirts.
The women all jump on point, the men flirt and quaff wine and there is even a little bravura dancing tucked into the proceedings.


U.S. AGENCY VOTES BAN ON A DART TOY
LEAD: The Consumer Product Safety Commission voted today to ban most lawn darts, citing the danger of death or serious injury from the pointed metal darts.


Moscow Issuing Visas To Israel's Delegation
LEAD: The Soviet Union has agreed to issue visas that would allow an official Israeli delegation to visit Moscow for the first time since the Kremlin broke off relations in 1967.


Behind Big Gap in Cuomo Budget: A Big Gamble Lost
LEAD: Just five weeks after its budget was enacted, the Cuomo administration says the state will be $900 million in the red, and the story of how it came to be that way, according to state officials and independent economists, is one of politics and miscalculation.


Nonprofit Tax Plans Advance
LEAD: After two days of closed-door debate, a House subcommittee today tentatively endorsed a package of proposals for taxing more types of income-producing activities of nonprofit organizations.


College Extends Honor Roll to High-School Teachers
LEAD: Cornell University today did something rare among the nation's colleges: It honored some of the high-school teachers of its top undergraduates.

GERMANS ARE WARY OF JEWISH SCANDAL
LEAD: In the week since the news broke that the much-honored head of West Germany's main Jewish organization evidently helped himself to millions in money intended for victims of the Nazis, the dominant reaction among politicians and newspapers has been a nervous circumspection.


Female Sportswriters Make Their Mark
LEAD: Female sportswriters, who once toiled for months at a time without seeing another member of their sex, are now numerous enough to have formed a professional organization that gathered here this week for its first convention.


U.S. Aluminum Outlook
LEAD: Aluminum output in the United States is likely to rise 15 percent this year, to 3.85 million metric tons, reversing a slump during most of the 1980's, the London office of Shearson Lehman Hutton said today.
It cited declining production costs and the fall in the dollar, making American smelters more competitive.

Golfer Hospitalized
LEAD: Byron Nelson, the Hall of Fame golfer, was admitted to a hospital yesterday after he complained of dizziness and fatigue.


How Banquets Can Feed Ethiopians
LEAD: The Ethiopian Government of Lieut.
Col.
Mengistu Haile Mariam appears bent on starving some two million people.
It refuses to allow international relief agencies access to stricken areas.
According to a State Department calculation, only 850,000 people are being fed out of perhaps three million threatened by famine.


John David House, 83, Co-Founder of Union
LEAD: John David House, a founder of the 110,000-member United Rubber Workers union, died Sunday.
He was 83 years old.


Passing Lie Test Said to Lead To Howard Beach Plea Deal
LEAD: A plea deal in the Howard Beach racial-attack case was made possible when a defendant passed two lie-detector tests backing his position that he had not seen the beating of a black man, according to people familiar with the case.


N.F.L. Roster Move
LEAD: National Football League owners voted to increase rosters to 47 players and approved the conditional sale of the New England Patriots to the Reebok International chairman, Paul Fireman, before adjourning their annual spring meeting yesterday at Miami Beach, Fla.


Precious Metals Off Broadly As Inflation Worries Ease
LEAD: Precious metals futures prices fell broadly yesterday on profit taking as fears of inflation eased and the dollar gained strength against other currencies.


Gardeners All, British Flock To Chelsea
LEAD: From noble Queen to common daisy, the ranking fauna and flora of the kingdom are congregating brightly here this week for the Chelsea Flower Show, a 75-year-old event that has evolved from a diversion for the Edwardian aristocracy to a blockbuster for the modern gardener.


Toll Mounts as Fighting Continues in Lebanon
LEAD: Shiite Amal militiamen taking cover behind a bullet-pocked wall as they battled pro-Iranian fighters yesterday in the southern suburbs of Beirut.
Syrian and Iranian efforts to end the fighting have been unsuccessful.
The Lebanese police said 296 people have been killed and 1,000 wounded in 20 days of fighting.
