2 at Princeton Get Jail Terms For Roles in Pledge Drinking
LEAD: Saying he would not treat the case ''as an undergraduate frolic that got out of hand,'' a judge yesterday sentenced two officers of one of Princeton University's private eating clubs to 30 days in jail for their roles in parties in February during which 45 students suffered alcohol-induced medical problems.

Where do you turn?

He was 69 years old and lived in Vero Beach, Fla.

LEAD: A former convict being held in Philadelphia as a suspect in the slaying of a housing police officer in Brooklyn was indicted yesterday for the killing.

HELMS ENDS FIGHT AGAINST ARMS PACT
LEAD: Outflanked and outmaneuvered, Senator Jesse Helms gave up his fight against the new missile treaty today, paving the way for a compromise agreement that could permit the Senate to vote final approval of the treaty as early as Friday afternoon.


Funeral Service for Slain Judge
LEAD: The coffin of Judge Richard J. Daronco being carried yesterday from St.
Catherine's Church in Pelham, N.Y.
Judge Daronco, only the second Federal judge to be assassinated this century, was killed Saturday by a retired New York City police officer, apparently because of the judge's dismissal of a Federal sex discrimination suit filed by the killer's daughter.


Manila Journal; Battling the 'Culture of Corruption' Day by Day
LEAD: One day, a neighbor told Miriam Defensor Santiago, the Commissioner of Immigration, that there was a burglar in her house.


Corrections
LEAD: The movie review and listing last Sunday on page 7 of the Television section for May 22-28 included ''The Birth of a Nation'' erroneously.
The program, on Channel 13 tonight at 10, is a contemporary British drama in the ''Channel Crossings'' series, not the 1915 film.


Review/Television; 'Omnibus,' a Potpourri From ABC
LEAD: ''Omnibus'' is a venerable name; it was the title of the wonderful series that ran first on CBS and then on ABC from 1953 to 1957.
High art and Pop art mixed, and then along came Jacques Cousteau or Jack Benny.
ABC News resurrects the series tonight with a special at 10 o'clock.
It is also called ''Omnibus,'' and it is intelligent and easy and nice.

LEAD: Three small oppositon parties in Singapore have announced that they will form an alliance to challenge the People's Action Party of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew in the next election.


Renaissance Picks Editor
LEAD: Robert Manning, 68 years old, former editor in chief of The Atlantic, has been named editor in chief of Renaissance, the Magazine for Living Well, which is expected to seek an audience of readers 55 and over who are both sophisticated and affluent.


Bridge
LEAD: The world's oldest pair event, the Goldman, will be contested for the 60th time Saturday.

LEAD: A House-Senate conference committee reached agreement today on legislation to protect the nation's Medicare beneficiaries against the cost of prolonged, acute illness.


A STALEMATE ENDS FOR CONTRA TALKS
LEAD: Contra leaders announced today that they planned to travel to Managua to open a third round of peace talks with the Sandinista Government, ending a stalemate over where the talks would be held.


For Airbag's Inventor, 17-Year Wait Pays Off
LEAD: John Pietz has spent 17 years tinkering in the laboratories of Talley Industries waiting for his favorite invention to pay off.
Now, two years away from retirement, the chemist responsible for a key breakthrough in the development of automotive airbags is finally seeing his discovery become standard equipment on many cars.

LEAD: Wesley McDonald Holder chooses his words carefully, as someone might who can apply nine decades of perspective to today's political conundrums.


Leon Shimkin, a Guiding Force At Simon &amp; Schuster, Dies at 81
LEAD: Leon Shimkin, who joined Simon &amp; Schuster as a 17-year-old bookkeeper and helped build it into one of the nation's major book publishing companies, died yesterday in New Rochelle Hospital in New Rochelle, N.Y.
A resident of Larchmont, N.Y., he was 81 years old.


Defense Counsel Seized as a Fake
LEAD: A man on probation in Westchester County for impersonating a lawyer was arrested on the same charge yesterday in a Manhattan courtroom.

Development Bank Offers 9 3/8% Notes
LEAD: The Asian Development Bank is offering $100 million of 9 3/8 percent notes due in 1995 at a price of 99.77 to yield 9.42 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.


American Stores Accedes to F.T.C.
LEAD: The American Stores Company said it had agreed with Federal regulators not to buy any shares of Lucky Stores Inc. until Saturday.
A 10-day waiting period expired today, following American's filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on its $2.5 billion buyout bid for Lucky, the country's sixth-largest grocery retailer.

Blueprint For Architects
LEAD: ATTITUDES About Architects Department: At the recent convention in New York of the American Institute of Architects, the pollster Louis Harris presented the results of a survey the institute had commissioned on what people think about architects.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about Zaire's politics and economy referred incorrectly to the country's living standard.
The average Zairian's wages, after accounting for inflation, are 10 percent of what they were in 1960.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Saatchi's Net Up 23.6%
LEAD: Britain's Saatchi &amp; Saatchi, the largest advertising holding company in the world and the parent of a number of agencies, announced its financial results for the six months ended March 31.
Revenues were up 25.1 percent, to $714.3 million, from $571 million in the 1987 period.
Net income rose 23.6 percent, to $40.8 million, from $33 million, or $1.18 for each American depository receipt, compared with $1 a year earlier.


National Parks Urged to Ban All Concessions
LEAD: The Federal Government should move all hotels and other concessions out of the national parks, an environmental group said Tuesday in issuing a report on what it considers the 10 most threatened parks.


CNW to Sell Unit
LEAD: The CNW Corporation said it had agreed to sell its snowplow manufacturing unit, Douglas Dynamics Inc, to Park-Kenilworth Industries for $100 million.
Park-Kenilworth is a new holding company affiliated with the Grabill Corporation, a closely held suburban Chicago company.
Douglas Dynamics is the nation's largest manufacturer of medium-size snowplows, sold under the Western and Fisher brands, for use on four-wheel-drive pickup trucks and utility vehicles.

Manuel Antonio Noriega to leave the country.

LEAD: Mozambican and South African officials agreed at a meeting in Maputo today to revive a nonaggression pact prohibiting support for guerrilla groups operating from each other's territories.


Outlook for Summit: Not Much Chance of Breakthrough on Arms Accords
LEAD: The summit meeting in Moscow may be the last chance for the superpowers to revive the prospects for completing a new strategic arms treaty before President Reagan leaves office.


Mexican Output Surges
LEAD: Mexico's public finances improved in the first quarter while exports remained strong and inflation dropped sharply, according to Finance Minister Gustavo Petricioli.
He told the Mexican Congress Tuesday that industrial production climbed 9.7 percent after a rise of 3.1 percent in the final quarter of 1987 and a drop of 2.5 percent in the first 1987 quarter.


Umbrellas, Parasols And Replacement Ribs
LEAD: SHOW me someone who has to open and close umbrellas indoors all day long and I'll show you someone who isn't superstitious. ''I can't afford to be,'' said Gilbert Center, manager of the Uncle Sam Umbrella Shop, which has manufactured, sold and repaired umbrellas since 1866.


Critic's Notebook; The Images at Cannes, On and Off the Screen
LEAD: The circus has left town.
Within 12 hours of the close of the Cannes Film Festival Monday night, most of the 20,000 or so film people have departed.
The huge advertising billboards along the Croisette have suddenly vanished.
Concierges, waiters and taxi drivers have become polite again.
The noise level has dropped by half and even the winds have stopped.


Angola Says U.S. Uses Zaire Bases to Train Rebels
LEAD: Angolan military commanders have charged that the United States is using six bases in southern Zaire to train and supply Jonas Savimbi's rebels for attacks in Angola.

Reviews/Music; One-Man Trombone Choir
LEAD: Albert Mangelsdorff, a West German trombonist who played solo concerts at the Knitting Factory on Friday and Saturday nights, is best known for his technique: he'll play three or four notes at once, or move a melody around over static tones.
At first it's a shock to hear the sound of a trombone choir coming from one person.

Quintuplets Born in Texas
LEAD: Quintuplets were born Tuesday to a 28-year-old woman who thought she was having twins. ''They told me two,'' Maria Esther Chavez said in Spanish. ''They're fine, thanks to God.'' Mrs.
Chavez said she was about 7 1/2 months pregnant when a girl was born about 1 A.M., followed by another girl, then three boys, within about four minutes.

Acid Fumes Fell 7 in Bronx
LEAD: Seven staff members received medical treatment yesterday after inhaling fumes from sulfuric acid that had been poured into a drain at the Bronx State Hospital, a Fire Department spokesman said.
The acid apparently came from a laboratory at the hospital at 1500 Waters Place, near the Hutchinson River Parkway.


Hanoi Plans 50,000-Man Pullout From Cambodia
LEAD: Western diplomats said today that they had been told that Vietnam was withdrawing 50,000 troops from Cambodia by the end of this year.

New I.B.M.Wafers
LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation said it had begun making computer chips from the biggest wafers in the industry - platters that are eight inches across.
Most semiconductor manufacturers use wafers that are four to six inches across.
I.B.M. said the bigger wafers can cost less and increase productivity.


Airbags on the Way As Chrysler Gives In
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation's decision to install airbags as standard equipment on several car lines this year and all its domestically made cars by 1990 signals the end of a nearly 20-year battle over use of the devices, according to auto industry executives and safety advocates.


Review/Ballet; Young Dancers in Recital
LEAD: Among the pleasures of attending the annual workshop programs by the School of American Ballet is that of seeing young dancers cope with the artistic challenges of ballets in several styles.
There was much to applaud in the performances offered Saturday and Monday nights at the Juilliard Theater.

Soviet Lists Afghan War Toll: 13,310 Dead, 35,478 Wounded
LEAD: The Soviet Union, ending a long silence about the exact number of its casualties in the war in Afghanistan, said today that 13,310 soldiers had been killed, 35,478 wounded and 311 are missing.


Death Ends 1,600-Mile Flight Of Learjet Stolen by Mechanic
LEAD: A flight mechanic who did not have a pilot's license stole a private jet in Virginia early today and flew it 1,600 miles to Denver, where he shot himself to death as the authorities closed in, officials said.


Relatives Ruled Eligible to Lease Vacated Units
LEAD: In a decision that further complicates the legal and political debate over who can inherit a rent-stabilized apartment, a New York State appeals panel ruled yesterday that live-in relatives could take over an apartment after the tenant named on a lease dies.


Reagan in Finland to Rest Before Summit
LEAD: President Reagan arrived here tonight for three days of rest before continuing to Moscow for his summit meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, but the traveling White House was distracted by lingering political troubles at home.


Jordan Named M.V.P.
LEAD: Michael Jordan, the National Basketball Association's scoring champion for the last two seasons, was named the league's most valuable player yesterday.

LEAD: Olympia &amp; York Developments Ltd. sait it would increase its stake in four companies, including the Campeau Corporation.
The real estate development company also said it would increase its majority stakes in Gulf Canada Resources Ltd., Abitibi-Price Inc. and GW Utilities Ltd.

LEAD: According to the latest polls, Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis's biggest problem now is deciding what to say in his inaugural address.


Corrigan Sees Market Flaw
LEAD: The financial markets need stronger systems for clearing and settling trades to help reduce the risk of a large default that could snowball and tie up the system, E. Gerald Corrigan, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said yesterday.


Shows in Accord With Guild
LEAD: David Letterman could return to the air and Johnny Carson would have his writers back under agreements both entertainers have reached with the striking Writers Guild of America, the union's president said Wednesday as talks resumed in the 12-week-old strike.

LEAD: In Sproul Plaza, the central gathering place on the University of California campus here, students congregate in racial groups, the blacks in one part of the great flagstone expanse, the whites in another.

Reviews/Music; 4 Scarlatti Piano Sonatas
LEAD: Christine Diwyk is a pianist who plays with startling power, clarity and variety, and who puts her impressive technique at the service of consistently insightful interpretive ideas.
At Weill Recital Hall on Sunday afternoon, she addressed works that ranged from the delicate to the grandiose, and from the formal to the impassioned, and retained a persuasive gracefulness from start to finish.

Killer Admits More Murders
LEAD: Richard Kuklinski, who was convicted in March of murdering two accomplices in a crime ring, pleaded guilty today to two other killings and confessed to a fifth murder.
In return for the pleas, prosecutors agreed to drop weapons possession charges against his 46-year-old wife, Barbara, and dismiss unrelated drug and weapons charges against his 19-year-old son, Dwayne.

LEAD: A switching station fire that melted fiber optic communications lines, damaged computers and interrupted telephone service in the suburbs of Chicago has raised questions about whether the nation's telephone system is becoming more vulnerable to major disruptions.

To Our Readers
LEAD: A series of slowdowns and other job actions by the drivers' union have curtailed distribution of The New York Times in some areas.
These actions are associated with contract negotiations, and The Times is unable to say how long the disruptions may continue.
We regret the inconvenience to our readers.


Margaret M. Ryan, Editor, 70
LEAD: Margaret M. Ryan, a retired editor with House Beautiful magazine, died of a heart attack yesterday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.
She was 70 years old and lived in Sparta, N.J.

LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were modestly higher for the week ended yesterday.


Chicago Smoking Ban Is Passed by Aldermen
LEAD: Aldermen in the nation's third-largest city approved an ordinance today that sponsors said would bar smoking in most public areas and force restaurant owners and employers to create smoking sections.

U.S. Abandons Effort to Persuade Noriega to Yield Power in Panama
LEAD: The Reagan Administration announced today that it had failed in its campaign to persuade Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega to give up power in Panama, and it said it would not engage in any more talks with him.


Reviews/Music; Pianist in Chopin and Liszt
LEAD: Krystian Zimerman is a pianist with so much to give that one longs for him to choose his gifts more carefully.
His program at Avery Fisher Hall Sunday afternoon settled into the deep ruts of familiar repertory - the Ballades and Fantasy in F minor of Chopin and the Liszt Sonata.
It is territory crossed and recrossed so many thousands of times in this city and elsewhere that its beautiful prospects and startling promontories no longer startle.

Commuter Chaos: Accidents and Rain
LEAD: As flames billowed from a disabled propane tank truck on Long Island for a second day yesterday, the traffic jams the accident created symbolized a chaotic day for commuters in the New York metropolitan region.


Navy Is Seeking Ships Undetectable by Radar
LEAD: The Navy is studying the possibility of making warships largely undetectable by radar in the same way as the Stealth aircraft, a development that would revolutionize naval warfare tactics, Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci said today.


Cherokee Gets Takeover Offer
LEAD: The investment firm Deutschman &amp; Company said that its newly formed Green Acquisition Company had offered to acquire Cherokee Group, which makes women's footwear and other ready-to-wear apparel, for about $166 million.
The $12.50-a-share offer sent the price of Cherokee stock up $4.125, to $12.125, in the over-the-counter market.


Transplant Baby Dies
LEAD: Michael Steward, a 10 1/2-month-old who was the last survivor among several children with rare multi-organ transplants, died Sunday of multiple organ failure.
He received a liver, small bowel, pancreas and a portion of his stomach in February at Rush Presbyterian-St.
Luke's Medical Center.

Water Crisis Imperils India's Farms and Cities
LEAD: For several weeks now, New Delhi has been struggling to assure itself of enough water this summer for its seven million citizens.


Media General Claims Victory
LEAD: Media General Inc. said yesterday that its board nominees had apparently defeated a slate backed by the Hollywood producer Burt Sugarman.
According to the preliminary count, the management slate won more than 56 percent of the votes, Media General's president, James S. Evans, said.
The final report will be issued after both sides inspect the proxies.

The 81-year-old former Taiwanese postal worker, who came to the United States in 1980, received a bachelor's degree. (NYT/Fred R. Conrad)


Baseball; Leary's One-Hitter Beats Phils
LEAD: Tim Leary pitched a one-hitter, allowing only a third-inning single by Darren Daulton, and Mike Scioscia and Jeff Hamilton each hit two-run homers tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 4-0.


New Study Sees Lower Costs for AIDS Care
LEAD: A new prediction of the nationwide cost of providing medical care to AIDS patients is slightly lower than previous forecasts despite the high cost of AZT, the only drug proved effective in treating the AIDS virus, a Government economist reported today.

LEAD: A sign outside the town hall proclaims Pawling the ''Pride of the Harlem Valley and Home of Positive Thinking.'' It went up in 1984, soon after the Chamber of Commerce and the Rotary Club gave a testimonial dinner in the Y.M.C.A. lodge for the positive thinker in residence, the Rev.
Dr.
Norman Vincent Peale.


Discovery Could Speed Diagnoses of Dystrophy
LEAD: A discovery that is expected to improve early diagnosis of forms of muscular dystrophy and prediction of the long-term outcome for children suffering from the wasting disease was reported yesterday.

LEAD:  Presenting the Tonys Last year's Tony Awards presentation won an award itself - an Emmy - for Outstanding Variety Program.

Bank Outlook For Texas
LEAD: Federal banking regulators today painted a gloomy picture of the industry in Texas and the Southwest, saying that 1988 would be ''a record bad year, the worse year since the Great Depression.''


Legal or Not, Drugs Kill
LEAD: The body of the young man looks beautiful.
A funeral suit covers the bullet wounds.
A choir raises a gospel lament and the preacher exhorts decent folks to fight the drug-gang warfare that has claimed the boy's life.
Then suddenly, the mourners dive for cover.
From a passing car, gang rivals of the dead boy restate their vengeance with new fusillades from automatic weapons.

LEAD: Dick Hyman's versatility as pianist, composer and arranger keeps him so busy creating film scores (for Woody Allen's films and, most recently, for ''Moonstruck''), performing at festivals and concerts or with his Perfect Jazz Repertory Quintet, lecturing on ragtime and stride piano or serving as artistic director and in-house pianist for the annual two-week Jazz in July Festival at the 92d Street Y, which begins on July 19, that he might be expected to welcome a night off.

Reviews/Music; The Art Songs of Europe
LEAD: Arden Shelton, a soprano, offered a cleverly chosen and sensitively sung program as a benefit concert for the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund on Saturday afternoon at Weill Recital Hall.
In her first half, she deftly covered about three centuries of Italian, French and German art songs, most of them lovelorn plaints, ending on a brighter note with Strauss's ''Heimliche Auffordering.

Boomerang Bounces Back
LEAD: GREAT news for fans of the 1950's.
Deluged by requests from a nostalgic public, the Formica Corporation has decided to reintroduce its famous boomerang pattern, designed by Raymond Loewy and originally named Skylark.


State Senators and Cuomo Differ On the Urgency of Budget Deficit
LEAD: Governor Cuomo is taking an unjustifiably dim view of the state's finances that would needlessly cost the state millions of dollars, the chief financial analyst of the Republican-led State Senate said today.


Review/Dance; Violence and Theatrics From Armitage Ballet
LEAD: Karole Armitage's choreographic sensibility often seems akin to Expressionism.
Yet she is also preoccupied with classical ballet and popular culture.
Such disparate interests ought to produce stimulating dances.
Yet, despite their eye-catching moments, few of her works are satisfying as totalities.


Mother of Brawley Gets Writ for Failure to Honor Subpoena
LEAD: A day after she defied a grand jury subpoena, the mother of Tawana Brawley, Glenda Brawley, was served with an order yesterday to explain why she failed to appear.

LEAD: Prices of Treasury bonds and longer-term notes moved higher in sluggish trading yesterday on signs the Federal Reserve Board may have tightened credit conditions another notch.


Cyanamid to Start $84 Million Cleanup
LEAD: The American Cyanamid Company has agreed to clean up its Superfund site in Bridgewater for $84 million, company and state officials said today.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Reviews/Music; Blues With Dash of Humor
LEAD: Zora Young, a blues singer from Chicago, put on a casual show at Tramps on Friday night.
That worked for her and against her: her backup band, led by Eddie Lusk, spent a dull hour grinding through some blues and novelty numbers.
But when she came out and wandered amid the tables, singing - and complaining about how her feet hurt -she made the audience feel as if it were sitting in on a show she was putting on just for friends.


A Portrait of an Artist's Quiet Courage
LEAD: The early sculptures of Joan Sovern are large works with soft, sensual curves, in bronze, terra cotta and marble.
The later works, smaller assemblages of stones or slate affixed to bases, are angular, stark and markedly different.


Corrections
LEAD: An article by The Associated Press in some copies on Tuesday about a tenure dispute at the Harvard Business School misstated the university's procedure for tenure decisions.


Marcos in Hawaiian Hospital After Suffering Chest Pains
LEAD: The former Philippine President, Ferdinand E. Marcos, is in intensive care in a hospital here after suffering chest pains, a hospital official said today.

Soviet No Longer Sees Ads as Capitalist Curse
LEAD: ''Advertising is a means of swindling the people by foisting upon them goods frequently useless and of dubious quality,'' the Soviet Encylopedia said in the late 1940's. ''Advertising involves the popularization of goods with the aim of selling them,'' the current edition says.


Nassau Prosecutor To Switch to G.O.P.
LEAD: The Nassau County District Attorney, Denis E. Dillon, who is the county's top elected Democrat and a strong vote-getter, said yesterday that he was becoming a Republican because of the County Democratic Party's support for abortion rights.


Wright Calls Republican Criticism of House Leadership 'Carping'
LEAD: Speaker Jim Wright today rebutted severe Republican criticism of his Democratic leadership in the House of Representatives, saying, ''I try to be fair.
I try to be bipartisan.''


BUSH LASHES BACK ON ISSUE OF ETHICS
LEAD: Frustrated by the Democrats' efforts to tar him with the ethical problems of the Reagan Administration, Vice President Bush tried to make the issue boomerang on them today.


A Dry Perch for the Nature Lover
LEAD: OPERATING on the design premise ''it's nice not to have to worry about a wet bottom,'' two former Outward Bound instructors turned their attention to chairs.


Farley Seeks U.S. Clearance To Purchase 15% of Pepperell
LEAD: William F. Farley, a Chicago industrialist, has asked for Government antitrust clearance to buy at least 15 percent of West Point-Pepperell Inc., the big Georgia-based textile producer said yesterday.


Boston Blackout Brings Disbelief
LEAD: Strained and stressed by an afternoon of thunderstorms and a steamy, emotional night inside brightly lighted Boston Garden, an ancient transformer malfunctioned Tuesday night, making the rink go black and rendering a Stanley Cup game nonexistent.

LEAD: The scene: Public School 205A in the Bronx.

ACCORD IS REACHED FOR STATE TO SHUT SHOREHAM A-PLANT
LEAD: The Long Island Lighting Company agreed in principle early today to sell the $5.3 billion Shoreham nuclear power plant for $1 to New York State, which will end more than 20 years of controversy over Shoreham by closing it.

Leiter Had Minor Concerns
LEAD: He stood in front of his locker stall Tuesday night and insisted that the common fears of being a rookie had not begun to weigh heavily on him.
No, Al Leiter told the gathered audience, he never believed he might be sent to the minors if he threw poorly again.

LEAD: The Soviet legislature, normally a docile forum that ratifies the Communist Party's will by unanimous show of hands, today found itself with an unexpected tax revolt on its hands.


Home Resales Rose in April
LEAD: Sales of existing homes rose 4.5 percent in April, the biggest advance since November 1986, the National Association of Realtors said today.

Tesoro-Pentane
LEAD: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation said that its board of directors had rejected a takeover offer from Pentane Partners L.P., calling it deficient and not in the shareholders' interest.
Under the proposal, Tesoro's common shareholders other than Pentane would exchange their shares, totaling 66.9 percent of Tesoro, for 34.6 percent of the surviving corporation plus $6 a share, Tesoro said.

LEAD: Special cheers for the Chrysler Corporation for deciding to equip all its new cars with driver-side airbags by 1990.
Chrysler's announcement, a dramatic end to a long struggle, guarantees economies of mass production for the lifesaving devices and eliminates the need for dealers to sell them as options.

Franklin Group to Offer International Bond Fund
LEAD: The Franklin Group of Funds announced yesterday that it would offer an international bond fund, the Franklin Global Opportunity Income Fund.


Review/Art; Ancient Chinese Arts In New Met Galleries
LEAD: Tomorrow's opening of the Charlotte C. and John C. Weber Galleries at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is a cause for celebration.
Here, finally, is a place to chart the development of Chinese art from its inception to the triumph of Chinese painting.
Here, finally, is a place where people can see the Chinese gift for sculpture and consider the mystery of why, at a certain point, it was virtually thrown away, never to be fully exploited again.


Embargo on Apples
LEAD: The European Community has stopped importing apples from the United States and some other countries, a European Community spokeswoman said.
The 12-nation trading bloc imposed import quotas on apples this year, and North America reached its limit of 17,600 metric tons in late April, Ella Krucoff, the spokeswoman, said Wednesday in an interview in Washington.

Money Fund Assets Fall
LEAD: Assets of the nation's 429 money market mutual funds decreased by $1.79 billion, to $273.31 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 118 institutional funds dropped $1.89 billion, to $73.52 billion.
The assets of the 214 general purpose funds decreased $163.6 million, to $84.07 billion.


Complaint on Wright Is Filed
LEAD: A formal complaint was filed with the House ethics committee today asking for an investigation to determine if the House Speaker, Jim Wright, violated House ethics rules.

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  The nation's economy grew far more rapidly in the first three months of the year than had been calculated a month ago, the Government said.
The report that the G.N.P. had increased 3.9 percent reinforced some economists' fears that inflation was picking up momentum.
They predicted that the Federal Reserve Board might be forced to increase interest rates, which the Republicans hope to avoid in an election year.

LEAD: New York State and the Long Island Lighting Company reached an agreement in principle today to end more than two decades of controversy over the Shoreham nuclear power station, a symbol of the country's troubled nuclear industry, by closing the $5.3 billion plant.

Sports People; Rangers Drop Kemp
LEAD: After Steve Kemp refused an assignment to their Oklahoma City triple-A team yesterday, the Texas Rangers placed the 11-year veteran on irrevocable waivers for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release.


Review/Theater; Judith Ivey in a Pre-Feminist Domestic Drama
LEAD: William Hanley's 1962 play, ''Mrs.
Dally Has a Lover,'' is the sort of talky ''kitchen sink'' drama that gives actors a chance to bite down hard on roles that offer rich opportunities for finely detailed characterization.
That's probably the main reason why the talented Judith Ivey chose to star in a revival of an earnest period piece that hasn't been seen in New York since it played on Broadway in 1965 with Arlene Francis in the title role.


Visas Extended to Help Keep Foreign Nurses
LEAD: Bowing to appeals for help amid a critical nationwide nursing shortage, the Federal immigration agency yesterday granted a one-year extension to foreign nurses facing deportation at the end of their temporary work visas.


Holiday Events Throughout the Region; Westchester
LEAD: From the soaring Dragon Coaster at Rye's Playland to the rolling woodland trails at the Rockefeller State Park Preserve, Westchester is offering many ways to spend Memorial Day weekend in the county.
A fair and a musical revue, art exhibitions, sheep-shearing demonstrations and a grand parade are among the activities.


On Keeping the Statues New York Has and Adding One More; Remember Irving Berlin
LEAD: To the Editor:


Toyota's U.S. Plant
LEAD: The Toyota Motor Company, the world's third-largest auto maker, opened its first United States assembly plant, with production of a white 1989 Camry sedan.
The 3.7-million-square-foot plant, situated on Kentucky farmland about 20 miles north of Lexington, is the fourth United States assembly plant built by a Japanese auto maker.

22 YEARS TOWARD SHOREHAM
LEAD: The Long Island Lighting Company's efforts to build a nuclear-power plant at Shoreham have covered more than 20 years and cost more than $5 billion.
April 1966: Lilco announces plans to build a 500-megawatt nuclear power plant in Shoreham on the North Shore, 55 miles east of Manhattan.
May 1968: Lilco applies to the Federal Atomic Energy Commission for a construction permit.

TV Weekend; A Vietnam Veteran's Mission
LEAD: In the inspirational tradition of movies like ''Pride of the Yankees'' and everything Frank Capra ever directed, ''To Heal a Nation'' is being presented this Memorial Day weekend on NBC, Sunday at 9 P.M.
This is the story of Jan C. Scruggs, the Vietnam veteran who had a vision of a national memorial that would ''symbolize the experience'' of Americans who fought in the war.

The Proof in the Trash
LEAD: To the Editor:


Holiday on Monday
LEAD: The Memorial Day holiday will be observed on Monday.
Following are holiday schedules.
New York  Government offices: Closed.
Post offices: Special delivery and Ex-press Mail delivery only; main office is open in Manhattan at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue.
Banks: Closed  Schools: Closed.
Parking: Sunday parking rules are in effect.


For TV Mammoths, Chasing a Mouse in Moscow
LEAD: Summit conferences rarely produce major news, and the meetings themselves take place behind closed doors.
But in the weeks since the announcement of President Reagan's visit to the Soviet Union and his meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the networks have sent their news anchors, along with hundreds of reporters, cameramen and technicians, to cover the event.

Vote on Arms Pact Delayed By Dispute on Interpretation
LEAD: The Senate today settled its last major dispute on the new treaty eliminating medium- and shorter-range missiles, only to become embroiled late in the evening in a new political snag.


Los Angeles Is Getting Automated Trolley Line
LEAD: A quarter of a century after Los Angeles ripped out its trolley tracks to make way for an ever increasing number of automobiles, officials have decided to build the nation's first automatic, driverless trolley line to try to get people out of their cars.


Metropolitan Museum Shows Retailing Bent
LEAD: In 1871, a year before it welcomed New Yorkers to its rented 14th Street quarters for its first display of paintings, the Metropolitan Museum of Art was busy selling etched copies of 10 masterpieces in the collection to art lovers in the United States and Europe.

LEAD: Their contention is that the National Park Service has been treated like an ideological soccer ball, kicked around by political appointees of both Democratic and Republican administrations in the last 20 years.
So, some members of Congress, conservationists and former park officials have begun pressing to turn the service into an independent agency.

Bids Up for Oil Leases
LEAD: The Interior Department said today that sales of oil leases in the Chukchi Sea off northwestern Alaska drew a record number of bids.
The deparment said that 653 bids, totaling $478.2 million, were submitted on Monday and Tuesday.
The Interior Secretary, Donald P. Hodel, said the bids reflected confidence that oil would be found, despite no previous leasing in the area and high exploration and development costs.

LEAD: Donley Communications, a 14-year-old financial public relations firm, has been acquired by London-based City and Commercial Communications for $2.3 million.

Prices Fall On U.S. Notes And Bonds
LEAD: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes fell and short-term interest rates moved sharply higher yesterday as market participants reacted negatively to a strong economic report and additional evidence the Federal Reserve Board has again tightened monetary policy.

LEAD:  Genuine Bistro Fare Some of the most authentic French bistro food in New York is turning up in a most unbistrolike setting.

LEAD: Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega accused the Reagan Administration today of inventing a crisis for colonial ends and making him a ''humiliating proposal'' he could not accept while maintaining ''the dignity and sovereignty of Panama.''


O'Connor Doesn't Want Job
LEAD: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor of the Supreme Court, mentioned as a possible Republican candidate for Vice President, said today that she was not interested. ''I most assuredly am not considering any other position in or out of government and do not expect to do so in the future,'' Justice O'Connor, who is 58 years old, said in a statement released by the Court.

United's Parent Is Again UAL
LEAD: Once again, the name of the owner of United Airlines Inc. is the UAL Corporation.
Stockholders voted at their annual meeting in Chicago yesterday to change the name of the airline's parent company from the Allegis Corporation back to UAL, which, of course, draws its initials from the airline.

This is no easy task.
Mr.
Matta-Clark died young - of cancer at the age of 35 in 1978 - and his major artworks no longer exist.

Springer Sale Inquiry Set
LEAD: The West German stock exchange is investigating whether insider trading occurred regarding the shares of the publishing company Axel Springer Verlag A.G., a spokesman for the West Berlin Bourse said today.


Auctions
LEAD:  A Tang Dynasty court lady, a richly glazed pottery study of a serene aristocrat seated on a bamboo stool, may rewrite the $660,000 record at auction for Tang art when it comes up for sale next week at Sotheby's.
The gracefully modeled eighth-century tomb figure, owned in recent years by three major collectors of Chinese art, is one of several major Oriental works to be offered at Sotheby's and Christie's next week.

The show documents various approaches to the complicated business of integrating sculpture and other forms of art into public spaces.

Review/Film; Crucifixion And Gore In 'Penitent'
LEAD: ''The Penitent'' is melodramatic enough to culminate in a crucifixion and ludicrous enough so the victim's greatest ordeal on the cross seems to be a runny nose.
At best, this garbled film is a study in unmotivated behavior.

LEAD: American officials went to the Soviet Union last month to work out a plan to cooperate on drug enforcement, a Federal official said tonight.

LEAD: A key Democratic Senator and a Reagan Administration official said today that they would not rule out military action to oust Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega now that negotiations had failed so far to get the Panamanian leader to step down.

LEAD: Joseph Cardinal Bernardin, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Chicago, yesterday called for a national consensus opposing ''euthanasia or assisted suicide'' for individuals who are sick, infirm, comatose or in pain.

LEAD: For Governor Cuomo, who had become perhaps the leading public opponent of the Shoreham nuclear power plant, the agreement to close the plant is one of the most important victories of his six years in office.

LEAD: Dr.

U.S. Seeks to Bar Tuna Merger Deal
LEAD: The Justice Department said that it plans to file suit to block the H. J. Heinz Company's acquisition of Bumble Bee Seafoods Inc., a merger that would join two of the nation's three leading brands of tuna.
Heinz owns Star-Kist Foods Inc., which markets several brands of canned tuna, including Star-Kist, the nation's largest-selling brand.

LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission approved a series of legislative proposals today that would give it the power to regulate stock-index futures and to close the nation's stock and options exchanges in the event of another market crisis.

Restaurants
LEAD:  Periyali Think of Greek food, as represented in the archipelago of New York, and the cliches abound: twirling gyros of gray lamb and foil-wrapped pita bread at sidewalk stalls; clattering coffee shops where taciturn waiters wear too-tight red vests and perpetual 5 o'clock shadows; stucco-and-plastic-flowered dining rooms specializing in skewered lamb, moussaka and mountains of iceberg lettuce with feta.


Tests Say Dioxin Level High Among Sprayers in Vietnam
LEAD: Blood tests on 147 Air Force veterans who were assigned to spray defoliants like Agent Orange on Vietnam show ''unusually heavy'' levels of exposure to dioxin, the Federal Centers for Disease Control said today.

LEAD: Soviet leaders have agreed to the creation of the first Jewish religious training institute in the Soviet Union in 50 years, a leading Israeli religious scholar said today.

LEAD: The first piano sonata of George Walker, a composer now on the faculty of Rutgers University, is a lively, well-conceived essay in what was, at the time of its composition 35 years ago, something like a mainstream idiom of American composition.
It fits comfortably with the music of Copland, Barber and Rorem.

Youth Symphony
LEAD: The New York Youth Symphony is to play the Shostakovich Fifth Symphony, Chopin's Piano Concerto No. 2 and the premiere of Scott Everly's ''Exultation Overture'' at Carnegie Hall on Sunday at 3 P.M.
The soloist in the Chopin will be Karen Beluso, the winner of the New York Youth Symphony Concerto Competition; and the concert is to be conducted by David Alan Miller.


Gooden Suffers His First Loss
LEAD: Rick Reuschel, with his receding hairline and advancing girth, has the look of a placid monk.
And he has the demeanor to match.
So when Howard Johnson's sixth-inning home run had cleared the wall in right field and finished rattling around beneath the scoreboard at Shea Stadium last night, Reuschel remained unflappable, his expression almost serene.


To Our Readers
LEAD: A series of slowdowns and other job actions by the drivers' union have curtailed distribution of The New York Times in some areas.
These actions are associated with contract negotiations, and The Times is unable to say how long the disruptions may continue.
We regret the inconvenience to our readers.

LEAD: A study ordered by Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci concludes that the Pentagon can eliminate 7,300 jobs from its headquarters around the world.

Admission is $12, minimum is $6.

LEAD: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the role of myths in people's lives misstated the relationship of three characters in Greek myth.
Hippolytus venerated Artemis and scorned Aphrodite.

LEAD:  Golf  Two Share L.P.G.A.
Lead: Patty Sheehan and Sherri Steinhauer each shot a five-under-par 67 yesterday to share the first-round lead in the $325,000 L.P.G.A.
Corning Classic.
Sheehan, who won the tournament in 1983, hit a 20-foot eagle putt on her second hole and picked up three birdies on the back nine at the 6,062-yard Corning (N.Y.) Country Club course.


Sales by Kaneb
LEAD: The Kaneb Energy Company said it would sell the oil and gas holdings of Kaneb Energy Partners, in which it is the largest investor, to Amax Oil and Gas Inc., of Houston, for $68.5 million.
Kaneb also said it would sell the partnership's 50 percent interest in a coal degasification project to Sonat Inc., of Birmingham, Ala., for $68.2 million.

Boeing Gets 3d Big Order: 30 of Its 757's for United
LEAD: United Airlines Inc. ordered 30 of Boeing's 757 jetliners today and took options for 30 more, giving the company its third billion-dollar-plus order in two weeks.


Quest for a 100-Year-Old Fish
LEAD: TOM EARNHARDT, an avid and accomplished fresh and saltwater fly fisherman, is taking his gear to China in a few days.
One of his planned angling adventures is a float trip of nearly 100 miles down a wild stretch of the Zhang River in quest of various little-known trout and a salmonoid called the taimen, which can reach well over 100 pounds and live for more than a century.

He thinks that by grooming his ward, Agnes, to be a simpleton, she will be eternally faithful to him in marriage.
As we know, that marriage will never take place.

Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday about the sentencing of two officers of a Princeton University eating club for serving liquor to minors gave an incomplete account of the Feb. 6 incident in which 45 students suffered alcohol-induced medical problems.
The 45 had been drinking at parties sponsored by several different eating clubs.


Pretoria Bombs Hurt 4 On Party Anniversary
LEAD: Two bombs exploded in crowded downtown Pretoria today, wounding four white women, two of them seriously, on the day the governing National Party marked its 40th anniversary in power.


No Payout Yet At BankAmerica
LEAD: The BankAmerica Corporation's chairman and chief executive, A. W. Clausen, said that the bank was not ready to restore its common stock dividend, despite improving earnings. ''We are not yet at a point where we can recommend reinstatement of dividend payments in the near term,'' Mr.
Clausen told shareholders at the company's annual meeting here.


N.B.A. Playoffs; Celtics Even Series
LEAD: Several times tonight at the Boston Garden, the message board flashed ''C'mon Celtics,'' as if it were begging for a victory.

Soviet Warns Reagan About Seeing Dissidents
LEAD: In a reflection of the Kremlin's irritation with President Reagan's plans to dramatize human-rights issues during his visit to Moscow, a senior Soviet offical said today that a planned Presidential meeting with Soviet dissidents would be an unwelcome breach of superpower protocol.

Economic Scene; A Canadian Case For Optimism
LEAD: IS the international economic system more stable than it looks?
Even in the age of Aquarius, are government leaders more rational than they seem?
Is there, in short, a case for optimism about our ability to absorb shocks and threats to the system, and, without actually solving any of the major problems we face, at least to survive them?


Key Senator Says Bork's Defeat Improved Process
LEAD: A key Senate Republican who helped defeat the nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court last year said in a commencement speech in New York yesterday that the Bork battle had probably produced permanent and healthy changes in the process of confirming nominees to the Court.


Field Publications Agrees To Buy Funk &amp; Wagnalls
LEAD: Field Publications, a division of the Field Corporation, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire all the stock of the encyclopedia publisher Funk &amp; Wagnalls Inc.


Truck Fire Burns Out, Ending 2-Day Ordeal
LEAD: A propane truck being lifted onto a flatbed truck yesterday before being removed from the Seaford-Oyster Bay Expressway in Long Island.
The 2,800-gallon tanker, which caught fire when the truck overturned Tuesday morning, burned itself out at 6:30 A.M.
About 500 families had been evacuated from their homes over fears the truck would explode.

Clark's Search for Hits Never Ends
LEAD: The ball glanced sharply off the glove of the third baseman, then shot high before it dropped softly near the foul line in shallow left field.
Jack Clark, his night at bat reduced to a couple of harmless grounders and a line-drive out to second, seemed satisfied that it was a hit.


Connecticut Prices $75 Million Issue
LEAD: The State of Connecticut yesterday tentatively priced $75 million of special tax-obligation bonds for transportation projects.


Libya Declares End to Chad War
LEAD: Libya's leader, Col.
Muammar el-Qaddafi, has declared an end to the 20-year-old war in Chad and said he would recognize the current Government of that country, Libyan television reported.


Soviet Moves to Curtail Communist Party's Power
LEAD: The Communist Party Central Committee has approved proposals made public today that would curtail the power of the party and limit the term of party and Government officials, in most cases to 10 years.

Golf; Irwin Leads on a Course to His Liking
LEAD: Hale Irwin, who won the 1983 and 1985 Memorial Tournaments at the Muirfield Village Golf Club and finished second in a playoff with Roger Maltbie at the first Memorial in 1976, said today he did not have a love affair with this 7,104-yard course.


Not Quite Radio City, But Backdrop Is Right
LEAD: All the anchors have arrived, and with them, so have the soft drinks, the staples, the copy machines, the clocks for every time zone, the camera operators, the producers, a few hairdressers and a couple of cases of Oreo cookies.


Reds' Milner Returns
LEAD: The Cincinnati Reds outfielder Eddie Milner, who was suspended March 30 for admitted drug use, will be eligible to return as part of an agreement reached with the Players Association, the commissioner's office announced yesterday.


Economists Predict Growth
LEAD: Economists for the nation's top businesses said today that they had raised their forecasts for growth in 1988 but that they still expect rising interest rates to push the country into a recession next year.


School Showdown in Jersey City
LEAD: New Jersey's Commissioner of Education, Saul Cooperman, threatens to use a new state law to take over Jersey City's public schools.
The law, together with Mr.
Cooperman's willingness to use it, deserves the attention and support of all states worried about the decline of local schools.


Reuters Buys Part Of Australian A.P.
LEAD: Reuters Holdings P.L.C. said it had acquired a 48.8 percent stake in Australian Associated Press Ltd. for $:30.8 million, or about $57 million.
The agreement gives Reuters and Rupert Murdoch's Australian-based News Corporation equal stakes in Australian Associated Press, Reuters said.
The remaining shares, or 2.4 percent, are owned by two regional Australian newspapers.


Sports of The Times; A Matter Of Deliverance
LEAD: Zeke could hardly speak above a hoarse whisper, so fatigued, so drained, so sorely disappointed was he.


AIDE TO EX-BRONX LEADER TELLS OF WEDTECH PAYMENTS
LEAD: A witness testifying yesterday in the racketeering trial of Representative Mario Biaggi described an elaborate system of payments made by the Wedtech Corporation, by a former law partner of Mr.
Biaggi and by a Bronx Democratic club to a former Bronx Borough President, Stanley Simon.


ANSWERS TO QUIZ
LEAD: Questions appear on page 12.


Vote Pulls Israeli Labor Party to the Left
LEAD: The Israeli Labor Party held its first open election of candidates for Parliament on Thursday, and when the votes were finally counted early today, the new list showed that the party was taking a swing to the left.


THE TREATY PROVISIONS
LEAD:  MISSILES ELIMINATED  *
Land-based medium-range missiles (range: 621 to 3,418 miles) and launchers are to be eliminated over three years.  *
Land-based shorter-range missiles (range: 311 to 621 miles) and launchers are to be eliminated within 18 months.  *
Under the treaty, the Soviet Union will destroy 1,752 medium- and shorter-range missiles based in its territory and Eastern Europe.


N.B.A. Playoffs; Mavericks Halt Lakers' Momentum
LEAD: After enjoying two games against Dallas that looked like highlight films, the Los Angeles Lakers ran into a wall this evening.
The Mavericks, reeling after two straight lopsided losses in Los Angeles, waged a desperate fight this evening and defeated the Lakers, 106-94.


NATO Will Bear Cost Of Shifting U.S. F-16's
LEAD: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization nations have agreed to share almost all of the $500 million cost of transferring 72 American F-16 fighters from Spain.


Driver Has Right Stuff To Pilot Indy Pace Car
LEAD: Chuck Yeager was strapped in, gunning the throttle, his narrow eyes seeing things that are hidden from most people.


Theater; Laughter Amid the Ruins Of Kitsch and Junk Food
LEAD: ''Splitsville,'' Richard Dresser's nightmarish satire of American junk culture, takes its title from a theme park that is being hastily built across the street from the Florida residence of a young married couple named Roy and Wendy.


George Gardner Hill, Minister, 68
LEAD: The Rev.
George Gardner Hill, a retired Methodist minister who served in churches in Connecticut, New York and Florida, died of prostate cancer May 20 at the Connecticut Hospice in Branford.
He was 68 years old and lived in New Haven.


Centel Acquiring Cellular Phone Unit
LEAD: The Centel Corporation said yesterday that it had reached a definitive agreement to buy United Telespectrum Inc., the cellular telephone and paging division of United Telecommunications Inc., for $763 million.


Forecasts of Dry Weekend Lift Soybeans and Grain
LEAD: Prices of soybean futures posted strong gains on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday in expectation of a dry Memorial Day weekend.
Grain futures advanced slightly.


The Met Plays Tokyo, Where It Has Ardent Fans
LEAD: With the trappings of rock star idolatry and more than a hint of commercialism, the Metropolitan Opera - 52 singers, 72 chorus members, 103 musicians, 50 technicians and 110 tons of scenery, musical instruments and costumes -has come to Japan.


Your Money; Financial Advice For Graduates
LEAD: When Edward W. Barrett was dean of the Columbia Graduate School of Journalism in the 1950's and 60's, he liked to give a special talk just before graduation.
His advice to those about to embark on their careers: ''Start a go-to-hell fund.''


Market Holiday
LEAD: Stock and commodity markets will be closed on Monday in observance of Memorial Day.
Government offices, banks and many businesses will also be closed.


China's Appetite for U.S. TV Shows Is Increasing
LEAD: On Wednesday nights in Shanghai, more than 70 percent of the television audience watches the American police show ''Hunter.'' This summer ''Our House'' and ''Falcon Crest'' will be added to the lives of 80 million Chinese in Shanghai and Beijing as well as Fujian and Guangdong Provinces.


Monte Kay Dies at 63; Founder of Nightclubs
LEAD: Monte Kay, a recording company president and jazz entrepreneur who was a co-founder of Birdland, a nightclub in New York, died Wednesday of heart failure.
He was 63 years old.

Correction
LEAD: An article on Thursday about acid fumes at a hospital in the Bronx misidentified the hospital because of information supplied by The Associated Press.
It was the Bronx Children's Psychiatric Center.


Entertainment Publications Bid
LEAD: Entertainment Publications Inc. said that a management-led group had offered to buy the company for $21 cash a share in a deal that values the printer of entertainment discount coupon books at around $110 million.
In addition to the cash, shareholders would receive preferred stock in the surviving company worth $2 a share and carrying a dividend rate of 16 percent a year, the company said.

Labor Dispute Embroils Westin in South Africa
LEAD: The Westin Hotel Company, which decided last month to withdraw from South Africa, was embroiled today in a dispute with the black work force of this city's most prestigious hotel, the Carlton.


DRUG INQUIRY SET ON BIRTH DEFECTS
LEAD: The Commissioner of Food and Drugs said yesterday that his agency had begun to investigate cases in which the anti-acne drug Accutane led to severely deformed babies, in hope of determining whether there was a pattern of improper prescription or misuse.


Polls Show Thrill for Le Pen Is Gone
LEAD: Jean-Marie Le Pen was in a foul mood.
He railed at a local newspaper - ''It's Pravda!'' - for asserting that French gypsies were angered when he showed up at their annual festival, and he denounced local electoral boards for challenging the intention of his National Front to run under the acronym Lepen.

Inquiries Into Crazy Eddie Find False Financial Data
LEAD: The new management of Crazy Eddie Inc. has disclosed that Federal criminal and civil investigations have found that all the company's financial statements before last November are inaccurate.


Marcos Leaves Hospital
LEAD: Ferdinand E. Marcos, the former Philippine President, was released from a hospital Thursday night, two days after being admitted for chest pains.
Mr.
Marcos was placed in an intensive care unit when he entered the hospital Tuesday night.
His personal physician, Dr.
Azucena Ignacio, said the chest pains were caused by arthritis or a rib inflammation.


Semiconductor Demand
LEAD: World semiconductor demand is forecast to rise 30.1 percent in 1988, but growth is expected to slow sharply in 1989, to 3.9 percent, the World Semiconductor Trade Statistics' Japan Council said this week.
The forecast, compiled by the council based on data from semiconductor makers from around the world, shows demand growing to $42.3 billion in 1988.


CORRECTION
LEAD: A map on Wednesday accompanying an article about a propane truck that overturned on Long Island incorrectly identified the area shown.
It was Nassau County.


Fixing Bridge, 4 Are Hurt In 30-Foot Fall
LEAD: One day after the Williamsburg Bridge reopened, four construction workers repairing its beams were injured yesterday, none seriously, when a wooden platform they were standing on collapsed, hurtling them to a work area 30 feet below.


COMPANY BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Affiliated Medical Enterprises, Orange, Calf., an investor-owned health-care corporation, announced that it had acquired American Health Group International Inc., Kirkland, Wash., for $100 million.
The acquisition included the purchase of four acute-care hospitals and a home health company.


Comings and Goings
LEAD: Kurt Sohn, a free agent who has spent seven seasons as a receiver and punt returner for the Jets, signed a one-year contract with the club yesterday.
The terms of the agreement were not announced.
Last season, Sohn, the Jets' player representative, caught 23 passes for two touchdowns. . . .
David Archer, the starting quarterback for the Atlanta Falcons two years ago, has signed with the Miami Dolphins.


Military Bill Voted as D'Amato Relents
LEAD: The Senate today approved a $299.5 billion military budget measure for next year after Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato dropped his insistence that it include an amendment allowing the death penalty for murders by drug dealers.

NURSING HOMES FACE PRESSURES THAT IMPERIL CARE FOR ELDERLY
LEAD: Rising costs, an acute shortage of nurses and government limits on spending are combining to cause severe problems at nursing homes across the country, according to industry and government officials.


Chase Wins Securities Case
LEAD: A United States Court of Appeals today upheld the Federal Reserve Board's decision to allow a commercial bank affiliate to engage in underwriting and dealing in commercial paper to a limited extent.

VW Price Rise
LEAD: Volkswagen United States, a unit of Volkswagenwerk A.G., said it would raise the prices of most of its vehicles by an average of 1.6 percent, or $181 each, effective June 6.
The price of the 16-valve GTI is to increase the most, rising $250, to $13,245.

LEAD: Susan Jaffe and Kevin McKenzie took over the roles of Kitri and Basil in American Ballet Theater's production of ''Don Quixote'' on Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.
The previously reviewed Ms.
Jaffe replaced the originally announced Leslie Browne, who is recovering from an injury.
Mr.


Heart Recipient, 13, Dies
LEAD: Eric Rutkowski, a 13-year-old Milwaukee boy became the youngest recipient of a Jarvik-7 artificial heart Thursday, but he died hours after the surgery when his lungs filled with fluid.
Eric, a seventh-grade student at Sholes Middle School, died at St.
Luke's Medical Center.
The youngest previous recipient of the artificial heart was Christopher Larson, 15, of Esdaile, Wis.


New Owner for Spurs
LEAD: B. J. (Red) McCombs, the president of the San Antonio Spurs, became the team's majority owner yesterday after two months of negotiations with Angelo Drossos, the chairman.


Shultz Makes a Pledge To Support Soviet Jews
LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz paid an emotional visit to the Jewish Community Center here tonight and pledged that the United States would never abandon the cause of Soviet Jews.


Wider Limits For Options
LEAD: The Chicago Board Options Exchange plans to act immediately on an exemption granted earlier this week by the Securities and Exchange Commission that allows institutions to hold larger positions in some options on the Standard &amp; Poor's 100- and 500-stock indexes.


About New York Not Quite Ready For the Ash Bin Of History
LEAD: The scene was the Sanchez cigar store, a hole-in-the-wall place at 265 West 30th Street where a dusty wooden Indian stands inside the window and two workers methodically roll 500 Cuban-style handmades a day.
Bill Terrio, a customer, gripped a handful of aromatic coronas and didn't give a hoot who minded.


Funeral Director Is Charged
LEAD: A funeral home director was charged today with stealing more than $3,900 from the apartment of a welfare recipient whom her funeral home had been hired by the state to bury.
The director, Concetta Cannici, 74 years old, of the DeLucia Memorial funeral home, was released on a written promise she appear in court to answer a charge of third-degree larceny, a police spokesman said.


Dirt Stars Try the Grass
LEAD: Nineteen 3-year-olds, 16 grass horses and the nation's leading milers will be in action this holiday weekend in four major stakes races in New York and New Jersey.


Theater; Revival of 'Last of Red Hot Lovers'
LEAD: Having been a long-running Broadway success and a Hollywood movie, ''Last of the Red Hot Lovers'' would not seem to be an ideal candidate for revival, except perhaps for an all-star summer theater package.
Undaunted, John Driver has staged the 1969 Neil Simon comedy at the American Jewish Theater.


GUIDEPOST: Short-Term Rates
LEAD: Since interest rates have started to rise again, many people have begun purchasing certificates of deposit with shorter maturities.
This strategy assumes that rates will rise still higher in the coming months.
With C.D.'s, customers have a choice of maturities, usually three months, six months or a year.

LEAD: The USG Corporation said today that it had won a proxy fight waged by Desert Partners L.P. for six seats on the company's 15-member board of directors.

LEAD: An undercover detective who investigated corruption in the 77th Precinct in Brooklyn in 1986 was arrested Thursday night and charged with possessing and intending to sell drugs, the police said yesterday.

LEAD: Roy Simmons Jr., the lacrosse coach at Syracuse, has seen enough David and Goliath stories to feel a little nervous these days.


Dollar Up in Light Trading; Gold Prices Finish Lower
LEAD: The dollar rose against major foreign currencies in light pre-holiday trading yesterday amid concern about higher United States interest rates.


The Superpowers vs. South Africa
LEAD: Here's a proposal for President Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev at the Moscow summit talks: Announce a cooperative approach toward southern Africa.
Start a multinational effort to aid the states that border South Africa.
Squelch the idea that the region is another arena of East-West rivalry.
Expose the root problem - South Africa's destabilization of its neighbors.


Aviation Agency Urges More Boeing 737 Checks
LEAD: The Federal Aviation Administration is proposing further toughening of inspections for older Boeing 737 airliners like the one whose fuselage ripped open over Hawaii last month.


Guokas a Magic Man
LEAD: The Orlando Magic, the National Basketball Association expansion team, plans to hire Matt Guokas, the former Philadelphia 76ers coach, a newspaper reported yesterday.


Western Gain in Gold Seen
LEAD: Western gold output is likely to rise sharply this year with increases from almost every producer nation except South Africa, the London commodity broker E.D.&amp;F.
Man said today.


The Editorial Notebook; Europe After the Missile Pact
LEAD: The Euromissile treaty that President Reagan hopes to flourish in Moscow next week is a triumph of American diplomacy.
But almost all changes, even those for the better, cause heartburn in the ever-fretful military alliance between the United States and Europe.
As was evident last week at a meeting of defense officials at the Wiston House conference center in England, the new pact will leave European governments with some wrenching problems.

Guido Orlando, 80, Press Agent Who Devised Outlandish Stunts
LEAD: Guido Orlando, a flamboyant press agent, charlatan and bemedaled publicist for dozens of the wish-to-be-famous, died of a heart attack Sunday at the Hollywood Presbyterian Medical Center in California.
He was 80 years old and lived in Los Angeles.


Official Who Restored Respect to Philadelphia Police Resigns
LEAD: Police Commissioner Kevin M. Tucker, who is credited with restoring respect and confidence in a Police Department that had been riddled with corruption and inefficiency, is resigning to take a banking position.


Raleigh-to-Paris Flights
LEAD: American Airlines said this week that it had started nonstop flights between Paris and the Raleigh-Durham Airport in North Carolina.
The flights are the first international service from Raleigh and the airport is being renamed the Raleigh-Durham International Airport, American said.

LEAD: Just as Scarlett O'Hara once drew strength from the rich soil of Tara, so George Bush took heart today from the tingling salt air of Walker's Point.

LEAD: Sandinista and contra leaders said today that their peace talks were making progress.

LEAD: The Kansas City Royals announced that they have placed the first baseman Steve Balboni and the outfielder Thad Bosley on waivers for the purpose of giving them their unconditional release.

LEAD: The decision to close the Shoreham nuclear-power plant and keep the Long Island Lighting Company an investor-owned utility resolves years of uncertainty that academic and business leaders say have hampered the planning and investment strategies of Long Island businesses. .

CORRECTION
LEAD: The Jacksonville Journal article yesterday mislocated Jacksonville, Ill., in relation to Springfield, Ill.
It is west, not east, of Springfield.


Bess Myerson Is Accused Of Shoplifting
LEAD: Bess Myerson, the former Miss America and New York City Cultural Affairs Commissioner who faces trial on Federal fraud and conspiracy charges next fall, was arrested in a small Pennsylvania town yesterday on a charge of shoplifting $44.07 in merchandise.

LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL 2-5  The Senate approved the arms treaty eliminating medium- and shorter-range missiles based on land, 93 to 5.
It was the first major American-Soviet arms control pact the Senate has approved since 1972.
Page 1  President Reagan stressed rights in a speech calling on Mikhail Gorbachev to improve the Soviet human rights record.


Icahn Offer Is Rejected By Texaco
LEAD: The board of Texaco Inc. yesterday turned down Carl C. Icahn's takeover proposal, and Mr.
Icahn used that rejection as fodder in his proxy campaign, as the two sides began a battle for the votes of the company's 211,000 shareholders.


SYRIANS FAN OUT IN BEIRUT SUBURBS TO ENFORCE TRUCE
LEAD: To the cheers of residents, several hundred Syrian troops moved into the southern suburbs of Beirut today to enforce an agreement to end 22 days of fighting between rival Shiite Moslem militias.


Federal Energy Official Resigns
LEAD: Another member of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission has resigned, leaving the five-member board with two vacancies and only one sitting member with a regular appointment.

Another Meese Aide Resigns; Department Praised in Letter
LEAD: Charles J. Cooper, who heads the Justice Department's Office of Legal Counsel, announced today that he was submitting his resignation to enter private practice.


Suit Seeks the Return Of AIDS Victim's Silver
LEAD: In a lawsuit filed in New York State Supreme Court, the photographer Robert Mapplethorpe has charged the New-York Historical Society with ''fraudulent conduct'' in obtaining a five-year loan of a collection of American silver from the art collector Samuel Wagstaff Jr.
The museum rejects the charges.


Grand Prix Track Opens
LEAD: The two American women with the best chance of winning Olympic gold medals in track and field in Seoul, South Korea, will head the field Saturday in the Bud Light Bruce Jenner Classic, the first of 17 events on the Mobil Grand Prix circuit.


Death Penalty Imposed on Illinois Kidnapper
LEAD: A 31-year-old man was sentenced to death today for the kidnapping and murder of a businessman who was buried alive and suffocated before his family could pay a $1 million ransom.


Oilers' Elation Fresh as Ever
LEAD: Hockey's playoff season may have been marked by intrusions bordering on the supernatural, but when the time came for a Stanley Cup champion to emerge, the season reached its natural conclusion.
The Edmonton Oilers, the National Hockey League's most talented team, retained the title with a sweep of the overmatched Boston Bruins.


Heinz-Bumble Bee Merger Delayed
LEAD: The H. J. Heinz Company said it had agreed with Bumble Bee Seafoods Inc. to extend their merger agreement until next Friday while they consider the Justice Department's opposition to the deal.
The Government on Thursday announced plans to try to block the proposed merger of two of the nation's top three canned tuna brands.


Juan Orol, Film Director, 90
LEAD: Juan Orol, a leading director during the golden age of Mexican cinema, died Thursday of complications from diabetes.
He was 90 years old.


After-Tax Income Shows Steepest Drop in 12 Months
LEAD: Americans' disposable personal incomes edged up a tiny one-tenth of 1 percent in April after a large 1.1 percent rise in March.
But on an after-tax basis personal income fell nine-tenths of 1 percent in April, the steepest drop in a year, as tax payments took a big bite out of paychecks.


Price of Lilco Stock Reflects Relief on Wall Street
LEAD: The complex deal that sealed the fate of Shoreham has been generally well received on Wall Street, even though the specific language of the agreement to abandon the $5.3 billion nuclear plant, including its financial details, have yet to be released.


Let's Add to the Rank and File of Congress
LEAD: To the Editor:


New Europe Import Tax
LEAD: The European Community this week imposed special import duties of up to 33.4 percent on Japanese computer printers, saying they were being dumped at unfairly low prices on European markets.
The European Community commission said in a statement that a yearlong investigation had shown that 14 Japanese companies, among them some of the biggest names in the electronics industry, had sold printers in Europe at prices lower than those at home or below the cost of production.


Justice Dept. Official Tangles With Panel Over Civil Rights
LEAD: The Justice Department's civil rights chief has criticized Congress for exempting itself from civil rights laws and has denied that he lied to senators last year about a Republican challenge of voter registrations in Louisiana.

LEAD: ''Soviet practice does not - or does not yet - measure up to Soviet commitment.'' - President Reagan, on human rights.  [ 1:4. ]

LEAD: Shoreham has been the centerpiece of electricity planning on Long Island for more than a decade, and so the decision to cancel the 809-megawatt plant leaves the Long Island Lighting Company with just one way to prevent brownouts in the next few years, persuading its customers to make do with less.

LEAD: Besides offering a low price and extra features, Miraclean hopes that sales of its Korean-made dry-cleaning machines will be helped by the large number of Korean families who own and operate dry cleaners in this country.


CORRECTION
LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Securities and Exchange Commission's vote to seek wider powers incorrectly described its position on a legislative proposal involving margin levels on stock-index futures.
The agency unanimously voted to consider at a later date a revised proposal that would give the Federal Reserve Board the right to review margin levels on stock-index futures.

Manuel Antonio Noriega said today that the United States should allow Latin American democracies to take the lead in any new negotiations over the general's ouster.

Non-Cancerous Lesions Are Removed From Koch's Face
LEAD: Five small non-cancerous skin lesions were removed from Mayor Koch's face yesterday morning.
The 63-year-old Mayor said the procedure was painless and he would not need any further treatment.

LEAD: A series of slowdowns and other job actions by the drivers' union have curtailed distribution of The New York Times in some areas.
These actions are associated with contract negotiations, and The Times is unable to say how long the disruptions may continue.
We regret the inconvenience to our readers.

LEAD: With two outs in the seventh inning, Darryl Strawberry stepped out of the dugout to pinch-hit.
Minutes later, Kevin McReynolds also emerged.

The laws of probability, though, would remain elusive.

LEAD: Robert Shaw is retiring in style as music director of the Atlanta Symphony, leading the orchestra in two Manhattan concerts and then embarking on a European tour, complete with the full Atlanta Symphony Orchestra Chorus.

IMPROVISING TROMBONIST
LEAD: The Village Vanguard can be a harsh place for young musicans.
The club has terrifyingly high creative standards, two or three sets a night, six nights a week, demanding deep improvisational resources and complete assurance.
Without them, a musician will die a slow, obvious death in front of the baleful pictures on the wall of the great musicians who've played there.

Anthony's on Houston Street was decorated with blue and white graduation streamers.

So lacking in glamour, among other things, the scene hardly looked like the 1 A.M.


New Ford Export
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said it would export the first shipment of Ford Probe sports cars to Japan on Tuesday.
The auto is built for Ford by its Japanese partner, the Mazda Motor Company, at Mazda's plant in Flat Rock, Mich.
The auto, which was introduced in the United States May 12, is sold out through October.

Ptolemaic Art
LEAD: A major exhibition of the Ptolemaic period of Egyptian art, from 305 B.C. to 30 B.C., will be shown at the Brooklyn Museum this fall, from Oct. 7 to Jan. 2.
The exhibition, entitled ''Cleopatra's Egypt: Age of the Ptolemies,'' will contain approximately 150 works from over 40 public and private collections in the United States and Europe.

John the Divine, certainly was spectacular.

LEAD: In a growing movement, at least 15 states are considering or have enacted legislation to regulate or ban collision-damage waivers for rental cars.

LEAD: The Maison Francaise at New York University celebrates its 30th anniversary with nonstop music from 1 to 11 P.M. today.

LEAD: WOODEN windowsills receive a great deal of abuse from weather.

Surrender
LEAD: To the Editor: Samuel G. Freedman's ''A Surrender, of Sorts, to Vacation'' (Travel, April 10) rang true to my experience.
I am a stockbroker and had the ''fortunate'' experience of flying to Egypt the Friday before last October's market crash.
Abetting my lack of news was the fact that I sailed on a Nile River cruise on Black Monday and did not arrive in Luxor until Thursday evening.

Remember the Families on Memorial Day
LEAD: WHILE all war memorials list the names of those who died, or who fought in a conflict, I have never heard of a structure for any war commemorating the families of the deceased.
Surely their suffering was almost as great as that of those who gave their lives or saw combat.
I know because I belonged to one of those forgotten families.

POSTINGS: Greenbelt-Area Projects; S.I. Mall Generates a Housing Boom
LEAD: Before the Staten Island Mall opened in 1973, the land around it, known as New Springville, supported truck farms and even boasted two private airstrips.
But the advent of the mall's 178 stores sparked a housing construction boom in this mid-island location nestled inside the bend of the Greenbelt park area.

LEAD: No matter what happens to President Reagan or to American drug-enforcement policy, Panama is now in a crisis that will not end soon and that carries far-reaching consequences for the United States and the region.


40,000 Left Soviet in 1987
LEAD: About 40,000 people emigrated from the Soviet Union last year and 20,000 received exit visas in the first four months of 1988, the official press agency Tass said today.
It quoted Rudolf Kuznetsov, head of the visa-issuing authority, as saying relatives of about 500,000 Jews, Germans and Armenians who left the Soviet Union after World War II accounted for most of those allowed to leave for family reasons.

MILITARY PLANS 3-STAGE ROCKET TO BE LAUNCHED FROM A B-52
LEAD: The Pentagon plans to build an experimental rocket that would be launched from an airplane to put military satellites into space, Government and industry experts say.


WHY DO N.B.A. CHAMPIONS NOT REPEAT?
LEAD: There are three reasons why N.B.A. champions do not repeat.
One is that when a team becomes the champion, a competitive fire is lit in other very well-equipped and prominent teams who feel that they have just as much ability as this champion.
Second, N.B.A. champions either lack the zeal or the same strong physical ability of the previous season.

LEAD: When first blockbuster insider-trading cases were brought almost two years ago, they were hailed as a breakthrough in the effort to stop white-collar crime on Wall Street.
But now some securities lawyers maintain that the Government may be endangering its goals with an overzealous pursuit of such cases.

21 Hours of Shakespearean Drama
LEAD: WHILE Connecticut's theater in Stratford, the traditional spring and summer home for Shakespeare, suffers a silent season, Stamford is taking up the slack by offering 21 hours' worth of Shakespeare's historical plays.
The plays - seven in all, under the collective title ''The Wars of the Roses'' - are to be performed by the English Shakespeare Company during a single weekend, under the aegis of the Stamford Center for the Arts, at the Palace Theater.

Afrikaner Identity
LEAD: To the Editor:


With Fish, Hazelnut Oil's Toasted Flavor
LEAD: ALTHOUGH hazelnut oil is usually used in salads, its rich toasted flavor also goes beautifully with fish.
The nutty taste is a perfect foil for red snapper, bass and trout or fish steaks such as halibut, swordfish or tilefish.
It is even better when fresh herbs such as tarragon, thyme or basil are added.

The move was made retroative to May 21 and the Cubs replaced Sutcliffe with another right-hander, Calvin Schiraldi, who came off the 15-day disabled list.

There are 140 planes in the C.A.F. fleet, known as the Ghost Squadron, nearly 70 different kinds, most of them American.

Grand Canyon
LEAD: To the Editor: As a veteran of three 18-day trips through the Grand Canyon on dories, I was pleased to see Franz Lidz's article (Travel, March 27).
I hope it keeps others who share his need for artificial means of stimulation out of the canyon.
Those of us who will never find this ''infinity of dry red rock'' boring will be left to enjoy the incomparable beauty of the voyage.

LEAD: ''THERE are old mushroom hunters, and bold mushroom hunters but there are no old and bold mushroom hunters,'' goes the old saying, by way of explaining that mushroom gathering can be a safe and lifelong sport when practiced with proper caution.
That caution is to learn from an expert and don't eat anything unless you are absolutely sure that it is not poisonous.

LEAD: IN 1944, the small industrial town where I lived, Mansfield, Ohio, was totally unified toward the war effort.

Unicef Urges Immunization
LEAD: The number of child deaths in Africa could be cut dramatically if leaders would take a personal interest in promoting immunization programs, according to the United Nations Children's Fund. ''If the immunization program is handled under the personal leadership of the heads of state and governments of Africa, the health of children can be so improved that the 1980 child death rates will be halved by the year 2000,'' Unicef's director, James Grant, said at a news conference here Friday.

Farm Subsidies Stifle Agriculture
LEAD: FOR more than 50 years, American agriculture has been the nation's largest recipient of political intervention and economic aid.
Agriculture has been subjected to an almost constant effort by the Federal Government to set prices, control producers and allocate capital.
So far, the clearest lesson of farm policy is that members of Congress have no incentive to correct their mistakes.

LEAD: SCHOOL buildings had been put up in the village of Harlem as early as the 1840's.
