WHY DO N.B.A. CHAMPIONS NOT REPEAT?
LEAD: Since 1980, out of a possible 16 different teams who could have reached the finals, only four did so.

Losing a sixth or seventh game of a close, final series by a few points after winning the previous year is no indication that the team was inferior, or that this year's winner is the new ''dominant force.

WHAT'S DOING IN THE: Twin Cities
LEAD: One of the first signs of spring in Minnesota usually appears in early April, while ice is still on the ground - convertibles full of college students cruising with tops down, eating ice cream cones and pretending they don't have the car heater on full blast.


With Fish, Hazelnut Oil's Toasted Flavor
LEAD: ALTHOUGH hazelnut oil is usually used in salads, its rich toasted flavor also goes beautifully with fish.
The nutty taste is a perfect foil for red snapper, bass and trout or fish steaks such as halibut, swordfish or tilefish.
It is even better when fresh herbs such as tarragon, thyme or basil are added.


A Gain for the Bald Eagle
LEAD: A pair of bald eagles has built a nest in Massachusetts for the first time since early this century, an occurrence that wildlife officials call a major step toward restoring a breeding population in the state.
The nest was spotted in a red oak tree near the Quabbin Reservoir in central Massachusetts.

OUR MUSCLE-BOUND NAVY
LEAD: Charles R. Morris's otherwise excellent discussion of our carrier-minded Navy has one serious flaw (''Our Muscle-Bound Navy,'' April 24).

Adapting the author's figures, this means that the battle group could launch 48 to 96 F-14 fighters carrying 288 to 576 Phoenix missiles to meet the oncoming Soviet bombers - not the 24 fighters carrying 144 missiles, which Mr.

DRUGS IN COLLEGES: TO TEST OR NOT TO TEST; RANDOM TESTS ABUSE DIGNITY
LEAD: NOTHING better illustrates the low regard that the National Collegiate Athletic Association has often had for the rights of student-athletes than its random drug-testing policy.
There are a number of alternatives for addressing the problem of substance abuse.
Unfortunately, the N.C.A.A. chooses an approach that protects the public-relations image of its member institutions but shows little or no concern for the dignity and privacy of the vast majority of hard-working young athletes who are drug-free.

What's In Now? Natural Music
LEAD: Regular concert-goers often find that listening to music through loudspeakers is a mixed pleasure, and their cavils are usually of a particular kind.
It isn't that they have unreasonable expectations of reproduced music being anything like the real thing.
They are willing to make allowance for the inherent and irreducible discrepancies between the music and its reproduction.

GLOBAL BRIEFS
LEAD: *
China will soon allow foreign banks to open branches in large coastal cities, Li Guixian, the governor of the People's Bank of China, said.
Currently, foreign banks can open new branches only in special economic zones in south China.
The New China news agency quoted Mr.
Li as telling a meeting of bankers that China should reform its foreign exchange system, letting coastal cities borrow more short-term foreign exchange, allowing a limited number of individuals to deal in foreign exchange and allowing companies to open foreign exchange accounts.

Korean Trade Surplus
LEAD: South Korea's current account surplus rose 41 percent in the first four months of this year from its level of a year earlier, the Bank of Korea reported Friday.
The current account measures trade in merchandise and services.
The surplus for January through April was $3.89 billion, up from $2.76 billion one year ago.

Onstage, Mr.
King passes himself off as an avuncular, happy figure; in contrast, his solos sound anguished.

LEAD: The Center for Army Lessons Learned here has discovered that too many tank and mechanized infantry battalion commanders were being ''killed'' in training exercises, after which their units deteriorated and were trounced in battle.

That's good news - but only because the previous news has been so bad.

LEAD: France's Defense Minister said today that several of the commandos who stormed a cave in the Pacific territory of New Caledonia to free 23 French hostages had committed ''acts contrary to military duty'' and would be punished.


British Trade Gap Wider
LEAD: Britain said Friday that its monthly trade deficit had jumped 27 percent, to $:1.125 billion ($2.09 billion), in April and that its current account deficit had nearly doubled, to $:525 million ($975 million).
Economists said the data could mean that a recent rise in the pound's value was pricing British goods off foreign markets.

LEAD: The pilot of a Continental Airlines DC-9 took evasive action yesterday to avoid hitting a light plane about five miles southeast of Cleveland's main airport, the Federal Aviation Administration said.

Review/Music; Kassav' Plays Zouk, Sound of Caribbean
LEAD: In a concert Sunday that left no hips unmoved, Kassav' defined zouk and zouke, the noun and verb in French Antillean Creole, for the band's first Manhattan audience.
Zouk (which rhymes with ''juke'') is the Caribbean's most up-to-date dance music; it comes from the cross-pollination of ritual and carnival music from Guadeloupe with other Caribbean and North American dance music and French pop, delivered with modern instruments and recording-studio precision.

LEAD: American human-rights specialists, among the first foreigners to get an extensive look at Cuba's prisons, say they found a harsh system where inmates snapped to a rigid parade-rest stance when guards appeared.

New Home for Trotter
LEAD: A Swedish horse dealer, John Erik Magnusson, said he had bought a three-quarter share of Mack Lobell, the world-record-holding trotter and last year's Hambletonian winner, for a reported $6 million from Louis Guida.
Magnusson, who now stands three trotter stallions at his farm Bladingeas near Alvesta in southern Sweden, said the 4-year-old Mack Lobell would retire to stud after another two seasons of racing in the United States.

Toronto Stock Prices Up
LEAD: Stock prices moved higher in mixed trading today on the Toronto Stock Exchange.
The composite index rose 14.10, to 3,187.20, as stocks falling in price outnumbered those posting a gain, 366 to 329.
Stock exchanges in the United States and Europe were closed for the holiday.

LEAD: Dino Ciccarelli of the Minnesota North Stars pleaded not guilty yesterday in a Toronto court to a charge of assaulting an opponent during a game.

Had Mr.
Kadar stepped down as Hungary's party chief, say, in 1976, he would have earned glowing notices for his economic reforms and for the relative political tolerance he adopted after ruthlessly crushing the revolutionaries of 1956.

Samaranch, who arrived in Seoul, South Korea, the site of the Games, for a series of meetings and ceremonies this week, said at an airport news conference that North Korea's bid to be co-host was against the Olympic charter ''and unacceptable because of its political nature.

Nezahualcoyotl Journal; In Plain of Hungry Coyote, Millions Dwell in Hope
LEAD: Just a quarter of a century ago, there was little here except barren plains and a salty, swampy lake bed.
Today, 2.7 million people live in this sprawling, jerry-rigged settlement just east of Mexico City.
This place, Mexicans, with a certain ironic pride and flair for drama, often describe as the largest slum in the world.

Health-Care Budget Cuts In New York Are Assailed
LEAD: A growing number of health-care advocates and public officials charge that Mayor Koch's budget cuts are jeopardizing patient care by failing to meet the crises of hospital overcowding and the AIDS epidemic.


World's Tallest Platform
LEAD: Seven tugboats today began hauling the world's tallest offshore drilling platform to a site off the Louisiana coast.
After its two drilling rigs are installed in the Gulf of Mexico, the platform, dubbed Bullwinkle, will weigh 78,000 tons and stand 1,615 feet high - 161 feet higher than the world's tallest building, the Sears Tower in Chicago.
